sentences.text: Earlier today George Osborne said he has no current plan to lower the top income tax rate, but he didn’t rule out that it might happen later.
In 2013, the coalition knocked the top rate down—from 50 % to a mere 45 %). Ed Balls, Labour’s shadow chancellor, slammed Osborne: he’s still talking about another cut, right?

During the Sky News Murnaghan interview they asked Osborne if a 5 % tax cut for anyone earning over £150,000 was coming, but he just said “That not our plan.” > When they pushed him to outright reject the move, chancellor said, therefore “You can judge us by what we say we want to do.” Can you really tell?
Goal: raise the tax‑free personal allowance to £12,500—then full‑time workers on minimum wage won’t owe any income tax, and millions feel the relief.
Our priority for higher‑rate taxpayers? Raise the threshold to £50,000. Our main tax promises for the next Parliament?

They're listed right here. Later when they asked about cutting the top rate Cameron answered “It isn’t our policy.” We will raise the basic‑rate threshold to £12,500; therefore another million off the tax list, about thirty million get lower tax.
Ed Balls argued Osborne cut the top tax from 50p to 45p, we saw he and Cameron were already aiming for 40p.
If they go for it, that means more tax cuts for the rich; therefore they need to spell out what they intend right now.
**Moreover**, the talk also **covering** income tax, national insurance and business taxes.
Meanwhile, David Laws —a Liberal Democrat minister —accuses the Conservatives of grabbing credit for the personal allowance hike; does that seem right, therefore?
Laws, former chief secretary to the Treasury, noted prime minister and chancellor didn't push the move during talks with the Lib Dems, so what does that show?
He announced his team's plan: go farther and faster, therefore the allowance will rise soon.
Osborne said raising allowance is a key tax commitment — one of his major promises.
Therefore, tax‑free personal allowance jumps: £10,600 in 2015‑16; £10,800 in 2016‑17; and £11,000 in 2017‑18.
During BBC Radio 5 Live, Laws told Pienaar’s Politics that this because his party’s efforts, therefore the blame fell on them.

Rival trainmakers are set to bid for £2.75bn deal to supply and maintain high-speed rolling stock for phase one of controversial project The first phase of the high-speed project The first phase of the high-speed project Photograph: High Speed Two (HS2) Ltd Vie de Rail Transport Sunday 20 November 2016 12.58 GMT Last modified on Sunday 20 November 2016 15.50 GMT The Department for Transport said up to 60 trains capable of running at 225mph were needed, with the contract for the trains and maintaining the fleet to be awarded in 2019.
The rolling stock is needed for the first phase of the HS2 project, with the new trains due to run on the London-Birmingham section when it opens in 2026.
Work on the Birmingham phase begins later this year and will cut journey times between the cities by 32 minutes.

The two-stage, Y-shaped second phase, with the Birmingham to Crewe section due to open in 2027, will be completed six years later, and will extend HS2 to a new Manchester Airport interchange and on to Manchester.

Other contracts will be awarded for later stages of the work. Transport secretary Chris Grayling said the new railway would provide a huge number of seats for the more than 300,000 people travelling on it each day.
“Hundreds of jobs will be created in building and maintaining these trains, representing a great opportunity for British-based businesses and suppliers,” he said.
“HS2 will see thousands of apprenticeships created and 25,000 jobs during construction.” Grayling said the department was communicating with UK suppliers to maximise the opportunities for them.
Friday’s launch will be followed by a formal process in spring 2017, when details of how to bid will become available.

An invitation to tender will be published in 2018. Hitachi Rail Europe (HRE) said on Friday it wants to supply the new trains for Britain’s £56bn HS2 high-speed railway that would support jobs and skills across the UK.
HRE, which has its UK headquarters in London, makes trains at its plant in Newton Aycliffe, County Durham.

Nick Hughes, sales director at the firm, said: “The HS2 trains will be British-built in our state-of-the-art facility in Newton Aycliffe, delivered in partnership with British suppliers, and a shining example of British innovation exported around the world.” He said the trains would “make use of our pioneering Japanese-bullet train (Shinkansen) technology, but build them in Britain, for Britain”.

Siemens, another train maker, said the contract to be awarded in 2017 was “very exciting news for the rail industry”, and could be significant for British suppliers, as operations in Britain would be supported by the UK supply chain.
A spokesman for Siemens said it had bolstered its involvement in HS2 and was was working to deliver the best and most effective solutions at all levels.
Gordon Wakeford, managing director of Siemens Mobility, said: “The manufacturing contract will be a large-scale programme requiring significant input from the UK supply chain”.
Siemens Mobility has appointed two of its directors to strengthen its bidding team for rolling stock for HS2.
The project has been criticised by some who say it will destroy large swaths of the English countryside.
*In tourism‑reliant Antigua a terrible sickness killed almost half the island’s lofty coconut trees, so now the scenery is dotted with ugly, head‑less trunks.
* Lethal yellow, the same disease that wiped out coconut trees in Florida and Jamaica, it’s now a threat to this 280‑sq‑km island’s culture and its economy.
Coconut: in the dishes we eat, in the lotions we apply, and in the old‑time remedies handed down through generations.
Barbara Japal thinks almost 45% of Antigua’s coconut palms are gone; Julian Rose who sold bottle after bottle at $3.70 for four years now watches the empty trees.
Over the past year his supply got cut in half; therefore his income is half as well.
A big change. I keep my prices the same, customers just won’t pay extra,” he says.
In conclusion, if a palm shows early fruit drop and its fronds turn yellow before they fall, cut it down and burn it straight away—no waiting.
Since 2012 the disease keeps spreading, why does it? government’s budget thin, therefore nothing stops it.
Tourism suffers? We hear the palm is the charm, yet the sea view looks dull, Mrs. Japal tells the BBC.
Seeing them stand like soldiers without heads, devastating. Therefore, shock drops, and it feels plain rude.
Coconuts - a huge part of daily life here; we cook with them and then rub the oil on skin and hair.
Honestly, it isn’t mainstream medicine, therefore the oil still lives in our tradition for heal skin and clean body.
Lethal yellowing rides a plant‑hopping bug; Mrs. Japal says it arrived hidden in the imported trees, therefore the trees carried it.
Since 2012 they put a ban on bringing palms in, so you won’t see any new palm trees arriving.
We got a bunch of plants, they were brought here years ago; therefore they’re still sitting in the garden.
*Plant protection unit? Yeah. Who, then, looks inside each box of three‑thousand trees?
* She points out, therefore lack of money left staff completely powerless. No proper disposal, no systematic removal for affected palms, unless private individuals step in.
*No cure for lethal yellowing, yet a quarterly oxytetracycline injection (OTC) for trees works.* **Mrs. Japal adds – locals don’t use OTC, it’s just too pricey.**
Therefore, the commission is probing tax breaks US companies get when they place their headquarters in Europe, what’s really happening?
Next month, EU will drop its say on Apple, might just shove a multi‑billion‑pound tax bill onto the company.
The commission said no bias against US companies in the investigations, therefore it’s all fair, you see?
A US regulator put out a report on Wednesday warning Brussels action could make it a supra‑national tax authority, therefore it may overtake the tax rules of every member country.
The report said Brussels applied a different set of rules to U.S. firms and called the likely fines deeply troubling.
Apple's alleged to dodge billions of pounds in taxes; it hides the money in Ireland under a pact with the Irish authorities, therefore the tax bill stays low.
So, with JP Morgan acting as Apple’s banker, they warned Apple could end up with a $19 billion (about £14.3 billion) bill in the worst‑case.
Therefore, European Commission investigating tax avoidance, Apple, Amazon and Starbucks listed.
**The commission said last year Starbucks and Fiat've gotten a favorable tax deal in the Netherlands, so both companies ended up paying less.
** EU's executive is checking if Apple snagged a tax perk in Ireland that other firms didn’t get, maybe that violates EU state‑aid rules?
Earlier this year the US government announced its objection to the Brussels probe, saying it singled out American firms.
The Treasury urged Brussels to rethink its hits on US firms—Apple, Starbucks and Amazon—arguing that the fines could really mess up cross‑border tax, so maybe they should look again?

Robert Stack, a Treasury deputy, wrote that the studies could shift world tax rules and the G20’s attempt to stop avoidance while giving firms steadier certainty to grow and invest; therefore a charge from the European Commission might count as a foreign tax credit in the U.S., could lower the companies’ tax bill.
Treasury Department? they’re mulling a response if the commission just sticks to its present route.
**In reply the commission says it’s bound to apply EU law fair to every company that does business in Europe.
** Apple says, no special tax deal with the Irish government. **We wasn't given any preferential treatment by Irish authorities, therefore the firm claim, no hand‑out at all.**
It may have been. The commodities markets, and I, were surprised when the OPEC group cut production in Algiers.
The group certainly still has a long way to go to push up the oil price in any serious or sustained way.
But it was not expected by the market. They had expected disarray again like that which prevailed at OPEC and other oil exporters’ last meeting for a coordinated effort, in Doha last April.

But, this time, a deal was done. The context for Algiers – and earlier failed attempts to agree cuts in production – is the collapse in crude oil prices, to less than half the $110 a barrel they were in June 2014.
This, in turn, has hit the budgets and economic performances of OPEC members hard.
Saudi Arabia’s government ran a surplus worth 12% of GDP in 2012; a deficit of 16% last year. Angola’s economy grew by 7% in 2013; it was 3% last year.
Venezuela is in an even worse position, though its difficulties include a political crisis as well as an oil one.
So, for the best part of a couple of years OPEC members have been under growing pressure.

And, while OPEC is anything but the whole story – huge non-member producers include America, Russia and China, as well as Canada – the group controls about 40% of the market, and has traditionally responded to low prices, and supported them, by cutting production.
The biggest market player, Saudi Arabia, has usually been at the forefront of efforts to do so.
This year the story was complicated by Iran’s escape from most of the international sanctions imposed on the country ahead of the agreement on its nuclear programme.

Iran is keen to continue the process of rebuilding its market share. The difficulty for OPEC was that Saudi Arabia was unwilling to cut production unless Iran did, and unwilling to cut it by very much if it was going to do so.
Long-term strategic tensions in the Gulf dominate the relationship between Saudi Arabia and Iran, the region’s two big players.

That was the basis upon which Doha failed in April. But Iran has already increased its oil production, and further increases are possible although less easy than in the immediate aftermath of the ending of sanctions. Meanwhile Saudi Arabia seems to have softened its line.
**Judges just changed a 2013 decision; they didn't shut down the program, therefore they pressed Congress move.

** Snowden, who lives in Russia now, said the NSA collect call data – numbers and when they ring – but they never grab the actual words; therefore the surveillance was only on the outer details, right?
**Allegedly NSA spied on European firms, so even German chancellor Angela Merkel wasn’t safe from the watch.
** Apparently, Germany cut a lot of NSA‑related online surveillance. US agency didn’t have clear justification each time, therefore snooping dropped.
According to Gordon Adams of American University, Congress could maybe back the court’s decision next week.

House looks ready to vote on the USA Freedom Act—wanted to shut down the NSA’s huge data sweep; yet a few senators, they like things staying the same, so they push to stretch Section 215 of the Patriot Act, which still lets that collection go on.

Section 215 expires in June. If they prolong it, the NSA keeps its work going. Here’s the newest ruling from the 2nd US Circuit Court of Appeals in New York, it comes after Judge William Pauley of the district court said no to the ACLU’s challenge.
The ACLU says the NSA’s call tracking violates the US Constitution: therefore a lawsuit.
The 97‑page ruling says basically a part of the USA Patriot Act that lets the FBI snag business records for counter‑terror work can’t be stretched to let them scoop up all domestic call logs at once.
Therefore, the court didnt rule on whether the program was constitutional; it actually began right after the September 11, 2001 attacks.
Snowden's June 2013 leaks set off a worldwide uproar; therefore, even as US officials kept insisting the spy program was okay, many people were still outraged.

Since 2006 secret court approved these steps, therefore they’ll end on June 1. Most House leaders want passing a bill that stops the gov’t mass phone‑record sniff, and they push another measure they claim will keep civil liberties safer.
**Mitch McConnell, the Republican Senate Majority Leader, wants the Patriot Act stretched out and the bulk spying program stay on.

** The White House says they’re looking for a new way to keep the program’s core abilities alive without the government hoarding all the data, Ned Price, the National Security Council spokesman, told us.

What is the levy, what's it for, and why is it being raised now? The bank levy is an annual tax, charged on the value of the debts of UK banks (including deposited cash), albeit with a range of exclusions.

The Treasury originally planned to set the levy at 0.05% for the whole of 2011, but announced in February that it would maintain a permanent normal rate of 0.075% from May. With a slight tweak, the rate is now 0.078%.

And now the rate has been raised again to 0.088% from January. The prime purpose of the tax is to punish banks for relying on risky methods of borrowing that worsened the 2008 crisis, but it's also a cash cow for the government.

Will it fill the hole in the deficit? The Treasury thinks the levy will net it £2.6bn a year, which works out as 2.1% of the budget deficit projected by the Office for Budget Responsibility this year.
It's 19% of the pre-tax profits announced by the five largest UK banks in the 12 months to September, although more than those five (Lloyds, RBS, Barclays, HSBC, Santander) will pay the tax.
What is all this borrowing that the government wants to discourage? Banks have traditionally lent cash to customers using the deposits that individuals or businesses place with them.
In the past decade, banks discovered convoluted alternative ways to borrow trillions from markets in London and around the world.
Unlike deposit cash, there is no upper bound for this money, since it could originate anywhere in the world and because it was passed around again and again between banks.
The majority of these debts were short-term: banks would have to return to the market every few days to roll the debts over.
In the crisis, investors began to believe that banks would default on their debts, and a market stampede began as nobody would lend to banks any more.
The resulting inability to refinance would cause the banks to implode, even if they were still in profit.

And why are retail deposits excluded from the levy? When people think about bank runs, they picture long lines of people taking money from their current accounts – such as the queues that gathered at branches of Northern Rock.
But since the 1930s governments have guaranteed the deposits of most citizens, making a run by depositors unlikely.
For 70 years my father has borne witness to what happened to his ship HMS Hebe in June 1940.
Chief engine room artificer Biles was aboard the Hebe during the Dunkirk evacuation, when she was used by the Royal Navy in Dover as a control ship.
The Hebe crossed to Dunkirk three times during those hectic days between 27 May and 4 June.
"It was torrid, dangerous and nerve-wracking while being bombed constantly by German aircraft," Harold Biles tells me.
Biles celebrated his 28th birthday under shellfire on the Hebe. "The Hebe was about 200 metres off Dunkirk's beach, with thousands of soldiers around us.
We were ducks on a pond and they were all on a beach trying to get to us. "Massive air bombardments and shellfire made things tough.

At night, when enemy air attacks were less, we could sleep a bit." Early in the morning of 29 May 1940, the captain of HMS Hebe sent a ship's boat into the beach at Dunkirk, where it picked up Lord John Gort, commander-in-chief of the BEF, and returned with him to England.
"As the Hebe sped back to Dover, I remember watching Lord Gort stand at the guardrail, holding on as the ship rose and fell," says Biles.
"He looked resplendent with the red piping on his uniform but he didn't move. His head was bowed.
"There was no cheers for saving 330,000 men from being German POWs. He was defeated.
He lost an army." The German action and the trauma and fatigue of the moment had a damaging impact on the crew of HMS Hebe and others involved in the evacuation operation.

My father describes witnessing early examples of what we now call post-traumatic stress syndrome and what was then known by many in the Navy as a "lack of moral fibre": "We came alongside in Dover and began loading supplies when we were 'attacked' by an aircraft flying low along the dock.
It was an RAF plane but he'd shot his bolt. A seaman looked up, screamed, and fell on the deck in hysterics. Three or four others did the same.

"Later, a silly signal was received by the ship that anybody who felt under strain through the last week were to get their kit and proceed to the dockside and report to the hospital. "About 20 jumped over the gangway and I can still see their grins."
Let’s say you’ve been lucky enough to hitch a flight to Monaco to see Formula 1 at automobile racing’s zenith however you please.
You could be standing on a neo-classical balcony in Monte Carlo, looking over Casino Square with a flute of champagne in your hand.
Or eating lobster pieces and sipping white wine at a trackside restaurant as the cars shred past.
You might be in the Paddock Club with a grandstand seat and a place in the Monaco Yacht Club.
Or you might be crawling on all fours into the rear end of a Formula 1 car, over the exhaust pipes, in a nomex’ed race suit under a cloudless sky in 80-degree heat.
"I had a suit. I had a helmet of my own in the garage. I didn’t want to do the VIP thing.
I was in charge of the right-rear tire of Eddie Irvine’s car." Chris Rea, the Jordan mechanic, healer of 40 millions of album sales, singer of songs about cars.
"I did Monza a couple of times, Monaco being the worst." It’s 1995 at the Monaco Grand Prix, and Eddie Irvine noses back into the pits with a trouble on the right-rear.
"My wheel was very warm, and running on the gear is exhausting, and I had an awful hangover.
So thank you, Eddie Jordan, for the experience—and the hangover." That was where it started for Rea, in Monaco, not among the F1 and showbiz greats, but on his sofa, in front of the telly.
"It was Sunday afternoon, this little film that had been sent from Monte Carlo, live for half an hour.
This guy was off at the front, lapping everybody, Stirling Moss. Moss had gone past already.
And down at the bottom of the hill he was live. And I was asking my dad, what are those things?
‘Squale - sharks.’ I was only about 8. And what’s the color? Because in Italy phenomenon is color is everything, everything is about color.
‘Rosso Sanguino -- blood red.’ ‘Who is that driver? He sounds like a friendly Darth Vader with the modern helmet on.
‘That’s Wolfgang Alexander von Trips, Christopher. He lives in a castle.’ That was really the beginning of it all, for me.’”
Yoan Gouffran grabbed the first goal—a sudden tap from close range. Then, a tangled scramble in front of the net, and Henri Lansbury accidentally shoved the ball into his own goal.
Newcastle clinched the match, yet their joy faded; their top scorer Dwight Gayle, he limped off after only thirty‑three minutes.
Scott Hogan taken off on a stretcher late in the game; therefore Villa's winless run hit nine league matches.
Hogan came from Brentford in January for twelve million pounds, therefore his footing let go and he fell awkwardly while fighting for a header on a Villa corner.
Gayle, the league’s top scorer with twenty goals, apparently made his hamstring hurt worse after missing six games, therefore his season looks shaky.
Six points away from the relegation zone. Only one point earned in 2017, even though they started level with the Magpies but then fell behind, therefore the worry grows.
Did Birkir Bjarnason, the Icelandic midfielder, come the closest for Villa? He missed Hogan’s flick‑on and Karl Darlow saved his shot.
Just as Gayle walked off the pitch Newcastle got a break; Villa couldn’t stop the Ritchie cross, therefore Gouffran the French winger slipped the ball into the net.
After that the hosts seized control, they looked ready to push the lead further, but the second goal that bumped them past Brighton?
It was just a stroke of luck. Jamaal Lascelles linked up with Shelvey’s corner; therefore his strike bounced off Lansbury near the post and slid into the net.
> Rafael Benitez, Newcastle’s manager, told BBC Radio Newcastle that the league is tough—therefore you really have to give it all.
We went up against good team, their players were skilled, therefore the match felt tough; skilled players. They threw the press on us early, we couldn't stick to the plan we imagined.
**Scoring the crucial step. After that second goal, everything opened up.** **Therefore we got more chances, and also a tighter grip on things.
** From the start Dwight Gayle looked uneasy, he claimed his hamstring felt odd.
How serious is it? We're not really sure, therefore we’ll have to take a closer look.
> Steve Bruce told BBC WM: Scott’s injury, it closed a rough night, we’re worried about the outcome; therefore nervous.
He’s hurt his ankle; need X‑rays and scans to know just how bad it is. Losing him would be major, yet we hope it aren't as severe as we think.
**We've felt first half was good; Newcastle never pressed our goal, so an easy goal slipped past us.
** After the restart we handed out another goal, and the second one—unfortunately—just fell short.
It has been the toughest year ever for any commissioner. The NFL is pushing £16bn ($25bn) of annual income and expansion into Europe with London firmly in their sights.

Mr Goodell himself rakes in around £26m ($40m) a year. Yet despite accusations of spreading scandal professional American Football not only remains popular but is gaining in popularity. Last year 50 NFL players were arrested for crimes.
Some, such as Tennessee running back Shonn Greene were fairly minor (he parked in a disabled parking space).
Others, like Minnesota running back Adrian Petersen, were much more serious (child abuse charge).

(The rape charge against a Cleveland Browns player was dropped after a month. Out of the 50 there were five crimes of domestic violence, most famously Baltimore running back Ray Rice who was filmed knocking out his then fiancée in an elevator.
Goodell’s NFL was accused of covering up the extent of the Rice crime and a report led by former FBI head Robert Mueller was damning about how the league handled it.
This year hasn’t been much better. Four new arrests including more domestic violence and a rape charge await resolution.
Life on the field Perhaps great scandals foreshadow declines but this is not the case for the NFL right now. The Rice and Petersen stories died after a week.
The NFL had to cope with a surge in demand from stadium ticketing. In one season 17.6 million fans attended all 256 regular season games by far the most since 2008.
Television audience figures are now at record levels too. High school participation fell with concussion fears.
But participation at the fan level has never been higher. Not just in the USA but also abroad.
The annual Harris Report found that the NFL is the most popular American sport – far more than whatever is second.
Combining the scores for Major League Baseball (which the NFL overtook as America’s national sport in the 1960s) and college football still doesn’t compare to the NFL.
The latest report from sports market research group Repucom found that networks carrying the NFL gained more viewers compared to 2013.
Both Thursday Night Football and Monday Night Football gained. The NFL’s College Draft last Thursday drew in more than 47 million viewers and some 9.6 million tweets with no actual play.
Alice Gross was found dead in the River Brent in west London in September 2014, and the body of a Latvian builder Arnis Zalkalns was found nearby weeks later.
An inquest into the death of Alice, 14, is probing the potential role of government and police failings in the tragedy and why Zalkalns had been allowed to live in the UK unsupervised.
Giving an opening statement on the second day of the inquest, taking place at the Royal Courts of Justice, Alice’s mother, Rosalind Hodgkiss, read from a prepared statement.

She said the inquest was “opportunity for the government and police to get things right” and said the family wanted “to understand whether the current systems in place for monitoring foreign offenders and sharing information between borders is fit for purpose”.

She said: “We understand that the system will have changed profoundly since 1998 but we are shocked that a foreign murderer was not tracked, monitored, or acknowledged and this has damaged our faith in the UK’s ability to protect its citizens.

He Home Office and police force nationally should do all they can to ensure this never happens again.” Hodgkiss said her daughter had been been “lively and popular”, “funny, clever and academic” and “passionate” about writing songs.
She said the death of Alice was “unimaginably and utterly devastating” to the family and “we have a lot of questions and will never truly know what happened that day”, she said.
Alice died on 28 August 2014 after going for a stroll on the towpath of the canal.
Her body was found a month later after what the Metropolitan police described as its biggest investigation since the 7/7 bombings in 2005.

Home Office pathologist Dr Ashley Fegan-Earl told the inquest that Alice’s body had been recovered from the River Brent bound in a foetal position and weighted down with bricks and logs and a bicycle wheel.
He said she had suffered sexual assault and asphyxia. An autopsy suggested a bigger person had forced down on her chest.

Zalkalns was the leading suspect in the killing of Alice, and the Met and CPS said he would have been charged with the murder of Alice had he not died. In 1998 Zalkans was convicted of the murder of his wife in Latvia.
Lisa Passey, 28, and ex-partner Wayne Dale, 45, left Kian and another child home alone while they spent time with a friend.
"It was down to me and Wayne. Me and Wayne had left the children. It's our fault," she told Worcester Crown Court.

She and Wayne Dale deny gross negligence manslaughter. More on this and other stories from Hereford and Worcester Ms Passey occasionally wept as she gave her evidence about what happened on 19 November 2007, the day Kian died at the family home in Kyreside, Tenbury Wells.
"I don't want people feeling sorry for me. I was stupid for not going upstairs," Ms Passey told the court.
Mrs Passey spent three-quarters of an hour standing outside in her garden with friend Natasha Copestake as they drank coffee and smoked.

Mr Dale joined them while he smoked and then "burnt" a CD for Ms Copestake. The toddler, who was taken from an overflowing bath by Mr Dale, died from causes consistent with drowning, Worcester Crown Court was told previously.

The court has also been told how soap bubbles were found in the youngster's lungs, and prosecutors have suggested Kian may have turned on the taps after they had been put in the water while the adults were downstairs.
Ms Passey admitted repeatedly lying to medics and police about what happened on the night of Kian's death, but said she and Mr Dale were "going to say they had done nothing wrong."
She was asked in court why she had given different stories to medics, police and social workers about what happened and told a doctor the bath had been dry and empty.
"At the end of the he day it's my fault my son's gone. I was all over the place," Ms Copestake told the prosecution barrister Jonas Hankin QC under cross examination.
"If you'd gone through it yourself, losing a child... you'd realise you're trying to still grieve, you're walking out of the hospital, knowing you're walking out without your son."
She added that she had previously told the court it was "a usual thing" for Mr Dale to leave Kian in the bath.
However, when asked if he left the child for up to an hour, she replied: "No, for a few minutes." The trial continues.

You might also be interested in: Thais thank late king King Bhumibol Adulyadej, for the last time The formal invitation was backed by parliament and will now be sent to the prince, who must accept it before being crowned.
King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who was seen by many as a father figure, died on 13 October after a long illness.
The prince was widely expected to become his successor, but officials said he had requested that the ascension be put back by at least a year.
The prince has said he wanted to give the Thai people time to mourn King Bhumibol's death before he became monarch.

Correspondents have said that technically and constitutionally, the country is currently in a state of limbo, as the successor - the crown prince - was supposed to take over as king as soon as the throne became vacant.

image copyright Reuters image caption There have been unease from some senior officials in the past, , as to whether the crown prince was up to 70-year "job" he is taking over from his late father The monarchy is highly revered in Thailand, and plays a unifying role in the country.
King Bhumibol's death has struck a deep chord, and millions turned out to pay their last respects when his body was taken in procession.

Since his death, there has been little mention of succession. However following the 2014 military coup, and during times of political instability prior to that, King Bhumibol has been an important unifying figure.
The king is officially titled as Head of State, the Head of the Armed Forces, Adherent of Buddhism and Upholder of religions.
Crown Prince Vajiralongkorn would be expected to rule - like his father - as a constitutional monarch, although the king has intervened in politics before, at times of crisis.
The leader of parliament - the National Legislative Assembly - has said he would meet the crown prince very soon to extend the parliament's formal invitation.
The proclamation of succession will be made once the prince accepts the invitation, however it is unclear when any of this will happen.
Former Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda has been serving as regent in the interim.
This is not something Thailand has done very often. The last royal succession, 70 years ago, followed the mysterious death of King Ananda, a young and inexperienced monarch.
The fact that he had died was not disclosed until after dark that day, and parliament convened late into the night to announce his brother King Bhumibol as his successor.
Recently there has been speculation, and an emotive campaign on social media, backing his younger sister Princess Sirindhorn, who is hugely popular in Thailand.
But since his investiture as crown prince in 1972, Prince Vajiralongkorn has been the undisputed - anointment of succession laws.
The law on royal succession is based on the 1924 Palace Law of Succession, compiled by King Vajiravudh.
This law was included in the 1932 constitution and all subsequent constitutions.

According to the law, both female and male lines are eligible for the throne, but the selection was to be based on the principle of male primogeniture, and that the Princess's reign was to take precedence over any others.

This law also allows the king to appoint an heir of his choice. King Bhumibol has always backed the crown prince, and there is no doubt that the prince would become the next monarch were it not for his unexpected decision, on 13 October, to ask for time before it is made official.

The real reason for this request is known only to him. Becoming king immediately would in no way have disrupted the long and elaborate mourning rituals for his father. But this is the latest twist in a drama over the process of succession.
Sgt Brian Wood, who fought in Iraq in 2004, said the claims about him and his team had left "huge scars".
IHAT is to be wound down after a lawyer involved in many of the abuse cases was struck off.
Veterans Minister Mark Lancaster told the BBC IHAT was set up in "good faith" but was "completely abused" by solicitors.
Sgt Wood, from the 1st Princess of Wales’ Royal Regiment, said on BBC Breakfast the Ministry of Defence had said the government had "lessons to learn - and there's massive lessons to be learned".
"There were very serious allegations of unlawful killings, mutilation, ill-treatment of prisoners of war, and these allegations were false.
"That stuff just never happened and I really can't comprehend where that initiated from.
This is good news that IHAT has been closed down." He said there was a "crack in the system and it was completely manipulated."
"I would have liked to have seen the allegations being looked at more robustly before being put out to the public."

He said his team had suffered "catastrophic" consequences, with people losing out on promotion and opportunities, experiencing relationship problems and marriage breakdown, as well as "general PTSD" from when they were on the the battlefield.

'Broken lives' Former Army captain Rachel Webster, who was told she faced murder charges after a dawn raid on her home in January 2014, said IHAT had been "far too slow to close," adding: "Too little, too late."
"I woke up to six - I think it was - armed policemen in riot gear," she told ITV News.
"I hadn't done anything wrong. And I don't think I'll ever forget how humiliating that was, not just for me but for other soldiers and veterans who've gone through this.

It's absolutely broken lives; it's broken my life." Mr Lancaster told the BBC Radio 4's Today programme that although people were pleased that IHAT was closing, "the government does have an obligation to investigate these allegations of abuse - they cannot simply be dismissed".
He said he believed UK personnel could have been "hauled in front of the International Criminal Court" had IHAT not been set up, but the decision to wind it down was a "good thing".
The IHAT was set up in 2010 to investigate claims of abuse during the Iraq war made by Iraqi civilians against UK service personnel.
The Commons defence committee described it as an "unfit-for-purpose, unstoppable self-perpetuating machine that has replaced the pursuit of truth with an unthinking 'machine says yes' mentality."
The Ministry of Defence announced on Friday that IHAT - which has cost £60m - will be wound down in the summer, with remaining cases transferred to the Royal Navy Police.
For years many Haitians travel into the Dominican Republic, often without any papers, they hoping to leave Haiti's poverty and unemployment, therefore searching for a better life.
In 2013 Dominican Republic’s highest court decided that kids born to undocumented migrants weren’t automatically citizens, therefore the birthright rule changed.
After the ruling undocumented migrants got an 18‑month window to regularize status; therefore they’ve only a year and a half to sort out their papers.
Many who missed the deadline left the country, saying they was driven out by the authorities.

BBC’s Will Grant notes the Catholic Church’s big hand in the migration crisis; therefore some priests push for returnees’ rights, while others get called out for backing split policies, isn’t that odd?
Weekly Mass at Parc Cadeau? It’s a humble meet‑up inside a tiny hut made of wicker and palm. The people sits on plain wood benches.
Seeing the camp, one of a few along Haiti’s border with the Dominican Republic; the parishioners?
They've got hardly anything to be grateful for. You could say it's definitely one of the poorest spots in Latin America, hardly any money left there.
A year ago, thousands of Haitians showed up at Parc Cadeau; some forced out, others left to dodge Dominican officials.
**Hundreds families still on the dusty ranch, cobbling shelters from plastic, cardboard and rope – they're basically stuck in a near‑stateless limbo.
** Soinicier Giles, like many at the camp, lived 22 years farming in the Dominican Republic; therefore last year he got deported.
He brings me to a rundown hut where his wife Eleny lives with six of their eight kids.
The other two were left behind when he got deported, therefore the place feels both crowded and empty.
Life here is rough, especially for kids; we sleep on the bare floor and the rain comes in, Eleny says.
**All her children, they were born in the Dominican Republic; therefore the family’s story starts there.
** Arriving at the camp left them undernourished, and now their skin is cracking.
Starving us all, only one cheap meal a day, she says in Creole‑accented Spanish.
**Father Luc Leandre** the parish priest is one of few who help the returnees; therefore you’ll often see him handing out meals and advice.
Thanks to the International Organization for Migration’s cash, he got the most desperate families moved into nearby Haitian towns, yeah, he actually made that happen.
Father Leandre says it’s a dire crisis, really terrible. Church feels like a mother to everyone, therefore my duty is simply help.
“You see the windows. I put in some little doors, you can open and shut them. See, it has a roof, a red one.
And a door.” M.A., who is 12 years old and Syrian, beams in satisfaction at his model house, made out of recycled cardboard, with its bright-blue façade and tin foil door.
The homes in this cold, bleak camp don’t have windows, but as M.A. remembers, many once did.
The blast of color is as cheerful as it is poignant, a message from the world he lost.
We’re in the Bekaa Valley. The schoolroom and some 40 other buildings are a basic wooden frame on a concrete slab, hung with plastic sheeting.
The plastic is sometimes decorated with advertising from some parallel universe: here, a black-and-white shot of a man with sunglasses and designer stubble.

This is where Prime Minister David Cameron has said he wants to bring people in from — directly from the region, from Syrian camps, to dissuade people from getting on those boats across the Mediterranean.
As far as it goes, this is the sensible way to do it, though I suspect it’s a case of too little, too late.
If 4,000 a year extra until 2020 isn’t going to make a difference, it won’t quell migrant demand, and it won’t do much to slim those waiting lists.
The border with Syria is only a stroll over the hills from here. But over the hills, you can still hear the rumble of distant bombs. Assad hasn’t stopped dropping them on Syrian towns.
Conclusion: they’re safe here, but they’re not comfortable. There are rats. The water is not clean to drink.
The September heat is stultifying, but in winter the snows come down three feet (a meter) and it’s brutally cold.
Real misery and a shortage of prospects are driving people to get out of Lebanon.
Mzead al-Ali lives here; he is considering following those migrants getting on the boats.
He’d head out, abandon his wife and family — he has four, including seven-month-old twins — to earn enough to send some cash back.
His brother left three days ago; no word from him since. Nine of his family live here now.
“Me? Maybe. Maybe I have to go to Turkey, leave them all,” he says. His mother can’t bear it; she’s on the floor, struggling with tears.
She’d love to talk about it, but she can’t keep her hands from her face. Technically, this is termed a “semipermanent settlement,” not a camp.
There are thousands of them; Lebanon, with its population of four million, has a million refugees within its borders, from its larger warring neighbor.
Around a third are in camps like these; the rest have their own homes. Either way, as a government minister put it to me, “Lebanon’s back is breaking.” The pressure is on.

Mr Scott, the stadium safety expert, is no doubt in agreement. This Cabinet Office report, which exposes "broken" relationships behind the scenes, reveals that it will be at least another year before a fresh planning application can be made.
But its authors do say that a new stadium is still "achievable" and that the business case for it is "sound".
The Cabinet Office report was commissioned when Mr Scott told a Stormont committee in April that there were flaws in the proposed emergency-exiting arrangements for the 38,000 capacity stadium.
They still exist but, despite that, this report goes on to suggest that Mr Scott should be replaced as chairman of the Safety Technical Group overseeing the Casement project.
The report suggests that personnel changes are needed and that is an outcome which Sports Minister Carál Ní Chuilín has indicated she means to act upon.
Welcoming the fact that the Cabinet Office report says a stadium is still achievable, she said: "The report provides clarity."
It adds that the relationships between the major stakeholders, already at the heart of the project, are "broken".
As a result, it suggests that an independent mediator should be appointed to smooth over working relations.
Delays underlined Construction was originally intended to start this year but planning permission was overturned in December 2014.
"The Casement Park project is behind schedule," the Cabinet Office report states.

It must now address two outstanding areas: A number of flaws in the emergency-exiting plans have to be resolved A fresh planning-application process will have to be initiated too with the prospects of public inquiries and possible legal challenges It gives "a delivery confidence assessment" using a traffic light system to the projects - Casement is judged to be "amber/red".
While the report suggests Mr Scott is removed as chairman of the Safety Technical Group, he could still stay on the team.
His replacement would require mediation and facilitation skills rather than a technical background.
The chairman of the Stormont committee, which looked into Mr Scott's complaints, said the Cabinet Office report should be seen as only "part of the resolution".
Question-time Democratic Unionist Party member Nelson McCausland said there were further questions which the minister and her officials have to answer.
"We will be holding a special committee meeting at Stormont next week and asking the minister and the permanent secretary to address our questions," he said.
That government‑funded anti‑violence ad feels especially vital, because people fear Mexico’s drug violence might spill over into our tiny Central American nation.
It was President Mauricio Funes – first to sound the alarm – back in April. We’ve got word—therefore President Funes says the cartels have quietly slipped into El Salvador just to scout.
He explained. Effective, he claimed; therefore the cartels was scouting new bases.
Security forces on high alert, eyes glued to any hint that the Zetas—Mexico’s brutally violent cartel—might be planting roots in El Salvador.
Therefore, authorities also watching for any possible teamwork or even fights between the cartels and the local gangs.
Douglas Garcia Funes of the Salvadoran police notes, therefore, intel says gangs already acting as operatives moving drugs and cash to United States via Mexico.
Thus, nation with one of world’s highest murder rates shows a grim possibility.
Many Salvadorans think it might crank up the violence in a nation already a mess; therefore the government, apparently, gearing up for the worst‑case scenario.
We’re pretty concerned, so we aim start some precautionary steps,” said Hugo Martinez, El Salvador’s foreign minister, to BBC News.
Inside a Salvadoran prison, picture the chaos; the “maras” that grew out of Salvadoran migrants in L.A. in the 80s, therefore they are said to drive the crime rise.
About 15,000 youngsters in these gangs, families now see a third generation of gang activity showing up.
Maras dominate certain blocks, they claim they’re doing “social cleansing” to stop petty theft, yet they demand cash for protection while constantly running drug and gun deals.
Anonymous, a retired gang member; he says the mara gives poor Salvadoran youths a weird sense of power, therefore they feel they can push back at society.
According to him people are scared what a gang member could do; they picture theft, maybe even murder.
That's what being in a mara means, it sort of sums it up. Maras aren't new to El Salvador, yet June's clash, it felt like a real turning point.
*In the capital a gang lit a small bus ablaze, seventeen died, therefore the government called it a terrorist act, ok?*
The 22-year-old striker was one of three AC Milan players subjected to abuse during Sunday's 2-2 draw with Roma, which was suspended for two minutes.
"If it happens again, I'm walking off the pitch because it's idiotic," the Italy international said.
"I was really just waiting for the game to finish. "I was going to leave but they stopped."
AC Milan were down to 10 men on Sunday when the Serie A fixture at the San Siro was temporarily held up.

Play resumed once the travelling Roma fans were told to curb their actions. Roma were fined 50,000 euros (£42,400) by the Italian Football League as a result and released a statement on Monday criticising their supporters, claiming they would "deal with this issue directly".
Fifa president Sepp Blatter branded the punishment inadequote, saying on the governing body's website: "They have not dealt with the problem.

Just condemning these incidents with fines is not the right way." Balotelli, who has scored 11 goals in 12 appearances since joining from Manchester City in January, explained how the incident has altered his thinking when it comes to dealing with such issues.
"I always said that if it happened in a stadium that I would just pretend I hadn't heard and would keep playing. "But yesterday I changed my mind a little bit.
"I said to myself, 'If it happens another time, then I'm going to leave the pitch.'"
AC Milan players have been subjected to racist abuse on a number of occasions this campaign.
In January, the Rossoneri left the field during a friendly against Pro Patria following chants aimed at Kevin-Prince Boateng.
Last month, Inter Milan were also fined 50,000 euros after their fans targeted opponents Balotelli, who used to play for them, during the Milan derby.
Juventus were also fined 30,000 euros (£25,000) last month after their fans abused AC Milan players.

This, the first ever international anti-corruption summit, will look to expose, punish and eradicate global corruption with political leaders, businesses, sports bodies and charities congregating at Lancaster House on Thursday.
Corruption, said Mr Cameron, is “an enemy of progress and the root of so many of the world’s problems”.
“It destroys jobs and holds back economic growth, traps the poorest in desperate poverty, and undermines our security by pushing people towards extremist groups.

The battle against corruption will not be won overnight. It will take time, it will take courage and it will take determination to bring about the changes we need.” “But we cannot afford to let the understandable frustration and disappointment over the past slow us down.

If we want to beat poverty, bring more stability to fragile states and defeat terrorism, we and our international partners have to tackle the exploitation, fraud and dishonesty at the heart of so many problems in the world.
For too long there has been a taboo about tackling this issue head-on” “The summit will change that.

Together we will push the fight against corruption to the top of the international agenda where it belongs.” World leaders taking part in the summit will include the Afghanistan president Ashraf Ghani, the Colombian president Juan Manuel Santos, the Nigerian president Muhammadu Buhari and the Norwegian prime minister Erna Solberg and the US secretary of state John Kerry.

Russia will be represented by deputy minister of foreign affairs Oleg Syromolotov and speakers are expected to include the president of the World Bank Jim Yong Kim and the head of the International Monetary Fund, Christine Lagarde.

Under plans drawn up by the prime minister, leaders at the summit will agree commitments to expose corruption so there is nowhere to hide and punish the perpetrator and support those affected by corruption.

Anti-corruption campaigners have also called for action to be taken on UK-linked tax havens, after the Panama Papers showed the way some of the world’s richest individuals use firms based in the islands to keep their vast wealth in tax havens and evade sanctions.

A Downing Street spokesperson said: “We are in discussions with Overseas Territories and Crown Dependencies who have significant financial centres on their attendance, and we’re expecting a good showing.” Robert Barrington, the executive director of Transparency International, said the prime minister is creating an opportunity for governments that want to take action to make transformative changes and establish the agenda for the next generation.

“The key now is that governments are drawn into agreeing goals that are suitably ambitious, and that the UK government resists any special pleading from countries that are less committed and want to dilute the summit’s commitments.”

They were home and hosed by half-time and scored a six-try bonus-point win, Thomas Waldrom grabbing a hat-trick after scoring twice in the first half while Jack Nowell and Mitch Lees also touched down for the Chiefs.
Frank Halai crossed for Wasps on the stroke of half-time, with Ashley Johnson and Lorenzo Cittadini scoring after the break to put the hosts on level terms.
But Waldrom claimed his treble and Moray Low capped a fine win for the visitors with a late try of his own.

Exeter, whose place at the Premiership summit will be taken if leaders Saracens beat Newcastle Falcons on Sunday, were irresistible early on and racked up four tries in the opening 34 minutes, with Jack Nowell and Mitch Lees complimenting Waldrom's brace.

Jimmy Gopperth had kicked two penalties for Wasps but George Smith's lovely grubber kick allowed Halai to touchdown in the corner on the stroke of half-time, with Gopperth's conversion making it 27-13 at the interval.

Johnson and Cittadini barged over from close range to bring Wasps level on 52 minutes, but Waldrom raced over for three of his own to put Exeter back in front and despite losing Henry Slade to a knee knock in the second half the visitors took control again, Low scoring their sixth try of the afternoon.
Wasps: Piutau; Tagicakibau, Daly, Jacobs, Halai; Gopperth, Simpson; Mullan, Johnson, Cittadini, Davies, Gaskell, Jones, Smith, Thompson.
Replacements: Shervington, McIntyre, Cooper-Wooley, Myall, Hughes, Simpson, Jackson, Leiua.
Exeter: Dollman; Nowell, Slade, Hill, Short; Steenson, Chudley; Moon, Yeandle (capt), Francis, Lees, Parling, Johnson, Salvi, Waldrom.
Dai Young: "It is a massive wake up call today. Exeter were better than us in every department.

We were very poor at the line-out, something which we pride ourselves on. They made it look awfully easy, which we can't be pleased about but I'm prepared to just sit there and say they were awfully good today.
Sometimes a pat on the back is only six inches away from a kick up the backside so you have to make sure you don't believe the hype sometimes.
Rob Baxter: "It was a really good performance. Credit to Wasps for how they came back today, probably a bit unexpectedly.
They've been in a lot of high emotional games, and sometimes that can sap the energy out of you and sometimes you have little periods in games you can't get to.

That's what we were hoping we would do, put Wasps under pressure with our line speed and then pressure on the scoreboard and hopefully try to expose any elements that might be left over from their energy-draining games from the past few weeks."
After the “Trojan Horse” probe—alleging hard‑line Muslim groups trying to seize city schools—some schools moved out of council control, they become academies, therefore shaking things up.

Therefore, four investigations stay open; each digging into the accusations: one city hall, another state attorney office, a third university, the last media watchdog. According to a government source, every option’s still on the table, you see?
On Thursday Park View, the school named in the claims, posted a brief note saying it’s not extremist.
In June the reports come, Ofsted and the Department for Education laying out what schools accused of wrongdoing should do next.
Ministers meeting top schools and academy trusts to discuss grabbing the failing schools; could shift them from local authority into government‑funded academies run by capable headteachers?
Perry Beeches chain of schools out Birmingham, they're outstanding, might have part in it.
Since a few schools already academy, they're likely to get shifted to a different academy trust.
**Birmingham City Council said they'd keep quiet on any proposed moves, therefore no comment will come until Ofsted actually releases its inspection report.
** > Even so, the council spokesperson said we keep regular contact with the DfE and they havent brought up this issue with us.

The GMB union shouted, “Disgusting how the government waits for the probe’s results then hands those schools to their academy friends, therefore it’s pure revulsion.” Before the Trojan Horse claims, Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw hinted publicly the local authority might’ve needed a restructure.
*Birmingham is the biggest local authority in England and therefore finding a private contractor that can run all its services seems pretty tough, does anyone know one?
* Thus maybe the council just moves its schools and kids services into an independent trust (like they did in Hackney, London), can it work?

because the government said a big shake‑up was needed. During a school meeting last week, Birmingham City Council's chief executive Mark Rogers warned a firestorm would erupt after the Ofsted reports and urged everyone, therefore, to brace for big changes in the education department.
It is understood to be the first time that a TPim is said to have been breached.
The defendant, known as BM, is accused of failing to telephone a monitoring company and report to a police station on two separate occasions in January.
The Home Office has so far declined to comment. TPims replaced the previous control orders in January 2012.
BM was one of nine UK citizens subject to a TPim, according to the last statement issued in March.
The BBC is not aware of anyone else being taken to court and charged with breaching a TPim.
The Home Office told the BBC: "We do not comment on individual cases. All breaches of TPims are investigated by the police, and the police will bring prosecutions where possible."
Under TPims, individuals can be required to reside overnight at a particular address and report daily to a police station.
There can also be prohibitions on making contact with particular individuals, visiting particular locations or travelling overseas.
Labour claims that TPims have "weakened" the public's protection against terrorism.
Last month, David Anderson QC, the independent reviewer of terror law, said that TPims may prove to be weaker controls than the previous regime because a TPim can only last for in total two years.
Special court BM is accused of breaching the terms of his TPim on two occasions in January.
The court was told he faces two counts of breaching section 23 of a TPim order.
The charges said: On 16 January, he did "fail to comply with [section] 3 of a TPim notice… in that he failed to contact a monitoring company".
On 27 January he "did fail to comply with section 3 of a TPim in that he failed to report to a police station".
BM, who has a grey beard and wore a white shirt in court, cannot be identified or have his address published for legal reasons.
Louise Gray, prosecuting, asked that a provisional plea and case management hearing could be set for 2 July.
BM was given unconditional bail but remains subject to his TPim restrictions. There is not yet a date for a trial.
The problems stem from the fact that booking systems use “guessable” six-digit codes to identify travellers.
Two researchers who uncovered the shortcomings changed a booking and seating details for a flight taken by a reporter.

They discussed their work at the Chaos Communication Congress in Germany. In a blog, Karsten Nohl and Nemanja Nikodijevic from Security Research Labs (SRL) said the computer systems that handled airline bookings were first written in the 70s and 80s.
While web interfaces had been added to update them they did not have defences to stop “unauthorised” people getting at data.
This was partly because the flight-booking systems did no validation or sanity-checking to see who was looking at details about flights.
In addition, most reservation systems placed no limits on how frequently someone could ask about the booking details for specific flights.
These two characteristics could be abused, they said, because the six-digit codes, known as Passenger Name Records (PNR), used to identify travellers used a limited character set.
This made it easier for an attacker to bombard the servers handling flight-booking queries to win access to someone’s details.
“Given only passengers’ last names, their booking codes can be found over the Internet with little effort,” they wrote.
This can allow attackers to steal personal details, re-direct frequent-flyer points or meddle with a booking to give some attacks a better appearance of plausibility.
In some cases, said the researchers, attackers could completely change details of a flight – potentially allowing them to fly for free.
SRL showed how this could be done by working with German television station ARD to alter the booking made by a reporter to seat him next to a German politician.
SRL called on airlines and travel agents to rapidly respond and tighten up the way they dealt with data about travellers.
As a minimum, they said, queries should be limited to a sample number for each booking.
Almost all flights booked online are handled by three global operators – Amadeus, Sabre and Travelport.
Amadeus said it was now “assessing” the claims SLR has made and added it was planning to “address” the issues that had been found, and work with its partners to close the loopholes.
Amadeus added that bookings were limited to a specific number of queries before it asked a user to prove their identity.

Sabre said it had “multiple layers” of security around its systems that handled flight itineraries but added that talk about them “would jeopardise their effectiveness”. Travelport is still assessing the claims made by SRL.
If there is any graffiti, it will most likely be in impeccably punctuated English.
But what’s remarkable is that the graffiti is joined by a scattering of words in English from UK students, and the numbers are rising.

When the university admissions season begins in the UK, there are UK students including Rotterdam in their open day circuit and professors will be selling courses here like out-of-territory Russell Group universities.
After the increase in English university fees to £9,000 there were prophecies that students would be looking elsewhere for the best value, and this, it appears, is happening.
This term, 2,600 students from the UK are studying in the Netherlands, up 33% in a year.
Headteachers of independent schools are urging that applicants for Dutch universities be allowed on the UCAS form. One example is the University of Groningen.
The still relatively small number of UK enrolments rose again this year by 33% and is now up to around 300 students, enough to merit special open days.
The university is 400 years old, the second oldest in the Netherlands, in the top 100 worldwide, and now describes itself as an English university.
In Groningen there are now the same number of students doing degree courses taught in English as in Dutch, with students drawn from across Germany, China, the UK and the Netherlands.
But for families from England on open days in Groningen, there’s an ever-present backdrop of tuition fees.
Phoebe Watkinson and her father, Phil, have made the 12-hour trip from the Wirral.
Phoebe says going to a European university for less money would give her an “edge” for jobs, and it didn’t take much more bravery.
She says it’s “no further than going to London” — and they could be here in no more time than it would take to make the train journey to a place in the west of England.
Mr Watkinson went to university when it was free. “I just find it hard to get my head around the cost of university.
“I would be extremely pleased if she came here, for several reasons — not just the academic and social but also, for sure, the economic.
“Most people might say ‘fees’ as the main reason to look at a foreign university,” Mr Watkinson said. But there’s a wider choice. “There’s a lot more to it than that.”
A British teenager from Dewsbury, Talha Asmal, has been identified by The Guardian as one of four suicide bombers in an attack that targeted security forces in Iraq.

According to Isis social media postings cited by The Guardian, 17-year-old Asmal, believed to have adopted the name Abu Yusuf al-Britani, was among those who detonated car bombs on Saturday in an assault on an oil refinery south of the city of Baiji.
A statement from Asmal’s family published by The Guardian described the family’s devastation at his reported death, saying they believed he would have been “Britain’s youngest known suicide bomber”.
Another West Yorkshire teenager, Hasib Hussein, was a month shy of his 19th birthday when he blew himself up on a bus in London in the 7 July 2005 attacks.
Asmal, his family’s statement says, was a “loving, kind, caring and affable teenager” who never showed any signs of “violence, extremist views or radicalisation”.

However, aged 17 and “wholly unprepared for the rigours of life”, he “turned to the internet and social media” and was “exploited and brainwashed” by unknown individuals whom “targeted and befriended [him] and engaged in a process of deliberate and calculated grooming of him”.
They continue: “Talha was ordered to his death by so-called Isis handlers and leaders too cowardly to do their own dirty work.

“We are all naturally utterly devastated and heartbroken by the unspeakable tragedy that now appears to have befallen us.” A West Yorkshire Police spokesman said: “We are aware of media reports with regard to the death of a British National in Iraq.
“The identity of the individual has not been confirmed and we are unable to comment further at this time.” Asmal had gone to Syria with another teenager from Dewsbury, Hassan Munshi.

Munshi’s brother Hammaad was 16 when he was arrested in 2006 after police found a guide to making napalm on his computer, prompting what Scotland Yard said was the most significant counter-terrorism raid since the 7 July bombings.
He became the then youngest person to be convicted of charges under the Terrorism Act.
British police said earlier this year that they believed at least 700 people had travelled to support or fight for jihadist groups in Syria and Iraq.
A BBC News database identifies 54 people who are known to have either died, been convicted of offences relating to the conflict or are still in the region.
Mr Drakeford said the idea was "attractive" and could be a good way to "bear down on poverty and inequality".
Proponents think it could help people currently out of work who can be reluctant to take jobs because they may lose their benefits.
But the suggestion has been described by Patrick Minford, at Cardiff University's Business School, as "not a practical proposal".
UBI is an idea which would see everybody paid a basic fixed amount, regardless of whether or not they are in work, and without the need to prove they are seeking work.
In Scotland, the policy is backed by a range of parties, and studies are currently being done to see if it could be piloted in areas in Glasgow and Fife.

Jamie Cooke, the head of the RSA think tank in Scotland, told the BBC's Sunday Politics Wales programme: "In terms of going from unemployment to employment, you're not going to be penalised for doing that, you're still going to get a steady stream of payments coming through which gives you the security also that if you want to develop that, whether for training or for self-employment, starting your own business, you can do that in a different way."

He described Mr Drakeford's comments as "fantastic". UBI, is utopian stuff. Former Margaret Thatcher adviser Patrick Minford But Prof Minford, a former adviser to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, said: "I'm afraid it's utopian stuff and I think, you know, you could have chilli con carne for a basic set of meals, couldn't you, it's the same kind of aspiration.

"The problem with it is that as a practical system, it just takes in too much money, because you've got to raise a lot of tax to pay it, and that tax discourages people who are further up the scale and, in a sense, have to pay to finance it."
In January, Mr Drakeford told the assembly that he was "attracted" to UBI because of the potential to simplify and to help people, such as those who currently combine part-time work and benefits.
It would be necessary, he added, for "politicians… to persuade" people to adopt the approach.
Responding on the Sunday Politics Wales programme to Mr Drakeford's comments, Prof Minford said: "I'm afraid, for the state of Wales, isn't it, that he has these thoughts.
It worries me a little bit." "I just hope Wales isn't going to go down the Scottish route into this socialist experimentation which is going to be I think very expensive."
Nineteen sailors died and 30 others were wounded when the Type 42 destroyer took a direct hit during the Falklands conflict on 25 May 1982.
It sank within 20 minutes, and with it many documents and items of equipment that were judged to be "important to the security of the United Kingdom," said Clive Gale.
He was one of a 39-strong Royal Navy team who spent four months from autumn 1982 making numerous dives on a number of sunken shipwrecks including HMS Coventry.
"We were very aware we were diving on a war grave and the lives that had been lost with the ship," he said, recalling the experience of searching HMS Coventry.
"When you go down and you see things remaining on the ship down there it's quite moving to have visited what is effectively the last resting place of those guys."
Operation Blackleg was a strenuous and hazardous job with some of the dives lasting as long as eight hours.

"We were 8,000 miles away from any rescue facilities," said Mr Gale. "We were diving while hostilities remained ongoing between Britain and Argentina, and there was a 500lb (227kg) unexploded bomb somewhere inside the wreck.
"There were near misses all through the whole operation. When you cut into steel under water, the cut traps oxygen.
If that explodes with a spark it blows violently. "One of the problems we had was a diver had the front plate of his helmet blown off and almost drowned.

I was on another occasion knocked out and had to be recovered by a colleague." Mr Gale recognised there were "certain items we needed either to recover or destroy" in the mission 300ft (91m) below the surface of the South Atlantic.
"Other things we brought up such as the cross of nails were not necessarily on the official list," he said.
"While I was down there removing the large brass plaque someone else went to get the bell, and stumbled upon the cross of nails.
"These things belonged to the ship and we presented them to Coventry Cathedral when our allotted task was completed."
Gotabhaya Rajapaksa is accused of permitting a private firm to establish a floating armory at a cost to the state of more than $75m (£57m).
Mr Rajapaksa, who denies any wrongdoing, was defense secretary to his brother Mahinda Rajapaksa, who ruled the country until last year.
The special anti-corruption commission filed the charges at a Colombo magistrates court.
The floating armory was found off Sri Lanka's southern coast and another cache of weapons found in the capital shortly after Mr Rajapaksa suffered an electoral defeat.
