Veterinary orthopaedic surgeon Dr Sandra Corr takes Daisy’s muscles and joints through a series of movements, feeling for signs of heat, swelling, crepitus or lameness, which might indicate infection or osteoarthritis.
Daisy, though, is no ordinary sheep. She is one of a flock of 13 clones living on a farm at the University of Nottingham.
And she is also one of four (along with Debbie, Denise and Diane) that were cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly, the first cloned mammal born in 1996.
They are, in sheep terms, Dolly’s twin sisters, writes the project’s leader, Kevin Sinclair, a professor of developmental biology at Nottingham.
Sinclair is the lead author on a paper just published by Nature Communications looking at the health of sheep clones.

“But [they] are also identical to the original sheep from which Dolly was cloned,” he says, “so where there was one Dolly there are now five.” We watched as the sheep were examined to see how sound their limbs are.
In a small pen strewn with straw on the university’s Sutton Bonington Campus, the four siblings were each put through the same tests Daisy endured.

And they seemed remarkably used to them. Seeing a friend poked and prodded in such a way can mean comic horror for some of us, but these remarkable sheep have a certain resigned patience as they are examined. It might be because they are among the most-studied animals in the world.
Advertisement But there’s a lot of research at stake here, and perhaps the whole future of cloning science could depend on results such as these.
The question that has hung over this research since Dolly was created, says Prof Sinclair, is: do these animals age normally and how healthy are they?

The question relates to a specific problem with the cloning process, which is that DNA is removed from a cell – of the animal that is being cloned –smuggled into an egg, and implanted in a female surrogate.
However, the animal cell will have divided many times, and there was a possibility that some “age-memory” would be transmitted into the next generation.
“What this could mean,” Sinclair says, “is that the clone might be older biologically than it is”.
In other words, the clone might be born looking like a lamb and behave like a lamb, but might get diseases of old age sooner. In fact, Dolly died young for a sheep.
She was six-and-a-half years old when she and some of the other sheep in the flock caught a virus that leaves lesions on the lungs.
They were put down. Image DNA structure – a computer illustration (How do you) solve a problem like DNA? Read more
Allan Whittern ran the grocery in Suffolk Parade from 1932, and it was where he died 50 years later, in 1982.
The shop closed in 1991 and his son donated the door to Cheltenham’s Wilson Art Gallery and Museum.
The Cheltenham Trust, which runs the gallery, is hoping to show it in a future exhibition after restoration.
Whittern’s daughter-in-law, Thelma Whittern, said the door was painted with Mr Whittern’s portrait after a representative from Whitbread breweries asked to put an advert on the warehouse door.
“Allan made a joke and said why don’t you paint my portrait, and that’s what happened.” She said she had had many questions since it disappeared.
“It used to be people would go past in semi-darkness of the evening and they would see the portrait and say ‘goodnight Mr Whittern’, they thought he was walking out of the warehouse.
Since it’s been gone, we’ve had so many people asking, ‘where is it? What’s happened to it?
You didn’t destroy it?’” A crowdfunding project has so far raised just over half the £3,000 needed for its restoration.

A further £1,400 has to be found by Friday. Chloe Moorhead at the trust said: “Preserving Cheltenham’s rich and varied heritage is very important to the trust and to the town – this is an amazing opportunity for people to help save a key piece of Cheltenham’s art heritage for the community.”
Titled Beyond Caravaggio, the exhibition features paintings by the Italian and 30 other European contemporaries who were inspired by him.
On loan from National Galleries in London and Dublin, Edinburgh is the last venue to host paintings after the "bad boy" of early 17th century art.
This is the first time paintings by Caravaggio and those who went on to be known as the Caravaggisti have gone on show in Scotland.
Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio died aged 39 in 1610. He had been living as a fugitive from justice after killing a man during a dispute over a game of tennis.
Christopher Baker, interim director of the Scottish National Gallery, told BBC Scotland Caravaggio was a "revolutionary artist".
Bad boy artist He said: "Caravaggio was the archetype bad boy artist, with a troubled life, called up in front of the courts, with a convict for being a murderer.

"But he was also amazingly creative and created some absolutely extraordinary paintings which really affected and moved other artists who came from all over Europe to be around him in Rome and Naples and this show talks about that story."
The exhibition includes a painting from the National Gallery of Ireland called The Taking of Christ (1602).
It is currently on indefinite loan to the gallery from the Dublin Jesuit Community.

It was rediscovered in a house belonging to the Jesuits in Dublin in 1990. Aidan Weston-Lewis, chief curator at the Scottish National Gallery, said it was offered free to the Scottish gallery in 1921 but it was turned down.
He said it was the only painting by Caravaggio ever to be in a private collection in Scotland.
It was bought by William Hamilton Nisbet in Rome in 1802 from the family who had commissioned it from Caravaggio 200 years previously.
It was kept at Biel House in East Lothian for 120 years. Mr Weston-Lewis said: "His descendants left to the Scottish National Gallery a very large collection of paintings.
Some were chosen because there was not enough space. "Sadly, this one slipped through."
The doctors’ union said patients were at risk because GPs were being forced to see up to 60 patients a day and called for more resources to be invested so that GPs could offer 15-minute appointments.
NHS England said it was up to doctors to decide how long each consultation should be and there was no national 10-minute restriction.
But the NHS Choices website tells patients: “GPs spend an average of eight to 10 minutes with each patient.

Make sure you discuss everything you want to.” Earlier this month, the BMA published a discussion paper on “safe working in general practice”, which called for a radical reshaping of the system and said GPs were under “enormous and unsustainable pressure” from their escalating workload and staff shortages.

The paper, intended as a contribution to the debate and a suggested model which can be adapted throughout the UK, said: “Traditional 10-minute appointments are too short for many of our older, multimorbid patients.

Clinics run late, GPs work excessive hours and patient care is potentially compromised.” The Cheshire-based GP Dr Nicola Hulme described NHS England’s suggestion that there were no limits on the length of appointments as “insulting”.
“With demand the way it is, if we didn’t work to 10-minute appointments, we wouldn’t get home: in 12 hours we wouldn’t even be close,” she said.
She said she always ran late in order to deal with her patient’s problems and never began catching up on paperwork until at least 7pm.
Despite starting her day at 7.30am, she said she would rarely get away before 8pm.
“None of us came into medicine to have an easy life, we are all grafters, but the level and intensity and demand isn’t safe,” she said.

Dr Ali Alibhai, who works on the Gray’s Inn Road in central London, said the pressure of chronic disease management for conditions such as diabetes meant that “we cannot safely meet demand” in an eight-minute consultation.
Dr Brian Balmer, of the BMA’s GPs’ committee said many patients had “complex conditions that require more time to treat, not less, particularly as we have an ageing population.

“To keep up with patient demand, GPs are being forced to offer shorter consultation times of less than 10 minutes and an increasingly unsafe number of consultations; we believe should be limited to 25 in one day, as recommended in other EU countries”.
Dr Balmer added: “We need a fresh look at the way that patient care is delivered by their local GP practice.

“Consultation lengths should be increased to 15 minutes. The government must support these changes with the necessary resources as pledged in NHS England’s GP Forward View.” The King’s Fund, a health thinktank, said GPs were under “huge pressure arising from increased workload without a matching growth in funding or workforce”.

Charity says patients are waiting too long for test results Read more NHS England said: “We are pleased the BMA, NHS England and the health department all agree that days of 10-minute GP appointments need to be consigned to the past.

More importantly, it is up to GPs to decide how long each patient consultation should be, according to their needs.” Dr Arvind Madan, the director of primary care for NHS England, said: “GPs are working incredibly hard, seeing more patients than ever before and performing more consultations a year than those seen in A&E.
“We know increasing the number of GPs available and improving other primary care services will help further support patients.
In April, NHS England committed to an extra £2.4bn a year for general practice services by 2020/21, which will improve patient care and access.”
Previously it had taken up to four years for trainee doctors to view real consultations.

New software called GP Live that streams consultations to students has been developed at Aberdeen University in an initiative hoped to attract more of them to the specialty and ease recruitment shortages.
The software, which broadcasts consultations to students minutes after they have occurred, was designed to give students a peek into the "fascinating" world of the GP.

The system allows students to view the consultations via the University's Digitally Enhanced Learning Spaces (DELS) in which interactive methods are used to teach students using 55-inch displays and advanced web conferencing equipment.
It was developed by Dr John McKeown, who is a senior clinical lecturer at the University and also a GP at Cults Medical Group in Aberdeen.

"The attraction for students is that the consultations are as close to live as we can manage with technology, and thus allows immediacy which appeals to our current generation of students, who are au fait with digital interactive learning," he explained.

"The key is making the sessions interesting, so we talk around what the GP is doing in the consultation – why he or she is reacting in that way, taking the consultation in that direction and advising that particular course of action.

"Because it is not one individual doing all the consultations with different patients, we can ‘cherry pick’ and demonstrate good practice as well as talking about what could have been done better, and that helps to highlight specific issues."
He added: "For example, many in society don’t appreciate the problems affecting GPs in less affluent communities, or remote rural situations – so this allows us to inform in an authoritative way."
From a teaching and learning perspective, the system also allows students to work through several consultations one after the other, as a GP would do during a normal morning surgery.
This illustrates the whole spectrum of skills from interpersonal through to diagnostic that are used in a normal working day.
Dr McKeown emphasised that by the time the current cohort of first years are in practice, Scotland will need even more new GPs.
“Americans have elected Mr Trump, now let him get on with it,” Berlusconi said in a comment to an Italian daily.

Like Berlusconi, Trump, a property magnate, was a businessman before entering politics, and although Mr Trump has had legal disputes he has not received the criminal convictions that have darkened Berlusconi’s career as a politician.
The 70-year-old who defeated Hillary Clinton on Tuesday night is the most well-known and flamboyant of US billionaires.
Forbes magazine estimates that in 2016 he had a net worth of $3.7bn (€3.4bn, £2.9bn).
Berlusconi, 10 times the age of the US president elect, has been Italy’s prime minister on four separate occasions.
In 2013 and 2015 he was convicted of criminal offences. Forbes estimates that he and his family have a net worth of $5.9bn.

Asked about points he had in common with Mr Trump, Berlusconi said in an interview with the daily Corriere della Sera that although there were “fundamental similarities”, as he and Trump had both been businessmen before entering politics, his personal “history as an entrepreneur and businessman was completely different to Mr Trump’s, who by the way I have never met”.
Berlusconi did not elaborate further. He may have alluded to their haircuts (both idiosyncratic) or perhaps their reputation as political bad boys.
Italians have rapidly pointed out the similarities between the new occupant of the White House and their former prime minister, initially headlining the hashtag “Trumpusconi”.
In the interview, Berlusconi did not quite welcome Trump’s victory, but explained why Clinton lost the night.

Trump, he said, “was chosen by Americans fed up with the old politics and it showed the error committed by the left (and not only the left) in today’s world – confusing ‘politically correctness’ with the real needs of the people”.

Four days after the constitutional reform referendum in Italy, seen as a vote of confidence in Prime Minister Matteo Renzi and his government, Renzi has pledged to stand down if the vote is lost, a possibility that the latest polls suggest is odds on.

That could enable Italy’s anti-establishment 5Star movement to take over. The movement’s founder, former comedian Beppe Grillo, described the Trump vote as the funeral of the media and elite intellectuals. Europe: could Trump-type revolution be imported?

Further storms had been forecast, prompting organisers to cancel the event. Several performances were called off on Saturday because storms were continuing.
The 92,000 people at the outdoor event were forced to take cover in cars and tents.
Organisers had no choice but to cancel the event after local authorities suspended its licence in the early hours of Sunday morning.
Writing on Facebook (in German), organisers called the decision regrettable but said it was the only responsible action.
The safety of fans was their primary concern, they said. Some comments on Facebook accused the organisers of not pulling the festival earlier.

Fans at Rock am Ring in Mendig Festivalgoers were told to leave the site by noon on Sunday The event is taking place at an airport in the town of Mendig, about 100km (62 miles) west of the city of Frankfurt.
At least eight people suffered serious injuries when lightning struck in the early hours of Saturday.
Widespread storms and heavy rain have hit much of central Europe for days. Eleven people have died in the storms over the past week in Germany.
The Rock am Ring festival is one of the biggest of its kind in Germany. It was also struck by lightning last year, when 33 people were taken to hospital.
Warnings regularly appeared on the festival’s website festival warning fans of heavy rainfall and thunderstorms.
Initially, the organisers of Rock am Ring, which is now in its 31st year, said on Saturday it would continue as planned and finish on Sunday evening.
They included bands such as the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Black Sabbath, Foals, Deftones and We Are Scientists.
Last weekend 35 people were injured when lightning struck their positions inside a football sparse in the south-west of Germany.
Three were left seriously hurt. In a separate incident lightning injured 11 people, most of them children, at a park in Paris during a birthday party on the same day.
UK researchers, writing in the journal Nature, were able to restore partial hearing to gerbils by using human embryonic stem cells to rebuild the nerves which transmit sounds to the brain.
Experts said that, if the technique were shown to work in people, it could greatly improve some people's hearing.

However, it is a big challenge which will not be possible for years. To hear the world around them, people rely on hair cells in the inner ear to turn vibrations into an electrical signal which can be interpreted by the brain.

However, in up to one in 10 people with profound hearing loss the hair cells are fine so the issue lies in the nerves which actually transmit the signal to the brain, a bit like starting a race and then dropping the baton after the opening leg.
The team at the University of Sheffield reasoned that they could 'implant' new nerves to complete the race in these cases. The nerves in question are called spiral ganglion neurons.
Previous studies have shown some restoration of hearing using stem cells, but they had used a different source of cells which would be unsuitable for treating people.
Stem cells hold promise in many different fields of medicine. They can transform into any other type of tissue in the body, from nerve to muscle, to liver, to skin.
On the nerves, there has been a lot of excitement in getting stem cells to reconnect the ear to the brain.
However, this technology will not help the majority of people with hearing loss.
Most cases are caused by damage to the delicate hairs that are used to convert the mechanical vibrations to an electrical signal.
The team has also been able to turn embryonic stem cells into very early versions of these hairs, however, how to get the hair cells inside the inner ear and restore hearing is still a challenge.
They need to face the right direction and be positioned in exactly the right spot.
"It is almost an impossible task," said Prof Dave Moore from the Medical Research Council Institute of Hearing Research.
"It is probably easier to make a whole new ear and put a new one in there." The scientists used stem cells taken from a human embryo.

They can turn into any other type of cell. They were, using a carefully orchestrated mix of chemicals, turned into cells that were very similar to to the spiral ganglion neurons, and they were delicately injected into the inner ears of 18 deaf gerbils.
Within 10 weeks, the gerbils had, on average, a 45% restoration of hearing range.

Dr Marcelo Rivolta, one of the researchers, said: "It would mean going from being so deaf that you wouldn't be able to hear a lorry or truck in the street, to the possibility of being able to hear a conversation.

Greater Manchester Police (GMP) has issued its apology for racial stereotyping after casting a fake terrorist shouting “Allahu Akbar” in a mock terror attack, but the organisers of a public meeting at Longsight Saath Saath are now calling for an inquiry.
GMP has declined to make any further comment about Monday’s training exercise at the Trafford Centre.
The mock suicide bomb blast, allegedly by a Daesh-inspired terror group, although GMP says the event was not in response to a specific terror threat .
The meeting, chaired by Syed Azhar Shah and attended by approximately 30 members, was told GMP’s apology for racial stereotyping was not sufficient.

GMP’s assistant chief constable Garry Shewan was repeatedly thanked for his attendance, clarification and apology but main speaker Syed Azhar Shah added: “It’s not big enough and if you offer us your resignation, the apology will be accepted.” He described the training exercise as “helpful” but “shocking to present Muslims as terrorists and saying only one mindedness people can do it.

“We cannot show children who watch these programmes, showing one group of people are terrorists and one group are Britishers and belonging to this country.” Mr Shah said he planned more public events to “condemn this that it can’t happen again” and demanded “strict action”.

He added that one apology “would not mend so many hurts”. One of those attending the meeting expressed concern that it had taken GMP two days to admit depicting a Muslim as terrorist was “the totally wrong message to send to our communities” and had created a division instead of an engagement between police and GMP.
“We are all Britishers. Islam does not allow any killings of everyone,” he said.

Police and crime commissioner for Greater Manchester Tony Lloyd said it was “frustrating” that the operation “was undermined by the ill-judged… and unacceptable decision” by Greater Manchester Police to include the terrorist shouting “Allahu Akbar” as they set off fake bombs.
Other locations used during the three-day counter-terrorism exercise included Redbank Community Home in Newton-le-Willows.
The 14-year-old walked 129km (80 miles) alone to a camp in Bentiu, in the far north.
He is among the thousands who have freshly escaped the town of Leer in the northern state of Unity that has of late seen some of the bloodiest fighting.
Kai left his parents and siblings behind. The fighting scared him. “At night, the people could come and shoot us and then we could run,” Kai says.
“We used to run to the swamp, and we only kept our heads above water.” He does not know how many days he spent in the swamp.
His family’s cows were taken, his brother, with whom he used to graze them, was killed, and their house burnt down.
He says he feels safe where he is now, but he worries about his family. “I don’t know whether my parents are alive or dead because the fighting is still going on.

Now I am wasting my time either between [going to] school or going back home for my parents.” On Wednesday, Festus Mogae, a former president of Botswana who is the head of a commission monitoring the implementation of a peace deal signed last year, said the ongoing fighting could result in an “uncontrolled escalation of violence”.
“Heavy fighting is reported in the outskirts of Yei in the southeast, Leer in the north and Nasir in the northeast of the country.
Security continues to deteriorate and road transport is most affected,” Mogae said at the release of the commission’s monthly report.
Rising violence and a rapidly deteriorating economy have seen the prices of basic commodities skyrocket, with 700% inflation reported in September.
Aid agencies have resorted almost exclusively to the much more expensive air lifts.
Every day hundreds of tonnes of grain, pulses and vegetable oil are flown in from South Sudan’s capital, Juba, or from the Ethiopian town of Gambella to dropzones near camps on chartered planes.
Even the fuel that runs the vehicles and the generators that power camps is flown in.

Unicef’s chief in South Sudan, Mahimbo Mdoe, says the situation has over-stretched the agency’s resources: more supplies, more staff and more security are needed to meet the burgeoning needs on the ground.
“Malnutrition is manifold in Northern Bahr al-Ghazal [state] … that means three times more supplies for children.
So the situation is very dire,” Mdoe says. Unicef estimates that six million children could be affected.

Mdoe warns that “unless the situation changes we could be going into a situation where it is going to be much worse for the civilian population, particularly for the children and women, but also a much more difficult situation for aid workers”.

In August, in what was seen as a move to address the growing instability, the UN security council established a 4000-strong Regional Protection Force (RPF) to provide security for Juba, the hotspot of deadly violence in the impasse between South Sudan’s President Salva Kiir and his former deputy, Riek Machar.
NHS watchdog Monitor is scrutinising the financial sustainability of Southend University Hospital Foundation Trust "on behalf of patients."
The move follows an increase in an already planned deficit of £7.8m with little sign of how the hole will be plugged.
The trust put down a higher shortfall to fluctuating demand and recruitment of staff.

Hospital chairman Alan Tobias OBE said:"This increased overspend is the result of important investments we have made in services and staff to ensure patients are always well cared for and by increased attendances.
"We welcome this review as it provides an opportunity for us to reassure Monitor, our patients and our stakeholders that our future financial plans are sound and sustainable."
The trust said it was working to cut the deficits and still provide "high quality care for local people" with an ambition to move to a surplus any time in the next three years.

Monitor said the independent investigation will review the hospital trust's finances, the extent to which it has the ability to manage them effectively and identify what it can do to make them more sustainable, for the sake of patients in south Essex.
The inquiry will also look at the arrangements the hospital trust has in place with other local health and care organisations to address its financial issues.

Katherine Cawley, regional director at Monitor said: "People want Southend to deliver quality care now and in years to come, and we are concerned that this could be at risk as a result of the trust's poor financial planning.
"We have started this investigation to gain a better understanding of the trust's financial situation and to find ways for it to improve."

Speaking after signs of congestion on the roads around the former prison site on the opening day, Terence Brannigan, chairman of the Maze/Long Kesh Development Corporation, said the rural roads were "not built for that sort of thing" and gave assurances that his team is working to enhance the infrastructure.
"In 12 months' time it will be different," Mr Brannigan said. "But let's be honest about it; in 12 months' time what we are not going to have is two roads that come into the motorway structure.
"There are a number of things happening at the minute to get two motorway links, one on the east and one on the west.
"We are going through an environmental assessment to get environmental OK, then planning, and then those roads will happen."
The three-day agricultural show made the short move out of the city this year from its long-standing site at the King's Hall.

At 33, Fay is set to win a record 185th cap when Scotland take on Slovenia in their opening Euro 2017 qualifier on Tuesday Advert Scottish Football Jennifer Beattie, Hayley Lauder and Lisa Evans named in Scotland squad for debut Cyprus Cup FRANCESCA FIFEY is still here.
It was 12 months ago, after those games in Holland, that she questioned whether she would be.

The 33-year-old could reach the 200 mark for caps, extending her position as Scotland’s most capped player, when Scotland begin their qualification process for the 2017 European Championships with a game against Slovenia on Tuesday.

Fay has been a lynchpin of the national side since making her debut in 1998 against the Czech Republic and if she contemplated her future after the narrow defeat to the Netherlands, this Slovenia game was pivotal in giving her a definitive answer.

A year ago, as Scotland succumbed over two legs to the Netherlands in a play-off for a place at last summer’s World Cup in Canada, the Celtic goalkeeper was weighing up whether or not she should continue.
Advertisement “I totally considered whether or not to keep going,” said Fay yesterday.
“There were a lot of questions running through my mind and whether I could help the squad for future campaigns.

The ambition for me is without doubt to reach a major championship. I suppose that would be the pinnacle of my career if we were to qualify for Euro 2017.” There has never been a better chance for coach Anna Signeul’s side to do that, with the draw pitting Scotland in a group with Belarus, Macedonia and top seeds Iceland, in a qualification process that splits the groups with two going through from all but one.
With the finals in the Netherlands two years away, there will never be a better chance for Scotland.
“People put that on us that they think we will qualify,” added Fay. “It is pressures that maybe they expect us to get through this group, but we never underestimate any opposition in the group.
We are not a big-headed or cocky enough squad to run away with ourselves and think that we will qualify.
We play in the moment and work hard for every game. There is no arrogance about this squad.

We will be paying every team the utmost respect and if we do that I believe we will do extremely well in this group.” Nova Gorica is the town where the Scots are based but the game itself will be played in Ajdovscina, half an hour away, right on the border of Italy.
“It is a lovely setting,” said Fay of the venue which, in a valley, is surrounded by mountains soaring up on each side.
“The pitch will suit us, hopefully they water it a little bit before the game. It is a fantastic setting to come and kick off the campaign.”
One hundred and eighty-six suspects have been arrested following the closure of a further 24 shops.
The Home Office said it was pleased so many retailers were prevented from making profits from this dangerous trade.
However, the charity DrugWise said the ban had forced trade on to the dark web.
Legal highs became part of the drugs scene around 2008. They include synthetic substances that mimic class A drugs, such as cocaine, cannabis, and ecstasy - with names such as Spice and Black Mamba.
Production, distribution, sale and supply of the drugs became a criminal offence at the end of May under the Psychoactive Substances Act.
The National Police Chiefs Council's Commander Simon Bray said London's Metropolitan Police force have confiscated nearly 14,000 nitrous oxide cannisters since the ban.

He said it was difficult to establish whether there has been a direct effect on drug use, but indicated: "Intuitively I think it must have had an effect," adding that the ban would have discouraged some first-time users.
A lot of people were under the illusion that these substances were legal, and therefore safe.
Online sales surge fears The Angelus Foundation, which campaigns against the dangers of the substances, said it appeared that a number of online sellers had also withdrawn.
The charity's director of communications, Jeremy Sare, told the BBC News website: "I think the ban has made a big difference and we support the legislation.
We had been concerned that there could have been a surge in [internet] demand, and can't figure out why that hasn't happened.
"It appears a lot of traders are no longer trading. It is still quite early days and it may change in 12 months' time, but it appears a lot have stopped trading.
They were acting legally and have now ceased trading because the law has changed." He said users of the substances included homeless people and prisoners.
Greg, who moved from Essex to west Wales, gave his story to BBC Radio 5 live about using a legal high called Holy Smoke.
"I used just a little... and my head began spinning, causing paranoia. I wanted to go home and hide but couldn't walk correctly.

"I honestly thought that I was going to die. It reported as still being pretty accessible, with many people assuming it's still legal," he said. "Alison", who is a former drug-user in recovery, also used legal highs.
MP Brendan O’Hara is hosting a reception to showcase the proposals for turning the former Nato base at Machrihanish into the HQ for UK space tourism.
Machrihanish is vying for the title of spaceport alongside four other sites in Britain, three in Scotland.
The UK government had originally unveiled a plans to have its first spaceport up and running by 2018.
In 2014, it launched a consultation on potential locations and later released a shortlist.
Prestwick in South Ayrshire, Stornoway in the Western Isles and Newquay airport in Cornwall were shortlisted alongside Llanbedr airport in Snowdonia national park.
In May last year, Prestwick was the only Scottish location in the running after the government included spaceport licensing in the Queen's Speech.
However, it killed off the competition by introducing an airport-style licensing system that permits any suitable location that applied to be a spaceport to be considered.
The Department for Transport said that an alternative approach could create an “environment which enables viable business models at a range of airports across the UK”.

This led two Scottish airports that were unsuccessful in the original process – Prestwick and Campbeltown – to invest in work to demonstrate that they are “perfectly suited” to being the first operational spaceport.
At the time ministers said that a future spaceport would have dual use for space travel and tourism, as well as satellite launches.

Spaceport competition: Machrihanish has previously been approved for space flight twice and in 1981 was officially named as a landing location for NASA's Space Shuttle Tom Millar, chairman of DiscoverSpace UK and chair and treasurer of Machrihanish Airbase Community Company, said: “The Scottish government is fully supportive of this bid to host the UK’s first Spaceport at Campbeltown.

The local Machrihanish Airbase Community Company have demonstrated what can be done when a community is fully behind a proposed project.” “The site has a runway in excess of 3,000 metres and ample land to develop the spaceport facilities, plus Argyll and Bute Council are very keen to see such an ambitious project go ahead and planning support is very forthcoming.

“Our site presents a very safe safety case; we are in a sparsely populated area, surrounded by sea and have an unobstructed launch and landing approach for both horizontal and vertical launches directly out into the North Atlantic.

“We would not only facilitate space tourism, through the provision of sub-orbital flights, but can deepen our understanding of space and spaceflight to be at the forefront of what is a developing industry.” SNP MP Brendan O'Hara said: “There is absolutely no doubt in my mind that the economic benefits to Argyll and Bute of a space port being based here would be significant, it’s quite literally a no-brainer and the case I’ll be driving home is that Scotland should take this opportunity to be at the forefront of UK space travel. The sky is not the limit.”

"We would risk too-speedy a descent of the economic aircraft," Mr Haldane, the most dovish member of the interest rate committee, said.

Interest rates have been at 0.5pc since the financial crash in 2009 and the first rise was widely predicted in late 2016, although forecasts have now been pushed back after the Bank's latest inflation report cited deteriorating global growth prospects.
Addressing the TUC on Wednesday, Mr Haldane said it was at least as likely the next rate move would be down, not up.
"UK monetary policy... needs to be both flexible and nimbler still, ready for lift-off as well as touch-down," he said.
Mr Haldane said wages could disappoint and that inflation could come in below the Bank's forecasts made in November which showed inflation running above the 2pc target in two years' time.
Consumer generated CPI inflation is currently 0.1pc. "In my view, the case for raising interest rates is still some way from being made," he said.
"The economic plane is not yet at sufficient altitude to prevent an unexpected air pocket leading to a more prolonged, and costly, descent.
And with inflation at its target horizon no more likely to be above than below 2pc, interest rate lift-off is not only not imminent, it could yet be some way off."
Mr Haldane highlighted house prices as one of the most pressing issues facing the UK economy. "The UK housing market is broken," he told the TUC.
"There is a chronic and deepening imbalance between demand and supply, which is driving up house prices to unprecedented levels."

By the time a baby is born, a mass of critical brain circuits have already been laid down.
These can affect the way a baby experiences the world and be involved in conditions such as autism, scientists believe.
But the details of how the intricate network of brain connections emerges in the womb is not well understood.
Now a team of researchers are attempting to produce a dynamic wiring diagram of brain growth that has never before been obtained.

The scientists, based at Guy’s and St Thomas’ hospital in London, King’s College London, and Imperial College and Oxford University, hope the tracks nerve bundles lay down in the final three months of pregnancy to learn how the process can go wrong and what might be done about it.

“There are far too many children who have developmental problems and disabilities as a result of human brain problems at birth and just before,” said David Edwards, professor of paediatrics and neonatal medicine and director of the Centre for the Developing Brain, who is leading the project.

“It’s terribly important that we do it in the baby before it is born, because it is during that period that the brain is setting itself up to make all the changes that seem to be affected.” The Developing Human Connectome Project will scan more than 1,500 babies to investigate different aspects of their brain development.

The scans will cover babies in the womb, prematurely born babies, and babies born at term to build up a picture of typical brain development and to study what affect if anything that birth problems have.

The results will be made available to the research community. One of the crucial elements in the project is the methods researchers use to image the brain through what is called magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
This can now reveal details of the brain’s wiring as it forms in the womb that were previously beyond reach.
Foetuses are free to move around within their amniotic sacs meaning it is challenging to take useful scans of them.
Scientists at the Centre for the Developing Brain have designed ways to compensate for the foetal movements and build up three dimensional images even as the foetus moves around.
Twelve people were killed during the attack on 19 December, after which Amri was shot dead by police in Milan as he attempted to travel to his native Tunisia.
Prosecutors believe Bilel A., 26, may have helped plan the attack or at least had prior knowledge of it.
He was arrested on Tuesday, but on charges of benefit fraud as there was not enough evidence to charge him in connection with the atrocity.

Frauke Koehler, a spokesperson for federal prosecutors, said Bilel had known Amri since 2015 and that the fellow asylum seeker had met the suspect at a restaurant for “very intense conversations” the night before the attack.
She said the homes of the 26-year-old, who was living in an asylum shelter, had been searched by police and authorities were analysing his communication devices.
He is also said to have used two fake identities between April and November 2015 and to have lived in various German cities.

The federal criminal agency is also seeking a former flatmate of the attacker listed “as a witness on interest.” Two days before the attack, investigative journalist George Manthey said Amri tried to contact this man twice on 19 December, but that it was unclear whether they managed to speak to each other.
German prosecutors said, nine days after the mass murder, that they could confirm “without reasonable doubt’ that Amri was the attacker.
The prosecutors confirmed that the 24-year-old from Tunisia who had used various identities in Germany, was behind the attack.
Forensic evidence at the attack site and in the truck showed only he carried out the attack.

Over the past three weeks, investigators across Europe have been able to piece together more details about what happened on the night of the attack – and how Amri was ultimately able to escape to Italy.

On Wednesday, Italian police confirmed that the gun Amri used to kill his first victim, the Polish driver Lukasz Urban, was the same weapon he used four days later when he shot a police officer in Milan before his own death.
German investigators believe Amri went to a street called Friedrich-Krause-Ufer, where he allegedly shot Mr Urban dead, and then left the scene to visit a mosque.
He later returned to the truck and mounted the attack at Breitscheidplatz in the German capital’s centre, a few miles away.
Hours later, Amri was filmed by security cameras near Zoo station with his index finger as a sign for the German authorities said Amri then fled.
Details are still fuzzy, but it seems Amri made his way to the North Rhine-Westphalia region in western Germany.

From there, his last journey took him through the Netherlands, Belgium, and France and finally to Italy – seemingly undetected, taking advantage of the open Schengen zone borders in most of the European Union.

There are parts of Amri’s story that have yet to go uncover her weed and Swiss police Wednesday announced they had opened a new investigation into the Berlin attack after receiving information from another law enforcement agency.
A 15-year-old travelling alone was removed from a plane after a double-booking mix-up, his mother has said.
EasyJet has apologised to Casper Read, who was flying to visit his grandparents in France, compensated him and is investigating.

The airline has acknowledged there was a duplicate booking. Casper's mother, Stephanie Portal, 45, from Worthing, West Sussex, said her son had been on the plane when another passenger was assigned his seat and he was asked to leave.
"There was an adult person arguing for the seat and Casper was the one made to get off," Ms. Portal said.
"I don't know whether it was just a toss of a coin, or whether they thought Casper will be the easiest one to move, but that isn't right."

'Heated discussion' She said Casper initially took a seat in the cockpit during what he thought would just be a short reshuffling of passengers, but then "the flight attendant effectively marched him off the plane" and took him to the information desk before leaving him.
He then made his way round the airport to easyJet customer service and missed out on seats on three earlier flights before being booked on the last of the day - 10 hours later.
Ms. Portal said she was told by an easyJet manager that the airline overbooks by a maximum of five people, on the basis that some people don't show up.
The last to check-in, rather than the last to buy a ticket, are those at risk of losing their seat.
"There's a fundamental flaw in the whole system. And then what the flight attendants did was particularly idiotic," she said.
"They should not be chucking children off flights and if you are going to kick someone off, that person should be on the very next flight - not hoping to get on during the day.
"And I don't think, if you book and pay for a seat, that you should risk losing it because an airline plays a numbers game, hoping some passengers won't turn up."
'No major drama' Ms. Portal said: "Casper is generally a floaty person, very laid back, and he knows I will always pick up a fight if needs be.

But he felt he was just kicked off and cheated." A spokesman for the airline said: "EasyJet can confirm that Casper Read was booked to travel on flight EZY8313 from London Gatwick to Toulouse on 20 July.
"Unfortunately the flight was overbooked. EasyJet is sorry that Casper was boarded onto the flight and then asked to leave the aircraft.

"We are in touch with Casper's family and the matter is under investigation. "Easyjet takes the safety and welfare of its passengers very seriously and has procedures in place to look after unaccompanied minors, however they were not followed on this occasion."
Ms. Portal said it "begs belief" that the easyJet attendants should have overlooked taking care of Casper as a minor.
"While on easyStreet, you just cannot help feeling someone as a minor is a less risky pair of hands than a disgruntled adult. They just did not apply any common sense."
The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics) said the flow of inquiries from would-be buyers grew at its slowest pace in almost a year in February.
The stronger mortgage deals on offer in recent months have gone some way to satisfy that pent-up demand, Rics said, but added that prices would continue to rise.

Separately, figures from mortgage lenders show the government's latest scheme to help people onto the property ladder, the new phase of Help to Buy in the form of mortgage guarantees, has helped reduce the average deposit from first-time buyers.
According to the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML), the typical deposit put down by first-time buyers in January fell to 18%, from 20% in December.
The number of loans made to first-time buyers and existing homeowners slipped between December and January, as the market showed its usual seasonal pattern.
The number of mortgages made to people moving house in January was 16% lower than in December, though it was up 30% on January 2013, highlighting the rise in sales over the past year.
The apparent slowdown in buyer demand shown in the latest Rics survey could continue, added Simon Rubinsohn, the surveyors' body chief economist.
"February could be a blip but time will tell whether the slower trend continues in the coming months.

"The growth in interest from potential buyers that we have seen for a number of months began to slow in February as the burst of demand created by the untangling of the property chain started to ease back into more natural growth.
"This is in part down to the pent-up demand that built up during the downturn, which is now gradually feeding through."

He said that January's rainfall and flooding may also have put off viewings. But the surveyors group also recorded a lack of new properties coming on to the market, which will probably push prices higher.
The cost of a home in the UK continued to rise in February, but at a slower pace than in previous months.

Mr Rubinsohn said: "The weather and the flooding was undoubtedly a factor for some in deciding to hold off selling their properties, but with house building slowly on the rise we would hope more choice will be on its way."
The weather and the flooding was undoubtedly a factor for some in deciding to hold off selling their properties Simon Rubinsohn, Rics chief economist More: State of the property market .
Chain reaction: Housing supply set to free up . Britain's top Channel ports face housing 'crisis' in 2021 .

Can everyone afford help for first-time buyers? Britain's top Channel ports face housing 'crisis' in 2021 The cost of a home in the UK continued to rise in February, but at a slower pace than in previous months.
A total of 45% more of the chartered surveyors questioned by Rics said prices rose rather than fell in February.
According to the surveyors' group, house prices have increased across the country for 11 consecutive months.
Recent official data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS), published in February, show that the average UK house price has topped £250,000 for the first time.
The ONS says that the cost of a home in the UK increased by 5.5% in the past year. Other surveys show lower average prices.
Nationwide Building Society, one of the largest mortgage lenders in the UK, says the average price of a home in the UK is £177,846.
That said, it also reports that the annual rate of growth in house prices is more than 9%.
The review, which comprised 5,000 studies into golf and wellbeing, found that the physical benefits of playing golf actually increased as the golfer got older.
The review is the first to be published through the Global Golf and Health Project, which is led by the World Golf Foundation.
Going forward, the project will look into further gaps in the golf science knowledge base, such as the effects of the sport on mental health and muscular strengthening.
Executive director of the project Dr Roger Hawkes said there was now an opportunity to put "scientific rigour" behind many of the claims about golf's health benefits.
"We've actually been very much of the opinion that we've underestimated golf's potential to have an impact on health for a few years," he said.

"We've got a preliminary review which tells us what we currently know, and we're going to systematically look at that research and fill in the gaps in knowledge, so hopefully in five years' time we'll have some really good evidence.
"Hopefully we'll turn that knowledge into something robust by fu challenging research and that will be great resource."
Chief medical officer of the European Tour, Dr Andrew Murray has led the first research.
His findings suggested golfers would live longer than non-golfers while they would have, "improved cholesterol levels, body composition, wellness, self-esteem and self-worth."
"Given that the sport can be played by the very young to the very old, this demonstrates that the sport is associated many health benefits for people of all ages," he said.
He said the review suggested playing golf could increase practitioners meeting or exceeding government recommendations regarding moderate or vigorous intensive physical activity.
"Golfers walking 18 holes will walk four to eight miles, typically burning a minimum of 500 calories," the review stated.
"Those playing and using an electric cart will cover four miles and expend a minimum of 500 calories."
Chief executive officer of the World Golf Foundation, Steve Mona, said the Golf and Health Project, "covers every aspect of our sport internationally".

"Nobody can dispute that golf brings people and communities together, it is played by over 50 million people worldwide, it gets people fit and active, and it even inspires our careers and shapes lives," Mona said.

"To have the academic validation of these health benefits through in-depth research and scientific support will provide great researched resources to governments, politicians, professional tours, governing bodies, golf businesses, PGA Professionals and more, for the overall benefit of the sport."
The research was published to align with the Alfred Dunhill Links Championship this week in St Andrews.
If you want to get started with golf, visit our Get Inspired activity guide on the sport.
Katie Milby, 13, of is one of 105 people in the UK who have the degenerative Morquoi A syndrome.
The condition affects mobility, health and stamina. Kyle Pirrie started an online gainsuted duff drug funding for a drug called Vimizim.
While there is no cure for Morquio syndrome, Vimizim can improve dramatically improve the quality of life.
It helps replace an enzyme those with the disease lack allowing children to grow, increases stamina and the ability to walk, and relieves pain.
The manufacturer of Vimizim has sponsored the cost but will stop unless the NHS in England and Scotland agree to pay for it.
Katie, who attends Stranraer Academy says her life would change without the drug.
"I wouldn't be able to move as I would be so sore," she said. "And I think I would have to stop going to school."
That's when her friend started a petition. The campaign has received nearly 2,000 signatures .
"As a friend it made me feel sorry that she might not be allowed the treatment," Kyle said.
"She's has a great outlook on life and is funny and friendly. I wouldn't like to think she would be sore all the time."

Galloway and West Dumfries, Alex Fergusson MSP, has got behind the petition. He said: “While this drug does not come cheaply, Katie herself asked the question in her appeal of ‘how does one put a price on a human life’.
"We are only talking about slightly more than 100 patients in the UK, only five of whom are in Scotland.
Patients who have been treated with Vimizim experience a dramatic reduction in pain and a significant reduction in other symptoms."
Life expectancy without treatment is rarely into a patient’s 30’s, but with Vimizim can be extended hugely.

Katie and her fellow pupils make a hugely important plea and I applaud them for raising this petition to ensure that this treatment should be made available.” The Scottish Medicines Consortium (SMC) is considering the drug, and expects to issue a report early September.
Prison officers are being offered a pay rise and a reduced retirement age by the government.

The deal will be put to members in a ballot. Last month, up to 10,000 prison officers in England and Wales took part in protests against what they described as a “dramatic increase” in violence in prisons, walking out for 24 hours before returning to duty after a high court order demanded that they end the action.
Officers will be able to retire on a pension at the age of 65, three years earlier than the current state pension age.
It will be cost neutral for staff and will be available on a full pension to those 55 or older.
All uniformed staff will be paid a consolidated pay rise of 0.5% to 1% each year over the next three years on top of performance- or progression-related increments.
Uniformed officers will also receive a “recognition and retention” package worth £1,000.

The prisons minister, Sam Gyimah, said the government had reached an agreement with the POA on significant “health and safety reforms and new governor flexibilities so they can best deploy their staff to support offenders in our prisons”.

The POA called last month’s action following unsuccessful talks with the government to resolve the union’s concerns about health and safety. It followed a string of violent incidents at prisons in England.
Jamal Mahmoud, a prisoner at HMP Pentonville in London, was killed in a stabbing in October that left two others injured.
Prisoners caused damage costing almost £1m in a riot at Bedford prison last month.
A few days later at HMP Isle of Wight, a jail officer was slashed in the throat with a razor blade by an inmate.
In response to safety fears, justice secretary Liz Truss has announced £1.3bn will be spent on new prisons in a five-year plan.
It will include employing an extra 2,100 jail staff, testing for drugs when prisoners enter and leave jail and giving governors greater powers to run their prisons.
In response to the new pay offer, she said: “This deal is a good offer which properly recognises the professionalism and hard work of officers up and down the country doing a tough job,” she said.
There will be at least 600 with the ambition to go above 2,000 in a network that aims to beam broadband around the entire globe from space, delivering especially into schools.
The scale of the constellation requires a revolution in satellite production techniques, particularly for Airbus.
Europe’s top space company is used to spending months, and even hundreds of millions building bespoke platforms.

OneWeb is on another level. The order is for high number, low cost - playing quite literally on assembly line principles familiar to automotive and aircraft plants, to turn out three units every shift at less than a million dollars a pop.
At first, Airbus CEO Tom Enders thought the OneWeb pitch was ludicrous. "It's all 'gold-plated' in space; it has to be, there's no compromise - and the most expensive materials, etc, etc.
We’ve had to change that tremendously; step back and get commercial, get cheap, which is imperative for the multinational economics of the OneWeb project," he told BBC News.
Airbus and OneWeb have married the first of three assembly lines in Toulouse, southern France.

The other two will eventually move to an adjacent factory complex in Florida. "The biggest innovation you can see in this factory compared with any other satellite cleanroom, is our trolley robot; that’s what ferries the satellites around work stations," said Airbus Chief Engineer Arnaud de Rosnay.
But it is not just about automation: "It’s a whole ecosystem. From the supply chain to parts, everyone has to learn to do it on another scale."
The first 10 spacecraft off the French line are set to go to orbit in April next year.
Another batch will then follow in November. After that, the launch rate will go ballistic.
To get the OneWeb constellation up and functioning will require the most concentrated rocket campaign in the history of spaceflight.
More than 20 Soyuz vehicles will be tasked with putting clusters of 32-36 spacecraft at 1,200km above the Earth.
By the end of 2020, roughly 300 satellites should be in operation, rising to more than 600 a year later, and 800-plus by mid-decade.

OneWeb and Airbus have competition. Other companies, such as SpaceX, Boeing and ViaSat, not to mention various other entrepreneurs, are asking regulators for approval of their own mega-constellations.

But not everyone is going to find the multi-billion-dollar capital needed to realise their plans in what is an untested marketplace, and Airbus is firmly of the belief that OneWeb has got the inside lane.
Kelly, who was disciplined after arriving late back in England following a trip to Australia, sat out Saturday's defeat by Leigh in the Qualifiers.
Peacock said a decision on his punishment and the stand-off's involvement in Sunday's game with London was "an ongoing process".
Asked whether Kelly would be at the club next season, Peacock told BBC's Super League Show: "It's all on Albert's door. And, at the moment, it's a bit in limbo."
Kelly has been in inspired form since signing for Hull KR at the start of 2015, helping the Robins reach last season's Challenge Cup final.

Victory over Leigh would have taken Rovers up to second in the Qualifiers table, but a 25-18 home defeat instead left them languishing in fourth place as they battle to preserve their Super League status for 2017.
Peacock, the former England captain, said: "It was a really hard call because Albert has done some good things for us this year, and given the importance of the game as well.

"But when you give somebody compassion and time to spend at home and they don't come back at the right time and it affects the preparation for what is potentially the most important game this year, you've got draw a line in the sand somewhere.
"It's disappointing, but I think the reality is that the team and the fans were all let down by Albert.
"He made a decision that his own self was more important than what we were trying to do as a team.
But it's an ongoing process [regarding his future]." Meanwhile, stand-off Maurice Blair will miss the London game after being granted permission to return to Australia for his brother's funeral.
The vote, which is being referred to as a referendum, will happen on Thursday June 23, 2016 Here's Newsround's guide to what's been going on with the UK's relationship with the European Union.

In 2013 UK Prime Minister David Cameron promised that the UK would have a referendum on the European Union, if his Conservative Party won the next General Election. His party did win the election last year, so now the vote is going ahead.
A referendum is when a country goes to vote on a particular question. Everybody who is an adult can have their say, and they are usually asked to vote either "Yes" or "No" to a question.
Whichever side gets the most YES or NO votes wins the referendum. The European Union (EU) is a group of 28 countries whose governments work together.
It was started after World War Two (1945) as many people thought that countries which trade together were less likely to go to war with each other.
Being part of the European Union is a bit like being a member of a club. Each country has to pay to be a member, and in return, its people get certain benefits.

Each country has to promise to obey the club's rules. The countries of the European Union are: Year joined Belgium 1957 France 1957 Netherlands 1957 Germany 1957 Italy 1957 Luxembourg 1957 Denmark 1973 Ireland 1973 UK 1973 Greece 1981 Portugal 1986 Spain 1986 Austria 1995 Finland 1995 Sweden 1995 Hungary 2004 Poland 2004 Czech Republic 2004 Slovak Republic 2004 Slovenia 2004 Estonia 2004 Latvia 2004 Lithuania 2004 Malta 2004 Cyprus 2004 Bulgaria 2007 Romania 2007 Croatia 2013 Members of the EU are all European countries who have come together to make things better, easier and safer for people.
Different member countries look after things like the environment, transport and making sure everyone is treated equally.

Trade means buying and selling things, and one of the EU's goals was to make it easier for member countries to trade with each other, and for people to be able to move easily and cheaply between them.

Being a member of the European Union has an effect on things such as: how many hours people can work how easy it is for people to move between countries what safety and hygiene standards goods must meet and pollution controls how much a country can fish One of the things that the European Union has is its own parliament.
In some respects, it is similar to the Houses of Parliament in London. It has Members who are called Members of the European Parliament, or MEPs for short.
They are elected by the people within each of the countries which belong to the European Union.

There are a number of important jobs that the European Parliament does - one of them is to change, approve or reject laws that affect all women and men living in the countries within the European countries.
Just like any club, the European Parliament has a number of rules for its members.
Over the 40 years the UK has been a member, there has been an ongoing debate over its involvement.
Some people feel the EU protects the UK and helps it be more wealthy and influential other argue it gives away British power to other European authorities.

Media playback is not supported on this device Great City Games: Greg Rutherford wins long jump contest 27 May 2017 Great City Games: Greg Rutherford wins long jump contest Olympic long jump champion Greg Rutherford won with a last-jump leap of 8.18m at the street games in Manchester.
The 30-year-old London 2012 champion held off Uruguay's Emiliano Lasa, who posted a best mark of 7.96m. Holly Bradshaw cleared 4.80m to break the British women's pole vault record.
The meeting opened with a minute's silence following a suicide bombing in the city on Monday that killed 22 and left 116 in hospital.
Competitors and spectators gathered in Manchester's Albert Square as a mark of respect for those killed and injured as people left an Ariana Grande concert at Manchester Arena.
The games were staged after the local authority and city police gave permission for the street meeting to go ahead in the centre of Manchester.
The Great Manchester Run is also scheduled to take place in the city on Sunday.
You can follow live coverage of the 10km road race on BBC One from 12:30 to 14:30 BST.

It was the first major event held in the city since the attack and drew thousands of spectators into a sun-drenched Deansgate and Albert Square, where a vigil was held earlier in the week for the victims.

Greg Rutherford held off the challenge of Emiliano Lasa by leaping 8.08m earlier in the contest Rutherford, also a world and European champion in the long jump, produced the star turn of the evening in the square.
He led with a wind-assisted 8.08m on his third attempt, then jumped two centimetres further with his last effort to clinch victory against Lasa.
"It has been incredible to see everyone turning out and supporting us," said Rutherford, who will defend his world title in London in August.
"It has been a horrible week and I'm delighted to be able to put on a show and make you all smile.
"Manchester is one of my favourite cities - not just because of the football, but because of the way you all support sport, it's incredible."

Media playback is not supported on this device Holly Bradshaw broke her personal best and the British record in the pole vault Bradshaw enjoyed a sensational evening, improving her personal best and extending her own British record in the pole vault.
She cleared 4.50m on her third attempt to see off Britons Rachel Gibbons and Sally Peake, as well as Belgium's Chloe Henry, who all failed to go higher than 4m.
The 25-year-old from Preston went on to clear 4.80m at the first attempt - her previous national best of 4.71m was set in 2012.
"It was a bit stressful to start with," Bradshaw, who finished sixth at London 2012 and fifth in Rio, told BBC Sport.
"But the conditions were perfect, and once I got my poles sorted I was delighted to clear 4.72 and then 4.80. My preparations are going superbly and I am in the best shape I've ever been."

Alexander Wotherspoon, 83, appeared at Paisley Sheriff Court to face a charge of causing death by driving carelessly.
Eilish Herron was just 17 when she was hit by his car at an Asda petrol station in Linwood, near Paisley, in September 2014.

The charge claims he lost control of the car while reversing. Mr Wotherspoon, who walks using a zimmer frame and lives in Houston, Renfrewshire, denied driving into the forecourt and starting the engine and reversing with the open driver's door.

The charge claims that caused him to lose control and drive into the Renault Clio Eilish Herron was filling with petrol, making her fall away from the vehicle, displacing her car and then reversing a second time and running him over, dragging her under the vehicle and inflicting fatal injuries.

Eilish Herron, 17, who died when a car hit her at the filling station The alleged incident took place at the Asda petrol filling station at Phoenix Retail Park of Dunlop Road, Linwood, on September 10, 2014.
Sheriff Susan Sinclair continued the case for a trial to be held in August and continued Mr Wotherspoon's bail.
After her daughter death's Eilish's mum Shanneal, 47, said: "Eilish was a fantastic girl, a typical teenager who loved life and her family and sporting activities.
"She was my friend and we would have a laugh together. Words can't describe what is has been like for the whole family as we are a close unit."

Image caption Public services began running from 06:00 BST when the £570m Chilwell and Clifton extensions program got under way in March 2012 The £570m Chilwell and Clifton tram lines, which had been condemned for causing misery to businesses and commuters, are now open.
Nottingham City Council said the scheme would eventually lead to a major financial boost to the city's economy.
Warnings of "months" of disruption because of the tram's extension were issued in April 2012.
Delays were blamed on moving pipes and cables, while track bed replacement was later carried out.

Chilwell and Clifton tram extension facts Initial budgeted cost £570m 28 extra stations 11 miles (17.5km) of additional track 22 new trams to take entire total to 37 20m passenger capacity ET,Vinci, which is carrying out the day-to-day construction of the tram routes, said earlier this month the problems cost its civil engineering department £165m.
Jane Urquhart, with particular responsibility for NET at Nottingham City Council, said: "It's a really great day.
"They will be running every seven minutes and it will open up access to destinations all over the city.

Image caption There were warnings in April 2012 of "months" of disruption because of the trams "Tram is certainly a really integral part of the city's integrated transport system and it plays a really big role in terms of keeping congestion low and ensuring that the environment in Nottingham is as good as it can be, and in turn that supports our plans to encourage people to live here, and work here and visit the city."
NET and the city council had both been reluctant to give a start date. Final phase testing and commissioning of Line 2 took place in recent weeks.

'Do wonders' Steve Barber, vice president of the Light Rail Transit Association and a former Labour councillor at Broxtowe borough council, said: "We thought we'd never see this day, it's been a bit of a trauma and everyone is relieved that it's now here and open.

Image caption The new lines were originally scheduled to open at the end of 2014 "I think this is the best thing to happen to Beeston since Boots came, I think it will really boost the town and certainly it's been a hard time for local businesses but Beeston is coming back as a thriving town - and it's fantastic for the city."

Clifton butcher Stephen Knight said: "We're open-minded. Obviously trade has been bad for everybody, we've gone down by about a third, but they've employed people in the area which is great and now we want people to come back, but it's a case of getting people to return now with very little parking."
Lisa Withers, who runs a florist shop in Nottingham, said: "I wanted to be here on the first tram with my daughter and husband from Clifton.
A town the size of Clifton needs to be connected to the city. I'm sure the tram will do wonders for Nottingham.
It's regeneration which the city really needs. "I think today is positive for the city and the tram will help Nottingham thrive as a good city for people to live, work or visit."
Jason Alexander , 39, used the credit card to get computers, iPads and mobile phones totalling £90,941.
While living in Griffithstown, Torfaen, Alexander admitted fraud and was jailed for two years in January.
At a hearing before Cardiff Crown Court on Thursday a judge ordered that he hand over the cash to his former employers.
“The evidence suggests you were perpetrating this crime with a benevolent purpose in mind,” said Judge Stephen Hopkins QC.

“You bought items up to the value of £5,000, which you then sold to your employees, sometimes for as little as £180, in the purported interests of helping them buy things they could not otherwise afford.” The court heard Alexander must pay £115,867 within six months or serve another 18 months in prison.
“A lot of innocent people have been very badly affected by what you did,” the judge added.
“The people who purchased items from you feel extremely stupid and are upset by reason of how they came by those items.

There was a considerable impact on morale among your fellow employees. It was a very, very bad breach of trust extended over a number of years.” Cardiff Crown Court heard Alexander used the credit card while working as purchasing manager for car parts manufacturer Northern Automotive Systems in Gilwern, near Abergavenny in Monmouthshire .
He made 287 online transactions with retailers including Amazon, eBay and Argos.
The company’s in-house accountant told the court the monthly credit card bill was usually a few hundred pounds, but rocketed to nearly £10,000 under Alexander.
The court heard he was caught after company managers became suspicious and asked employees whether they had received any offers of cheap electrical items.
Members of staff came forward after being approached with offers of iPads and flat-screen televisions at discounted rates.
Prosecutors said Alexander deleted emails in a bid to cover his tracks. He gave staff bogus invoices, receipts and credit card statements.
The court heard he also used the credit card to buy petrol for his white Land Rover, and for a red Mini and his partner’s Ford Fiesta during his 14 years at the company.
He and his son, Bello Abba Mohammed, are accused of channelling $1.5m (1m) earmarked for the buying of arms for soldiers fighting Islamist Boko Haram militants.
They denied the charges. President Muhammadu Buhari, who took office in May, ordered a probe into military arms procurement.

Mr Dasuki, who co-ordinated the fight against Boko Haram under former President Goodluck Jonathan, denied the charges.

Bello Haliru Mohammed, a former defence minister from 2011 to 2012 and a senior member of the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP), was brought to the High Court in Abuja in a wheelchair and was taken to hospital once the case was adjourned, the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) said.
His son was remanded in prison custody before a bail application will be heard on Thursday.
More than 17,000 people have been killed in Boko Haram's six-year campaign to set up an Islamic state in north-eastern Nigeria.
Troops complained that they were under-equipped even though larges sums of money were being allocated to the military.

They now say they are better equipped, since President Buhari took power - although allies of the former president say this more down to orders placed while Mr Jonathan was in power, says the BBC's editor in Abuja, Bashir Sa'ad Abdullahi.
