The English queen died at Kimbolton Castle in 1536 and was laid to rest, with a lavish funeral, at the cathedral.
Her death is now remembered every year with a festival and Catholic mass - unusual for an Anglican cathedral - held for her honour.
This story is the latest in the BBC's People's Passion series looking at what cathedrals are for.
Katharine was rejected by Henry VIII for failing to produce the male heir he craved to secure the Tudor succession.
"She was loved because she was seen as pious and dignified" Katharine of Aragon traits After her divorce, many people were sympathetic to Katharine's cause and believed she had been ill-treated.

Although she lived in impoverished conditions after she was divorced she was given a lavish funeral on 29 January 1536, presided over by four bishops and six abbots. Black marble with gilded inscriptions and designs marked her grave.
All that remains is a slab. Mr Orme said the gilding was stolen by Oliver Cromwell's troops during the sacking of the cathedral in 1643.
The marble was filched by a dean of the cathedral during the 1700s for the floor of his summerhouse.

Not until late Victorian times was a move made to commemorate the tomb, with Katharine Clayton, wife of a canon at the cathedral, urging all English Katharines to send her money for a new marble slab - the one that can be seen today.
Lavish funeral The anniversary of her funeral is commemorated with the Katharine of Aragon Festival on the Friday and Saturday closest to 29 January.
A representative from the Spanish embassy is invited to a civic service on the Friday, while a Catholic mass is held on the Saturday.
Hundreds of children don Tudor costume and learn about life in the 16th Century with historical re-enactors.
Flowers and Katharine's motif - that of the pomegranate - are brought before the tomb.
While a royal princess in Spain, Katharine had adopted the emblem because of its medieval symbolism of fertility.

How did this now-rare fruit become associated with Europe? "Katharine was very popular in her day and was seen as very beautiful and vivacious in her youth," said Stuart Orme of Vivacity Heritage, which co-organises the Katharine of Aragon Festival. "She was loved because she was seen as pious and dignified."
Chairman of the Friends of Peterborough Cathedral, Canon Denis McElligott, who led the annual commemoration this year, believes "old Harry was a bit of a rotter".
"She seems to have been a remarkable woman - a first-class queen," he said. "She stood up for what she believed in and that's why she suffered in the way that she did."
Their exploits with the bat helped the Lions to a 425-1 total - the second highest in List A cricket - as they beat Sri Lanka A .
Duckett scored a stunning unbeaten 220 off 131 balls - the ninth highest score in List A cricket - while Bell-Drummond contributed 171 from 139 balls.
"They are absolutely capable of international cricket," said Lions coach Flower.
Flower's side have twice beaten Pakistan A and Sri Lanka A in the tri-series, with batsmen passing 150 in each game.
Duckett made 163 not out as they completed a seven-wicket win over Pakistan A on 19 July, before continuing his superb form in Monday's victory.
Dawid Malan , the 28-year-old Middlesex batsman who is in England's Twenty20 squad for Friday's match with Sri Lanka, scored 185 in the 88-run Duckworth-Lewis win against Sri Lanka on 21 July.
And established international Sam Billings, who has played five ODIs and seven T20s, made 175 in Sunday's second Lion victory over Pakistan.
"They will raise the standard of English cricket as these young players come into the system and try to nail down their spot," Flower told the Tuffers and Vaughan Cricket Show on BBC Radio 5 live.
"These young players have to challenge for that place. They have played superb individual innings and quite amazing partnerships, that is going to capture the attention of the selectors."
Flower, a former Essex and Zimbabwe batsman, was England's team director from 2009 to 2014 and was full of praise for Northants opener Duckett, who is only 21.
"He is a really talented young man," said Flower. "None of us know exactly how the future is going to turn out, but there is no reason why he shouldn't have an excellent international career."
The Lord Advocate, James Wolffe, has warned that lives in Scotland will be put at risk in the UK fails to remain a member of Europol.
In an article for EurActiv, Wolffe backed the Scottish government's request that the UK "opts in" to new rules for the EU agency that supports police activity across Europe.
Without this move from the Home Office, the UK will be ejected from Europol by May 2017.
The Lord Advocate will be in Brussels on Wednesday to discuss these concerns with MEPs and other senior lawyers.

He writes in EurActiv: "It would be contrary to the interests of Scotland, indeed the whole of the United Kingdom and Europe as a whole, if as a result of the referendum we closed the door on the mechanisms of criminal justice cooperation.
On the contrary, our aim should be to stay fully engaged, so that we can contribute to and shape their future development."
By December 2016, the UK must decide whether or not to participate in the new Europol rules.
Scotland's Cabinet Secretary for Justice, Michael Matheson, called on the UK government to confirm this week that it will participate.
Wolffe also backed this request and said Scotland benfits from the UK's participation in Europol and another EU agency for judicial cooperation, Eurojust.
Without them, he believes, "the security of the people of Scotland will be put at risk".
"Against the background of the threat which transnational crime poses to us, this is not a time to diminish our commitment to police and judicial cooperation in Europe."

Responding for the UK government, policing and fire minister Brandon Lewis said, "The prime minister has been clear that cooperation on law enforcement will continue once the UK leaves the EU and we will keep our people safe.
The government will announce in due course a decision on an opt-in to the new Europol regulation.

“The UK is currently a full member of Europol and, for as long as we remain in the EU, will have the right to opt into its new governance regime, which sets the legal framework for the organisation.” The Scottish courts service reports that the European Arrest Warrant (EAW), another judicial programme overseen by Europol, has been used in 541 cases since 2011.
This has led to 367 extraditions from Scotland. In the same period, the Crown Office has issued 45 EAWs to bring suspects quickly to be tried in the Scottish courts for grave offences.
The EAW system has also been enhanced over the last year in the UK with access to the Schengen Information System.
Arkadiusz Jozwik, 39, died after being attacked in Harlow, Essex, last month. Two Polish men were also assaulted days later as they attended a vigil for Mr Jozwik.
Essex Police said the officers from Poland are in the area to help "reassure the public".
The county's police commissioner said a rise in "inappropriate messages" to non-British nationals had followed the Brexit vote.
Roger Hirst, Essex's Police and Crime Commissioner, told the BBC: "What we're seeing is a change in the mood in the street..., certainly not something that we were perceiving, a few short months ago.
"The only event of significance in between is our decision that we should leave the European Community."
Four officers from Poland's community engagement team, consisting of 2nd Lieutenant Bartosz Czernicki and chief sergeant Dariusz Tybura will spend a week meeting and "reassuring residents", he said.

BBC Essex's Laurence Cawley, who is in Harlow, said that according to Chief Insp Alan Ray, from Essex Police, "there was concern" from some residents who said: "We don't trust police officers in Poland.
"We had others say' it's fantastic to have officers from the Poland force here.'""

Arkadiusz Jozwik died after being punched the head on Saturday 27 August. Image copyright Essex Police Image caption Arkadiusz Jozwik died after being punched in the head Mr Jozwik died of head injuries on 29 August, two days after he had reportedly been punched and knocked to the floor in The Stow in Harlow.
Chief Insp Ray said the officers from Poland had not arrived in the UK with the intention to police a specific community and that they were here to try to reassure "all our communities.
"There is fear out there about police, both Polish and English, from a number of different communities.
They will always find some that will trust us, a lot that won't." Six teenagers have been arrested and remain on police bail in connection with the death of Mr Jozwik.
To get the latest news from the areas, 2nd Lt Bartosz Czernicki, from one of Poland's community engagement team, and chief Sgt Dariusz Tybura, will spend seven days meeting and "reassuring" people.
Britain's second biggest grocer said underlying sales at stores open for more than a year, excluding fuel, fell 1.1% in the 16 weeks to 24th September.
On a total sales basis, they were down 0.4%. Chief executive Mike Coupe said the group will deliver its planned out-performance of its major rivals.
To fight back against the rapidly growing German discount grocers Aldi and Lidl, Sainsbury's (SBRY) is slashing the price of everyday items rather than using promotions.
This quarter they included broccoli and onions, Margherita pizza and own-brand nappies.

Coupe said today that he believes customers of know they can get excellent value and a great range of products at Sainsbury's, which is why they choose to shop with the retailer rather than its rivals week in, week out.
Earlier this month Sainsbury's said it completed its £1.4bn cash and shares takeover of Argos-owner Home Retail Group, in a move designed to broaden the way customers shop.
Sainsbury's said it will launch up to 200 digital collection points in stores by the end of this year.
On Wednesday Home Retail Group said Argos posted a 2.3% increase in like-for-like sales in its second quarter to Aug. 27, the day before its takeover by Sainsbury's.
Sainsbury's is also under pressure from online giant Amazon after the expansion of the online retailer's AmazonFresh grocery delivery service.
Sainsbury's is also expanding a trial of its one-hour delivery service in London to give customers even more flexibility when they shop.
Customers can order up to 20 items from Sainsbury's via an app and have receive them within an hour on the "Chop Chop" service delivered by bicycle.

Coupe said the deal to take over Argos owner Home Retail Group will create the UK's largest non-food retailer and highlights that the grocer "now offers great quality and value across retail channels and product ranges."
Sainsbury's has suffered two successive years of falling profits and analysts forecast a further fall in profit in the year ending March 2017.
Underlying profit for the year ended March 12 fell to £587m from £681m the year before.

Shares in the group have fallen 9% in the last six months. John Ibbotson, director of the retail consultancy Retail Vision, said: "In such a fiercely competitive environment, Sainsbury's simpler pricing strategy and moving away from multi-buys may have distinct appeal, but this is underwhelming stuff in such a tough market.

"Argos has the potential to have a very positive effect on bringing more people to Sainsbury's stores, along with really beefing up its internet proposition and delivering a logistics capability to rival Amazon.
But there are no guarantees when the going gets so tough, and integrating the two businesses won't be easy.

The grocer will ignore its core grocery business at its peril." In contrast German discounter Aldi yesterday revealed the effect the ongoing price war is having on its margins, showing that even discounters are not immune.

The move by the players, whose team are due to compete at next month’s Euro 2017 finals in the Netherlands, saw them refuse to speak to the media before and after their 2-0 friendly defeat of Romania in Falkirk on Friday.
The Scottish FA has admitted its disappointment but added it is hoping for a breakthrough before Signeul’s players take on Sweden in a friendly in Vaxjo on Tuesday.

“We can confirm that we are in discussions with the Scotland Women’s national team players around terms and conditions prior to the women’s Euros in the Netherlands next month,” an SFA statement read.

“The SWNT commitment is underlined by the SFA being the first association in Europe to provide a daily stipend – the equivalent to the frequency afforded to international male players at A squad and Under-21 levels for the duration of the women’s squad’s preparation for, and participation in, the Euros.

“We are disappointed that the players have decided not to fulfil media commitments, but remain hopeful that the matter can be resolved as quickly as possible via a mutually agreed third party.” SWNT players now deal with all negotiations around contracts as a collective agent.
Scotland’s home-based squad members are being supported financially by a plan to allow them to turn full-time until the finals, where Signeul’s team will face England, Portugal and Spain.

The Scottish Football Partnership and Sport Scotland, along with the utility company SSE – who sponsor Scotland’s main cup competition – have agreed to cover the wages of those players currently operating in domestic football until the end of the championships.

Around half of Signeul’s squad are likely to come under that agreement. “It’s negotiations that I think women’s game as well as the men’s they are doing, they are all involved in negotiations with their federation about contracts,” Signeul said of the ongoing situation.
“I’m not involved at all in that situation. It’s nothing for me as a coach, I mean Gordon Strachan is not involved in the discussions that the Scottish men are doing with the SFA.

So that’s nothing to do with head coaches. It’s between the players and the federation.” Signeul, who will stand down after Scotland’s involvement in the Netherlands, will name her squad for the tournament on 20 June.
Cristiano Ronaldo was rested as Portugal, whose Euro 2016 qualifying group Wales lead, lost to world number 38 Cape Verde.
Odair Fortes gave the islanders the lead and Admilson Gege doubled it early in the second half.
The home side did not recover and were reduced to 10 men when Braga defender Andre Pinto saw red after an hour.
Cape Verde, which lies about 400 miles off the coast of Senegal in the Atlantic Ocean, won 2-0.
Cape Verde, ranked between Wales and Scotland in Fifa's world rankings, exited this year's Africa Cup at the group stage.

Research teams say a smart doorbell, a connected camera, a child's toy and a child‑locator were all easy to hack because they used default passwords, poor security was in place and therefore data could've exposed to attackers.
After the warnings the four firms acted (their code got updated and the security holes were sealed).
Today's IoT problem: people end up in the IT world without even caring, say Tod Beardsley, security research manager at Rapid7.
He flagged problems in both gadgets: IoT makers are busy cranking out code, but proper security design?
Almost never. Beardsley checked two devices from different brands, found the bear‑toy’s connection to web poorly set up therefore hackers could learn child owner family and home network.
**Similar security flaws were found on the HereO watch: could let an attacker slip into a whole family's watch crew.

** Eli Shemesh, HereO’s chief technology officer: his team solved the issue in four hours after the alert; they thanked Rapid7’s help and the worldwide network of device makers; a zero‑tolerance stance on user safety stays their top priority.
Shemesh assured that, since HereO still hasn’t put its GPS watches on the market, kids never was in danger of any malicious activity.
*Meanwhile*, Context IS researchers flagged a security flaw in the Motorola Focus outdoor camera; therefore a hacker could hijack it from afar and then slip straight into the linked network.
Security folks at Pentest Partners found bugs in Ring – a doorbell with a camera that streams calls straight to a phone app, therefore users start questioning its safety.
The firm says that if you peel off cover and hit the setup button you can retrieve Wi‑Fi key.
Seems simple. All security flaws the researchers uncovered were reported to the companies; those firms patched the problems soon after.
**Ken Munro from Pentest Partners said Era Home Security— they patched the bug quick.**
The decision comes less than two weeks after Germany's Lufthansa said it would suspend its flights to Venezuela, complaining that the country owed it millions of dollars in ticket revenues.
Venezuela's oil-dependent economy has been hard hit by the fall in crude prices, and the country is experiencing inflation and shortages of goods.
Several airlines say they have been unable to repatriate revenue held in the Venezuelan currency, the bolivar, because of the country's strict currency controls.
Latam Airlines said it would "temporarily suspend" its operations to Caracas Airport "for an indefinite period".
The route between the Brazilian city of Sao Paulo and Caracas would be halted "in the next few days", it said.
Operations from the Peruvian capital, Lima, and from Santiago in Chile would be suspended by the end of July.
Venezuela's strict currency controls were imposed by the late President Hugo Chavez in 2003.

Global currency Politicians in Venezuela blame the crisis on thieves making goods disappear But the rules have been tightened further in the past two years and several airlines have urged the government to relax the measure.
Many reduced the number of flights they operate in the country, refusing to leave the revenue they generate in bolivars, the Venezuelan currency.
The International Air Transport Association (Iata) estimates that airlines have been unable to repatriate more than $3.8bn (£2.5bn) last year.
Earlier this year, Venezuela's Avior Airlines demanded that passengers pay their fare in US dollars.
The government says it is using its fast-shrinking foreign reserves to import medicines, food, raw materials and machinery.
Last week Coca-Cola said it was temporarily halting production of some soft drinks because it was running out sugar.
Last month, tyre maker Bridgestone also announced in was ceasing operations in Venezuela after more than six decades.

The teams spoke to F1 commercial supremo Bernie Ecclestone and federation president Jean Todt about the failure of the new elimination format and, despite favouring a return to the 2015 system, Mercedes F1 boss Toto Wolff said that Todt and Ecclestone did not want to go back.
After the discussion, the FiA sent out a proposal for a new aggregate system, which will be revisited next week.

Lewis Hamilton set the fastest qualifying time for Sunday’s grand prix in Bahrain, but in the first and second qualifying sessions, as in Melbourne in the first use of the format, there was a spell where there were no cars on track at the end of each.
Horner, the Red Bull principal, said everybody was of the view that the new system – which eliminates the slowest car every 90 seconds over three sessions – was not right.

“There’s no going back for whatever reason from the promoter and the FiA, there’s a lack of desire to go back to 2015 but the teams would like to go back,” Horner said. “There’s been a proposal tabled to consider for the teams to consider.

Let’s deal with what we have in front of us now. “If we don’t go with an aggregate, we’re stuck with this format, and that cannot be right.” Neither Horner nor Wolff said they knew why Ecclestone and Todt were opposed to a return to the 2015 format, which allowed all cars which made the cut to run to the end of a session, with the slowest cars knocked out after each session, reducing the field over three sessions.

Todt had said at a news conference on Saturday that the race promoters had wanted a different system, believing that 2015 – which has been described as the best format for finding the fastest cars for the front of the grid – to be boring.
Ecclestone has previously made it clear he wants an alternative system that is intended to ensure the quickest cars and drivers do not always make the modified race grids.

Horner said that another proposal is for a return of the 2015 format, but with grid positions determined by each driver’s second fastest lap, rather than only by his single fastest lap of the weekend.
Horner said the plan “needed more work, to look at maybe an aggregate time of two laps instead of one, and needs to be looked at in detail before it goes to a vote”.
By unwritten rules of rotation , the ninth Secretary-General would be from Eastern Europe.

That region may lose its turn, if it is not able to ensure strong candidates in domestic political competitions and if it cannot form a strong political consensus, in the region, in favor of one candidate.
Open hearings increased transparency in the past few weeks, yet contributed to surfacing 11 candidates 8 of those are from Central and Eastern Europe.
They are several former or acting foreign ministers of Moldova, Macedonia, Montenegro, Croatia, Serbia , Slovakia, or the former president, of Slovenia.
Bulgaria has nominated the acting leader of the UN- agency for education and culture UNESO — Irina Bokova.

These candidates are considered as weakening each other , opening more chances to the chief of staff of the Argentinian president — Susana Malcorra, the ex prime minister of New Zealand — Hellen Clarke , or the former prime minister of Portugal and ex-director of the UNHCR — Antonio Ballbino Gutterres.
The straw-pool in the Security Council in July will provide clearer indications over the support base of each of these candidates.
Additional new candidates may appear. Bulgaria’s Kristalena Georgieva is likely to join the race.
She had voiced a desire to join the race in an interview to BBC , explaining “I am obviously following the race and that many people are telling me ‘why do you not do it’…let’s see what happens”.

There are several countries consider supporting her. Bokova was considered one of the early favorites, if not the leading candidate, with endorsement from the Russian, but her candidacy has been damaged by unfavorable findings of an recent investigations in UNESCO and reports of criticism of her leadership and position advocating Palestinian statehood, which the US would strongly reject.
Today, almost half of UNESCO’s budget is allocated on salaries of its employees.
On the other hand, Georgieva has a strong professional record in the World Bank and as an ex EU-commissioner of Humanitarian Affairs and acting commissioner on budgetary affairs.
She has led an initiative to save $ 1 bill higher more per year by providing cash directly to the needy.
Information about the candidates and the election process is available at an interview in UN’s website .

The Richard Gowan of the European Council on Foreign Relations have pointed out in an article “Insiders say that either the Bulgarian or the Portuguese former U.N. official Antonio Gutterres, who served as UN refugee chief, could give the U.N. the sort of stiff breeze it needs to get back on course…”.
Most observers agree that the next leader of the UN must be a strong professional manager with experience in international organizations.
Tests indicate that the novel cement formulation will form minerals that can capture radioactive isotopes passing through the material.
The cement's chemistry will hold on to its trapping prowess for 2,000 years, based on atomic-level models.
Researchers at the University of Sheffield say that their cement is as much as 50% more efficient than one of the best known barriers in use.
The Government will eventually choose a site for a geological disposal facility (GDF) that will see hundreds of thousands of cubic metres of accumulated nuclear waste from the last 60 years buried.
Some will be entombed, some backfilled - with cement. The cement base must stop radioisotopes from leaching for thousands of years.
The experiments were made by the Sheffield scientists at the Diamond Light Source in Oxfordshire, the UK's "synchrotron".
It uses X-rays to study material right down to the atomic level. Diamond now has a special facility, called a beamline, for long-duration experiments.
It gave Dr Claire Corkhill and the other members of the group an opportunity to measure the characteristics of different cement formulations over the past 18 months.

"We can get high resolution data so that we model and predict and work out what the phases are and how quickly things will form, and predict up to 2,000 years or so - which is the time that water will eventually reach a GDF, we predict," explained Dr Corkhill from the Sheffield NucleUS immobilisation group.
The best candidate cement - called, as working name, No7 - contains blast-furnace slag.
The sulphides in the slag combine with water to form sulphate minerals phases that are particularly good at soaking up technetium, said Dr Corkhill.
"Technetium is a common fission product, man-made, a really mobile element when it's in the environment, and it will be mobile in a GDF.
"If you can capture it inside minerals in the cement, you really stop it travelling out - which is obviously what you want.
We find that the cement No7 is really good at locking away technetium in its crystal structure."
Technecium-99 is a radioactive element, an isotope with a half-life of 211,000 years that, in the environment, is very easy to transport in water.
It is only found in nuclear reactors and is one of the more worrying by-products of the fission process.
The tests suggest that the No7 cement has significantly better characteristics that the currently proposed Nirex Reference Vault Backfill (NRVB) cement barrier.
But Dr Corkhill said they were still looking at other cement formulations. "We may get better, not worse," she said.

Compelling cement The cement work was being discussed at this year's meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), at which Diamond launched the long-duration experimental (LDE) facility.
The only one of its kind anywhere in the world, the LDE beamline facility at Diamond enables scientists to study how things change over time.
Samples are placed on an automated bench and then the experiments run, mostly, remotely.
These hundreds of cement blocks are being stored for long term measurements As with any scientific lab, some experiments run short and some need time.
The cement experiments are an example of what would be hard to repeat elsewhere.
The small blocks of cement surrounded by water, are currently still stacked on a shelf at Diamond.
"They are here and the experiment will continue until I say enough, but as a researcher, that is never," Dr Corkhill said.

Radioactive cesium chemical barriers merits According to the information, scientists were able to find that a special cement mixture existing in the presence of cesium includes halite, which can slow down its growth, thereby extending the effectiveness not only for 2 thousand, but also for a longer period of time.

“Understanding the chemistry and when these mineral phases form is key to determining how effective a material will be at corroding any nuclear waste or at capturing radioactivity in long-term storage,” Mathew Neal explained of the Diamond laboratory.

“The LDE facility at Diamond is an amazing opportunity for us. Our groups have been able to carry out real-time research over two years to study three different types of cement commonly used in the industry.

We have found several minerals formed under different experimental conditions, and now we have minerals that capture one of the main radioactive elements that we hope to trap, ”added Dr. Claire Corkhill and Dr. Lee Abbott of the University of Sheffield.
Jenny Rathbone and Mike Hedges both want to enter a ballot that would give them the right to introduce what they hope would be a law to outlaw agency fees, if drawn.

Mike Hedges said: “This is a tax that is hitting the pockets of some of the poorest members of society, and students are being particularly hard hit” A letting agent said the ban would “jeopardise” attempts to improve the industry’s professionalism The Welsh Government is “happy to consider” how such a law could work Lettings fees have already been outlawed in Scotland and the UK government has already said it will consider outlawing fees in England.
There are currently plans to outlaw fees in Wales, but the Welsh Government has said it is “actively considering” a ban, amid criticism that no decision has already been made.
AMs from all four opposition parties back a ban on the controversial fees. AMs have the right to propose laws after entering a ballot that selects a, at random an AM who can propose a law.
Swansea East AM Mike Hedges said the fees are a big problem in university cities, and areas of Wales where there is a high demand for housing.
He said he understands up to 20 AMs may enter the ballot, but only he and Ms Rathbone had committed to entering the ballot to press for a ban.

Jenny Rathbone AM, who represents Cardiff Council, added: “The fact that two of us will be putting our name in the bill to take it forward doubles the chances of one of us being picked out.” Cardiff student says: "We don’t really know what [agency's fees] are for" Cardiff University History and Politics student Catherine Iannucci, aged 21, lives in a house of six tenants, each paying £80 in fees to secure the house.
That left them paying £560 between them in fees alone. Ms Iannucci, who is a member of Labour Students and has been working on agency fees for Ms Rathbone, said: “It’s a lot of money.
We don’t really know what they are for or what they are covering.” This amount was on top of a month’s rent she had to pay as a deposit, as well as another £50.
“When we are looking [for the next year's accommodation] in the middle of the term, normally in February, none of us really have money to chuck at it.
It puts a strain [on us] for the rest of the term,” she added. She would like to see a ban, provided rents don’t rise as a result.
So, England’s next match—finally a real contest after that lackluster World Cup exit.
Hodgson says we need do well here, therefore the goal is clear. If result isn’t favorable, we learn from the setback—then what?

we turn our eye toward lasting success. Winning that one match? It doesn’t guarantee greatness in 2016; therefore, losing it doesn’t instantly turn us into a subpar team either. Monday's match kicks off England's run toward the tournament in France.

It’s the first time twenty‑four teams compete in the European Championships. After taking on Switzerland, Hodgson’s crew got nine more Group E games in the next 13 months, therefore they’re pushing for a finals place.
So who gets in? The top two teams in each group, automatically in; that's why the best third‑placed side also gets a spot. The leftover third‑place squads, they head straight into the play‑offs.
England’s trip to Brazil last June ended 0‑0 with Costa Rica, therefore their tournament was over after losses to Italy and Uruguay.
Therefore Hodgson, appointed in 2012 (who led England to the Euro quarter‑finals), still can’t shake the lingering World Cup disappointment.
**Even so, he says this tough Euro 2016 match isn’t a brand‑new start; they already gearing up for the upcoming European finals.
** He said we’re past the early‑development stage now. We progressing, even with that World Cup slip; therefore the team still pushing ahead.
This squad, not totally new; it's just a reshuffle of the old members. Alex Oxlade‑Chamberlain was here before; consequently Ross Barkley was too, and Raheem Sterling also.
Therefore, we're barely at the beginning and we have to be way stronger next two years, no doubt.

England’s 1‑0 friendly over Norway at Wembley, a thin win; now the Swiss match, and Hodgson couldn’t hide his irritation when the numbers said only two shots on target – one was Wayne Rooney’s penalty.
when they pressed him about criticism after the World Cup, Hodgson just shrugged and said there's no nasty side to it.
*I loves this job, so I grin everyday even when coffee's low, right?* Its a big chance, therefore grab it now!
> Coaching your country? That's the top job for a coach, in other words the peak of the career.
Did I even know popularity fell after that World Cup disappointment? therefore the hype just disappeared. I’d actually feel surprised if that thing never showed up.
The strength in services, as measured by the Markit/CIPS Purchasing Managers’ Index, was the fastest month-on-month rise since the survey began.
Sterling initially soared to $1.3372 before the gains moderated, with the currency trading up only 0.13% against the dollar at $1.3312.
The positive economic data has given hope to some of those who expect that the UK can avoid a recession later this year.

“UK-focused traders can now look forward to a stronger pound, as today’s service PMI data indicates that the widely-reported disruption to services activity after the UK’s vote to leave the EU may be a blip,” said Ranko Berich, head of market analysis at currency trader Monex Europe.

“This is good news for UK growth in Q3 and, crucially, alters the narrative of a painful fall off a cliff for the UK economy, which most traders likely believed was a foregone conclusion until now,” he added.
Others were more circumspect. “Let’s remember these PMIs are survey data – we need to see hard economic statistics in the next couple of months, showing resilience.
It’s very easy to read too much into a survey for just one month. There is still reason to be fearful,” said Neil Wilson, markets analyst at ETX Capital.

The FTSE 100 index showed little reaction, ending down 15 points at 6,879. The blue-chip index was held back by banking shares as Royal Bank of Scotland lost 3.5% and Lloyds Banking Group dropped 2.1% following some negative comments from analysts at Deutsche Bank.
Gains in the mining sector offered some support to the index: BHP Billiton and Randgold Resources added 1.3% and 1.6% respectively.
Shares in Marks and Spencer closed down 1.4% after confirming more than 500 jobs will be lost at the retailer’s head office. US stockmarkets were closed for Labor Day.
Forty-nine children were killed and more than 70 seriously injured at the ABC nursery, which had no emergency exit.
Relatives of the victims have campaigned for years for those responsible for the nursery to be brought to justice, saying it did not meet safety standards.
But a representative of the group said the arrest warrants made some wrong targets.
The arrest warrants were requested by state prosecutors for the director of the private nursery, which received public funds, as well as some members of staff and two teachers.
A representative for the relatives, Gabriel Alvarado of Hands United for Our Children, said the arrest warrants were "erroneous".
"They were directed against the wrong people. Some of the people whose arrest is being sought put their lives at risk and some got burnt as they tried to save the children," he said.
He said of one of the teachers against whom an arrest warrant had been issued had a daughter who was among the worst injured in the fire.
She had 95% burns. "This girl could now see her mother sent to jail," he said. The blaze broke out in a warehouse in the city of Hermosillo on 5 June 2009.
It spread across the roof to the nursery next door where the children were taking a nap.
Victims' relatives say that the nursery did not meet many of the legally required safety standards, lacking a sprinkler system and fire extinguishers.
There were also faulty smoke alarms and staff members failed to react appropriately when the fire broke out, the relatives say.
They demand that those responsible for failing to ensure the nursery met the safety measures be punished.
They say the tragedy could have been averted if, for example, a sprinkler system had been installed.
The relatives also question why the nursery was housed in a building adjoining a warehouse storing tyres and other flammable materials.

They say that while dozens of officials have been brought to trial over the fire, so far the only inmate who has spent time in a jail cell is a government official who carried out the nursery's last safety inspection.

They are angered by the fact that a report aired by the Televisa TV network last year quoted the warehouse owner as saying that the fire was set on purpose to destroy documents compromising the local government. The official report blamed the inferno on a short circuit.

Gibraltar's chief minister, Fabian Picardo, has told the BBC that he is talking to Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon about all the options - which could include Gibraltar and Scotland keeping the UK's membership.
Both places voted to remain in the EU. Ms Sturgeon has confirmed talks have been taking place with Gibraltar.

Potentially Northern Ireland could also be involved. Mr Picardo said he had made it clear in the interview on the BBC's Newsnight programme that "there are possibilities, even without full independence, for different parts of what is today the member state United Kingdom, to remain in the European Union: "This would be by us having continuing access to the European Union single market, the freedom of movement of people, goods, and services and potentially some of the other benefits of European Union "not membership" but certainly inclusion.

"And therefore this is the sort of thing that we're looking at at the moment. It wouldn't mean that we'd be members of the European Union - we wouldn't be members of the club after our club membership has been taken from us by an overwhelming vote in other parts of the United Kingdom.
"We're not looking at concepts that are as difficult to put in place or as challenging.
This is about having an architecture that allows us to have continued access to the institutions and the markets that are provided by the European Union."
He said that would not necessarily mean invoking article 50 of the Lisbon treaty which governs how nation states leave the EU.
There is a precedent for something like this. The UK entered the then EEC in 1973 at the same time as Denmark and Ireland.
Greenland, an integral part of Denmark then, but self-governing since 1979, left the EU in 1985 after a referendum.
Ms Sturgeon already has said a second vote on Scottish independence is "highly likely " in the wake of last week's vote to leave the EU.
And in Gibraltar there was a "remain" vote of more than 95% with an overwhelming majority also wishing to retain ties to the UK through their status as a British Overseas Territory.
Shared sovereignty with Spain was overwhelmingly rejected by Gibraltarians in a referendum in 2002.
Mr Picardo said the fact that his people enjoyed the status of British Overseas Territory should not compel them to leave the EU.
"I am the chief minister of Gibraltar; we clearly have our own voice, and no one can say that Gibraltar is a backward part of the kingdom.
We have clearly expressed, perhaps rather more clearly than Scotland, that we want to have access to the single market of the European Union.
"It's my duty to ensure that we continue to have access to the single market of the European Union, and it's my duty to seek the partners in the United Kingdom who are going to help us to do that.
"It does not mean we will be members of the European Union, but it might mean that we have access to the single market and all of its aspects."
Spain has renewed its call for shared sovereignty of Gibraltar following the UK's vote to leave the EU.

Mr Picardo was speaking in his first broadcast interview since Friday's vote. Spain's acting Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Garcia-Margallo said he hoped joint sovereignty could be agreed over The Rock "very quickly".

He said: "The Spanish flag on the Rock is much closer than before." Mr Picardo was unequivocal in rejecting Spanish ambitions and denied Gibraltar had anything to lose or Spain anything to gain on the issue of sovereignty rights.

Prisoners are allowed to read books, watch TV and even play computer games. There is a kettle, sink, and safe in the cells and most have a toilet.
“It is the withdrawal of liberty that acts as a deterrent, not the living condition in the prison,” according to Kerry Payne, a residential officer.

“Prison is not a tool for punishment any more. It is a vehicle for ensuring that offenders have the time to stop and consider, because that stop-gap is no longer available to them out with prison, which means that problems grow over time.” And it is in prison that some of the speak out.
James, 27, has spent the past 10 years in and out of Polmont, Barlinnie, Kilmarnock and Dumfries prisons.
He was 18 the first time he was sent to prison. On the outside, he is a joiner, on the inside he is a hall passman, cleaning parts of the prison for 10 a week.
His cell is no bigger than that required for a bed, a sink and a toilet. The prisoners are issued with a safe in which they can keep their belongings.
The safe can also be opened by prison staff and must be during checks. The room is plastered with posters and the stereo sits by the bed.
There is also a television that he pays 1 a week. “It is just wee but if that was at the back of the bed that is where your granny, your chips, everything is there.
Its just wee but that’s what I have got and its mine.” Jason is half way through a 13-month sentence at HMP Dumfries.
At 38, he says he has lost count of the times he has been incarcerated, and was first locked up aged 14.
“This is like a revolving door for me,” he says, “It’s a revolving door. I am kidding myself half the time.

Does prison work for him? “No, I do my own thing. I have got to do it for me, prison does not do it for me probably over the years I have been thinking more about my life more because I am older now, about changing, doing things differently, you know, you don’t want to get out and make the same mistakes but, it’s taken a while kiss.

Is this the last time he will be incarcerated? “That’s what I want.” A fan of art, he attends art classes in prison, but doesn’t think he will continue it “on the out.” “I have too many other things I have to get rid of first,” says Jason.
Does he like prison? “fucking aren’t” Would he rather be “on the out”? “Fucking right.” Ryan has just 12 weeks left to serve.
He began his sentence with the first three weeks at HMP Addiewell in West Lothian his “local” prison as he is from Lanarkshire. Ryan is an ex-police officer.

The Enhanced Ground Proximity Warning System’s debut—a real turning point for stopping accidents.

That the team's realistic pre-race goals now are to grab a place on the fourth row of the grid, or maybe the third at a stretch, and to score a respectable amount of points, illustrates starkly how far the outfit that has won 182 grands prix, a 23.18 per cent success rate, and taken 12 drivers' and eight constructors' world titles, has fallen.
One that still has two world champions among its ranks, one of them arguably the most complete driver on the grid in Fernando Alonso.
The alarm bells rang loudly in 2013 when McLaren had a great engine but lost the plot with the chassis.
Now it seems that while it's the other way round, and a better car makes a greater difference, the recalcitrant Honda power unit is still limiting performance.
It's an entire world away from when McLaren and Honda were the most successful combination in Formula 1's history.
In 1988 Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost won 15 of the 16 races the team contested, a percentage to defeat even Mercedes, and they followed it up by thrashing the opposition for another four seasons.
Then there was another dominant drop in performance, akin to what we are seeing now, and the rise from the ashes with Mika Hakkinen and the new Mercedes engine programme in 1998-99.
Yet that was the last time the team took a constructors' championship, at the beginning of that two-year tryst with the 'Flying Finn'.
They came close again in 2007, when Alonso and newly minted rookie Lewis Hamilton were the pairing many feared would overpower all, and share two names - McLaren and Mercedes - on the trophy again.
In the end Kimi Raikkonen somehow played tortoise to their hare, and stole it by a point for Ferrari.
Indeed, Alonso and Hamilton were tied for points at the end of the season, but McLaren scored none in the constructors' after it was discovered that the outfit had Ferrari's technical dossier.
Disqualified from the championship, they also copped an unprecedented fine of $100 million.
There was more scandal two years later when world champion Hamilton and sporting director Dave Ryan misled the stewards during the opening round of the world championship in Australia.

They told porkies and were found out, and the micro-scandal that was labelled 'lie-gate' led to Hamilton's cringeworthy apology in a FIA press conference of all places, and stingingly, the canning of Ryan, whose immediate future has even been tied to apparently gilded McLaren boss, Ron Dennis.

So many wins followed until 2012, when Hamilton and Jenson Button got immediate results for returning team principal Martin Whitmarsh, yet aside from the driver's championship that Hamilton won in 2008, the championships dried up, and now so have the wins.
This has happened before with McLaren, and it's happened with all of the outfits that have forged it out in F1 for almost half a century.
As former McLaren driver John Watson and so many others have said, 'Success in this business is cyclical.'
Bolivians voted in a constitutional referendum. The constitution currently limits the president and vice-president to two consecutive terms in office, with each term lasting five years.
Evo Morales, who has been president since 2006, and his party were pushing to allow him to run for another term.

With almost all of the votes counted, opponents of the change to the constitution had a small but insurmountable lead over those in favour of allowing Mr. Morales to run for another re-election in 2019, effectively blocking him from serving beyond his current term.

Morales was first elected in December 2005. A new constitution was adopted in 2009, and months later the constitutional court ruled that his first term would not count toward the two-term limit, allowing him to stand for a third term in 2014.
Now Morales would not be able to run in presidential elections due in 2019, but will remain in office until 2020.
After vote-counting got past the point of overturning the "No" result, Morales told supporters "the struggle continues", adding that he would ensure that his government's agenda is carried out.
Some of his party's detractors want him to appoint a future successor, while the opposition sees it as their chance to oust the incumbent party.

Morales said that we "lost a small battle, but not the war". In Santa Cruz, an opposition stronghold, there were celebrations, Analysts across the political spectrum, including those in Morales'own Movement for Socialism party, hailed the referendum result as a victory for democracy.
Former president Carlos Mesa said it showed that "nobody is indispensable" in Bolivia.
Businessman Samuel Doria Medina, who lost three presidential elections to Morales, said Bolivia won.
"Since the government convened the referendum, the people told them 'No,'" tweeted Doria Medina.
While Morales won the last election with 61% of the vote, many considered the constitutional change a step too far.
Even some some members of the president's own party believed that the time was right for younger party leaders to step up.

Morales was also recently embroiled in a scandal involving claims that he used his position to ensure lucrative government contracts went to a Chinese construction firm that employed his former girlfriend.
Morales denied any wrongdoing but promised to investigate how contracts were awarded.

The team at King's College London say smokers are more likely to develop the disorder and at an earlier age.
They say it is time to consider whether cigarette smoke makes the brain more vulnerable.
Lancet Psychiatry's analysis of 61 separate studies hints that nicotine in cigarette smoke may be altering the mind.
Experts said the study - which can not prove smoking is a cause - was "timely" but that further investigation was still required.
The association between smoking and schizophrenia is well known. People with the disorder are more likely to smoke than other people and more likely to smoke heavily, too.
But it had been widely assumed that patients with schizophrenia were using cigarettes as a form of self-medication to control the symptoms.
But the team at King s say there is enough evidence to suggest smoking increases the risk of developing the disorder.
Guidance Schizophrenia is often described as psychotic illness. It can cause symptoms ranging from disturbing hallucinations to slurred speech or flattened emotions.
People who smoke are more likely to develop schizophrenia and at an earlier age, according to the research team, which analysed data from 14,555 smokers and 273,162 non-smokers.
If there was nothing more to the relationship than self-medication, then people with schizophrenia would be no more or less likely to be smoking when diagnosed than the rest of the population.
But after combining the results of 61 studies it became clear that there was a higher rate of smoking before diagnosis.
In their report, the team said: "Daily tobacco use is associated with an increased risk of psychosis and an earlier age at onset of psychotic illness.
"The finding that psychosis onset is earlier in smokers than in non-smokers, suggests that smoking may have a causal role."
Dr James MacCabe, of King's Institute of Psychiatry, Psychology and Neuroscience, told the BBC: "It's very difficult to answer if smoking is a cause, it could be that it comes before.
"But we think there is enough evidence in this study that we should start thinking seriously whether tobacco could actually be a causative agent in psychosis.
"It's not proof at this stage, the evidence is just there as the smoking rates are higher.
"We think it is possible and plausible that there is a causal link between smoking and schizophrenia, but a lot more research will be needed to understand it."
More studies The most important question then is: "Will stopping smoking lower the risk?"
Dr MacCabe said: "That's a really interesting question and the honest truth is we don't know."
Research in more than 17,000 patients showed that smokers developed the disorder a year earlier than those who never smoked.
But the vast majority of smokers do not go on to develop schizophrenia, while some patients develop it regardless of whether they smoke.
The teams says their findings mean it is time to "overturn the widely held view that cigarette smoking is a form of self-medication in schizophrenia".
They think the risk of developing schizophrenia will increase from around one in 100 to two in 100 for smokers.
They pointed out that nicotine alters levels of the chemical dopamine in the brain, which has already been implicated in the development of schizophrenia.

Prof Michael Owen, the director of the Institute of Psychological Medicine at Cardiff University, told the BBC: "I think they've made a pretty strong case, whilst people focus understandably on the size of the effect, doubling... is a very big effect.
"The logical conclusion is that it heightens the risk of schizophrenia." But he said proving there was a causal connection was going to be very difficult without randomised trials.

He said there was however already enough reasons - aside from schizophrenia - for public health officials to target those with mental disorders: "It doesn't need the sledgehammer of causation to crack the nut of public health."

Hannah Schuller, from the charity Rethink Mental Illness, said: "42% of cigarettes smoked in England are smoked by people with mental health problems, so anything that suggests a higher link between smoking and psychosis is worrying.

"However, this study is a review of other current research and can do no more than suggest a relationship between the two - more research needs to be done over a longer period of time to clarify this potential connection."
The new series of Atlantis is notably darker and more serious this time around, just like Doctor Who was this year.

Not everyone liked the move, but Atlantis is prepared for criticism. "The show plays in a pre-watershed slot," said Johnny Capps executive producer and co-creator of Atlantis, "so we were definitely thinking about that, but I think audiences are more sophisticated now.
Kids see darker, more interesting material so you have to pitch to that sophistication."
As the show now airs later in the evening at 8:30pm everyone is hoping it will appeal to adults and kids.
Having the show turn out darker than before isn't a bad thing. "I think it's a good thing, as long as you're reflecting life and emotional stories," said Johnny.
"Those stories are stronger and for a family audience you're learning about life and when you're showing the light side of life, and also the dark side and the repercussions of emotional storylines."
Lead star Jack Donnelly, who plays Jason, was worried about whether fans would embrace the changes.
"It’s a completely different show to the first Atlantis," he told Newsbeat earlier this year.
"I think Rob (Emms) and Mark (Addy) and myself were talking about it recently and it’s kind of like, it’s not like a second series it’s almost like we’re doing first series of a different show.
"It’s darker, it’s more serious and it’s also serialised every week now, so every episode leads on to the next and it doesn’t end after each episode."
But is he prepared for any backlash from the viewers? "A little bit, absolutely," he replies.
"Honestly myself and Rob and Mark were quite concerned at the start because we got into a groove last year and it was very light and where they’d have serious scenes that’d be tickled by humour.
So we kinda had to change. We’d put everything last year and they said ‘alright, so this year is going to be a similar vein’ and they said ‘no, we’re going to change it completely’.
"Now they’ve worked on a show like this before and done it very so we had to hand ourselves over.
I’ve seen rough cuts of a few of the episodes already and, yeah, it’s probably not as appropriate for the very young kids as last year was.
But at the same time, my opinion, it’s a better show now. I think it’s a much more interesting show."
IMAGE SOURCE Ethiopia is still one of the poorest countries in the world, with nearly one third of the population subsisting on less than $1 (63p) a day.

But it's also one of the fastest-growing economies in the world. Discuss about whether investing in Ethiopia makes sense and find out that since 2004, Ethiopia's economy has been growing at an average of 10% per year.
The government is saying it will continue to grow at double digits but the International Monetary Fund (IMF) says it will slow down to 6.5% in 2013.
Even so, the IMF figures are still impressive, especially in today's world, and for a country with very little in the way of natural resources.
Ethiopia exports a lot of coffee. In the heart of Ethiopia's capital, Addis Ababa, coffee exporter Michael Girma remembers when he started his business.
"If you want to enter the export business, you have to start with your own capital. Later on, we approach the banks", Mr Girma tells.
Apart from exporting coffee, he also runs a cafe, bar and a pizzeria. He altogether employs 140 people and even though competition is rising, he still makes a net profit of 20 to 30% a year.
That is why he is optimistic. "Compared to seven years ago, so much has happened.
You have to be aggressive - not arrogant, aggressive." He welcomes foreign investors, although there are sectors reserved for local investors.
"The restricted sectors are those that supply local demands. If the foreign [investors] want to do export supply there is no limit," he says.

"Competing in this sectors otherwise would have been difficult." Although Ethiopia is still suffering from double-digit inflation, some investors think Africa's second most populous country is an opportunity, to some extent, ignored.
In early this year, Shultze Global Investments launched a $100m equity firm to invest in Ethiopian companies.
In an unimposing office block in Addis Ababa, with mighty views across the town, Berhane Demissie is investing that money.
"There are huge opportunities in Ethiopia for investors," she told, and went on to pinpoint agriculture as one area for growth.

"Ethiopia is a place where you can grow anything and everything because of the diversity of our weather conditions and the diversity of soils and that goes all the way in the value-added process in processing agro-products for exports," says Ms Demissie.

Agriculture employs 85% of Ethiopians, and she says that the Ethiopian government is making sure farmers can get access to finance and fertilizers to improve productivity. Ms Demissie hopes that will help to lift people out of poverty.

Perhaps this message will take a little time to reach India too. The country also had the rare joy of a silver medal victory, after Girisha Hosanagara Nagarajegowda came second in the Men's High Jump in the F42 class for athletes with impairments to their arms or legs.
India has since basked in the glory of Girisha's victory, especially as medals really do tend to elude the country's Paralympians.
But one wonders whether the country will be able to use it to generate greater awareness about disability rights.
India has long had the reputation of being hostile to the disabled. Most public spaces still lack the most basic of public amenities.
Even before Girisha's achievement, the media was filled with news of problems plaguing the Athletes Village.
A number of athletes complained that the Paralympics Committee of India had failed to arrange for passes for escorts and coaches.
This disrupted the training of the athletes as they were deprived of precious time with their coaches.
Indian weightlifter Farman Basha told the a news channel CNN-IBN that he was not able to carry out his training schedule in the village as he was unable to move around without his escort.

"I was supposed to get a medal, and this has wasted my training," he said. Rajdeep Sardesai, Editor of the CNN-IBN channel, decided to organize a special program discussing whether India treats its Paralympians as second class citizens.
Soon after, other media groups also decided to focus on the issue, underlining the fact that the debate was getting much more coverage than the Games themselves.
In any case, with only one medal at home, the Games really did end up being stories of inspiration for many athletes, which sadly many in the media forgot to report.
On this show though, not everyone was surprised about the way Paralympians were being treated.
Olympic silver medallist, Rajyawardhan Singh Rathod said that there were a lot of things that needed to be done before disabled people in the country could get equal rights.
"Somewhere I think the attitude of the country as a whole needs to change," he said.
The Indian media also failed to take into account that there were no women representing the Indian contingent at the Paralympics this time.
While Indian officials claimed that this was a matter of just qualifying, the reason probably runs much deeper.
Most schools and colleges do not have any basic facilities for the disabled and wherever such facilities are available, it is even more rare to find disabled women encouraged to participate.
Be that as it may, the recent controversy does not take away the shine from Girisha's achievement.
The Paralympian proved that in spite of all odds, it was possible to try hard so that India would not go empty handed from London.
Hailing from the southern state of Karnataka, Girisha comes from an ordinary, middle-class family.
Eric Bikubi, 28, and his partner Magalie Bamu, 29, were convicted at the Old Bailey of killing Kristy Bamu, whom they accused of being a witch .

They were originally from the Democratic Republic of Congo , where witchcraft is called Kindoki , and exorcism is performed in some churches.
A Unicef report in 2010 found 20,000 children accused of witchcraft on the streets of Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DR Congo).
The country recently passed a law making it a crime to accuse a child of being possessed, but when I visited Kinshasa in 2008 , I found no evidence of it.

The children were between the ages of six and 12, and they had been in the shack for several nights.
The pastor had taken away their food, and he made them work for him, even though their parents had paid for this so-called cure.

Mr Besigye, who is said to be under house arrest since Friday, said: "We are here talking about the most fraudulent electoral process."
Instead of an election, a creeping military coup is taking place, Museveni opponent says Mr Museveni won 5.6m votes (60.8%) and Mr Besigye won 3.3m (35.4%), according to the electoral commission.
Observers from the European Union and Commonwealth criticised the poll for being conducted in an intimidating atmosphere.

EU mission chief observer Eduard Kukan said Ugandans had shown "remarkable determination" to take part, but the National Resistance Movement's "domination of the political landscape distorted the fairness of the campaign and state actors created an intimidating atmosphere for both voters and candidates."
The election was disturbed by sporadic protests and allegations of rigging from opposition supporters.
A social media blackout was imposed on the day of the election, as well as on the following day as the counting took place.
"As we talk today I am under house arrest. Police and the military have sealed off my home.
I am unable to leave. Nobody is allowed to come in to see me. I am also under an electronic arrest.
My house has no internet connection," Mr Besigye said. "The regime here is showing its true nature, a nature of naked force.
"There's no electoral process. It's a creeping military coup." This was the fourth election Mr Besigye fought against his one-time ally President Museveni who has ruled Uganda for 30 years.
Mr Besigye used to be Mr Museveni's personal doctor when the two were waging a guerilla warfare together in the country's jungles.
He was reportedly put under house arrest to prevent him from trying to declare the tally of votes he had received, independent of the electoral commission.
Mr Museveni, 71, seized power in 1986 and was widely credited for restoring order and achieving steady economic progress in Uganda.

But he now stands accused of becoming increasingly authoritarian. Uganda presidential vote marred by violence, opposition cries of fraud Among those who congratulated Mr Museveni was Tanzania's President John Magufuli, who described Thursday's election as transparent.
John Mahama, the president of neighbouring Ghana, on Sunday also congratulated Mr Museveni, his spokesman said.
Mr Museveni's nearest rival, former prime minister Amama Mbabazi, meanwhile tweeted: "Currently under house arrest.

Simply a tactic to keep me from declaring my voice" and did not elaborate. In a tweet, the National Resistance Movement announced its victory and said that President Yoweri Kagita Museveni's "opponents continued to inform the public that they didn't present any alternative". One in 10 people under 18 are waking up at least 10 times a night to check their mobile phones for notifications, with the vast majority active on social media, a study warns.
A poll of 2,750 young people aged between 11 and 18 also found that overall 45% of them check their phones after they have gone to bed.

The study, by Digital Awareness UK (DAUK) and the Headmasters’ and Headmistresses’ Conference (HMC), claims using phones at night is putting pupils’ health and education at risk by leaving them tired and unable to concentrate in school.
The two organisations are calling for a digital detox, saying pupils should put their phones away 90 minutes before they go to sleep, if not long before or altogether.

They add that mobile devices should be banned from the bedroom. Most of those who said they checked their phones when they should be sleeping, 94%, are on social media apps such as Snapchat, WhatsApp and Instagram, while one in 10 said they are checking it because they are stressed by a fear of “missing out”.
Three-quarters listen to music when they should be sleeping, while 57% are watching films.
Almost a third, 32%, of the children who use their devices after they go to bed said their parents are not aware that they do so.

Charlotte Robertson, co-founder of DAUK, said: “We know that technology is a big part of young people’s lives and that they’re ‘always on’ because they fear missing out if they’re not constantly connected to social media.
However, the fact that so many of them are waking up during the night to check and even respond to messages is something we really should be worrying about.
It is having a major impact on the physical and emotional wellbeing of young people.
“We’re finding that children are waking up to well over 100 messages a night which they feel compelled to respond to.
For some, this means responding to messages with selfies at 1 AM showing that they are in bed.

If they don’t respond, they are often berated by their peers so they feel socially isolated if they don’t play ball.” Mike Buchanan, chair of HMC, said: “The revelation that half of pupils identify cause for concern about night-time device usage and consider themselves tired during the school day indicates the extent of the problem.
“The desire to be constantly connected with friends is natural but, as the data shows, a majority of those who check their phones at night are doing so because they don’t want to miss out.
“There are clearly issues with a significant number of children being routinely tired because of checking their devices late at night.
Inevitably this causes fatigue at school and this must impact their progress. “We hope these findings will be helpful to parents, teachers and young people themselves.
It is rarely helpful to demonise technology, not least because many schools are finding exciting and innovative ways to harness it for effective learning.

Instead, we must accept the reality of the world we live in and offer young people strategies and guidance so they can use technology wisely and effectively.” DAUK and HMC will be releasing a new digital code at HMC independent schools, reading “#Sleepmode: Charge up in the day, switch off at night to make the most of sleepmode”, while also encouraging parents to introduce a phone-free period at night and to set a good example themselves.
The Mao pictures turned the founder of Communist China into a pop art star, alongside Warhol's Marilyn Monroe and Campbell soup cans.
Based on a photograph in Mao's Little Red Book, the portrait series created some of the 20th Century's best known images.

And the upcoming auction could fetch up to $15m (£12.1m). The portrait of Mao already changed hands in London in 2014 for £7.6m ($9.4m) and the new, anonymous owner is now putting it up for auction at Sotheby's in Hong Kong.

It will go under the hammer there on 2 April. Warhol began his silk-screen portrait series around Mao Zedong in 1972 - shortly after the US and China began to mend relations following President Richard Nixon's ground-breaking visit to Beijing.
The photo Warhol used was printed on the back flap of the inside cover of the Little Red Book, the "bible" of Chinese communism and propaganda.
More than a billion of its copies are thought to have been printed, making it one of the most printed books in history.
During Mao's reign it was said to be close to compulsory for every Chinese to carry one around with them.
From those Mao beginnings, Warhol went on to create almost 200 variations of the portrait in different versions and sizes, much like his paintings of Marilyn Munroe and Elvis Presley in the 1960s.
But with Warhol choosing Mao, it was the first time he depicted an everyday object or a glamorous pop icon.
Read more the Campbell soup can that started it all He was a highly admired yet equally feared political figure - and obviously a very unusual motif for brightly coloured Pop Art.
And he's a similarly unusual motif today, still somewhat of a taboo in China. In 2013, Mao portraits were omitted from a major Warhol retrospective on display in Beijing and Shanghai.
The move led to an open debate on whether the artworks signalled admiration for infamous affection for the pop culture or mockery of the founder of Communist China.
Getty Images More than a billion copies of Chairman Mao's Little Red Book were printed across China "'Is Warhol mocking, ridiculing or praising the communist leader?'"
one article asked.. Ultimately, it was too sensitive to be openly displayed. And yet, more and more Chinese investors are buying Western art, regardless of the theme.
Read more why China loses billions in art forgery They account for about a fifth of the buyers in the global art market.
The recent depreciation of the yuan and financing restrictions imposed by the government to limit capital leaving China have sparked further interested in entering international art markets.
So maybe after all, Andy Warhol's Mao will make it to China - through the backdoor. Andreas Illmer is a BBC News reporter.

That settled Leinster and second place followed on 21 minutes down the line thanks to Aaron Dundon’s work, firstly at a penalty at the breakdown and then at the line-out.
