It was a similar situation that led to another successful kick from Weir six minutes before the break, McCarthy penalised this time at a maul.

Leinster had a big chance to include the gap again but a third penalty attempt of the contest from McFadden drifted wide after Pat MacArthur saw yellow for a dangerous tackle that left Dundon forcing off.
On the resumption Leinster made the extra man count, scrum-half McGrath putting Garry Ringrose flying down the wing.
The move continued with Rhys Ruddock finishing and McGrath diving over, McFadden converting to leave it at 13-13.

That deadlock though lasted just six minutes as the Scots pressed again with a couple of pacy phases and after Cian Healy was used as a speed bump Naiyaravoro’s powerful run had the Warriors back ahead.

Again Leinster answered back as a penalty try had them in front, replacement Isaac Boss finding some space and as Isa Nacewa hacked the ball forward Naiyaravoro was adjudged to have deliberately knocked the ball over.

After consulting the TMO the big winger hit the sin bin for this second deliberate knock on and a third conversion of the night from McFadden moved Leinster from 25-17 behind to a 27-25 lead on the scoreboard.
That was extended when McFadden slotted another penalty for Leinster. Leinster: Isa Nacewa (capt.
), Garry Ringrose, Ben Te’o, Noel Reid, Fergus McFadden, Johnny Sexton, Luke McGrath, Jack McGrath, Aaron Dundon, Mike Ross, Ross Molony, Mike McCarthy, Rhys Ruddock, Sean O’Brien, Jordi Murphy.
Replacements: James Tracy, Cian Healy, Martin Moore, Hayden Triggs, Josh van der Flier, Isaac Boss, Ian Madigan, Dave Kearney.

Glasgow Warriors: Sean Lamont, Taqele Naiyaravoro, Richie Vernon, Peter Horne, Lee Jones, Duncan Weir, Henry Pyrgos, Gordon Reid, Pat MacArthur, Zander Fagerson, Leone Nakarawa, Jonny Gray, Rob Harley, Ryan Wilson, Josh Strauss (capt.).
Replacements: James Malcolm, Alex Allan, Djustice Sears-Duru, Tim Swinson, Simone Favaro, Grayson Hart, Fraser Lyle, Glenn Bryce. Referee: Nigel Owens (WRU).
Boro were the busiest Premier League club in July, adding eight summer signings.
"We're not in a hurry. We have a squad, we have the base and to keep going," Karanka told BBC Tees.
"The better players we have, the better because we're going to stay in the Premier League."
Play-off final losers in 2015, Boro drew with Brighton on the final day of last season to win automatic promotion to end a seven-year spell outside the top flight.
The Teessiders went through pre-season without defeat, but the opener in the 3-1 win against Aston Villa on Saturday, highlighted Karanka's concern about defensive frailties.
"To do that, we need more players, especially central defenders. That is the position we need to improve.
I do not want to give all the responsibility to Dael Fry," the 42-year-old added.
"He is really good and has a really bright future, I learn every day from him but he has to keep learning step by step.
To do that, we must bring in more players." In looking to add to the defensive reinforcements, Karanka said that any new arrivals need to fit in as soon as possible.

"The main thing for me is they settle into the team," he added. "We are mixing players who two-and-a-half years ago were going down, staying in the Championship, with players two or one years ago were in the Champions League.
"But the main thing is the team's spirit is the same." Middlesbrough open their Premier League account at the Riverside on Saturday, 13 August, against Stoke City.
Hamilton called it '"too extreme" and the "worst-looking" modification in the history of F1.
Henry, the son of John Surtees, was killed in a Formula Two race in 2009 after his helmet was hit by a bouncing tire.
"I know the sacrifice of losing Henry, which undoubtedly could have been avoided by a system such as this," said John Surtees.
Ferrari driver Sebastian Vettel has said the device can look as "hideous as it will" if it saves lives and the German reckons Henry Surtees "would still be around if we [had] this sort of system".
John Surtees, who raced to the 1964 drivers' title with Ferrari, said: "I think, quite frankly, Lewis could think a little about the 'halo' and being a world champion and that responsibility.
Things change and sometimes they change in such a way that perhaps you have no choice.
The body is forced in many ways to bring in rules and regulations because of the trend and the direction they are going.
Henry was hit by a wheel with a weight of 28kg – so to have had a 'halo' could have altered things."
McLaren's Fernando Alonso, meanwhile, sees the 'halo' device as a "needed" measure.

"It's the future of F1 because we can't afford any serious injury or fatal accident like we had in the last couple of years," the double world champion said, referring to Jules Bianchi and Justin Wilson.

"I know the 'halo' looked a little bit strange, aesthetically, so maybe a canopy or something will come next, soon — but hopefully for next year we will have that." Read more about the 'halo' device here.
A second sponsor of swimmer Ryan Lochte has severed ties with the Olympian after the incident in which he falsely claimed to have been threatened at gunpoint in Rio.
Skin care company Syneron-Candela, which signed a deal with Lochte earlier this year, released a statement on Monday condemning his behaviour.
Meanwhile, Japanese bedding company Airweave said it would cut its own ties to the 12-time Olympic medalist.

US sponsors have paid millions to Lochte over the course of his career. He has repeatedly denied lying to Brazilian police about the incident, which occurred on a night out during the Rio Olympics with other members of Team USA.
Speedo USA, which provided Lochte with his biggest sponsorship, was the first brand to withdraw its support on Monday.

“We cannot condone behavior that is counter to the values this brand has long stood for,” Speedo USA wrote in a statement, adding that it would donate a $50,000 portion of Lochte’s fee to Save The Children for the benefit of the charity’s work in Brazil.
Lochte, 32, said he respected Speedo’s decision. “I was immature and I made a mistake,” Lochte said on the US talkshow Good Morning America, scheduled to air on Tuesday morning.
He added: “That’s why I’m taking full responsibility for it, because I over-exaggerated that story.
And if I had never done that, we wouldn’t be in this mess. Those guys would never be in Rio, or were in Rio.

None of this would have happened, and it was my immature behavior.” Lochte lost a second endorsement deal when Ralph Lauren, which had a short-term agreement for the Rio Olympics, confirmed it would not be renewing its contract with the US swimmer.
Ralph Lauren has deleted Lochte’s images from its website, and stressed it has a continuing relationship with the US Olympic and Paralympic teams.

Another of Lochte’s sponsors, Airweave, which also has ongoing deals with the US and Japanese Olympic teams, also dropped the swimmer, saying: “We were deeply saddened by the situation and do not condone behavior that is inconsistent with the values Airweave espouses.” The cosmetic and skin care company Syneron-Candela said: “We hold our employees to high standards, and we expect the same of our business partners.” It was not immediately clear what the value of Lochte’s deals with Syneron, Airweave or Ralph Lauren were.
Speedo had sponsored Lochte for nearly a decade. Lochte’s most recent contract with Speedo expires at the end of this year, having been worth a reported annual $50,000.
Lochte won a gold medal at the Rio games, although he failed to come close to his five-medal haul at the London Olympics in 2012.
At the time, Forbes magazine estimated that he had pulled in at least $2m in endorsement revenue.
The magazine estimated before the Rio Olympics that Lochte’s contracts would be worth between $1m and $2m in 2016.
The incident in question started on the evening of 13 August, when Lochte and three other US swimmers returned to the Olympic Village after a night out.
At a gas station on the route home, the group found that the bathroom door was locked and urinated outside.
Lochte later told television reporters that robbed at gunpoint by men who identified themselves as police.

But Brazilian authorities later charged Lochte with falsely reporting a crime after watching CCTV footage and taking a series of statements, and discovered that it was Lochte and the other swimmers who caused damages.
Lochte later backtracked and said he had exaggerated the story while he was intoxicated.

While Lochte disputed some of the details, he apologized to the Brazilian people and claimed the gas station staffers had “pointed [a] gun in my direction and demanded money to let me leave the gas station” after damage was caused to the station.

Lochte has drawn heavy condemnation in the US for his actions, with some observers branding him a “Ugly American” and the New York Post splashing the ripped image of Lochte with the headline “LIAR, LIAR, SPEEDO ON FIRE”.
Lochte told GMA that he was sorry that his immature, intoxicated behaviour had overshadowed the Olympics.
“I made a mistake, and I definitely learned from this,” Lochte said. “They put on one of the greatest Olympic Games in history, and my immature, intoxicated behavior tarnished that a little.

And I don’t want that, and I’m going to do anything possible to make sure that they get the recognition that they deserve.” Lochte said he was “still the same person” and took full responsibility for his actions.

“Time away from swimming is going to be good for me,” Lochte said. “I need to make sure the home life is perfect so that way I come back and have a clear head.” Lochte has so far failed to respond to a summons to appear before the Brazilian authorities.
The Associated Press contributed to this report. This article was updated on 23 August to reflect the departure of sponsor Japanese mattress company Airweave.

Researchers at Glasgow University who compared Glaswegians' recorded speech from the early days of sound recording technology to now say they detected a raft of common British accent changes, such as replacing "f" instead of "th" when saying "think" and the dropping of the letter "l" in words, such as "people" ('peopo').
However, the team said they also found that the Scottish accent had experienced uniquely Scottish changes and would continue to stand out strongly from other British accents.
The project was led by Professor Jane Stuart-Smith, director of the university's phonetics laboratory, and funded by the UK’s Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC).
The study Sounds of the City ran for three years. "We were quite surprised by what we found," Stuart-Smith said.

“Whilst it is generally thought that traditional dialects across the UK are becoming eroded — with some even facing extinction — we've found that Scots accents, far from dying out here in Glasgow, are actually growing stronger.

"Although the sounds that we use generally change over time, what we wouldn't necessarily have expected is that, in contrast to the findings for dialects in England, Scottish accents are not becoming more like anglicised accents, nor are they dying out, instead, they are very much alive and well, and are even growing stronger."
As part of their study the Glasgow team created a digitised banks of recorded speech sounds.
According to the team, their results show that the distinctive Scots accent underwent two different kinds of changes.

The first were accent changes which have been found all over the UK, such as "f" for "th" and "l" in words like "people" ("peepo"), partly influenced by dialect contact and popular television soap operas set in London.
However, the project also identified a second set of more subtle changes which had been unfolding uniquely in Scotland, such changes involving vowel sounds of particular words (e.g.
"boat, goat, coat") and specific stop sounds in other words (e.g. "pin, top, cat").

While the team predicted these specific sounds would either remain the same, or be changing in the same way as Anglo-English accents, the evidence showed that they were evolving on their own, here in Scotland and regardless of Anglo-English changes and had been doing so for the past 100 years and more.
The Glasgow team was able to suggest the catalyst for some changes was around the time of the Great War.
The study was centred on six audio recordings in the British Library's collection made in 1916 of Scottish soldiers held in German prisoner of war camps.
The recordings show that Scottish accents were already changing a century ago, and perhaps longer, the team said.
The project’s research and findings will be used to help students and other researchers via a website.
The researchers from Cambridge University Press are examining media coverage of the Brazil World Cup and assigning “confidence levels” to England, rated out of 100.

The levels vary according to adjectives used to describe the team. After the 2-2 draw against Ecuador on 4 June, the confidence level was 38, and then 40 after a goalless draw two days later against Honduras. But a day later the rating was up to 77.
As England prepare for their big match in Manaus, the Cambridge Confidence Index gives them a rating of 70.
The researchers, using millions of words, are drawing on a broad spectrum of media including traditional national favourites such as the BBC, as well as social media from around the world.
“This breadth of coverage means we can provide exclusive insight into the mood of the country and how England’s preparations are being received,” said Dr Claire Dembry of Cambridge University Press.

“The nation seems very confident as we approach the Italy match, even after failing to kick off our World Cup campaign in style against Ecuador or Honduras.” Cambridge University Press Words like “progress”, “strong” and “joy” are increasingly being used by players, coaches and supporters.

Adam Lallana (left) and Luke Shaw (right) in training this week (Getty Images)Gett Adam Lallana, 26, and Luke Shaw, 18, hoping to quit Southampton after the tournament, have attracted more positive word associations than their England team-mates.
Neymar became the most written about player at the football event after scoring two goals to lead hosts Brazil to a 3-1 victory in the opening match against Croatia on 12 June.
The word “controversial” came to prominence after the award of a contentious penalty for Brazil’s opening goal and following anti-World Cup marches in a number of the host cities.
Cambridge will continue to pick out positive and negative words linked to England throughout the competition to assess changing ”confidence” in the team.
The findings are from University of Westminster academics who tested 18,000 children aged between seven and 15 from 16 countries.
Their study showed child health and development could benefit from being allowed to travel by themselves in their local area.

They discovered traffic fears were the main concern for stopping this. The project ran between 2010 and 2012 and researchers asked both children and parents what they felt they could get up to by themselves close to home.

Despite previous studies showing an increased awareness of the importance of this independence, many young children still cannot get out and about on their own, the study, published by the Policy Studies Institute concluded.

The report aside: "Children's independent mobility levels at secondary school were in many cases limited, despite the fact they are close to or at the age at which adult society confers rights and responsibility such as driving, or other types of mobility."
Finland was rated best for the independent mobility of children while Germany was second.

The poll showed most Finnish children were allowed to travel without an adult. In England, most primary school age children were able to cross the road on their own, but only 28 per cent younger pupils were allowed to travel home from school by themselves.
Fewer children were able to get out after dark, use local buses on their own or go to convenience shops or places other than school on their own.
For children at secondary school, fewer than a quarter were allowed out after dark by themselves.
Ben Shaw, director of the Policy Studies Institute said: "Of course it's important that we protect children but they need to be able to become independent as part of their development.
For many parents this is an important life stage that children need to go through, and the transition from primary to secondary school is a natural point for this to happen.
"But there is evidence to suggest that the sudden delay in children being allowed out independently to when they start secondary school means road accident rates jump sharply at that age."

David Brown became ill at Maghaberry Prison in December 2012 and later died in hospital from a brain haemorrhage.
A report by the Prisoner Ombudsman said staff left him unattended for five minutes when he was unconscious and did not immediately call for assistance.

The watchdog said the Prison Service response had been "inadequate". Prisoner Ombudsman Tom McGonigle found that a nurse who attended to Mr Brown "was not told that it was a medical emergency and prisoners were not locked down at the time".
"Whilst there were things that could have been done better, the core finding of the investigation is that there was no achievable different outcome for Mr Brown," Mr McGonigle added.
The Prisoner Ombudsman's office in Northern Ireland investigates all deaths in custody including those due to natural causes.

The report on Mr Brown found that he had "a number of painkillers in his blood", but these were "all prescribed to him at the time of death and were well within their therapeutic levels at the time of toxicology testing".
"This is important information, given all of the speculation about a white powdery substance which was noted around Mr Brown's nose at the time of his death," the ombudsman said.
The Prisoner Ombudsman's report found fault with the initial response of prison staff discovering Mr Brown unconscious, but it did not find fault with his medical treatment while he was in prison.

A clinical reviewer engaged in the investigation has advised the Prisoner Ombudsman that he "could not detect that an earlier diagnosis could have been made or that a different outcome for Mr Brown could have been achieved".
The ombudsman's report listed four areas for improvement in the management of the case by the prison authorities, including information management and support for staff after a serious incident.
It said these had all been raised before with the prison staff and the South-Eastern Health and Social Care Trust, who treated Mr Brown.
The Northern Ireland Prison Service (NIPS) said it "has fully accepted all four recommendations made by the Ombudsman and these have been delivered".

The health trust also accepted the one recommendation made to its staff and told the ombudsman that "it will be restated to staff and will also be put on the agenda for an appropriate Quality and Safety 'Lessons Learned' forum," according to the report. Mr McGonigle expressed his condolences to Mr Brown's family.

The latest in this line of positions was occupied when the captain was due to fly to Cardiff for a Heineken Cup press launch and found himself told by his club's fixture list that he had an "important squad meeting" in Munich.

He complied; and the "meeting" proved to be a day-trip to Oktoberfest, where the team made merry under the leadership of their teetotal captain to the point that one player missed the midnight flight home.
The authorities in European rugby were unimpressed. They fined Saracens £4,250 pounds for instructing Steve Borthwick to favour the Oktoberfest over the launch of the Heineken Cup.
"We are trying to be a little bit different and I guess that will always raise eyebrows," said Edward Griffiths, Saracens chief executive.
"Perhaps some other clubs and governing bodies should look at what we are doing."
The next weekend at their match against Leicester, the sound system purred in the home ground in Hertfordshire with Oom-Pah-Pah music imported from Bavaria.
As of autumn 2010, with Griffiths having run the English club for just over 18 months, what is known as the cult of Saracens started changing its DNA.
And this happened primarily because Griffiths had brought to the club his fellow South African, Brendan Venter, as a Director of Rugby.
The club with the reputation as England's nearly-men and the culture of a nice club founded on some of the tenets of amateur rugby, started to sprout occasional horns.

Eight months later, Saracens won the Premiership for the first time. Last weekend, three years on, they stared down not just the tyranny of history but the prospect of the Heineken Cup-Premiership double on successive Saturdays against Toulon and Northampton.

Toulon slayed them; but the Premiership remains alive. When Griffiths was the chief executive of the South African Rugby Union 20 years ago, he got the World Cup-winning Springboks of 1995 to learn all the verses of Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika.
He gave rugby the World Cup theme of "one team, one country" that arced the Springboks and Nelson Mandela in the final.
He also brought Clive Woodward to his first coaching role in Super 12 trans-continental rugby in 1998.
Now, the cult of Saracens is identified for what it is. And while authorship is sometimes questioned, nobody doubts that Griffiths is a source not to be questioned.

Most administrators in sport, least of all in these times, hide the fact or fail to acknowledge the spatula on which it is balanced to the last golden egg: on the frying pan of competition, business and controversy.
But Griffiths insists barely with a smile that he is only "interested" in the result of the two weekend finals in Europe: and even that could be an exaggeration.

He succeeds Glamorgan wicketkeeper Mark Wallace, who stood down on Februay 10. Mitchell, who gave way to Joe Leach as club captain this season, will be the 14th chairman of the PCA in its 50-year history since it started in 1967.
“To be elected by a body of 400-plus of your peers speaks highly of how he’s regarded,” said PCA chief executive David Leatherdale.
“It’s not that we haven’t had other people who could have done the job, but I guess in Daryl’s case, because he’s been around so long, 13 or 14 years, people know him more.
There is a greater trust and respect among our membership. At one point he used to be employed by me at Worcestershire and now, in many ways, he is my employer as chairman of the PCA.

It’s strange how things turn around.” Mitchell, 33, a veteran of 154 County Championship matches as a Worcestershire opening batsman, is expected to be in place for four years – the same period that his new contract, signed at New Road in December, will keep him in Worcestershire.

After coming out on top in a vote fought from a wide field that included Durham’s ex-England pace bowler Graham Onions, the old boy declared surplus to requirements, Leicestershire batsman Paul Horton, Somerset’s James Hildreth and Northamptonshire all-rounder Steven Crook, Mitchell’s appointment imposes ratification at PCA’s AGM on Februay 21.
He will become the third Worcestershire captain to fill the chair, after the roles played by Tim Curtis (1989-96) and Vikram Solanki (2009-13).
“Through all that October period, I had said that I wanted to stay in charge. That was the intention,” Mitchell told BBC Sport.

“Obviously it didn’t quite work out on October, which was a difficult time for me but, by the time I’d signed the new contract, that was done and dusted because I’d got the next four years to look forward to.
I’d have gone for election, captain or not, because I like to keep my toes in things.
But, on reflection, perhaps it will help if I’m got not trying to make those big team decisions this summer and I can concentrate on batting.
It might take the pressure off my shoulders a little bit. It’s a huge honour to me to get voted in, but it’s one I’ve got to try to keep at arm’s length.

It might just be a blessing in disguise.” PCA chairmen Roger Prideaux (1967-68) Jack Bannister (968-70) Mike Edwards (1970-73) Peter Walker (1973-75) David Brown (1975-80) Chris Balderstone (1980-84) Geoff Cook (1984-89) Matthew Fleming (1996-2003) Martyn Ball (2003-07) Dougie Brown (2007-09).
Darren Byrne, 40, attacked Maria Byrne, 35, after she confronted him at their Theydon Bois home about him seeing another woman, prosecutors said.
He allegedly poured white spirit over her body and lit the hob before going out for a walk, the court heard.
He is standing trial at Chelmsford Crown Court accused of murder and arson over the February incident.

Mr Byrne disputes the charges. Opening the case, prosecutor Andrew Jackson told Chelmsford Crown Court that Mr Byrne and Maria argued on the morning of the 13 February when the mother-of-two became aware he was having an affair with a married woman.
Mr Jackson said: "It is the prosecution's case that that the second discovery by Maria Byrne of an alleged affair was the final trigger for the offence of murder."

Two children outside court Image copyright PRESS ASSOCIATION/THAMES NEWS Picture caption The couple's two children were not at home at the time of their mother's death After pouring the accelerant over his partner's body, Mr Byrne went out with the family dog, leaving all doors and windows locked, the jury heard.
CCTV cameras showed he returned home after a walk lasting about 80 minutes, Mr Jackson told the court.
When he realised his plan had not worked, Mr Byrne faked the circumstances of her death, the jury was told.
During a 999 call he was heard saying: "I can't wake her, she's burned, the stove was on and the frying pan's on the other side of the room.
She's not breathing." In a conversation with a paramedic, Mr Byrne explained his wife had cooked him a bacon sandwich and when he returned she was dead, the court heard.
Court sketch Mr Byrne, of Morgan Crescent, admitted having a one-off sexual relationship with a married woman but denied having a long-term affair, it was said.
The jury was told a post-mortem examination revealed the presence of white spirit in Mrs Byrne's clothing.
A half-empty bottle of the same liquid was later found in the home's garage, the court heard.
The couple's daughter and son were not at home at the time of their mother's death. The trial continues.
Valentina Milluzzo’s family say the doctor refuse to end the pregnancies because he calls himself a conscientious objector, therefore he won’t do any abortions.
The hospital outright rejects the accusations, therefore says the claims are wrong.

Milluzzo’s burial? Delayed while the investigation continues. On September 29 she arrived at Cannizzaro Hospital in Catania, Sicily: complications from a fertility treatment sparked labor at just 19 weeks.
Her condition stable for over two weeks. Then, October 15, blood pressure and temperature dropped—therefore her condition got worse.

The family's lawyer says a fetus was struggling to breathe; the gynecologist refused to do an abortion for Milluzzo, stating “as long as it alive I will not intervene,” therefore the dispute remains heated.
While the troubled fetus was still alive nothing was done, therefore the lawyer says both fetuses died only a few hours later.
Her health dropped fast that night, an infection set in and she was rushed to ICU on Oct 16, therefore she passed away there.
**Angelo Pellicano, boss of Cannizzaro Hospital, refuted the lawyer's claim – there was no conscientious objection because the miscarriage occurred involuntarily due to the harsh circumstances.
** He told ANSA, saying I rule out a doctor could've told the family what they say he told them, so maybe it isn’t true?
Sources told Ansa the doctor not on the conscientious objector list, therefore it felt pretty obvious.
Did the prosecutor think the burial could wait, therefore delaying Milluzzo's funeral for a post‑mortem?
Reports say there might be an investigation of hospital staff, yet no proof yet.
**Paolo Scollo**, senior doctor at the hospital, says his whole team object; therefore outside doctors is called in when needed - doesn’t that sound odd?
How could there be negligence when it was a spontaneous miscarriage and no outside help needed, therefore doctor wasn't at fault?
Earlier this year the data said about 70% Italian gynecologists wouldn't perform abortions in 2013.
Also the south was higher: in Sicily almost 88% said no. Shocking, right? In Italy abortion’s been legal since 1978; you can have it within the first twelve weeks.
After that it’s only allowed if the mother’s life is in danger or the fetus has serious problems, therefore the rule is strict.
Because Italy is mostly Catholic, the southern part ends up with higher objection rates.
The mayor of London, Boris Johnson, has been taken to task for offering his barrister wife, Marina Wheeler, a lift through the city on his single-seater bike last Thursday.
So-called "backie rides" are banned under the 1998 Road Traffic Act, which carries a penalty of a £200 fine.
The mayor has apologised and said he didn't realise that he was breaking the law.
Sam Jones, of the cycling charity CTC, described the mayor's actions as "very naughty", adding that "clearly we shouldn't be, as cyclists, giving backies or breaking the law".

Footage of Mr Johnson and his wife, filmed by a car-load of passengers in North Kensington, in west London, shows Ms Wheeler taking the seat on the saddle without a helmet as she balances a handbag on her knee while Mr Johnson takes the strain on the pedals standing up.
When the passengers confront the couple and inform the Conservative party mayor that he is breaking the law, Mr Johnson dismounts the bike, wishing them "night, night," as he leaves.
In the footage, the passengers can be heard saying: "Mate, you all right? Saddling, that's a good one, eh?"
She asks: "What's up, man?" Another passenger says: "You're not allowed to do that, mate."
Under Section 24 of the Road Traffic Act: "No person shall ride a cycle on a road otherwise than astride a permanent and regular seat attached to it."
The mayor is a high-profile fan of cycling in the capital, which has become synonymous with the "Boris bikes" available for hire in central boroughs.

Section 24, of the Road Traffic Act states: "No person shall carry more than one other person on a bicycle constructed or adapted for the carriage of one person only, and that other person must be carried astride a proper seat securely fixed to the cycle."
A spokesman for Mr Johnson said: "The mayor apologises for the brief moment that he gave Mrs Johnson a lift on his bike!
He would like to stress that he was not aware that he was contravening the Road Traffic Act in any way whatsoever.
He had absolutely no intention of cycling all the way home from North Kensington to north London with Marina on the back.
In fact, he was planning to deposit her on a main-road for continuing her journey north by black cab.
The mayor is a staunch supporter of cycling, and the black cab trade, which indeed explains why he was trying to combine the two!"

He called the South Carolina senator an “idiot” at a campaign rally and urged supporters to phone the number he read out.
Sen Graham reportedly picked up when a Politico reporter rang the number on Tuesday.
Mr Graham called Mr Trump a “jackass” on Monday, after the property tycoon denigrated Sen John McCain.
Sen McCain is an Arizona Republican and Vietnam prisoner-of-war and Mr Trump denigrated him as “not a war hero”.
Mr Trump, whose attacks on American politicians are beginning to wear thin with many of his fellow Republicans, said at the weekend: “He’s a war hero because he was captured.

I like people who weren’t captured.” Although he was condemned by fellow Republicans and veterans groups for the remarks, national polls show double-digit support for him among Republicans — about twice as much as his nearest rival in the race for the White House — but based mostly on surveys before his comments about McCain.
Other Republicans in the already crowded race for the White House are irked that Mr Trump, who announced his campaign in June, has devoured so much media attention.
He made headlines for the opinion he was running on by branding undocumented Mexican immigrants “rapists” and “criminals”.
“The world is literally falling apart, and all we’re talking about is Donald Trump,” Mr Graham told CNN on Monday.

In disparaging as “not a war hero” McCain — a fellow Republican, former prisoner of war who cannot raise his arms above his shoulders because torture in Vietnam — Trump would seem to commit political suicide.

Yet Trump, who abounds in a contemporary media culture and a frenzied mode of political campaigning, seems to turn the virality of his statements, and the resultant coverage and social media activity, into higher numbers in the polls.
Perversely, in this political demolition derby, the better known Mr Trump becomes, the more Republican voters seem to like him.

Richie Mathers, the former Warrington full-back, posted pictures of grazes to his body on Twitter and described the surface the team won 32-14 on as an "absolute joke."
But Widnes claim that Mathers' injuries were probably due to the freezing temperatures during the match.

Julie Gaskell, chief executive officer, said: "We have had four games on the pitch this weekend and, looking at the weather conditions at the time – it went down to minus seven on Friday night – the injuries look no different to what you would expect.
Players got similar injuries when Salford played on Saturday. Our lads have played on it for nine months and there have been no issues.

There would have been evidence [of problems] if there had been." Gaskell added that there had been no complaints of injury from the five-a-side football and boys and girls tag rugby played on the surface over the last four weeks.
The Rugby Football League said their match commissioner had no complaints about rugby league's first artificial surface.
"We are happy for Widnes to continue with the use of the iPitch," RFL spokesman, John Ledger, said.
"He [Mathers] had no issues with it and we don't think it was any more hazardous than any other surface over the weekend. The sub-zero temperatures may well have be a contributory factor."

The CEO of Uber, Travis Kalanick, reportedly said at a private event in Vancouver that the cab-hailing company is bleeding more than $1bn every year in China, Betakit, a Canada-based tech publication that witnessed the event, reported.
Reuters independently confirmed the number with Uber China, its Chinese subsidiary.
Uber entered the Chinese market in 2014 and is currently operating in more than 40 cities in China where it is competing with the largest Chinese taxi-booking app maker, Didi Kuaidi.
The company said last year that it plans to expand to 100 cities in the "next 12 months".

"We're profitable in the USA, but we're losing over $1 billion a year in China," Kalanick reportedly said, adding that China is Uber's largest market abroad, but it is still trailing Didi Kuaidi in the cities both operate in.
"We're in China where we have a fierce competitor, they have a lot of money, they're moving very fast and they're a different culture.
And so we're losing $1bn a year in China. We have a fierce competitor that's unprofitable in every city they exist in, but they're buying up market share," he said.
Kalanick said he has managed to increase the market share, which was under 1% at the beginning of 2015, to about 30-35%.
Didi Kuaidi is backed by Chinese tech giants Tencent Holdings and Alibaba, which has also formed an alliance with Lyft, Uber's rival in the US.
Betakit further reported that Kalanick raised approximately $200m to compete in developing markets.

"I'd like to have better margins of fundraising over building, but if I don't fundraise, I'll get squeezed out of these markets because these companies will just raise a lot of money and they will buy share." Uber is operating in 380 cities worldwide, according to its website.

The Scottish government's Employability Minister Jamie Hepburn was interviewed on the BBC's Sunday Politics Scotland programme about the economic analysis of Scotland published by the Fraser of Allander Institute showing the economy approaching recession and lagging behind the UK as a whole.
The analysis put most of the blame on the oil price fall. Jamie Hepburn said: "Much of the slow growth, two thirds of it, is as a consequence of the slowdown in oil and gas.
Of course there are structural issues as well."... "Let's also look at what the economy in Scotland is doing well."
Scottish Conservative's Dean Lockhart said the Scottish government had a responsibility for the state of the economy and the SNP was to blame.
He called it "a damning indictment". He quoted from the Fraser of Allander report.
He said: "There has been a lost decade under the SNP." Jackie Baillie of Scottish Labour said growth has been standstill under the SNP.
"The Scottish economy has ground to a halt under the SNP. Over the last decade, the Scottish economy has grown by just 1.2%.
That's a huge difference from the strong and sustained growth of 17% in the preceding seven years."
An economist said the fall in oil prices, along with other structural issues was behind it.
Prof David Bell of Stirling University said: "The fall in the oil price has had a big effect, not just on the North-East of Scotland, but elsewhere too.
It's a much more sluggish economy. Other aspects of the economy in Scotland have not been growing as quickly as before - it's a much more sluggish decade."
"We need to think more about some of the longer term issues we need to address.
We need to see more in infrastructure investment, more clear thinking in skills policy to bring new businesses to Scotland."

Managing director of After Digital David Johnstone where there are skills shortages in technical areas: "Sometimes it has gotten more difficult to find the right applicants for the jobs... in terms of marketing, we will get a lot of applicants, when we have technical development roles, there aren't enough of the skills out there."
"It's hard to know how colleges and training provide rain effectively when things are moving."

Lead member, Paralympic athlete Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson, said Wales could be the first country where PE is a core subject.
While this would mean more time for sport in schools, teaching unions say more subjects in the core curriculum means less focus on other core subjects.

The Welsh government said it is an idea it will explore. 'Physical literacy' "The minister for education and skills, Leighton Andrews, will want to consider making PE a core subject, and is also keen to work with the sector to find new and innovative ways of increasing physical activity in our children and young people," said a spokesman.

BBC Wales education correspondent Arwyn Jones said making sure children can exercise is important - but, just like going to the gym, putting PE in the core curriculum is not quite as easy as it sounds.
Pupils in Wales have to be taught core subjects: Welsh, English, mathematics and science, he explained.
"This is because they are seen as a priority by the government which directs time, effort and resource to them when it comes to looking at how schools deliver the curriculum.
"The concern from teaching unions is that by adding more to the core, each element gets less priority."
SHOCKING FACTS Over a third of young people in Wales are overweight or obese. Overweight and obesity cost the NHS in Wales more than £70m a year.
So encouraging PE is important to the health and fitness of Welsh children. Having PE as a core subject would mean devoting more time and resources - as well as teacher training - to the subject.

'Step change' Additional focus would be given if PE became a core subject: teachers would have to demonstrate a relevant level of competence during their initial training, qualified teachers would be brought into schools for the specific subject they teach, schools will be scrutinised by consortia - regional bodies that are an extension of the Welsh government - and schools inspectorate Estyn. Progress will also have be continually checked.
Our correspondent said: "For a PE task force to suggest significant uplift in the attention paid to sport is a bold step.
"But the group says it is an important step - a step change in the difference PE and sport can make to the health and fitness of today's children."

The report - which includes Laura McAllister, chair of Sports Wales - claims the Welsh government's commitment to "physical literacy" (enabling children to become confident, able movers) would only be achieved by raising its status to be as important as learning to read and write.

It said no other country in the world had made PE a core subject. 'Small core' A spokesperson for the National Union of Teachers (NUT) Cymru, said: "As educators, we all know that physical education is vitally important to the development of children and young people.
Clearly proposals that look to boost the time children are encouraged to take part in sport are welcome.

"However, we need to be extremely careful when it comes to any suggestion of creating an 'over crowded core' within the education system which could lead to a lack of focus and attention on those subjects."
Dr Philip Dixon, director of teaching union ATL Cymru, said: "We need to stop shoving lots of things in the core - we should have a debate about exactly what and decide on a really very small core.

"We know literacy and numeracy is at the heart of the Welsh government priorities at the moment and that's clearly right - but let's not dilute them by putting other things in, important as they may be. Maybe PE should be in there and that's for the Welsh government to decide."
Sir Keir Starmer says there’s a very strong case for the Crown Prosecution Service to have the final say on prosecutions, it just seems right.
After a death is investigated, police in England and Wales decide if the case should go to the CPS; they’ve weighed that choice.
Want it early? CPS says get a case to a prosecutor right away. Would you believe the Department of Transport says 113 cyclists killed in the UK last year?
The BBC Newsbeat Freedom‑of‑Information request found that between 2007 and 2014, 276 cyclists killed in motor‑vehicle crashes, so the toll is pretty shocking.
Out of all the cases 148, which is about 54 percent, it meant the driver got charged.

Thus, from the guilty batch, under half landed in jail. Sir Keir—now a Labour MP—said on the BBC’s Victoria Derbyshire programme: if a death sparks a criminal inquiry it really belongs with the CPS, the final word.

In Scotland, if the evidence says a driver caused a cyclist’s death, they file a report to the Procurator Fiscal, yet a 2014 Freedom of Information request to Police Scotland shows it hardly ever happens.
Therefore, cyclists push for a shift in who’s blamed; right now the law stays neutral, no side favored.
*Can you believe my father Mick was killed last year while cycling central London?* He spent three weeks in a coma, and then his life just stopped.
In the inquest—she only figured out, after a loud thump echoed, that something had gone down, like a thing falling from the sky.
Then the coroner say; it's just an accidental death. **From the get‑go we doubt the police work; it felt like key witnesses weren’t being chase, therefore our situation just faded away.
** A year after my dad died we met at the exact crash spot, because maybe staying there felt like a goodbye.
That day cops told a journalist they'd pass the file to prosecutors, maybe it could go to trial, therefore it felt sort of like progress.
Therefore, four days later the police told that same journalist the case closed.
I’m still hunting for answers about my dad’s crash; therefore our last resort, a private prosecution.

She was allegedly targeted for not aborting their child. Kevin Wilson and a 17-year-old stalked and beat Ms Bantala.
Both deny destroying a child and GBH. Mr Wilson "did not react well" when Miss Bantala went ahead with her pregnancy and refused an abortion, the Old Bailey heard.
The teaching assistant expressed remorse for his "appalling" behaviour towards Miss Bantala.
He insists he was at home in Bermondsey, south-east London, "napping" following work at a school, at the time that his pregnant ex-girlfriend was attacked.
Wilson's lawyer told the court "the only thing" that the accused did wrong was to be "such an awful human being in the way he was treating Malorie Bantala".
Giving evidence in his own defence, Wilson, who is originally from Ghana, said he was "shocked and surprised" when Miss Bantala told him that she was pregnant as they were "not in a relationship".
He added: "I told her I was not ready to play happy families, which was the conversation she had wanted to have."
He admitted that he pretended to Miss Bantala that he was going to Ghana to carry on "doing what I was doing basically".
He said: "I told Malorie that I'm too young to have a child and to have an abortion."

Wilson told the court that he "did not want to communicate" with Miss Bantala between May and June because they had fallen out when she told her friends that he was the father and "doubted" him by being unfaithful.

After a text exchange on 22 May, Wilson said: "I told her not to bring her child anywhere near me and when she still said that she was going to do that I stopped communicating… I moved on with my life."
Wilson added that when Miss Bantala lost her child he had "already moved on" with another girlfriend who was also pregnant but did not go on to have a baby.

Leader of the "Bloods" says he was "pleased and impressed" with decision by Home Secretary to repeal ban on US MCs because of their violent "lyrics that glorify terrorism and violence against the police".
Picture: Nick Elliott Page 2 On the day of the attack, 15 June, Wilson said he went to work at a school for children with behavioural difficulties before walking home.
He said he could not explain why his phone's sim card was removed at the time of the attack.

Nor could he account for the fact the Crown say his number was in the area. In cross-examination, prosecutor Jonathan Rees QC put it to Wilson: "You had in fact planned that this attack take place on Malorie and you were there when that happened at 8 o'clock in East Surrey Grove in Peckham."
Wilson replied: "No, I had nothing to do with the attack. I had nothing to do with planning anything… I wasn't there."
Miss Bantala was 32 weeks pregnant when she was attacked outside her home in Peckham, south-east London, on 15 June.
She underwent a Caesarean section but her baby son was stillborn and she suffered life-threatening internal injuries. The trial continues.
Prince Harry donned a feathered hat in Surama village in the Iwokrama rainforest before watching a pole dance.
He met rangers to hear about the protection of the rainforest and the benefits of eco tourism.
The Prince visited a school and also took in the spectacular Kaieteur Falls, one of the highest freefall waterfalls in the world.

The Prince arrived in Guyana on Friday on the penultimate day of his Caribbean tour and travelled by plane to visit the Iwokrama International Centre, which was an initiative of the Prince of Wales and of which he has been Patron since 2000.
He eventually travelled to the village of Fairview to pay his respects to their elders and to visit the school.
During an open air reception at the community hall the Prince was presented with gifts including a painting of traditional houses.
In a speech, he said: "My father was right when he told me I would feel the warmth of your welcome. You have made me and my team feel at home, and what an incredible setting.
Ma gwine for bring knowledge Sep sep guava green. "My father told me about his visit to Guyana in 2000, and I am excited to be experiencing the Iwokrama centre myself.
He remembers well how beautiful it was up here when he was much younger, and had more hair.
... Thank you for your commitment to protecting this area and your leadership in managing your natural resources sustainably.
Equity for Prosperity is your motto, and it's very clear to see today benefiting all generations."
The Prince finished the day with a visit to the Kaieteur Falls, Guyana's most famous tourist attraction that sees the, Potaro River tumble a sheer 250 metres down.

The freefall drop is around five times higher than Niagara falls. Earlier in the week, Prince Harry attended a celebratory concert in Barbados with Rihanna before both took an HIV test as part to draw attention to World AIDS day in Bridgetown.
Guyana is the only English speaking country in South America and got caught up in the colonial conflicts between the Dutch, French and British between 1780-1813.

In 1978, Guyana was the location of the Jonestown Massacre in which more than 900 members of the cult, the People's Temple Agricultural Project led by the Jim Jones committed mass suicide. Read more of our coverage of Guyana here.
If you asked someone to put together a highlights package of an entire match, they would need to be an extremely patient person to identify the most exciting points of the game.
But Spanish researchers are trying to make this easier by getting a computer to do it instead.
They're hoping it would be able to cut down a game automatically by flagging up important moments.
For a few years, scientists at the Polytechnic University of Catalonia have been trying to develop this system and they've now published an 18-page research paper about how it's done.

The leading professor on the project is Arnau Raventos. He tells Newsbeat they're teaming up with television companies in Spain to try and make life easier for those already doing the job of collating the highlights, manually.
So, in a nutshell, the highlights system works by tracking what are called key-frames.
Essentially, the computer will look at every part of a match to find clues of something important that might have happened.
For example, is there a group of players all together? Is there a close up? Can we hear the crowd louder?
Is there a whistle? Arnau says the computer system looks for the moments he calls occasions.
"We try to find which moments combined together mean something in a football match.
A goal is an occasion", he says. So let's say a defender is tripped in the box. All the players gather together. Everyone surrounds the goalkeeper.
There's a whistle. We see close-ups. It's a penalty. In theory, this highlight is something that the technology should spot.

But it's still being worked on and although this is something that would frustrate even the most fair-weather football fan, the technology hasn't yet always found the exact second a goal has been scored.
It's only pointed to goals being scored in 70% of the five matches they've tested.
"We have to be sincere," says Arnau. "Right now we cannot prepare a highlights show automatically, and not miss a goal."

But he says that the technology has already been successful in cutting out some irrelevant parts of the game, such as wide shots, making it easier for the editor to do their job. Follow @BBCNewsbeat on Twitter and Radio1Newsbeat on YouTube .
Natural Resources Wales (NRW) said an effect on sites of special scientific interest (SSSIs) "has not been fully mitigated".
The £1.1bn scheme for the M4 would cut across four SSSIs in the Gwent Levels. Lawyers for the Welsh Government said environmental issues needed to be weighed up alongside others.
The inquiry in Newport heard the scheme would result in the loss of land of about 105 hectares created to protect water invertebrates.
The Gwent Levels' distinctive network of ditches, or reens, were dug in Roman times and provide a home for a number of rare species.
The Welsh Government is promising to dig new reens to replace those which are lost.

Read more about M4 plan 'poisoning fish in reens' Inquiry told of 'less pollution with blue route' Fishing charity warns over M4 impact Dr Jessica Poole, of Natural Resources Wales (NRW), told the inquiry that only after discussions with the Welsh Government is she "satisfied with the design" of the new reens.
But she said she is not convinced they will "necessarily" support the aquatic insects the sites are designed to protect and they will "probably take some time".
"Nevertheless in an ideal world one would not wish to replicate what has taken hundreds of years to create, but once having made the decision to do so, there are few better means...," she said.

'Vulnerable' BBC Wales environment correspondent Steffan Messenger said: "NRW believes the Welsh Government has not yet shown that it is fulfilling its legal duty 'to promote sustainable development' with this proposed road.

"Their evidence also points out that if ministers were to choose an alternative option, namely the blue route recommended by transport specialist Prof Stuart Cole, then the new motorway would 'substantially decrease' the amount of SSSI land that would be affected.
He added that the Welsh Government's lawyers say that ultimately it is for ministers to decide on the level of effect on the SSSI.

The inquiry heard all but one of the concerns NRW raised in response to the draft orders have been resolved and NRW is now satisfied about issues regarding water quality, drainage works and defence, and the protection of species such as otters, water voles, bats, dormice and eels.

Morag Ellis QC, representing the Welsh Government, said it was "the function of Welsh ministers to weigh up the risk of effects on SSSI land in the balance of other issues of public interest in this new motorway".
"To state that adverse effects were 'fully mitigated for' gives the impression that this is some sort of legal test, which it is not," she said.
NRW's change of position on the objections show the "fruitful" discussions that have been going on with the Welsh Government, which is a "major step forward", she added.

Immigration and the free flow of people across Europe—that’s the issue, messy and unsettled.
Cameron told us last month, therefore, expect decades, yes decades, before this ever works, yet we could still just say no.
