**Food Standards Scotland's report says stores push way more salty and sugary foods, therefore you can't escape them.
** Stirling University scholars, the report’s authors, push for a “retail revolution” – it’s meant to steer shoppers toward healthier choices, therefore?
Even with those findings, the Scottish Grocers’ Federation criticized the report: they say it ignored the push for healthier eating.
**Food Standards Scotland notes that about 30 % of Scots are obese now—therefore it could climb to 40 % by 2030.
** Leigh Sparks, writer of the report, talked on BBC Radio Scotland’s Good Morning Scotland; therefore, stores don't promote all food types equally, leading to an imbalance.
**He said stores usually hype junk‑food, like huge bags of chips piled everywhere, therefore shoppers end up grabbing the less‑healthy choices.
** He said manufacturers need change product makeup; retailers should give shoppers clearer info and also tweak promo strategies.
He mentioned that retailers are getting more aware of the problem nowadays; therefore they’re starting to look for fixes.
Therefore the voluntary schemes hasn't moved the needle because junk‑food ads still dominate. > Also, the report backs a sugar tax. Seems like a decent idea, right?

Dr. Gillian Purdon, senior dietary adviser at FSS, pointed out that the report matches the agency’s aim to push the sugar tax beyond just soft drinks; therefore, lower sugar, fat and salt in products, shrink portion sizes, clamp down on unhealthy food ads, and provide clearer labeling in both stores and restaurants, right?
**This report should spark new ideas for retailers, more healthy choices on shelves and bigger ads, therefore pulling in more shoppers,** she said.
**Healthy eating can’t happen with just one trick; it needs a bunch of different steps working together.
** Putting rules on promos for high‑fat salty sugary foods and drinks, in any store or restaurant, should be top priority.
Turns out about fifty percent of less‑healthy food buys happen when there’s a promotion, while only roughly thirty percent of the healthier picks do.
The report says the way stores let shoppers pick things actually changes Scottish people's health and diet, so aren't we all affected by the aisle layout?
Can we really count on people to act on their own, or just trust shoppers to choose wisely? That's just not enough.
Many shops in Nairobi and other cities have not shut. The Kenya National Commission on Human Rights said at least 24 people had been shot dead in violence since the election on 8 August.
Mr Odinga alleges the election was stolen in order to re-elect President Uhuru Kenyatta, and has appealed for a "day of mourning for the fallen patriots".
Kenyans have, however, started running the hashtag #TurudiKaziniChallenge (Let's return to work), appealing for normal life to resume.
President Kenyatta has also urged the country to go back to work, saying: "At the end of the day, we are all Kenyans.
We don't need to fight one another, destroy property and take life." Mr Kenyatta added that "Kenyans have proved that they were tired of the election and most of the people have returned to work".
Small groups of young men were burning tyres early on Monday morning in the Kibera slum in the capital, Nairobi, a stronghold of Mr Odinga, the BBC's Tomi Oladipo reports.
Afraid of losing more business, some of Mr Odinga's supporters in Kibera agreed that the election was rigged but went ahead and opened their shops.
In the coastal town of Mombasa it's business as usual. Our correspondent says high court clerks are also getting to work.
The call for a strike in Kisumu, another stronghold of Mr Odinga in the west, is being followed by some, with some shops open and other closed.
A traffic police officer has reportedly been killed in the town. Some 54% of voters backed President Kenyatta while Mr Odinga received 45%, according to official results.
On Sunday, Mr Odinga called for people to stay away from work, saying: "This is a failed regime, they are resorting to killing people instead of addressing the real issues.
The vote was stolen, there's no secret about that." Foreign observers have said the poll was free and fair.

European Union foreign affairs chief Federica Mogherini and former UN Secretary General Kofi Annan have both urged Mr Odinga to resolve his complaints through the courts, something the opposition coalition has ruled out.

The Association of School and College Leaders (ASCL) is introducing seminars in most major towns and cities in England to discuss new legislation and how schools and colleges should address radicalisation.
The seminars will be delivered by Kamal Hanif, the principal of Waverley School in Birmingham, who is an expert on Islam and citizenship.

The union say the seminars are to support and guide senior members in the wake of episodes such as the three schoolgirls from London who travelled to Syria in February and are now in Raqqa, a stronghold of Islamic State.
Last week the family of one of them blamed the authorities for failing to share information that could have prevented the girls from fleeing to Syria.
The Counter Terrorism and Security Act 2015 places schools and colleges under a duty to prevent young people from being drawn into terrorism.
The seminars, which will take place in June and July, will help school and college leaders to carry out this duty, offering practical advice.

They are focused on encouraging an ethos of equality and diversity, as well as giving teachers an insight into the use of social media to recruit and groom young people influenced by extremist ideologies.
Hanif is manager of the building bridges project, an organisation backed by the Muslim Council of Britain tasked with bringing people from various cultures and faiths together.
Hanif said: “The seminars will expand understanding of definitions of radicalisation and extremism.
I want to be able to help head teachers ‘spot the signs’ and deal with issues in the right way without getting too panicked.
“Our young people spend a long time in their bedrooms and are not far away from their smart phones or computers.
They are receiving information in an environment where there is nobody to challenge the ideas of extremists.
“Our seminars will help our schools and parents, who in many cases are not fully aware of what young people are doing online.
This will bring them to understand some signals and how to deal with them in the right way.

“The seminars support school leaders to challenge the extreme rhetoric with counter arguments.” Hanif will be joined by Sara Khan, a counter extremism campaigner and co-founder of the cross-faith organisation Inspire, and ASCL’s parliamentary specialist, Anna Cole.
Khan said: “The seminars will clarify what is expected from schools in terms of the law.

There are wrong assumptions in the public domain at present about what the statutory duty involves for schools and their pupils.” Cole said it was vital to avoid criminalisation of young people by ensuring early intervention and risk assessments.
She said: “Schools have a key role in developing a school culture where learners are central, and diverse views and ideas can be explored in the open.”
A video of Bailey Matthews discarding his walking aid before reaching the finishing line has been watched more than 27 million times on Facebook.
Bailey, from Doncaster, received the Richard Whiteley Award at an event in Leeds on Friday night.

Cricketer Joe Root took the Sporting Achievement Award. The Yorkshire Awards, now in their 27th year, dig beneath the surface to celebrate the rich variety of people and businesses in in the county and this year were sponsored by communications company KCOM.
Bailey took part in an event for children staged at the Castle Howard estate in North Yorkshire in July which comprised a 100m swim, a 4km bike ride and 1.3km run.

Twice he fell to the ground as he neared the finishing line but he picked himself up and in the final 20m he abandoned his walking frame, built to support people with disability in allowing them to walk.
“We are delighted so proud of Bailey’s efforts and to receive the Richard Whiteley Award is such a huge honour, it means even more that we are proud northerners,” Bailey’s family said.
Sheffield-born Root became the top-ranked batsman in the world with the International Cricket Council after helping England reclaim the Ashes from Australia.
In a summer run-glut, the 24-year-old confirmed his status as one of England’s best cricketers with a total approaching 3,000 runs in Test matches in games which stretched into October.
Root, describing his award as a “real honour”, paid tribute to those who have helped him on the way.
“I pride myself on the fact that I’m a Sheffield lad and a Yorkshire lad, and that’s where I started my cricket, so a huge thank you,” he added.
TV cook Rosemary Shrager, who has lived in Yorkshire for many years, picked up the Woman of the Year Award.
Former Conservative Party leader and foreign secretary William Hague, who was born in Rotherham, was named Man of the Year.
Hague, the MP for Richmond until stepping down from parliament at the general election in May, has a deep affection for the county.
“Whatever I have done, and wherever I have been in the world, I have never stopped being a Yorkshireman, and never will,” said Hague.

The Lifetime Achievement Award went to Sir David Wootton, who served during 2011-12 as Lord Mayor of the City of London, and Huddersfield-born poet Simon Armitage, whose many awards include a BAFTA for best documentary for the 2002 film Feltham Sings, for which he won an Ivor Novello Award for best lyric, won the Arts and Entertaining Award.
The Business Enterprise Award went to Howarth Timber, which began life in Leeds in 1840 with a single man and now employs more than 1,000 people.
North Yorkshire farmer Gareth Barlow took the Countryside Award while junior football coach Stephen Shipley took the Community Hero Award.
One of Nepal's top cricketers and sports celebrities, Sharad Bheswakar, has a problem.
National selectors are considering naming him the captain of Nepal's national cricket team.
But while Bheswakar lives in Nepal, competes for Nepal, is Nepali-born and bred, he remains, officially, an Indian national .
And he says this is despite the fact that his father is Indian and his mother is Nepali, which, under the law, would make him eligible for citizenship.
He says he has tried repeatedly but has never been able to obtain his Nepali citizenship.
"I have been waiting for almost eight to nine years to get my citizenship. I am still facing problems.

I feel frustrated sometimes," he says. In the past, he has been issued a special temporary travel document so that he could play in international tournaments. "I have been trying for the last eight to nine years to get my citizenship.
I am still facing problems"Under Nepal's 2006 Citizenship Act, Nepalis are entitled to acquire citizenship at the age of 16, as long as their mother or father verify and vouch for them.

However, it is common in Nepal-where culture has traditionally valued men over women-that women face difficulties passing on their identity to their children if the father is not present, or not Nepali.
Without citizenship papers, one cannot get a driver's license, open a bank account or enroll in higher education.
One can't own property or even have the legal right to buy and sell in the country.
"From our perspective this is a fairly major concern" says Robert Piper, United Nations Resident Humanitarian Coordinator and a senior United Nations official in Nepal.

"The Election Commission found over 2m people that it interviewed in 3years in villages- that does not include the entire population of Kathmandu and Pokara-that could not show their citizenship card," he says.
Usha Kala Rai, a former member of the now dissolved Constituent Assembly, says Nepal's bureaucracy is misogynistic.
"Many women are suffering with violence and discrimination. Many women returning home from foreign employment and those raped, abandoned or divorced, can lose their identity," she says.

Bhagwati Chettri, 55, is a Nepali and was abandoned years ago by her husband. Since she never received citizenship through her parents or from her husband, the couple's two children have no formal identity-even as they now grow into adulthood.
"I have been trying for the last eight years to get a citizenship certificate," says Chettri.
Jeremy Corbyn will confirm on a visit to Birmingham on Tuesday that a Labour government would enhance Carer’s Allowance by 17% to reach more than one million carers in the first year of payment.
Under the plan, Carer’s Allowance would increase from £62.70 a week to £73.10. The party would invest an extra £2bn in social care over three years.
At present about 6.5 million people across the UK receive the benefit in their capacity as carers for elderly or disabled or seriously ill friends or family members.
They must care for the person for at least 35 hours a week, and earn no more than £116 a week after tax.
Corbyn regards the change as a way to help carers, mostly women, who often quit the jobs market to look after an elderly relative living at home.
He said told the BBC that caring for others was often very rewarding, “but it should never force people into social isolation or into a life of poverty”.
In his speech on Tuesday, the Labour leader will claim that “Britain’s social care crisis” is a result of a series of Downing Street decisions to cut council care budgets by £4.6bn.

That has left “unpaid carers” with extra duties.” They save taxpayers £132bn every year, and their often unrecognised contribution to society is mostly down to a sense of love and duty, and simply doing what is right.

“But the thousands of unsung carers in Britain deserve so much better. Labour understands that increasing Carer’s Allowance by over £10 a week will make a real difference in so many lives, and as the social care provider of last resort, it is not just completely the right thing to do morally, but financially too.
“Conservative changes to inheritance tax will be reversed under Labour, simply making it fairer, and only the wealthiest few in Britain will pay it.
Labour is committed to modernising the social care system in Britain and helping family carers.

This important policy announcement is a vital step along that journey. Carers and those who depend on their care need support, not cuts like under the Conservatives.” Labour calculates that upgrading carer’s allowance would probably cost the exchequer £538m in 2020/21, and would be funded by cancelling the inheritance tax cut worth £650m by 2020/21.
The inheritance tax change due to come into force raises the threshold for the death duties, with couples able to pass on a home worth up to £1m tax-free.
But the Conservatives said Labour’s promise to raise the allowance would be unaffordable.

Luke Hall, a Conservative member of the Commons work and pensions select committee said: “While we recognise the important contribution carers make to our society, hundreds of thousands of people off work for sickness receive that allowance, they hold the safety net for those who are unable to work due to their condition today.
“We’re making good progress, making sure we get the right people back into work and so far since 2010 we’ve increased Carer’s Allowance by another £450 per year.”

The protein-packed patch, tested on mice and pigs, encourages healthy cells to grow and discourages the formation of a scar that can impair the heart’s ability to pump blood after a heart attack, the scientists said.

The development is reported in the journal Nature, along with separate research that could improve organ transplants, from stem cell-grown organs to transplanted kidneys. Heart attacks starve the heart muscle of blood, causing cell death.
It has long been thought that repairing, or replacing, at least some of these cells would be beneficial.
In the latest study, an international team of researchers triggered heart attacks in animals and then applied a simple patch made of collagen and soaked with a protein called Fstl1.
The scientists noted that this is naturally found in healthy hearts, but disappears from one layer of the heart after an attack.
New muscle cells and blood vessels formed in the heart within two weeks of applying the patch, and the organ’s ability to pump blood was improved.
Prof Pilar Ruiz-Lozano, from Stanford University in California, which has patented the patch, said: “The treated animals were sick animals, just like one sees in a clinic.
They really have no other options. Now you can patch the heart so it can grow back some of the cells it has lost, rather than put on a sticking plaster.
It isn’t a cure, but it significantly augments heart function in animal models.
“Those animals were so sick that they would’ve been candidates for heart transplantation.
My hope is that one day, people that are in the same situation will be able to avoid heart transplantation.” She added: “We’re trying to figure out which patients would benefit the most.

The patch probably won’t be for ones who have had very small heart attacks and don’t have significant damage, but one can imagine you’re a patient in an ambulance going to have an operation and there’s an hour of waiting, and at that moment the surgeon says, ‘Why don’t we put a patch on?’” Improving the function of the worst-damaged hearts could also make devices such as pacemakers and pumps more effective, she said.

Commenting in Nature, Prof Gordana Vunjak-Novakovic, of Columbia University in New York, said the work could foster new approaches to treating heart infarction, but added: “Many studies will be needed to see whether these implants are similarly effective and safe in larger animals and humans.” Applications in organ transplants A separate paper published in Nature suggests that blocking a protein called HMGB1 could make organs that had been grown from stem cells - or organs from one species transplanted into another, known as xenotransplants - more viable.

Both approaches have generated excitement as a way to address the shortfall of donor organs, but they have traditionally prompted a strong immune response, causing the recipient’s body to eventually reject the organ.
The authors show that HMGB1 is produced more quickly in these “neonatal” tissues, which appear to be more inflammatory than adult organs transplanted into the bodies of animals.
They found that by blocking the protein, animals that had neonatal organ transplants survived for more than 400 days - a significantly longer period than others who had the same procedure.

“We may one day be able to mitigate the body’s rejection of organ transplants that originate from a different species or stem-cell source,” said Megan Sykes, director of Columbia’s centre for translational immunology, after the publication of the research.

“A clinical trial in humans is still a long way off, but we now have a better understanding of what’s happening at the cellular level during these transplants and a way to curb the rejection response.”
Two years later, Jones—a mom now—says this experience gave her a deeper feel for what Gemma Foster, a mother of one, actually went through.
> Being a wife and mother made me understand seriousness of a family breaking apart; night after night I'd get home, baby sleeping, I just sit wondering.
It showed me why two people who fall in love, have a baby, and then drift apart can still make sense—maybe love changes, maybe life just pulls them in different directions.
Even while we’re hurting, try to parent in each other’s lives, don’t add extra pain for the child, therefore keep the kid’s wellbeing first.
Jones sometimes brought her son onto the set, he never appeared on screen, **moreover** she giggled saying *he looked much better than I did* on camera.
Now she’s eager — more downtime with him, finally; isn’t that what she wants? *Work‑life balance? Hard for everybody; I just try keep work apart, she explains.
* Grateful, I’ve slogged through endless tasks and now finally let myself rest. I’m around till christmas, just hanging out at play park in my Converse shoes, therefore watching kids run by.
The second series kicks back in, and now Gemma’s former husband Simon – Bertie Carvel’s character – rolls into Parminster with a brand‑new family, right where she lives and works.
They’re swamped by brutal fallout of divorce; Tom the kid ends up stuck right there.
Jones admits watching it gets uncomfortable at points; still, there’s that weird, sexy edge he can’t ignore.
**We know how awkward it feels, that weird pause in a room with an ex; so she says.

** Everyone's had a relationship, an ex, and also some really hard moments. I think Bertie and **me** dug into our own thoughts and feelings, then used that to capture the emotions. So, the style and tone? they let us push the edges.
Dreamy scene yet somehow real; therefore you picture how far you could go if truly pushed.
Carvel, famous for playing Miss Trunchbull in the West End’s *Matilda*, says Mike Bartlett’s writing really excites him; the Doctor Foster plot — a real page‑turner?
"He builds characters that feel oddly deep," the actor says, moreover playing a role that changes in viewers eyes turned out to be really fun.
He notes, therefore you often end up looking at everything from a totally new perspective.
Renewable Heat Incentive may have been the straw that broke the camel's back but it was not the reason for the election.
"The reason for the election was the fact that Sinn Féin and republicanism wanted another crack at the election, they got the message out to the people.
"We fought a good campaign and we got a good response from the electorate. We will turn up at Stormont on Monday and there is work to be done.

I have said that if Sinn Féin do well we will all do well." "I argued that in a normal democracy people would vote on delivery and on that basis I didn't think either the DUP or Sinn Féin should have been returned to power ... Well, I have been given a pretty certain answer.
"I don't think I have the authority or the mandate to continue as leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, so I am standing down."
"This is a victory for those who laid down their arms, who said there is a better way to do things through devolution rather than Direct Rule, and through power sharing.

"Everybody needs to work together to ensure that we don't hand power back to Theresa May and James Brokenshire, hand control back to the British government, but we keep our power within our own Assembly." "It's been a good day for Alliance, all in all.

Nationally we look to have increased our vote, including in areas where we haven't typically performed so well, and these are signs that to continue in building [to] take the votes to him and to the restoration of devolution."

"The worry ... is this place as an institution is now under threat, the centre ground has been pushed out, non-sectarian government is being pushed out, the DUP and Sinn Féin will not share power with each other."
"There are mutual obligations on everyone to now engage intensively to try and get an Executive up and running and we've got to do that in a much-shortened time period.
"And I can say the UK Government goes into the days ahead with the best of intentions."
"Mike Nesbitt has done the right thing tonight. It saves horrible conversations within the party.
During any of the discussions that take place in the near future, it's going to be essentially a DUP-Sinn Féin discussion –the SDLP and the Ulster Unionists will be on the fringes."
"We are now in a position with these two parties almost neck-and-neck and I think that people will want to reflect on the voices that have been expressed throughout the course of the election.
Like every political party we will have some things that we need to learn from."
The high turnout "demonstrates that the people of Northern Ireland remain supportive of the institutions laid down in the Good Friday Agreement and the devolved power-sharing government".

The pledges are contained in the party's five-year government programme, which also promises more free childcare and more apprenticeships as well an M4 relief road and a South Wales Metro public transport scheme.
Plaid Cymru said the programme was "lacklustre", while the Conservatives said Labour had failed Wales.
Among the most expensive commitments are 30 hours of free childcare a week for parents of three and four-year-olds, available for 48 weeks a year, and 100,000 apprenticeships for all ages.

The programme sets out what the Labour-led Welsh Government wants to achieve, but details of cutbacks and where the axe is expected to fall will not emerge until October when the draft Welsh budget will be published.
A Welsh Government source indicated that a detailed review of spending is under way, partly because of financial uncertainty following the UK vote to leave the EU.
"Salami slicing will not do it this time," he said, suggesting that some projects and services will be pared back.
In an interview on BBC Radio Wales, the first minister said there would be cutbacks "because the budget we have is shrinking...
There will have to be difficult decisions in the future." He said schemes that had been running for a number of years might have to be looked at by ministers.
The "Taking Wales Forward" programme largely repeats commitments Labour made in its Welsh Assembly election manifesto in May.
Mr Jones hailed Labour's determination to deliver on its election pledges, including building an M4 relief road around Newport and developing a South Wales Metro.

He said: "There can be no doubt that Brexit brings economic and financial uncertainty but this ambitious programme for government makes clear that Labour's priorities are on driving the economy forward and improving public services; those things that matter most to people's everyday lives."

Answering questions about whether the programme confirmed Labour would go ahead with council mergers in England, Mr Jones referred to "wider local government reform" with "wider service delivery in the future".
The document includes three pledges from Plaid Cymru in return for Carwyn Jones's re-election as first minister.
Plaid Cymru AM and shadow economy secretary Rhun ap Iorwerth said it was evidence of the "gulf" between the two parties.
"A lacklustre manifesto has unsurprisingly led to a lacklustre government programme," Mr ap Iorwerth said.
An extra division of 20 teams is planned by the Football League from 2019-20 to create a five-division set-up of 100 teams, up from the current 92.
There are now 24 teams in the Championship, League One and League Two, and the Football League said the changes would ease fixture congestion and improve the finances of its members.
The plans have the backing "in principle" of the Premier League and Football Association.
Ninety per cent of the current 72 Football League clubs would need to agree to the proposal for it to proceed.
The issue will be lodged for decision at their annual general meeting in June 2017.

Football League chief executive Shaun Harvey told BBC Sport that the proposals present a "once in a generation opportunity" to do "what many of us feel is the right thing and create a more balanced professional game for the benefit of everyone".
"Fundamentally the Football League believes there are clear benefits for everyone that will make the whole of our league stronger, and that this is an idea that we should be taking forward," he said.

"This could be a significant moment in the recent history of English football and we'd like everyone who shares our passion for the game and what it means to our communities to start thinking about how we make this work for our game."
But response amongst Football League clubs themselves has been mixed. Accrington owner, Andrew Holt, tweeted that the plan has "no merit".
To Oxford United chairman Darryl Eales, it "nearly works but not quite", while former Leyton Orient chairman and sports promoter Barry Hearn said he felt the idea has some "merit".
Other club officials said they only learned of the plan on Wednesday and had not been consulted or fully briefed before it was made public on Thursday.
Some clubs also harbour genuine fear that the loss of fixtures would precipitate a financial crisis.
"We believe this is an idea that is in the best long-term interests of the leagues and one we would like to try and progress," said Harvey.

He added that the Football League had the support in principle of the Premier League and Football Association because the changes would have "potential benefits on an international basis", but added that "at the moment this is just an idea that we would like to manage through a proper process".
"The game as a whole needs to think collectively about its long-term future and we look forward to engaging with all parties in a positive debate about change," he said.
The FA said "it is clear the overall fixture calendar does need to be reviewed across English football for the benefit of all".

"Simply, the number of matches being played needs to be addressed across the game, whether a winter break is introduced or not," it added in a statement, saying only that it is "engaged" with the Football League and Premier League ".
On its part, the Premier League said it had been "involved in initial discussions" and will "contribute to future conversations".
Bradford City's joint-chairman Mark Lawn believes the current structure is right for most clubs and is against any changes.
His team is currently bidding to reach the Championship via the League One play-offs.
Lawn told BBC Sport that the proposals would mean a loss of at least three home games per season, compared with the current 23.
"How are we supposed to replace that revenue and how are we to be compensated for it?
They are going to have to come up with something very good to replace that revenue stream for the 72 clubs, including 11 that will no longer remain in the league," he said.

"If it isn't broken, why try to fix it?" Mark Devlin, chief executive of Brentford, currently playing in the Championship said: "Credit to the Football League for coming up with a really innovative and far-reaching approach to try to solve some of the issues facing Football League clubs.
"The debate and the consultation process could produce something that's really workable for Football League clubs."
The plans would need the backing of 65 Football League clubs by means of the 90% majority required to carry any motion to the league's AGM in June 2017.
The Football League board has made no recommendations for action to be taken, but is urging its members to fully consider the proposal.
Talks failed to produce an agreement on the sharing of river waters, after an intervention by the chief minister of India's West Bengal state.
Nor was there any agreement on Indian overland access across Bangladesh to India's north-eastern states.

On the positive side, there was progress for "stateless border people". The two countries pledged to start the process of incorporating nearly 50 Bangladeshi enclaves inside India into Bangladesh and over 100 small pockets of Indian areas inside Bangladesh into India.
The people living there will be able to choose to become Indian or Bangladeshi under "a protocol between the states", with details to be hammered out later, officials said.

BBC Bengali editor Sabir Mustafa says that the failure to reach an agreement on the sharing of water from the Teesta river is a blow to Bangladeshi leader Sheikh Hasina, who put her political reputation on the line to get the agreement.
"The relations between the countries are now at their best since the early 1970s, when India helped Bangladesh's independence from Pakistan," Sabir Mustafa says.
"But that bonhomie is hiding growing discomfort over the contours of the new relationship.
"The concern is that the current Indian leadership might be building a relationship based more on an alliance with Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina's Awami League rather than the state of Bangladesh.
"If the opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) comes to power or forms part of a coalition, as now seems likely, that could sour the relationship.
"There is also growing discomfort in Bangladesh over what is seen as Sheikh Hasina's undue willingness to accommodate Indian demands."

Some of the gloss was taken off the visit - the first by a sitting Indian prime minister for 12 years - after India indicated at the last moment that a major agreement on sharing river water would not be reached.

Instead, they agreed merely to look at the issue again in future. Mr Singh said after the talks that "substantial progress has been made on the sharing of water of common rivers" but that "these issues will need to be pursued further".
Most analysts say the deal did not come off because of last-minute objections from the chief minister of the Indian state of West Bengal, Mamata Banerjee.
She is reported to believe that India is proposing to give Bangladesh too much water.
Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg has confirmed Peter Thiel will remain on its board, even though Thiel is seeking to "fight back against Gawker-style bullying".
Mr Thiel has been accused of using his money to seek to shut down sections of the press.
That could be awkward for Facebook, which relies on the press to share articles on its page, to create videos it can distribute exclusively, and to sell advertising.
"Peter did what he did on his own, not as a Facebook board member," Ms Sandberg said while speaking at the Code Conference - a showcase for tech companies - in California.
"We're an independent board. Members do speak out when they wish... on the board there are strong, and very, very diverse perspectives, which make Facebook stronger."
Even so, some analysts have wondered whether he'll be able to remain a board member at Facebook, where he was one of the first investors.

"Facebook would never have thought of itself as a publisher, it would have always thought of itself as a tech company, but increasingly it has some of the duties and responsibilities to the public sphere of being a publisher," says Steve Hewlett, media consultant and presenter for the BBC Radio 4 Media Show.
"If Facebook is a tech company, it's not really a problem. If it's a publisher, then it's a massive conflict.
How would anyone respond to a billionaire member of the Times board or the BBC board launching law suits for vexatious reasons to shut down other places?"
The Gawker feud goes back to 2007, when an article was published titled: Peter Thiel is totally gay, people.

Mr Thiel recently revealed to the New York Times that he's financially supporting a legal team which represents people he described as the "victims" of Gawker's journalism - none of the cases are related to technology or Facebook business.

He described them as "philanthropic" lawsuits to encourage "greater reform". First known victim of that effort: wrestler Hulk Hogan, who won $140m after the publication of a video showing him having sex in what should have been the privacy of a friend's home.

Gawker is now appealing that decision, which threatens its existence. Gawker founder Nick Denton has disputed whether Thiel should even be a Facebook board member, asking in an open letter to Thiel: "You are a board member of Facebook... have your personal views... on politics, the press and Silicon Valley influenced corporate decisions?"
The donation of 64m Microsoft shares, about 5% of his fortune, means he is still the world’s richest man.
Mr Gates, 61, and his wife, Melinda, have made charitable donations of $35bn since 1994.
The latest donation was made in June but became public on Monday following a filing with the US Securities and Exchange Commission.
Mr Gates owns 1.3% of Microsoft. He has made two larger donations in 1999 ($16bn) and 2000 ($5.1bn).
The pair’s previous donations have mostly funded the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which works to tackle global poverty and disease.
Their foundation also backs educational projects and initiatives to expand access to information technology.
Advertisement It is not clear who is benefitting from the donation, but federal filings often reveal donations to charitable foundations, according to the Chronicle of Philanthropy.
In 2010, Mr and Mrs Gates and Warren Buffet – the investor and philanthropist – created the Giving Pledge.
1 58 people or couples have signed up to the commitment to give away at least 50% of their wealth to charitable causes as of May 2017.
They included the US billionaire Elon Musk and Richard Branson, the UK-based founder of the Virgin Group.
Monday’s donation is the biggest charitable donation of 2017, the Chronicle of Philanthropy said.
The second biggest came from Mr Buffett, who gave nearly $3.2bn to the Gates Foundation in July.
The third largest came from Michael Dell, the founder of Dell Computer Corporation, and his wife Susan.
They donated more than $1bn in May to their foundation, which focuses on children’s issues and community initiatives.
Kepler-452b, as it has been named, is orbiting a close cousin of our own sun, which puts out about 20% more light than our own star.

The planet’s size – 60% greater than Earth’s radius – and its distance from its star would place it in our solar system’s habitable zone, where liquid water could exist on the surface, so is of interest to astronomers looking for extraterrestrial life.
Indeed, mission scientists have hailed it as our nearest twin and the most Earth-like planet yet found.

John Grunsfeld, associate administrator at Nasa’s Science Mission Directorate called it “Earth 2.0” and on Twitter Jeff Coughlin, Kepler research scientist at SETI said it is “the closest so far,” to Earth.

At a distance of 1,400 light years away from us, what this discover really shows, said Jon Jenkins, Kepler data analysis lead at Nasa's Ames Research Center in California is that “we are getting close."
Introducing the newly discovered planet at a press conference on Thursday, Jenkins called Kepler-452b “a new kid on the block, if one of the same age and disposition of our own.

It is a great place to live, if it is rocky.” Kepler-452b has certain similarities with another exoplanet, Kepler-186f, which made headlines in 2014 when it was considered the first truly habitable Earth-like planet.
However, Kepler-186f is smaller and circles a red dwarf, a star far dimmer and cooler than the sun, whereas Kepler-452b orbits a sun-like star, only 4% more massive and 10% brighter than our own.
The planet’s year lasts 385 days, only 5% longer than the Earth’s. The mass of the Kepler-452b cannot be measured yet, though models predict it to be around five times the mass of the Earth.
In that case, said Jenkins, it would have more than twice Earth's gravity, and would likely still be able to hold on to a thick atmosphere and have active volcanism.
Not only are astronomers celebrating the existence of Kepler-452b, but also the planet is one of a group of 500 possible planets identified by the Kepler space telescope, which was launched in 2009.
All of Kepler’s potential planets require confirmation that they are indeed planets, and so far, half of these have been, including Kepler-452b.
Of the 500 new potential planets, 12 are less than twice Earth’s diameter, and exist in the so called “habitable zone” of its star.
This region on the edge of a star system, often called the “Goldilocks” zone, is the right distance from a star to allow the existence of liquid water, given appropriate atmospheric conditions.

Dr Suzanne Aigrain, a lecturer in Astrophysics at the University of Oxford, who is not part of the Kepler teams says “Kepler-452b has the dubious honour of having the most Earth-like properties of any exoplanet to date which has been confirmed as a bona fide planet.
The side story is that they add another batch of planets to the extensive Kepler planet catalogue.
This time they list 12 which have radii which are below twice Earth's radius, and are in the so-called habitable zone.
A Inverness local claims his former boss just ignoring his messages, apparently on purpose.
James Nicol says he was exposed to asbestos while working on council houses in the 1980s.
Therefore, he asks the Highland Council to acknowledge that exposure. Can they talk about Mr. Nicol?
No, the local authority says they can’t comment, saying any claim would be handled by a solicitor, so they stay quiet.
Now 85, Mr. Nicol was a laborer for the agency once called Highland Regional Council, which today goes by Highland Council.
He says he ran into asbestos while repairing council properties in Inverness. Later he also ended up as the school janitor, hired by the regional council.
Diagnosed in March, he had mesothelioma — a terminal lung cancer, almost always tied to asbestos. While swimming he felt his health dip, therefore he go see the doctor.
**“I could swim, just slower; therefore I had to see my GP,” Mr. Nicol told BBC Scotland.
** After I saw my GP, therefore I was in Aberdeen getting x‑rays, scans plus a biopsy.

The hospital at Raigmore in Inverness finally confirmed his illness; the doctor stared at him and said, therefore, “It’s all bad, Mr. Nicol—no cure.” Even though he still gets a local authority pension, Mr. Nicol claim Highland Council ignored the letters from his solicitor about his condition.
Therefore a Highland Council spokesperson says: *can’t comment on this.* Appointed a solicitor to sue Highland Council—communication?
It runs through the solicitor, not the claimant. Founded in 1984 to help shipyard workers, Clydeside Action on Asbestos now reaches people in all kinds of jobs—especially more women.
Phyllis Craig, senior welfare rights officer, says we’re seeing a lot of construction workers; teachers, nurses and doctors also turn up, and even police and fire staff appear.
She flagged the myth that women only met asbestos by cleaning their husbands' overalls—still women in hospitals or schools faced the same threat as men, therefore the danger wasn’t only on them?
Scotland’s new laws? They hand sufferers and their families more rights than you’ll find in the rest of the UK, therefore relief finally shows up.
**Annie McGhee—formerly a textile factory employee in Motherwell—maybe eligible for a single government payment, therefore?**

It’s another Tuesday in “normal Tuesday” Northern Ireland, where there is good domination of political stories on today’s front pages despite the ticking having supposedly stopped around 4 yesterday afternoon.

The Belfast Telegraph lets of a righteous howl of indignation over the failure of MLAs to “sort out their differences”, suggesting “PAY OFF MLAs AFTER 3 MONTHS IF NO DEAL”: For a full year, this rolls in at an annual cost to the taxpayer over £13.5m – the same as the catastrophic Renewable Heating Incentive scheme that has brought down the power-sharing executive.

Former Assistant Chief Constable Alan McQuillan says that the public will be outraged if the MLAs are allowed to keep their noses in the Stormont trough in the prolonged absence of an executive function at Stormont: “We have thousands of jobs under threat and our services under massive threat because politicians can’t do their jobs.

“People are deeply frustrated at the failure to reach a deal, so if the MLAs weren’t working and would be on full wages for months, people would be really angry.” Political commentator Malachi O’Doherty writes after the British Government placed the mainstream parties here in the North on “hothouse hot!” Mr [James] Brokenshire, the Secretary of State, is in a hard place.
He has to find a way forward and prepare the Province for it. A wrong step might deepen the divide.

The Bel Tel also carries a report that the family of a “Missing Londonderry man faces anxious wait” to find if a body found in the River Foyle on Monday is that of 23-year-old Jack Glenn who vanished earlier on a night out on February 2.

Our compatriots in the News Letter use their “Morning View” front page editorial to launch an assault on Sinn Féin for “holding Northern Ireland ‘to ransom’?” At what point does London stop being distracted by pleadings from Dublin and instead recognise that a party with 72% of the electorate opposed to it cannot be allowed to steer the Province’s future towards one of indifference to the consequences if it fails?

London is always cowed by the notion that it might lead to violence. While this is unlikely to materialise, the government cannot continue to act like a coward because of the possibility of such a recurrence.

The News Letter assures its readers that this stance taken is “hardly the product of sectarian partisans” and that in its independent exposure of the shenanigans over the RHI, “Northern Ireland now has a large problem again, over governance.”
The 23-year-old goalkeeper, on loan from Chelsea, was the Chairboys' match-winning penalty shootout hero when Blackpool were knocked out of the EFL Trophy here in January.
And on this occasion, with just four minutes to go, Blackman again came to his side's rescue, keeping out Potts' spot-kick to guarantee his team a point.
Adebayo Akinfenwa had the first chance of the game on 10 minutes but fired over the top.
Then at the mid-point of the first half, Potts launched a speculative effort that grazed the top of Jamal Blackman's crossbar.
Three minutes before the interval, Paris Cowan-Hall tested Blackpool keeper Dean Lyness, but his low effort was comfortably kept out.
Not long after the restart Blackman again showed why he is rated so highly by keeping out another Potts effort on the line, despite Blackpool protests that the ball had crossed the line.
And Blackman's man of the match display was capped off with his stunning late stop to keep out Potts' close-range effort.

A MAN who stabbed a ‘blameless’ pensioner after a low-speed car crash was suffering from undiagnosed paranoid schizophrenia, a court has been told.
Matthew Daley, 35, admits stabbing Donald Lock, 79, in Findon near Worthing in July last year on the grounds of diminished responsibility, but denies murder.

On the third day of his trial at Lewes Crown Court, jurors heard that while he was thought to have suffered from Asperger’s syndrome, Daley has a long-standing paranoid schizophrenic illness which lay undetected for years.
It has led him to be sectioned under the Mental Health Act. Forensic psychiatrist Dr Roderick Ley was called in to examine Daley following the incident.

Former solicitor Mr Lock was repeatedly knifed in the head, back, neck, chest and arms on the A24 in West Sussex on July 16 after his Toyota collided at about 16mph with the back of Daley’s Ford Fusion.
The great-grandfather, who days earlier was told he had been given the all-clear from prostate cancer, died at the scene.
Daley brought his car to an emergency stop in a 40mph zone, forcing keen cyclist Mr Lock to brake sharply, the court has already been told.

During the course of the trial, jurors have been told the defendant, previously of St Elmo Road, Worthing, had suffered from mental health problems for about 10 years and that his family had urged professionals to section him for treatment.

Dr Ley said yesterday: “I do not believe he has ever suffered from Asperger’s syndrome, I think that diagnosis is wrong.” He added: “Mr Daley has a long-standing paranoid schizophrenic illness which remained undiagnosed until relatively recently.
“I don’t think he is continuously psychotic. He has a tendency to ‘down play’ the extent of his psychopathology.

He has somewhat ‘narcissistic’, ‘histrionic’ and ‘self-centred’ personality traits and I don’t think he will ever completely get better.” Dr Ley added: “In my opinion, at the time of the incident he was suffering relapsed psychotic illness.” However, consultant forensic psychiatrist Dr Philip Joseph said his opinion – after assessing all the evidence – was that Daley was not in a psychotic state during the stabbing.
Jurors yesterday also heard from the defendant’s father, John Daley, who said his son was a “nice guy”, liked family pets and was a “scrupulously honest” man who found it hard to tell lies.

Mr Daley, of Long Furlong, Findon, told the court he became concerned for the future of his son as he began to hear voices and that he started a detailed journal to keep track of how the public services were treating him.
He said: “I did it because I was so concerned about his future and I didn’t want to look back in my 80s wondering, ‘What did I do?’” The trial continues.

‘Astounding’: Police and MI5 believe the stolen documents could endanger life, it is claimed Picture: Paul Faith/PA Wire Download The Policing Board is facing questions in the wake of the arrest of a former ombudsman investigator over the alleged theft of secret security papers, as police and MI5 believe the documents may contain information that could endanger life.
The Police Federation of Northern Ireland ( PFNI) called described the move as "astounding and very worrying".
Detectives from the PSNI's Serious Crime Branch arrested a 69-year-old man in Dartford, Kent, on Sunday on suspicion of theft following a joint search operation with local officers.
It is understood the man in question has been retired from the ombudsman's office for a number of years and the paperwork is not connected to any current cases he was involved with.
Mark Lindsay, chair of the PFNI, said yesterday that been treating police officers fairly was crucial.

Asked if he believed everyone was treated fairly in the ombudsman's office, Lindsay said: "That is why we have been asking the [Stormont's Justice] minister, and the [Police] Ombudsman to look at the police complaints legislation, and to look at it properly to see how we could reform it "Police officers need the same safeguards any other members of the community and that certainly is not provided within the ombudsman's office at the minute," he said, speaking on Good Morning Ulster on BBC Radio Ulster, the Belfast Telegraph reports .
He said that while the Police Ombudsman’s office was indispensible, "it has to be accountable" and "police officers have to have confidence in it".
Police have begun a criminal investigation and stopped passing further top secret material to the ombudsman's office until its security measures have been reviewed.
Ulster Unionist MP Tom Elliott believes the ombudsman's office must answer questions.
"Clearly, if there is any alleged wrongdoing here then PSNI should be involved at an earlier stage that might provide some form of independence to any investigations," Elliott said.
He added that he did not want to see an end to the Police Ombudsman’s set-up but "there is clearly some gap here that needs to be resolved".
Newswatch The BBC quotes a spokesman for the ombudsman as saying that police contacted him last week to inform him of the theft of sensitive material from his office.
The Police Ombudsman’s office added that it was understood that the block on passing further material will last only long enough for the review to be conducted.
Viewers were finally given the resolution they had been waiting for, when Hart’s eponymous heroine got married.
The last ever episode drew a series high of 7.3 million in the overnight figures, beating the first part of the finale on Christmas Day, which drew 6.7 million.
Neela Debnath of The Independent said the show’s ending was “sweet and heart-warming” with more than a few “unexpected emotional” and “tender” moments thrown in between the pratfalls.
The episode saw Miranda standing up to her mother before realising what she really wanted in life and being true to herself.

Gerard O'Donovan of The Telegraph wrote: “With a whoop and a grin and a skip and hug, we finally got all the laughs and all the good vibes we could possibly have wanted last night in a finale episode that was a masterclass in romantic comedy writing and performance when it led to a wedding” Mark Lawson in The Guardian wrote: “Miranda (BBC1) gave her fans two classic pratfalls in her festive farewell.

Her tantalising potential, beyond this sharply scripted and performed sitcom, suggests that reviewers may not see her fall metaphorically.” Just before the final show aired, Hart tweeted: “Happy New Year Day and goodbye to my baby (eight) day.

8pm BBC One. Now I can't guarantee it- but you MIGHT spot [Gary Barlow] on tonight's show.” The sitcom, which originally aired on BBC Two in 2009 before moving to BBC One, stars Hart as a joke shop proprietor who struggles with regularly dropping social faux-pas.
co-stars include Patricia Hodge as Miranda’s mother, and Sarah Hadland as the assistant manager of the shop.
Both the show and Hart have won awards from the Royal Television Society Awards and the British Comedy Awards.
The first episode of Miranda series three was the most-watched television programme on Christmas Day 2012.

The 41-year-old actress, who has downplayed speculation that she is poised to be the next Great British Bake Off host, will next be seen in the American spy comedy Spy, with Jude Law and Melissa McCartney, directed by Bridesmaids director Paul Feig and released in the UK in May.
Hart will also released her second personal book, Peggy And Me, based on her life with her dog, Peggy, later this year.

Haye-Hearn spoke to 34-year-old WBC cruiserweight champion Tony Bellew, who stopped David Haye in a shock win at heavyweight last month, about the potential of a fight with WBA and IBF champion Joshua, 27 - and the Liverpudlian replied: "You are having a laugh.
I don't need that. He is too good." Bellew's promoter, Eddie Hearn, mentioned a possible clash with WBO champion Joseph Parker as the more likely scenario.
New Zealander Parker, 25, defends against Romania's Razvan Cojanu in Auckland next weekend.
Bellew said in the wake of Joshua's win: "I still have this dream of winning a heavyweight world title, but it's a different one from what AJ holds now."
Bellew said he is contemplating retirement after his win over Haye last month, having moved up to the heavyweight division for the fight.
On an encounter with Parker, he added: "I'm sure Eddie knows what he is doing."
Hearn told Sportsweek on BBC Radio 5 live there was "no interest" in a Bellew-Joshua fight as they are "good friends".
Bellew is not a natural heavyweight, and stepped up from the cruiserweight division to face David Haye in March.
Bellew weighed 96.6 kg (15st 3oz) for the fight, and Joshua was a career-heaviest 113 kg (17st 12lb) on Saturday - almost 20kg heavier than his compatriot.
Deontay Wilder, who holds the WBC heavyweight title and has a unification fight with Joshua on his radar, is also a possibility for Bellew - if he was to overcome Parker.
He said: "I want to bring that WBO belt back and after I take care of my mandatory fights, we can make a big fight at the beginning of the next year."
He was called by President Ashraf Ghani after he first told his story to the BBC.

Columnist: Inayatulhaq Yasini BBC Pashto A man named Jahangir whose wife was allegedly raped in Badakhshan province, in the north-west of Afghanistan, eight years ago, says he has not been able to have those who gang-raped her arrested because they have political power.
Speaking to BBC Persian, his wife said: "I begged those who raped me and said 'For the sake of Allah, I just gave birth and I am like your son, even your daughter is older than my age'.
"They hit me really badly. Even after many years I could still show you their teeth marks on my body."
Jahangir decided to break the silence, often maintained around sexual crime in Afghanistan, and tell his story of what happened to his wife.

The publicity his story received prompted President Ghani personally to assure Jahangir that that he would make sure the whole case is properly investigated by the courts and the culprits are arrested.
"I want justice for my case because I don't want others to do the same to other women in the country," his wife told the BBC.
The attention the couple received in Afghanistan also compels the Afghan government to look at the case and try to find a solution.
His and his wife's bravery in choosing to speak publically might also inspire others to do the same and have some impact on how such cases are dealt with.
Jahangir, a policeman, told the BBC that initially eight men were arrested, but only two now remain in custody.
Most of them, he says, have now been freed, because they are parliamentarians or have political support.
Last week, Jahangir and his family who say they fear for their own lives came to Kabul.
He appeared on Afghan TV and told viewers that unless the government arrests "powerful culprits, who raped my wife, I will commit suicide".
"If they are not brought to trial, then I have no choice but to end my life," Jahangir told the BBC.
This week Jahangir met the ministry of interior to raise his case with officials.
And while he was speaking to the BBC he got another call from President Ghani. Jahangir started to cry while he was on the call.
Mr Ghani was sworn in as Afghan president in September. He made tackling corruption one of his priorities.
While political corruption and crimes against women do exist in Afghanistan, usually, they don't receive much attention.
One of the exceptions was seen in October when five men convicted of gang-raping four women were hanged, prompting national protest.
There were 99,293 students in further education (FE) colleges in 2013/14, according to the Department for the Economy (DfE).
However, by 2015/16 that had dropped to 82,818. There was a similar 15% fall in the number of enrolments in FE colleges in the same time frame, as the same student can enrol on more than one course.
In total, the DfE said there were 180,825 enrolments in colleges in 2013/14 compared with 154,817 in 2015/16.
The worst affected college was Belfast Metropolitan College (BMC), which had 36,685 enrolments in 2014/15.
That number dropped to 28,514 in 2015/16 - a fall of 22.3%. BMC did not give a response on the figures.

'Loophole removed' Meanwhile the president of the NUS-USI student union movement, Fergal McFerran, said the "staggering drop" in FE enrolments meant the executive "must invest substantially more in tertiary education and student support" in the next budget.
The smallest reduction in enrolments of any college between 2013/14 and 2015/16 was South Eastern Regional College, which saw a drop of 8.3% to 32,858 enrolments.

Further Education colleges: Number of enrolments by year and by college - Ballymena Limavady Ibermagee Belfast Bangor Bangor Lisanally Court Street Antrim 2015/2016 2014/2015 2013/2014 NICVA A number of reasons have been suggested for the fall.

Colleges run a number of different courses for numerous types of students. Up to date figures Including 'facilitated' enrolments and courses Source: BBC However, BBC News NI understands that one reason for the drop is that FE colleges have had to operate within a reduced budget, leading to some courses and staff being cut.

More than 400 staff were offered voluntary redundancy in 2015/16. "Other FE-related savings exercises include a reduction in the volume of leisure/non-regulated provision in order to meet enrolment targets set out in the FE Means Business targets," said a spokeswoman for BMC.
'Education is critical' A reduction in leisure and non-regulated courses has affected enrolments from people who are often lifelong part-time learners.
According to DfE's own figures, the number of enrolments on non-regulated courses fell from 39,000 in 2013/14 to about 24,500.
That followed a policy called "Further Education Means Business" instigated by DfE in 2014, to get colleges to concentrate courses more on those it sees as essential to the economy.
Gerry Campbell, the chief executive of Colleges NI, said that "Further Education is key to Northern Ireland's future economic prosperity".
"Over the past three years there has been a steady decline in the number of leisure and/or residential courses, which is in line with DfE policy, as well as reductions in further education budgets.

'A delay is worrying' "Nevertheless, colleges have been increasing the number of economically relevant courses and are actively working with local employers to identify and to provide the right skills these businesses need," Mr Campbell said.
A spokeswoman for the Department of the Economy also said that: "The budget for FE colleges for 2015/16 was reduced by some 10m".
Sterling initially pulled back some of its losses, but markets think the pound would fall if we pull out.
Markets expect that there would be a sharp fall in sterling if we were to vote for Brexit.
There is a reason for this based on the fact that most (not all) serious economists think our economic performance would be damaged by leaving the EU (EU membership - effects on trade… UK Economy).

In part, this is a fear of uncertainty while new arrangements are negotiated: for a while we won't know how easy it will be for British exporters to sell into the EU market and it might get aimed harder to sell to that market.

Foreign investment might dry up while the uncertainty persists. And we have a large current account deficit; this is a term covering Britain’s trade (buying and selling goods and services) plus some flows of money round the world.
Because it is in deficit, we need to borrow or attract foreign investors to buy sterling financial assets.
If people start to think that we might lose from Brexit, foreign investors might only be prepared to fund the current account deficit at a lower price for sterling.

There is a contrary view (Economists for Brexit launch, with optimism) not shared by most economists, that the UK would do just fine outside the EU but for the time being and particularly in the short run, markets are likely to focus on what a majority of economists believe.
That is likely to determine what happens to the exchange rate for sterling in the short term.
Our reports on the currency markets typically focus on spot rates - the exchange rate if you want to buy currency now.

But there is another dimension: you can also buy options, which as the name suggests, confers the right rather than an obligation to buy or sell currency (or other financial assets) in future at a specific price (the strike price).

This provides a form of insurance over currency values. If the change you anticipated doesn't happen, you just don't exercise the option; with insurance, your house didn't burn down, but you still paid the premium.
And this part of the market already suggests that investors think a leave vote would have a depressing impact on sterling.

Neil Trotter preyed on females at Edinburgh’s Waverley Station and in Buchanan Galleries, in Glasgow, between June and September last year.Trotter, 54, from Falkirk, was told by a sheriff that “women should be able to go about their business without fear” as he was jailed.Trotter, who was also put on the sex offenders register for 10 years at the sentencing hearing, previously admitted committing a breach of the peace aggravated by sexual motivation at Edinburgh Sheriff Court.Prosecutor Aidan Higgins said Trotter travelled in to Edinburgh by train every day for his work and on Monday, September 29 a commuter had seen him acting “in a curious, a sinister manner” on an escalator at Waverley Station.He added: “The accused deliberately attempted to position himself close behind the female travelling immediately ahead of him on the escalator.”The fiscal said the witness saw Trotter holding his phone at an angle “so that he was clearly apparently taking photographs under the skirt” of the woman.The commuter told British Transport Police about his suspicions and Trotter was identified from CCTV and arrested the next day as he got off the train.Trotter’s mobile phone and computer were examined and Mr Higgins said Trotter “is seen on various occasions using his mobile phone between June 11 2014 and September 29, 2014”.He added: “The phone contains 22 video clips depicting up the skirts of women.”Defence solicitor Neil Hay said Trotter was “most ashamed of his actions” and completely accepted “no woman should be subjected to this appalling behaviour”.He added: “He has lost his career, all but financially ruined his family, and brought squalor and social disgrace on himself and his loved ones”.Sheriff Peter Braid jailed Trotter for 18 months.He said: “You have pled guilty to taking images of women in a clandestine fashion for reasons, it turns out, stem from your voyeuristic tendencies to achieve sexual gratification.“It is true, as your counsel says, that no actual sexual offence is libelled.

However it does seem to me that planning went into the commission of the offence, which on the Crown narrative lasted for over three months and was carried out in public places.“Women should be able to go about their business in public places without fear.
Providing a deterrent is required to reflect public disquiet at offences of this nature.“I can see no alternative to a custodial sentence, both by way of punishment and deterrence.”More on this topic
David Cameron said a stadium would "inspire young people and bring jobs and wealth" to the county.
The Labour Party called it a "cynical" attempt to distract voters, the Liberal Democrats questioned where money would come from and Mebyon Kernow has questioned the Tory commitment.
The future of the stadium has been thrown into uncertainty by a row over planning.
Cornwall council members deferred a decision in March over whether to grant permission for a superstore that would help fund the stadium, putting the plans in doubt, according to supporters.
Amended plans for the stadium at West Langarth are due to be submitted to the council in May.
Mr Cameron said the Department of Culture, Media and Sport will work with Sport England, Cornwall Council and local sports teams to help build it.
"This stadium is a great proposal, we should make it happen. And if we need to put in more money, I'm prepared to say that that money will be there," he said.
Stuart Roden, Labour candidate for Truro and Falmouth, said: "The Tory prime ministerial announcement on the stadium is a cynical empty promise which will come to nothing.
This is a cloud of smoke with no substance and voters in Cornwall will not be conned with this unfunded distraction."
Simon Rix, Lib Dem candidate for the seat, told BBC News: "I want to see it in the right location and the money available.
But, like their pledges on the NHS, the Conservatives are not saying where the money would come from."
Stephen Richardson, Mebyon Kernow candidate for Truro and Falmouth said: "You'll have to forgive me if I don't believe a single word of anything David Cameron says during the election campaign."

Jamie Robinson told BBC World Have Your Say staff "deserted" those on board and locked themselves in a service compartment.
His comments corroborate a statement by French actor Jean-Hugues Anglade who described being crushed against a metal partition and calls from passengers going unheeded.
The attack happened on a high-speed train travelling from Amsterdam to Paris on Friday.

Mr Robinson said he first realised something was wrong when, moments after the Thalys train departed Brussels, three train staff came sprinting down his carriage, number 11 - the one next to the carriage in question where the attacker emerged.
"They said nothing. There was a man and two women," said Mr Robinson, a medical physicist.
"They looked alarmed, they did not look in control. They ran to the end of my carriage, opened a service door and locked it behind them."
He said his carriage was the last on the train and the locked door led to a section only staff are allowed.
Moments later people started running back from carriage 12, some injured, others ly shout there was a man with a gun firing at people.
"We were left trapped in there, roughly 20 to 30 of us including Jean-Hugues Anglade and his family.

We were left in the dark," said Mr Robinson. Mr Anglade, who sustained a hand injury trying to activate the train's emergency alarm, also described the train staff locking themselves in a private cabin.
He said they would not communicate with passengers and could have led people "at least to the baggage department".
He told Paris Match (in French): "We called out to the staff, in vain. No-one responded.

There was a lack of courage and it was terrible." Thalys transport's company president and chief executive responded by saying an internal investigation would be carried out and that on-board staff would have to "account for their behaviour in those dramatic minutes".
Mr Robinson said at this point somebody entered the carriage and told them a gunman had been stopped, which "was massively reassuring".
After 10 minutes of terror, this man was initially greeted with scepticism, Mr Robinson told me.
This man introduce himself as Anthony and was later identified as Anthony Sadler, one of the Americans who helped overpower the attacker.
Mr Robinson said afterwards there was an "explosion of relief", as people were left in disbelief and shock.
Passengers were told to stay quiet and not move until the train came to a halt at Arras station, where suspect Ayoub El-Khazzani, a 25-year-old Moroccan, was arrested.

There have been calls for Douglas Ross to be sacked as the party’s justice spokesman after missing a meeting of the justice committee at Holyrood because of his duties as an assistant referee at a football match between Sporting Lisbon and Real Madrid on Tuesday.
According to his Scottish Parliament register of interests, Mr Ross could earn up to £40,000 as a self-employed specialist assistant football referee.
He also holds a third position as a councillor on Moray Council. His trip to Portugal also meant he was not at the council’s policy and resources committee on Tuesday.
The SNP MSP Ben Macpherson said this was not the first time refereeing commitments had clashed with parliamentary business.
He said it was reported that Mr Ross had missed a key vote due to World Cup referee training in Switzerland.
“The arrogance and sheer chutzpah of ‘three jobs’ Tory Douglas Ross is stunning,” said Macpherson.
“The last time he dodged his responsibilities because of his weekend job as a football referee, the Tories said it was a ‘one-off’.
This time it’s a clear red card and a sending off. “His larger £40k-a-year weekend job and flying to Lisbon is more important to him than his Holyrood or his council titles.
He is clearly treating voters with contempt. “If Douglas Ross can’t fulfil his Holyrood or council title, it’s time he gave up refereeing on the side.
But at the very least, he should be booted from the Holyrood justice committee.

It’s time Ruth Davidson took action and booted him from her frontbench.” A Scottish Conservatives spokesman said: “Earlier this year, Ben Macpherson offered Douglas an invite to come and talk about refereeing to clubs and his constituency. We assume that offer no longer stands.” Mr Ross was unavailable for comment.
Surface ponds on the Khumbu Glacier in the Himalayas have merged to form larger lakes.
The glacier is the first hurdle climbers on Mt Everest have to cross, including the dangerous Khumbu Icefall.
Rapid melting of glaciers in the Himalayas is a cause for concern as global temperatures rise.
Scientists say this is a new phenomenon for Khumbu, though other glaciers in the Himalayas have already grown large, surface-lakes.
The lakes can burst, causing downstream flooding and loss of life and property.
This is the first scientific expedition to the area since last April's devastating earthquake.

"Yes, there were ponds on this debris-covered glacier some 10 years ago but in the last five years they have started to grow and connect with each other," said Ann Rowan, who came from the universities of Sheffield and Leeds to lead the field survey.
Chain reaction She specialises in physical geography and is particularly interested in studying debris-covered glacier such as the Khumbu glacier.
She added, "In particular, on the left side of the lower part of the glacier, there are now some seven or eight ponds which are quite big and they are just starting to join and make the chain.
"The melt-water from the upper part of the glacier is moving through these ponds which allow them to merge.
At the moment, this glacier is just falling apart and could form into a couple of really big lakes."
Dr Rowan has studied 15 years of satellite images of the Khumbu glacier and done on-the-ground surveys three times since 2009.

She says although there is no considerable retreat, mainly in the lower debris-covered part of the glacier, it is lowering because of ice melt underneath which enables water bodies to form and to expand.
Their research indicates that in the last 15 years the glacier has on average lowered around two meters a year.
Unlike elsewhere in the world, most Himalayan glaciers are not beautiful smooth bodies of ice - they are covered with debris like sand, gravel, and rocks.

Scientists say due to increasing temperatures, most glaciers in the Himalayas have already started to lose ice on their upper parts in close proximity to the peaks, causing a decline in the amount of ice that flows downstream to lower sections of glaciers. This is leading to thinning of the glaciers.

'A group of Asian men treated me like an adult and I didn’t think I could say no’ Basharat Hussain (left) and Qurban Ali are among seven defendants in the historic case A child victim of one of Britain’s worst paedophile gangs told a court today she was 12 when she was plucked from a care home and abused by Basharat Hussain and two other men. She also spoke of being taken to Blackpool where several men raped her.

Mr Hussain denies the offences. He is one of 7 individuals being tried for alleged child abuse in Rotherham Sheffield Crown Court heard the witness, who cannot be named for legal reasons, say first abuse took place when Mr Hussain and multiple other Asian men took her and a friend out for breakfast.

“I felt like an adult,” she added. “We were taken out for breakfast. I felt I couldn t really say no.” The witness added that when she was 16 she was taken to Blackpool to help in a restaurant, which prosecutors claim was arranged by Mr Hussain.
She said she remained there for two months being forced to have sex almost every day, returning to Rotherham with several forms of sexual disease.
Arshid Hussain, 40, of High Street, East Cowick, Goole, East Riding of Yorkshire, is accused of 30 offences including five counts of rape.
Qurban Ali, 53, of Clough Road, Masborough, Rotherham, is accused of four offences including rape and conspiracy to rape.
Majid Bostan, 37, of Ledsham Road, Rotherham, is accused of indecent assault. Sajid Bostan, 38, of Broom Avenue, Rotherham, is accused of seven offences, including four counts of rape.
Basharat Hussain, 39, who has no fixed address, is accused of 15 offences, including two counts of rape.

Karen MacGregor, 58, of Barnsley Road, Wath, South Yorkshire, is accused of four offences including conspiracy to rape; and Shelley Davies, 40, of Wainwright Road, Kimberworth Park, Rotherham, is accused of three offences including conspiracy to rape.

The witness was questioned by Gillian Batts, defending Hssain: Batts: “The truth is you have never met Basharat Hussain have you?” Witness: “Yes, I have.” The court has heard Mr Hussain was one of a group of seven people who were complicit in the sexual exploitation of children between 1987 and 2003.
They were allegedly uniquely targeting, sexualising and subjecting children to debasing and violent acts. The trial continues.

The Home Office said the Detained Fast Track (DFT) system would be suspended amid concerns over safeguards, particularly for "vulnerable applicants".
Immigration minister James Brokenshire said he hoped the DFT system would be up and running again in weeks.
About 800 applicants will be able to apply for bail with about 100 possibly requiring release from detention.
The DFT was introduced in 2000 to speed up legal hearings and appeals, with applicants kept in detention centres.

Officials used it where they believed a case was relatively straightforward. In June, the Court of Appeal ordered the system to be suspended immediately after a High Court judge ruled it was "structurally unfair".
But Mr Justice Nicol, sitting in the High Court, placed a "legal stay" - or temporary delay - on his ruling on 12 June after a case by the campaign group Detention Action.
This meant the system could continue to operate until all appeals to higher courts had been resolved.
BBC home affairs correspondent Danny Shaw said officials were worried that they could not prove that the procedures they were using were robust.
Making a ministerial statement to be placed on the record of the House of Commons, Mr Brokenshire said the system was facing "significant legal challenge".
"It has become clear that there are risks of unfairness in the operation of the DFT," he said.

"There is particular risk that the criteria used to assess whether an applicant should be allocated to the DFT may exclude some vulnerable applicants from commencing their claim in the non-detained system.
"For these reasons I have suspended the operation of the detained fast track policy.
"I hope that this will be a temporary measure, with a view to the DFT resuming in a matter of weeks, but only when I am satisfied that the risk of unfairness has been sufficiently reduced."

DFT applicants who are currently in detention awaiting a hearing will now have their position reviewed at a "senior level" to see whether they can be released to continue with their asylum application, he said.

Mr Brokenshire said applicants in detention for other reasons, including the risk that they might abscond before their claim is heard or those awaiting imminent removal, would be "unaffected by the suspension of the DFT system".
DFT applicants will therefore only be released if it is not possible to justify their detention under normal criteria, outside of the DFT process.

Mr Brokenshire added: "We are clear that where an applicant can be removed to a safe third country or statements by that person or other objective evidence indicate that the applicant poses a risk to the public, including foreign offenders, that applicant should be detained." In 2013, DFT saw about 4,300 asylum applications or decisions speeded up.
