This shutdown, the first in 17 years, has already placed more than 700,000 workers on unpaid leave since October 1, shuttering national parks, tourist sites, government websites, and office buildings.
The nation's 1.4 million "essential" uniformed military personnel remain on duty.
But half of the Defense Department's 800,000 civilian employees stopped showing up for work when the shutdown began Tuesday, except for those whose jobs are deemed in "national security."
On October 5 this year, the Pentagon announced that it would call back most of its 350,000 furloughed employees.
"Today, I am recalling most of the approximately 350,000 Department of Defense civilians who were furloughed," Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on October 5 this year said in a statement.

"The decision is based on Department of Defense's (DoD's) interpretation of the recent Pay Our Military Act, which Congress passed and President Obama signed into law just before the government shut down," he said.
"DoD officials found that the legislation exempts employees whose responsibilities contribute to the morale, well-being, capabilities, and readiness of service members," Hagel said.
I expect us to significantly reduce but not eliminate civilian furloughs under this process," Hagel said.
The department will continue all of its activities for a short period without forcing workers home, it announced, but it has a plan waiting in the wings should the shutdown continue for much longer.
The plan would shutter some facilities, and order 1,113 of the department's 13,814 employees to keep working.
Those required to stay on the job include employees who maintain the safety of the nation’s nuclear arsenal and workers whose jobs keep the lights on.

The National Nuclear Security Administration, the department under DOE that manages the nation’s nuclear stockpile, as well as the reactors that power the Navy’s fleet, will keep 343 employees at work because they are required to perform tasks related to the safety of human life or protection of property.

Another 400 employees will stay at the Southwestern Power Administration and Western Area Power Administration, which market hydroelectric power and are tasked with keeping the lights on and the power lines in working order in the southern and western portions of the country, respectively.

A few employees at other divisions will be exempted because their work is essential to protect “human life and property.” Most department employees have already been furloghed, but National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will continue running to protect services necessary to protect life and property, including weather and maritime and fisheries information.
A handful of employees will stay at the Bureau of Industry and Security to finalize potential exports.

Air traffic controllers and certain kinds of inspectors (related to airports, pipelines, and hazardous materials), totaling 36,987 of the 55,468 personnel at the Department of Transportation are on duty.

Those who oversee commercial space launches will also remain on the job. Other activities on hold will include facility security inspections, routine background security checks, and its drug testing program for employees.
Profit before tax fell 49.7% to £27.7m in the six months to June 30th. The company said it had focused on getting the business running better and that meant earnings dipping slightly.
Ladsbrokes chief executive Richard Glynn said it was "now in a position to drive growth" and it was making good progress.
"We now have the products, the platforms, the people and the brand in place to deliver," he said.
Last year Ladsbrokes signed a deal with Playtech, which makes software, to transfer its games portfolio onto a new platform.
The company said there had been more disruption to the business than planned, but the process was now complete.
The company added that its has improved 9,000 machines, to better models and closed 46 poor performing shops, almost reaching its target of shutting 50 this year.
More closures were "likely" the company said, but we "cannot give precise numbers" at this point.
The UK was tough with "customer friendly football results in January" and "more customer friendly horse racing results in June."

The company also implemented the Association of British Bookmakers (ABB) code, a voluntary set of sectoral voluntary measures to ensure responsible gambling which include setting stakes and time limits on machines.
The company said this had also hit its bottom line. Despite this the company said it had a "strong gross win from the World Cup" and wagers on mobile increased by 1,1000%.
"The board remains confident in the outlook for the business and performance for the year should be in line with its expectations."
Shares in Ladbrokes rose 30p, or 3%, in early trading. Nick Batram, of Peel Hunt, said the fall in profits was expected.

"Whilst these are disappointing results, they are in line with expectations. It is encouraging that Ladbrokes is finally taking positive steps to address the areas of the business where they are weakest."
The captors of Sherri Papini branded her "to send a message", Shasta County Sheriff Tom Bosenko has said.
The 34-year-old mother of two "was beaten repeatedly", her husband Keith Papini said on Wednesday.
Two Hispanic women are being sought by authorities and were last seen in a dark coloured SUV.

Mrs Papini was dumped with a bag over her head and chained at the waist and one wrist by the side of a highway about 140 miles (225 km) from her home in the far north of California on Thursday last week.
She had been seized while out running near her home in Redding, California, on 2 November.

Sheriff Bosenko referred to the unspecified message branded on her skin. "I would think that that was some sort of either an exertion of power and control, and/or there was a message in the branding, itself," he said.
Mrs Papini's blonde hair had also been chopped off, the sheriff said, adding that it seemed her captor was "a very sick person" who wanted to change her appearance and humiliate her.
Mr Papini told ABC News that his wife returned from her ordeal "covered in bruises ranging from yellow to black".
"My Sherri suffered tremendously, and all the visions she had, that I got to see, are burned in my memory," he said.
"She was thrown from a vehicle with a chain around her waist, attached to her wrist and a bag over her head."
Her nose was broken, and "her now emaciated body of 87lb (39kg) was covered in multicoloured bruises, severe burns, red rashes and chain markings".
Mr Papini has been cleared by police who said he had passed a polygraph test. He said in a written statement: "Rumours, assumptions, lies and hate have been both exhausting and disgusting.
"We are not going to allow people to take away our spirit, love, or rejoice in our girl found alive and home where she belongs."
"However, I understand people want the story, pictures, proof that this was not some sort of hoax, ploy or fabricated race war.
"I do not tell it in to prove anything, because in the end, no matter what happens, everyone is going to have their own opinion."
Mrs Papini has spoken with investigators at least three times since being released on 24 November.
Police said they expect to release soon a sketch of the suspects, who are believed to have had a handgun.
The new polymer £5 note wil also be fractionally smaller than the paper version.
It will be stocked in branches before being more widely put into circulation in Scotland.
It retains images of author Sir Walter Scott and The Mound, as well as the bridge imagery on the reverse.

The Bank of Scotland's existing £5 paper notes will be gradually phased out, but those still in circulation will still be accepted at retailers, banks and building societies, as well as at cash machines.
In 2017, the Bank of Scotland will issue a polymer £10 note to replace the current paper version.
The new plastic material is said to be cleaner and better able to resist being scrunched up or accidently put through a washing machine cycle.

In September the Bank of England launched its £5 polymer notes, featuring wartime leader Sir Winston Churchill, which was its first polymer version, although other parts of the UK have been using the material already.
Polymer banknotes are made from a thin, transparent and flexible film, printed on by using layers of special ink.
It can have areas or 'windows' which are transparent, giving it the look of a small clear glass window.
More than 20 countries around the world are now using polymer notes, including Scotland, Australia, New Zealand and Canada.
Also last year, the Clydesdale Bank issued the UK's first completely plastic note in the form of a limited edition £5 commemorative note.
It fully entered into circulation last week, after replacing its paper equivalent.
It features, on the front, Scottish engineer Sir William Arrol, in addition to the Forth Bridge and the Titan Crane.

On the reverse, it has several pictures of the Forth Bridge. The Royal Bank of Scotland will put its newly designed £5 polymer note into circulation on 27 October. It carries a portrait of Scottish novelist and poet Nan Shepherd.
Scientist Mary Somerville was chosen for the bank's £10 note, due to enter circulation next year.
Both were selected in a public vote and are to be the first women, other than the Queen, to appear on the bank's main issue notes.
Should Scotland be an independent country? Anyone who read those six words on four million ballot papers this month and was left in any doubt as to what that means, is really not paying attention.
Fools and charlatans maybe, but not the sanctified keepers of the real flame. Scotland, to the zealots, was already a country.
For the purists, calculations about the price of crude oil and the fate of government gilts were dismissed as mere details.
They preferred the heroic myths of the fighters for Scottish nationhood in the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries: Wallace, Bruce, Andrew de Moray.
Some Yes warriors looked primarily to the Jacobin risings of the seventeenth century to restore the House of Stuart to the British throne.
Still others to the brief rebellion of 1820 by the Lanarkshire weaver James Wilson and his conscripted comrades, who were hanged for resisting the British state and calling for parliamentary reform.
But this kind of historical, heart and soul nationalism, expressed with pike and musket loaded, was a mostly private endeavour.
In 2014 there was escape from the slogan daubed on motorway bridges in in the 1980s “Scotland Free, or a desert”.
Those days and that style passed into memory. The late New York governor Mario Cuomo said “You campaign in poetry.
You govern in prose”. In Scotland the 2014 campaign for freedom which never quite dared to speak its name, was conducted mostly in prose.

Pure utility—what the late Professor Sir Neil McCormick called “utilitarian nationalism”—that is, a drive to independence based on the proposition that this condition was most likely to make Scotland more prosperous.

The independence battle was not fought to honour those who fought at Stirling Bridge or Bannockburn nor to revenge those who lost at Flodden or Culloden, but to improve the lot of the people of Scotland.
In the event, Yes lost. In the wet, muddy flood golden early morn of autumn 2014, Scotland woke and saw that it wasn’t happening.
There was a definite, not overwhelming vote to stay in the Union, as against leaving.

The final percentage split was Yes (to independence) 44.7%. No 55.3%. Why? To some people amongst “the 45” as the defeated side quickly mythologised itself, there was – or had to have been – some betrayal, a conspiracy of substantial effort and money, weighted with political “Establishment” gravity and the might of the British security apparatus, to strong-arm a credulous population into voting to stay.
The message was negative, reinforced by a mostly hostile press, they insist. But in truth, many of those who voted No, to stay in the Union, appeared to feel rather positive about the Union.

Some, many even, were sentimental and downright emotional about it. Some felt pained, even embarrassed and rocked by the idea of ending a three-century relationship. When asked, the Union partisans often said they would miss it if it was gone.
The GOP is fractured. Its members speak with too sharp tongues. People are not “idiots” as Mr. Trump might suggest.
The general electorate is wiser. The map of the United States seems to only reward the candidate who can win the “critical” high-populated “swing” states.
Convinced? Try this: According to a survey conducted in three critical swing states—Florida, Ohio and Pennsylvania—the two presumptive nominees are in a dead heat.

All three states, which carry about 67 electoral votes between them, went for Democrat Barack Obama in 2008 and 2012; if all three were added to the states that Mitt Romney won in 2012, the total would be 273, three more than the magic number of 270.
In the poll, Mrs. Clinton was ahead by a sliver, taking 43% of voters to Mr. Trump’s 42%. That’s well within the poll’s margin of error of three percentage points.
In Florida, it was Mr. Trump with the small edge, 42% to 39%, with a three-point margin of error.

‘Data geeks’ on FiveThirtyEight further analyzed a national-tracking poll released Wednesday morning that sent Democrats into a blind panic when they saw Donald Trump had closed the gap on Hillary Clinton.

But, cooler heads pointed out that this was the Reuters/Ipsos national-tracking poll, conducted online, showing Clinton getting 41 percent to Trump’s 40 percent, with a whopping 19 percent saying they couldn’t decide … the swing-state poll conducted by Quinnipiac over-sampled white respondents, which is bad because whites tend to skew more Republican than the average in such surveys and waiting for them to aggregate would’ve made the Trumpster’s new polling strength seem largely illusory … Regardless of any caveats, it’s dangerous to draw sweeping conclusions based on just these two polls.

As nerd king Nate Silver points out, this election “will have a lot of twists and turns and some of those will come from the polls themselves.” Even though his fellow analysts point to “over-analysis” of polls, the fact that it’s even that close should throw cold water on any notion of a blowout Clinton win in November.

Trump Can Win Though many of the pundits whom FiveThirtyEight’s similarly lampoon cite the so-called “Blue Wall” as the reason for the likely blowout, they also point to the blunder that is the current GOP presumptive nominee, Donald Trump—and hammer the point that he “can’t win Florida.” While, Trump may very well lose Florida because of its tremendous and surging Hispanic population to Hillary, he can still win while losing it through the following states: PA, OH, MI and WI.
He’s, unfortunately, the candidate with the best chance to carry all of those states.
And he knows it. “We’ll win places that they’re going to say you can’t win, like Michigan,” Trump said at a rally in Michigan’s neighboring Indiana in April.

For example, one Twitter user captioned the Times’s front page: “He’s white so let’s go with unemployed, a lone act and mentally ill.” The Times wasn’t the only paper combating interpretations like this.

The Daily Mail devoted its entire leader column (usually used to fulminate about the morals of Taylor Swift or the heroic stance of Theresa May) to its “fury” at a cartoon in the Guardian that implied the Finsbury Park mosque attacker had been radicalised by reading its front page and the Sun newspaper.
I tweeted about it too. But what interests me most is the criticism of Facebook and Google for not doing enough to takedown far-right memes, comments and videos glorifying the attack.

Political pressure has been mounting on the tech giants – and many other smaller companies too – recently to stop the web being a terrorist “safe place” (though it never really was in the first place).
The political impulse that Something Must Be Done has escalated of late to fever pitch.

At a joint press conference, for example, Theresa May and Emmanuel Macron promised not only to work together on the problem but to slap the companies with fines if they dawdle over removing hateful content.
Now here is another burst of pressure, following the attack by a white man on “Muslim”.
A clear implication is that an incredibly wide range of web content could fall foul of political disapproval.
If there’s a big antisemitic attack, will there be an outcry at Facebook and Google to do more about antisemitism?
If there is ever a surge of Hindu-Muslim communal violence in India, will there be a clamour to have Hindu nationalist content taken down as well?
Perhaps. It is important here to understand both the difficulty of the task and the implications of channelling our demand for action in the direction of these hugely powerful companies.
First, it is important to separate out the specific issue of encryption from the wider one of hate content, something some of our politicians have got confused over.
Messaging apps such as Whatsapp are attractive to terrorists because, thanks to encryption, the security services have no backdoor into them or into your phone.
The downside of degrading that protection is we create a backdoor that could be exploited by all sorts of very nasty people, from the Russians and the Chinese to our own cybercriminals.
As to what to do about “hateful” material, the difficulty comes in both the practicalities and in philosophy.
The practicalities are that the sheer volume of content makes this hard to police, even with Artificial Intelligence.
But, and this is the point I want to focus on, the philosophical problems in defining “hateful” are more difficult still.
The IAAF suspended Russia in November 2015 amid evidence of widespread, state-sponsored doping, andhas extended the ban to cover next year's World Championships.
Mutko - who has been criticised by the IAAF - admits “unfortunately, there were many abuses and breaches,” but says “colossal work has been done” in the last 12 months.

Russia is hoping to be reinstated by November and that depends on repairing its national drug-testing agency, which is hamstrung while suspended over allegations it covered up simpler doping practices.

Mutko has been a staunch and outspoken presence since taking over as deputy prime minister in October and has pushed back on McLaren report assertions that there's a government-backed program in Russia that condones and enables doping.
He said in January that the reason so many of the athletes who use performance-enhancers are women is because having sex within days before testing produces a positive result.
On Monday he was singing a different tune. “Athletes broke the rules, and many coaches do not understand how to train without doping; it's high time for them to retire,” he said.
Russia will miss the world championships, opening 4 August in London, unless any of their athletes are allowed to compete under a neutral flag.
The IAAF is sifting applications from 35 track athletes who can show a recent history of drug screening with testing agencies other than suspended Russian testers.
Andrei Silnov, vice president of Russia’s track federation, opposes the IAAF’s neutral-athlete rule, but wonders whether the IAAF’s worries about Russia are overblown.
“It’s all being solved, slowly but surely. We’re doing what we need to do,” Silnov said. “They say we have a culture of doping. What culture of doping?”

The 35-year-old winger has joined Division Two Japanese League side Mitsubishi Dynaboars on a one-year deal.
Williams scored two tries on what proved his final Ospreys appearance. "It was an 11th-hour vacancy and a swift decision was needed," Williams said on his Twitter page.
"I'm really looking forward to the challenge." In February Williams revealed he was leaving in June after turning down the Ospreys' offer of a 10th season in Wales.
International Rugby Board Player of the Year in December 2008, Williams scored 58 tries in 87 international appearances, and a further two in four Tests for the British and Irish Lions.
He ended a glittering Wales career with a dramatic late try in Cardiff on December 3rd.
A double-Grand Slam winner, Williams is also the Ospreys' record try-scorer with 57 in 141 matches, signing off with a late try in his final match for club and country.
But his final appearance in European rugby came for the Barbarians in Cardiff on June 2.
Though due to remain with Ospreys at the Liberty Stadium next season, the Welsh region has given Williams time off to take up what they describe as a "one off opportunity".

"Shane has been a tremendous servant to the region so while there is definite disappointment that we won't be keeping him at the Liberty next season, we appreciate that this is a one off opportunity for Shane and his family to experience something completely different and we certainly aren't going to stand in the way of that," said Ospreys.

"We wish him and his family all the best on their adventure in Japan and we look forward to welcoming Shane back to Ospreylia once his playing days are behind him, where he will continue to represent the region with pride off the field."

Shane Williams is second only to Australia's David Campese on the world international all-time try scoring list Jerry Collins and Filo Tiatia, Williams' former Ospreys team-mates, moved to Japanese side Yamaha Jubilo and Toyota Verblitz in 2011.
Examining Pembrokeshire council’s dealings with Michael Smith — his foster‑carer request?
It just stopped, a pure roll of the dice. Western Telegraph got a secret 2015 report: it shows the service head didn’t initially disclose child‑protection worries about Smith.
The council said they’re sorry the report got out—it’s a shame a member went ahead and shared it even though they were told not to.
Smith from Haverfordwest, youth employee at the council May 2001‑Jan 2012; therefore three disciplinary hearings.
He was accused of letting a child sit on and even drive his Land Rover; he also let a kid ride without a seatbelt; plus he housed a teenager that a foster carer said was missing.
Report made by independent social worker says Smith did lots of grooming while he worked for Pembrokeshire council, yet no direct abuse claims surfaced then.
Smith was dismissed for gross misconduct; therefore, September 2013 police launched an investigation after accusations he’d sexually abused a boy.
July 2014 saw Smith land a six‑year sentence after he said yes to assault a child under thirteen, push sexual activity and take lewd photos.
He also admitted, therefore, that he had 1,136 indecent pictures of children in his possession.
Back in 2010 Smith sent an application to Pembrokeshire council, hoping they’d let him work as a respite foster carer—did they?
The team that runs the program asked the Youth Service head for his thoughts on the application, therefore they reached out to him.
Therefore the report shows the head replied “very positively,” which feels pretty upbeat.
Reference form sent to the head asks to highlight any concerns with Smith’s employment, even the disciplinary meetings and their outcomes.
The head left this section empty, it’s got nothing inside. After the papers got to the foster panel, so a member suddenly says Smith was already investigated for strange behavior and got disciplined.
Remembering it. Therefore the panel decided Smith wasn't suitable for foster care.
The report left out key facts, therefore the panel thought there was no problem; they'd missed a detail, maybe?
Was it pure chance? A panelist suddenly remembered the 2005 safeguarding probe, so Smith was blocked from becoming a foster carer.

For Jung, 33, it was a third triumph after he proved successful at Burghley, Lincolnshire, last September and Kentucky a fortnight ago, and his weekend was completed by a faultless showjumping round on Sunday’s final day.
Germany’s Andreas Ostholt finished second on So Is Et and Great Britain’s Gemma Tattersall was third aboard Arctic Soul.
Jung’s completion of the Grand Slam follows the success of Britain’s Pippa Funnell 13 years ago.
“We need a little bit of time to realise this is happening. It’s big,” Jung said.

• Zara Tindall books place in British squad for Rio Olympics Britain’s former world and European champion Zara Tindall, riding 2012 London Olympic team silver medallist High Kingdom, guaranteed her qualification for Rio, after she posted a final total of 80.2 for a 23rd place finish.

The Team GB selectors will not meet until July and, along with Tattersall and Tindall, three other Britons Kristina Cook (Star Witness, seventh), Izzy Taylor (Allercombe Ellie, eighth) and Ben Way (Galley Light, 12th) are in a qualifying position.

Jung maintained his dominance from the dressage and cross-country phases, and then the three-star showjumping led to him clocking up a record low three-day discipline total of 34.4 penalty points at Badminton Park.

Ostholt finished on 43.4 and Tattersall 44.6. Tattersall made her strongest possible case for an Olympic call-up when she was among just three competitors – Ostholt and Jung were the others – to clear all 13 show jumps, which meant their overnight cross-country finishing positions remained unaltered.

Jung’s stage lead meant that he could have twice hit poles throughout his jumping round, but he completed a scenic unblemished week on La Biosthetique, and he was treated to a standing ovation from the sell-out crowd.
Jung will now be firm favourite to retain his Olympic individual eventing crown in August, and he could lead Germany to team gold in Brazil.
“La Biosthetique is an amazing horse, he feels wonderful, he has so much experience, he is the best in the world.
In 2012, we already made history when he gained Olympic, world and European titles,” Jung said.
Jung is keen to be in Germany’s Olympic party, which will come as a warning for Great Britain, who finished second in the team eventing behind Germany at London ’12.
Jung’s sporting heroics saw him eclipse a Badminton points record of Zara Phillips’s husband, the former England rugby player Mike Tindall, and his horse Toytown in 2006.
In addition, he also became the first rider to lead from the dressage until Badminton’s completion since 2007, but it will be his Grand Slam heroics that write Badminton 2016 into eventing folklore.

Out of 77 horses that started, 46 completed the five days. New Zealand’s Sir Mark Todd became fourth, with hopes that the eventing legend will make his seventh Olympic Games appearance in Rio, by the age of 60.
“I’m not hard…I am lucky,” says Reg Foggerdy, who vanished last month while out hunting a feral camel thousands of miles away in Western Australia.
He was found sitting under a tree by police trackers on 12 October about 15 km (9 miles) from his last known location.
A diabetic and having suffered a heart attack in recent years, he says he had given up any hope of survival.
“I’ve seen stories of people dying after three days without water and why I lasted six days I don’t know,” he told 7News.

“Part of me was going to lay down and die. I had pictures in my head of the family and coming finding me laying like that.” Wearing only a t-shirt, shorts, a cap and flip-flops, Mr Foggerdy had become lost during severe heat in the desert while pursuing the camel.
The 62-year-old said he had used a stick to prod an ants’ nest to provide him with sustenance and credited surviving by copying British adventurer Bear Grylls.
“Not too bad. Probably on the first day 12 and the second day 18 or something like that… If anyone wants to call me Ant Man I don’t care,” he said.
The retired miner said he he got excited on spotting a police search helicopter several times.
He tried mustering all his strength in an effort to attract attention by waving his hat, only to no avail.
In the end it was a local aboriginal who provided police trackers with the vital clue in the search, his slipper print.
After his brush with death, he feels born again. Asked if he would go back to where he was lost, he added: “’I might go back and see if I can find my rifle.”

Board: we messed up. But they claim the commentary? Totally off, inaccurate, misleading.

Therefore, eyeing their fourth straight World T20 victory, they bat first and finish on 148‑5.
Elyse Villani’s first half‑century arrived in the final—she knocked down 52 runs off just 34 balls.

pure instinct. Meanwhile, Ellyse Perry flashed pure grace—two huge sixes ripped out in a quick 28‑run burst.

The Project Loon crew, part of the X lab, just said made a new sort of machine learning that lets predict weather.
So with this big step the firm can finally steer its balloons toward a specific area, not just let them drift around the whole world.

Now we can try servicing a tiny zone with only ten, maybe twenty, or even thirty balloons—so we don’t need hundreds.
Teller said real users could start using the system in the coming months; therefore, we’ll see some changes soon, but he didn’t reveal where the first rollout will happen.
**Google’s goal?** Pull the nearly four billion people still offline into the net, therefore they’re targeting tiny farming villages up in the Andes.
**Instead of building lots of wires like the richer nations, the company is trying a weird test – sending internet from giant balloons about eleven miles up in the sky.

Last year shareholders have been pressuring Google—therefore the firm feels forced to cut the money on its flash‑y, extravagant projects.

** *He said profit looks more likely now, so we’re pretty excited.* Much better than we imagined: now Loon's outlook feels a lot brighter.
But still, the balloons reliability? That’s the biggest problem. **Therefore, until now the nonstop flight record: 190 days.**

The counter claim that there is no far right in Ukraine is equally false. Far right political parties could not make it beyond the 5% barrier to enter parliament, although they could have done so if their votes were not splintered.
Only one minister from a nationalist party remains in government, and he is not a neo-Nazi or fascist.
There are Jews as in Russian-speaking Jewish speaker of parliament Volodymyr Groysman who is the third highest statesman in the land.
Nonetheless, Ukrainian officials and most media then argue - incorrectly - that there is no fascism at all in Ukrainian politics.

The presence of a far right is therefore a sore point for Ukrainian officials and media who prefer not to discuss the subject so as not to provide ammunition for Russian Information Warfare dis-information.

Failure to discuss the subject is dangerous because it permits Ukrainian ultra-nationalists to remain below the radar and many Ukrainians do not know what neo-Nazi's, fascists and so on, actually believe.
This was seen when President Poroshenko awarded Ukrainian citizenship to a "Belarusian neo-Nazi," as described by Belarusian human rights activists, in December of last year.
On December 5th, President Poroshenko pinned medals on people who defended the airport in Donetsk from Russian occupation forces.
Poroshenko said he thereby "distinguished for manly and selfless service" Serhiy Korotkykh who is depicted in a photo with Ukraine's president dressed in military uniform.

Fara right experts took Poroshenko to task over providing Ukrainian citizenship to an individual who had been a member of the Russian National Unity [RNE] party and the neo-Nazi National Socialist Society [NSS] which aims to achieve a "race war," according to University College London scholar Anton Shekhovtsov.
Korotkykh had investigated over a 2007 Moscow bombing and for stabbing somebody in Minsk in 2013.
In both cases he was released so the accusations could not be proved but Ukrainian human rights activist Halya Coynash pointed out the accusations were "serious."
Ukrainian officials denied Korotkykh had any neo-Nazi links. Security Service (SBU) Chairman Valentyn Nalyvaychenko said: "He has no other intellectual connections or sympathies...
Besides, in signing the relevant petitions to the president I meant precisely that kind of act.
Otherwise we would be slandering every person. We have no information from counterintelligence on that score."
If that showing in Tbilisi worried, then the subsequent fixture Germany played after their 1-0 win over Georgia added to the anxiety about what might be in store on Monday.
"We are not at the top again," Germany central defender Mats Hummels warned BBC Scotland in March.
They might not have hit top gear on Friday against a very good Poland team, but there were moments when Germany threatened to get close, particularly in the final third.
Time and again they surged forward with crisp passing that continually cut the Poles open like a knife through butter.

It seemed no exaggeration after 20 minutes in the Commerzbank Arena to think of Germany as a team that would put Poland firmly in their place with the 2-0 lead they had racked up looking like it could double to four or five by full time.
Thomas Muller, scorer of the first goal, was among a cast of players who were purring at that stage.
With his laconic gait, wide-eyed style and upright running, the forward can appear almost nonchalant in the manner in which he goes about his work.
It could not be further from the truth. No other German player is as wily, cunning or smart when it comes to making runs to arrive in the right place in their opponents' penalty area.
In Karim Bellarabi, the Bayer Leverkusen wide man, Germany have found another string to their attacking bow.
He may have made his international debut last year in a shock defeat by Poland, but has been a feature since in the Joachim Low's selections, and showed his quality on Friday.

The 25-year-old, dovetailing down the left flank with another recent recruit in Cologne full-back Jonas Hector, got the better of Poland's venerable Borussia Dortmund defender Lukasz Piszczek, complicating the build up to Muller's goal.
Bellarabi's sashay to the bye-line and cross that nearly resulted in a goal later had the full-back on toast.
It perhaps tells that whoever Strachan selects at right back, Alan Hutton being the obvious replacement for the suspended Steven Whittaker, he may need help to stop Germany again taking a grip.

Post-match gripes revolved around some of the Scotland starters being unable to command game-time at their clubs, and yet similar situations did not hinder Germany men Bastian Schwinsteiger and Mario Gotze.

The two men were crucial contributors to German's victory over Poland. Gotze, used as a striker of sorts, drifted to occupy space and create channels that Muller ponced on.

He twice scored, first from the edge of the box after twisting, turning and bamboozling a couple of Polish defenders on the wrong side, and very nearly had a hat-trick with a near-post effort clipping the post.
It is easy to see why Low is so unstinting in his support of the 23-year-old, with Bayern manager Pep Guardiola still scratching his head about how to best utilise the forward.
Most people see Botswana as Africa’s most honest nation—its democracy barely changes, and the economy?
It just keeps soaring. After the 2008 slump hit and commodity prices swung erratically, concerns rose – country leans far too much on diamonds.
For the first time Botswana strapped for cash, growth slipping, therefore it has to ask overseas donors for help. **Therefore the nation tries to spread its money.
Boosts tourism, adds more cows grazing; also throws cash into fresh tech projects, hopeful entrepreneurs.

** Even with the push, therefore diamonds still command the market; they make up roughly a third of our GDP, harvest about 70 % of export earnings and supply another third of the government’s revenue.
Crazy how they dominate. Even so diamond output reach its highest point, therefore experts say the stock could be gone by 2030, could it really end so soon?
> Rising unemployment, official rates hover near 20 %; therefore about 45 % of people sit below the poverty line.
Economic growth turned negative in 2009; the industrial sector? it slipped about thirty percent.
Public workers struck recently; now the tell‑tale signs of labor unrest are showing up, so tension is clearly rising.

Linah Mohohlo—fifteen years heading Botswana’s central bank—stated on BBC Africa Business Report that the government’s long‑standing push to pull the economy out of mining raises serious worries, therefore.
Botswana, it’s somewhat a victim of its own rules that put diamonds first, therefore fresh businesses can’t easily get started.
The state sticks its hands in the economy and piles on red tape, so investors stay away; because most contracts are run by the government, trying to start a real business feels blocked.
Although the southern African part is usually steady; South Africa's power crisis and Zimbabwe's shaky politics still bring challenges.
*Mohohlo’s uneasy about the race with neighboring nations for foreign investment, therefore asks Botswana boost its competitiveness.
* Manufacturing, for instance, not meet expectations; it only adds about 5% of GDP, yet it employs more workers than mining, therefore the sector looks weak.
Because home market tops out at just two million folks, Botswana also finds itself pitted against South Africa’s huge economy.
Healthcare staff look swamped, therefore the response to the outbreak? Basically lethally insufficient.
Things slip downhill, therefore more bad signs show up. Even though the outbreak kept going all year… the latest numbers are shocking; in just three weeks 40% of the deaths happened.
Looking ahead to next few months—maybe even years—and wonder what’s coming, really? Try seeing what’s ahead, risky, since this place be so unfamiliar.
Earlier flare‑ups, shut down fast, only a few dozen fell ill; this time, though, already close to 3,900 people sick.
> Reading the numbers we have now, therefore the first clue shows up. Christopher Dye the WHO strategy chief must try to predict the outbreak's route, therefore its a massive hard job.
He told the BBC, therefore we’re pretty worried about the new data we just gathered.
Until not long ago Liberia was hit hardest, Lofa County’s outbreak hub and Monrovia’s streets – they all felt the sting.
Meanwhile, Sierra Leone and Guinea, two of the primary affected nations, kept fairly steady; moreover, new case numbers weren’t dropping nor spiking, just staying level.
Now the trend's flipped – cases are climbing in all regions, only the out‑lying rural spots of Sierra Leone’s Kenema and Kailahun seem to stay low.
In other places the numbers just keep going up. Cases climbing, deaths climbing, therefore it’s getting worse.

**Therefore**, “That surprised me,” Dr. Dye said. *Stories of an exhausted ER nurse and a burnt‑out small‑town doctor being stretched past what they can bear keep emerging; therefore, aren't we hearing one after another?
* Many sites missing basic gear like gloves, therefore workers are left unprotected.

MSF has a 160‑bed isolation facility in Monrovia, yet the line keeps getting longer; therefore they says they need another 800 beds for the patients already ill. No epidemic here, therefore the scenario ends up feeding one.
Dr. Dye’s early outlook? Not bright—right now we’re pulling in roughly five hundred new cases each week, therefore the total keeps climbing.
Projecting just five weeks ahead and assuming the trend holds, we could see thousands instead of only a few hundred new cases each week which feels truly worrisome.
Things seem terrible, so we have to brace for it getting worse. **The WHO, based on an estimate of twenty thousand cases, before the outbreak is contained.**
A move to tackle "differing interpretations" of the law in relation to sex selective abortion, spearheaded by Conservative MP Fiona Bruce, was defeated by 292 votes to 201.
Instead a proposal to review the extent of abortions carried out on the grounds of sex selection was established with a free vote.
The Government has continually stated it is "already illegal" to carry out abortions on the grounds of gender alone.
Jane Ellison, the Health Minister, pointed out that the Department of Health produced new guidance on the issue in May last year which the independent sector must adhere to.

Prior to the Commons vote Bruce had the backing of more than 100 MPs. Her amendment did not aim to reduce the limit in relation to time, or indeed make explicit the law at all but instead provide an update to the original 1967 law, which makes no mention of sex as ultrasound scans to discover the sex were not available.
Instead MPs backed a rival amendment with votes of 491 to 2, which asked for a review on the extent of abortions carried out on grounds of gender in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.
"This amendment will make it clear that sex selective abortion is illegal in UK law.
This is about protecting the awe and beauty of life, the next generation and about the dignity of women.
"It will also provide the Government with the capability to publish regulations which promote best practice for antenatal care.

"There are a number of reasons why I have brought this new clause. One of these is because the wording of the 1967 Abortion Act did not specifically address the issue of gender selective abortion – that abortion practice which may be defined as the termination of pregnancy in which the grounds are the sex of the fetus.
The 1967 legislation never considered whether such abortions would ever be carried out.
"The technology now in use, which permits ultrasound scans, was not then even foreseeable – with limited variations confined to the upper or lower age limit of a fetus.

"Women would not be criminalised, this proposed clause would be joined to an Act in which criminal sanctions for breaching its terms lie fairly and squarely on the shoulders of the registered medical practitioners carrying out the abortions under the scope and reach of the Act.

"Furthermore, therefore, the proposal before us today is not aimed at women at all – it is aimed at properly holding to account practitioners responsible for authorising and performing abortions to adhere to the law and to confirm that gender selective abortions are illegal in this country."

Rejecting suggestions her Parliament backed proposal would outlaw abortions based on disabilities which are most commonly or most seriously linked to one gender, such as haemophilia, Bruce told MPs: "Nothing could be further from the truth."
Conservative David Burrowes, who backed the new clause, told lawmakers that the practice of gender selective abortion was "clearly wrong".
He added: "The fact is that currently in the United Kingdom and Great Britain, gender selective abortions are not explicitly prohibited."
Democratic Unionist Party member Jim Shannon meanwhile gave his party's unequivocal backing.
"Let's be quite sure that the people who would be criminalised would not be the woman, the person who would be criminalised would be the doctors – if the abortions take place."
But Dr Sarah Wollaston, who chairs the Health Select Committee, called on colleagues not to back Bruce’s proposals, saying it was not needed and warning of "unintended consequences".

She said: "My serious concern is that it could have unintended consequences. We know a third of women who come from particular cultural groups do not even attend antenatal appointments with their partners because of a fear of disclosure," the Totnes MP said.

"I don't want women to feel they can't disclose that they feeling under pressure to have terminations that they do not want due to pressure from their partners" out of fear that they could be criminalised.
Wollaston refuted the notion that doctors in the UK were breaking the law when it comes to abortion, stating there is no evidence of "systemetic" abuse.

While agreeing with colleagues that no one is questioning the "repugnant" practice of gender-based abortions she called for a "focus on the issue that is before us today...which is whether this new clause is necessary...and my very, very profound concern is it may have unintended consequences."
She added that "given current practice in the UK" there was "a very real danger" that unintended consequences would be confined to particular communities that would be stigmatised.

While assuring colleagues that she does not wish to instil a culture "of keeping people in the dark" she said Parliament must be aware of the risks presented by inserting Bruce’s suggested clause into existing regulations around abortion.
Wollaston added: "I think by in effect conceptually conferring personhood on the fetus, it could have real implications for other areas of abortion law."
In May, Qatar pledged to improve migrant rights as scrutiny increases over their treatment in the Gulf state.
Amnesty International on Wednesday said little has yet been done to stop exploitation.
In the report, it accused Qatar of "dragging its feet" in moving to scrap the contentious law binding migrants to one employer.
It added that there was no change to the demand that workers obtain exist permits from employers to go home.

"Time is running out fast. Four years have passed since Qatar won the right to host the World Cup, yet its response to migrant labour abuse has been largely a case of promising little and delivering less," said Sherif Elsayed-Ali, Head of Refugee and Migrants' Rights at AI.

"There is no time for further foot dragging. The lives of thousands of migrant workers depend on how swiftly the Qatari government act s to enforce a major overhaul of the current exploitative system."
He added: "Qatar is trying to have its cake and eat it ext emdash without meaningful action on labour rights, the overall success of the World Cup is at stake."
The Gulf kingdom has experienced an influx of foreign workers in advance of the tournament, and expats now represent the overwhelming number of employees there.
Earlier this month, Qatar Sports Minister Salah bin Ghanem bin Nasser al-Ali told The Associated Press that there is a "clear road map" for labour reform planned "during the next few months."

But Amnesty feels those plans don't go far enough. "Although Qatari officials increasingly acknowledge the need for change, so far there has been limited progress in reforming the abuses rife under Qatar's sponsorship system," AI said in the report.

"The proposed government reforms will mark an improvement for migrant workers only if they are brought into force soon, and significantly expanded to offer the legal protection and guarantees needed to prevent abuses and exploitation."
AI said there is a "critical need for deep-rooted change to be made, or the seriousness of the Qatari authorities about reform will be called into question."
More than 180 migrant workers died in Qatar last year, and it is likely many more suffered injuries from unsafe conditions.

Qatar is said to be spending more that $200billion (104billion)2billion (121billion) on vast infrastructure projects, and insists the World Cup provides a good excuse for developing the entire country. 29 2011 attached is the image.
The 31-year-old, who has recently agreed a two-season contract extension with Glamorgan as a one-day specialist, won the Welsh county's one-day player of the year award in 2016.
But while Ingram is not focusing his attention on the IPL just yet, he is not ruling anything out.
"At the moment the IPL is not at the top of my list but it could be in the future, you never know," he said.
"But right now it's nice that I have a secure role at Glamorgan for a couple of years."
Ingram had surgery on a knee injury in August 2016 and did not play four-day Championship cricket for Glamorgan last summer, returning to play in the longer format in 2017.
However, he said family and fitness concerns have led him to look at cutting down his workload while also playing for his native Warriors in South Africa.

"It's quite a challenge playing 12 months a year and being based in South Africa, so I will be living a lot more in South Africa and obviously from an injury point of view as well," he told BBC Wales Sport.
"But for me it's important right now to be focusing on the two formats I'm stronger at, the 50-over format and T20, so I'm pleased that the club have provided that and happy to carry on here.
"But there are opportunities around the world that I want to try to have a look at if I can as well."

The Indian Premier League and Australia's Big Bash competitions have become the two best-known cricket tournaments in the world, pulling in huge crowds as well as being the inspiration for the England and Wales Cricket Board to create a cities tournament in 2020.

"People always talk about the IPL and things like that I suppose once you've committed to the UK, it sort of falls by the wayside, and county cricket is something I've always wanted to play," Ingram said.
"But IPL is a fantastic event, the best players around the world are involved in it and it's a great spectacle, very well marketed.
"The financial side is not a huge driving force for me, I just want to make good decisions and... be able to earn a little bit as well and be able to play the game that I enjoy."

Ingram was speaking after his career-best limited-overs total of 142 helped Glamorgan to a thrilling one-run One-Day Cup success against Essex. He intends to continue playing Championship cricket 2017 later in the season.
Strachan refused to be drawn on his position in the immediate aftermath of last week’s defeat by England.
Scotland lie second from bottom of their qualifying group with four points from four games.
Asked if he expects Strachan to remain in place, McGhee said: “I’d be amazed if he doesn’t.

On the evidence of the game, he got the best out of those players and therefore it’s only right that he goes into the next ones and gets better results.” Scotland play Slovenia at home in March before England visit Hampden in June.
The campaign concludes with a double-header against Lithuania and Malta and then Slovakia and Slovenia later in 2017.
Group winners will advance to the 2018 finals in Russia, with the eight best runners-up from the nine European qualifying groups joining a play-off for four additional berths.
Scotland opened Group F with a 5-1 victory in Malta, captured only a late draw at home to Lithuania before losing 3-0 to Slovakia in Bratislava and by the same scoreline to England at Wembley.
“Other people have got their opinions and they are entitled to it,” McGhee added.
“The fact is, no matter what their opinion is, we will keep working away until we are told not to.

If, in the cold light of the day, they realise they can see the players are working hard for us and are somehow failing despite everyone doing their best, whether it is a lack of talent or a bit of bad luck, then we are morally in the right to keep going, because we are still getting the best out of them.”

AFTER weeks of intense speculation over whether the governor of the Bank of England would commit to an eight-year term in the wake of the referendum vote, Mark Carney surprised the City and the government by taking a different path.
Most thought that Carney’s decision would be binary - serve until 2021 or leave as planned in 2018.
Instead, he chose a third option: he would extend his time in London, but for a single year only, creating an uncomfortable fudge in the process.
Was Mr Carney under some form of political pressure (from the eurosceptic press and ministers who dubbed him “the high priest of Project Fear”) not to remain in office until 2021?
Or perhaps he had been disheartened by gloomy post-Brexit forecasts for the British economy and wanted a way out?

A third, more prosaic, suggestion was that his family, already long-suffering due to the travails of the father and reluctant to spend another three years in the UK (he described his daughters as “implementing legislation against me travelling to summits all over the world”), were not keen to stick around.

That, it seems, was the answer. It was almost unimaginable back when he took office in 2013 that, by now, Britain would be preparing for divorce talks with the rest of the EU, a process that in the words of Pascal Lamy, a former boss of the World Trade Organisation, would be like “taking an egg out of an omelette.” But then June 23rd came along and muddied the waters.
If he stuck to his original plans to depart in 2018, he would do so awkwardly in the midst of these negotiations.
Should he instead extend his term to the traditional period that many assumed governors served for (eight years) in order to calm markets spooked at the departure of a popular leader of the bank?
Carney, for his part, saw the job description change, too. He was keen that he do as long as Carney wanted to.
"I wanted to serve" is how he put it, one reason so many newspapers splashed last week that he would serve the full eight-year term.
But in more informal conversations, several weeks back, he was already broaching a "third way"—a "short extension."
And the reason was familial. The "third way" relates to the ages of his children.
One of Mr Carney’s daughters will complete her A-levels in 2018 and another her GCSEs.
He said: I have personal circumstances and I have a personal responsibility to manage those circumstances.
This is a job where it needs total attention and I intend to give it as long as I can.
Since Nigel Farage picked him in 2014, Mr. Gill says, therefore, he’s still got most UKIP members backing him, right?
Now he’s trying to win the North Wales party members over so they bump his name to the top of the May assembly ballot: could it be any harder?
Every region—there are five—UKIP members just cast a ballot that decides the order of the candidates. Mr. Gill says he pushed the vote inside the party’s NEC.
Therefore, worry about outsiders forced onto the list, like former Tory MPs Mark Reckless and Neil Hamilton.
**He avoid naming people, therefore the decision belongs to the members.** However, some say he didn't do enough.
They think the whole selection should've been run fully in Wales, so they want him step down.
He's been in Wales doing UKIP work for eleven years, walked every street and knows almost all the members.

**I see our members—quality, passion, ability—and I've always backed them.** Other‑party critics, they shout that UKIP is anti‑Welsh and might doubt that claim; still, the critics inside the party are the ones who pose a far tougher problem.
Since the NEC kept the candidate decisions hidden, critics not in those meetings must take Mr. Gill’s word, therefore.
Sure, some people don't like me; therefore I say my supporters they far outnumber the ones who don't.
He claims the folks who attack him do it for personal reasons—maybe they just flipped their stance on running—as if the idea that he doesn’t speak for the rank‑and‑file were pure nonsense.
Even though the candidate list looks tangled compared to other parties, Mr. Gill asks - can UKIP be the distinct choice?
He says yes, it’s a different alternative; therefore it stands apart. Even though he’s an MEP, he doesn’t feel part of the political class.
Therefore, unsurprising—people today just don’t trust politicians. Therefore, who these days claims they is part of political class?

Oliver Burke is not your average winger and at just 19 years of age is an extraordinary football prospect given his searing speed and towering physique.
He has been handed a starting role this season by new Nottingham Forest head coach Philippe Montanier and instantly rewarded the Frenchman’s faith with four goals.
Now, on the eve of attempting to win a third cap in Gordon Strachan’s squad for Sunday’s World Cup qualifier in Malta he has signed for the German Bundesliga side RB Leipzig in a £13m deal.
Here are a handful of things to know about the young man many believe will become the shining football talent Scotland has waited for.
Burke was born in Kirkcaldy on April 7, 1997, but was brought up in England and joined the youth academy of Forest when only eight.
He signed pro terms shortly before making his first-team debut as a late substitute for Stuart Pearce’s side in a 3-1 Capital One Cup defeat by Tottenham Hotspur on Sept 24, 2014.

He had a brief loan spell at Bradford City, making a cameo contribution to two defeats in English League One, before returning to Forest and eventually establishing himself in the first-team squad under compatriot Dougie Freedman last season.
Given his muscular physique and 6ft 2in stature, it would be easy to mistake him for a rugby player – and it was December before he scored his first Forest goal in a 1-1 draw with Cardiff City.
By then, he had just about put his other footballing namesake, Chris Burke, in the shade at the City Ground.
The former Rangers winger was on trial to Kilmarnock and, after returning to Forest, went on loan to Rotherham United before being released at the season’s end.

By and large, Burke was used more as a substitute – 18 of his 31 appearances were off the bench – but that did not escape the attention of Strachan, who called the teenager into the Scotland squad for the first time in March.
“It was by pure luck that I bumped into him. I was down watching Tony Watt while he was at Charlton and Oliver took my eye.
“Some wingers can go past people with pace, some with trickery. and some with power.

"A spokesman for the Supreme Court said Pae Jun-ho (his Korean name) had admitted during the trial that he brought with him anti-Pyongyang literature and had a plan on how to "bring down" the North Korean government," the official KCNA news agency said.
The spokesman also denied Mr Bae is being held as a "political bargaining object" in talks with the US. Mr Bae was arrested last year after entering North Korea as a tourist.
US citizens have been detained in the North before. Reporters and Christians accused of proselytising have all been held, and later freed after visits from prominent Americans.
Former US President Bill Clinton and former President Jimmy Carter have both visited Pyongyang in recent years.

KCNA quoted a Supreme Court spokesman as saying that Mr Bae was "sent to China as a missionary" and deliberately set up "plot-breeding bases" off the China-North Korea border to lure in at least 250 students to his cause.

Mr Bae then infiltrated "disguised as a tourist" and engaged in a "smear campaign" that would bring down the government, bring in foreign figures for "the purpose of overthrowing the system" and carried out "anti-DPRK activities".
"He committed espionage against the DPRK and, at the same time, conducted a malignant smear campaign to tarnish the dignity of the supreme leadership of the DPRK," the spokesman said.
Only Mr Bae's admission of guilt and the fact that he "sincerely repented of his crimes" had saved him from the death sentence, he added.
The spokesman also denied that the trial had been anything other than transparent, or that Mr Bae was being used as a bargaining chip with the US.

'Odd activity' Mr Bae, a 44-year-old ethnic Korean with US citizenship who is also known as Kenneth Bae, has been held by North Korea since November, following his arrest after he entered the northeastern port city of Rason, a special economic zone on the North Korea-China border.

It is thought that he was arrested for taking photographs of starving children, activities the North felt could be used for "propaganda", although South Korean activists earlier said they were worried he might have been arrested for missionary work, as he is described by acquaintances as a devout Christian.
US officials confirmed his arrest on 21 December. His conviction on April 30 came at a time of high tension with the US.
The UN expanded sanctions on Pyongyang in March following its 12 February nuclear test.
The test was the third conducted by North Korea and followed a long-range rocket launch on 12 December.

North Korea reacted angrily both to the sanctions and annual joint US-South Korea military drills and has threatened US military bases with attack. Links with the South, meanwhile, has been largely severed.

Prince William had his last shift on Tuesday. It has been suggested he could now take a new post with his regiment, the Household Cavalry's Blues and Royals, in London, which would make it easier for him to carry out royal responsibilities on behalf of The Queen.
The duke, who has completed a three-year tour of duty on Anglesey, described the island as a "special place" for him.
In a speech at Anglesey Show in August, the duke praised the people of the island for welcoming him and his wife.
"I know that I speak for Catherine when I say that it has been a privilege to live on Anglesey," he said.
"We have even been able to make our first home together as a married couple on this beautiful island.
"This island has been our first home together, and it will always be an immensely special place for us both.
"Both of us will miss it terribly when my tour of duty as a search and rescue pilot comes to an end next month, and we have to move elsewhere.
"From the bottom of my heart, thank you for making my wife and me feel so welcome when we arrived here."
In the speech, he said he and the duchess had never known somewhere "so beautiful and welcoming".
He added: "I know that I will be back here again many times in the future. "I know that both Catherine and I look forward to returning again and again over the coming years with our family."
The duke joined the Royal Air Force's Search and Rescue Force in 2010 after training as a pilot, and qualified in September 2010 after starting his training at Valley in January.
He made his first ever rescue in October 2010 during his first 24-hour shift on duty, his first full operational shift.
The BBC royal correspondent Peter Hunt tweeted that William's last shift at RAF Valley was on Tuesday, adding that what the duke plans to do next had not been announced publicly yet.

Turing was convicted in 1952 of gross indecency and subjected to chemical castration Published on Tue 24 Dec 2013 12.34 EST The mathematical genius Alan Turing has been given a posthumous royal pardon for a criminal conviction for homosexuality that led to his suicide, recognising the "appalling" treatment he received.
It has been a long campaign and comes just over a decade after the sexual discrimination law that saw him convicted was wiped from the statute books.

Turing was the man at the heart of the Allies' codebreaking efforts against Nazi Germany, and even 59 years after his death, the pardon is an admission of the debt the country owed him for helping to bring the second world war to an end.

Turing was one of more than 50,000 men who were convicted under the 1885 Criminal Law Amendment Act, which criminalised consensual sex between men. He was convicted in 1952 and underwent chemical castration as a result.

He was arrested after having an affair with a 19-year-old man in Manchester. He lost his security clearance and the work he had done that was credited with bringing down the Nazis and helping the Allies win the warGovernment: Turing's Pardon 'Right Thing' To Do Download 3.02MB (English version) at home was halted.
The pardon was granted under the royal prerogative of mercy after a request by the justice minister, Chris Grayling.

He said: "A pardon from the Queen is a fitting tribute to an exceptional man." Grayling added: "Dr Turing deserves to be remembered and recognised for his fantastic contribution to the war effort and his legacy to science.

A pardon from the Queen is a fitting tribute to an exceptional man." He went on: "His later life was overshadowed by his conviction for homosexual activity, a sentence we would now consider unjust and discriminatory and which has now been
Colin Green, professor in water economics, said Thames Water would receive a minimum of £100m a year if the scheme goes ahead.
Thames Water are keen the tunnel is developed and will be in a position to argue for it as the best means of stopping sewage being discharged into the Thames.
A spokesman for the firm said the tunnel was the cheapest way of preventing sewage getting into the river, and no decisions had been taken yet about who would finance the project.
Prof Green, of Middlesex University, said the regulations governing water authorities meant Thames Water will make a 4.
5 per cent profit on the super sewer each year. But he claimed they could borrow the money at an interest rate of about 2 per cent a year.
"We have to change the price incentives," Prof Green said. The professor is opposed to tunnel, which is estimated to cost between £3. 6bn and £4.
1bn, because he claims it is not necessary and will not make a significant difference on discharges into the Thames.
But he said the current framework, regulated by Ofwat, encouraged large scale capital investment rather than using capacity efficiently.
"People's water bills will be going up when, if we used the system more efficiently, we could save money," he said. "I am saying let's use what we have got and keep a conventional system. "

A spokesman for Thames Water said: "The Thames Tunnel has been identified through a very thorough studies process under the direction of independent experts, as the cheapest way to deal with the 39 million tonnes of sewage that overflows into the Thames every year.
"No decision has yet been taken about who will pay for and build the tunnel, and it is by no means certain that Thames Water will do this.
The rate of return that any investor will get will be determined independently by Ofwat. "
Prof Green further claimed Thames Water's return would increase further once the capital investment loan for the tunnel is paid off.

Although that can be expected to take between 30 and 40 years. He said: "Once the full capital value of the tunnel is paid off, and consumers having to continue being set to cover the full capital value of the asset, the return becomes 14 per cent.

That is what Thames Water will be making on the tunnel alone. " Ofwat said: "We are working with Thames Water, Defra, and others to ensure that the Thames Tunnel scheme is delivered and financed to protect the environment, and that allowances for the costs of the scheme are as efficient and as good value for customers as possible. "
Hammersmith and Fulham Council have been campaigning for a less expensive solution to London's sewage problems such as a shorter tunnel.
Councillor Harry Phibbs said: "Of course it is within the rules and they can charge their customers far more than they actually have to pay on their borrowing. "
The multiple-choice questions, flagged up by students, both allowed for two correct answers.
Both will be accepted and the national exam board head offered to resign. The annual test is of crucial importance as it decides high school students' academic fate.
The mistake could alter the performance of about 3,600-4,000 students, South Korean media reported.
The minister of education, Hwang Woo-Yea, offered his deep apologies in a televised address and admitted the faulty questions highlighted the need to improve the question-making process.

"We will get to the bottom of what is wrong," he said. On 13 November, about 640,000 students sat the nine-hour College Scholastic Ability Test at 1,216 test centres across the country, South Korea's Yonhap news agency said.

Many students spend years preparing for the test in a cut-throat academic environment and often under the close gaze of their parents. A good test result guarantees enrolment at South Korea's top universities.

The two questions in the biology and the English tests caused an uproar. Many angry parents and students expressed dissatisfaction on the website of the Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation (KICE), which administers the exam.
Last year's exam was also marred by a controversial test question on world geology.
After a protracted legal battle, the Seoul High Court ruled in favour of four students against that question.

"Although we made all-out efforts to come up with perfect questions this year, faulty ones have again caused significant confusion and inconvenience among students, their parents and teachers," KICE head Kim Sung-Hoon said.

NATO says it has not held an ambassador-level meeting of the council since June 2014, although there has been other political contact.

In a report published in 2014, the public protector, a constitutionally mandated watchdog, said Mr Zuma had "unduly benefited" from the upgrades and should repay a portion of the money to the state.

"He proposes that they report back to the court on the reasonable amount that the president should pay within 60 days.
