Africa Live: News updates from BBC News In quotes: Zuma's offer to pay some of the Nkandla money The expansion of Mr Zuma's rural home in Nkandla, KwaZulu-Natal, has turned into a major political controversy in South Africa.
Taxpayers' cash has been spent on the construction of an amphitheatre, swimming pool and even a cattle enclosure.

However, the opposition Democratic Alliance (DA) and Julius Malema's Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF), which asked for an investigation into corruption claims, say despite the president's latest move, they are going ahead with their court case.
'Pay back the money'# After Mr Zuma's latest announcement, #PayBackTheMoney has become the top trending hashtag on Twitter in South Africa.
It was the chant that the EFF MPs used to disrupt the president's state of the nation address in parliament last year.

However, many are saying they will believe it when they see it. President Zuma Punches at the South Africa Parliament Mr Zuma has been ridiculed over the huge cost Punches at the South Africa Parliament Court action aimed at stopping the spending on Mr Zuma's house Punches at the South Africa Parliament Why did Zuma sack two finance ministers in a week?

All figures in 2013 financial terms Source: Public Protector Report Analysis: Milton Nkosi, BBC News, Johannesburg# President Jacob Zuma's offer to pay is most likely a face-saving exercise to at least avoid the embarrassment of defending the complaint at the country's Constitutional Court next week.
It could also be related to the local government election, expected some time later this year.
The Nkandla affair has caused a huge headache for the governing African National Congress (ANC) under President Zuma's tenure, as the party's cadres try to drum up support from the voters.

Political analyst Professor Somadoda Fikeni says it is also possible that due to a potential vulnerability in the president's political position as he enters the "lame-duck" phase approaching the end of his tenure and the recent debacle surrounding the appointment of at least three finance ministers last year, he may be wanting to capitulate.
There remains the possibility that Mr Zuma also wants to avoid a repetition of what happened during the state of the nation address at the opening of parliament last year.
Mr Malema's EFF MPs disrupted his speech, chanting "pay back the money" when the president started his address.
The parliamentary security guards had to be called in to remove some MPs who chanted even more vigorously, drowning Mr Zuma's voice as he continued to deliver his speech.
In a rare interview, Petraeus outlined the difficulty of dealing with what he called “industrial-strength extremists” and warned that military power alone cannot resolve the problem.

The general, who is as closely identified as anyone with the Iraq war, devised the “surge” strategy that deployed about 30,000 additional U.S. troops to the war and won the cooperation of many Sunni tribesmen in Iraq’s battle against al-Qaeda.

Now he watches Iraq’s U.S.-supplied army try to recapture ground lost to IS. Petraeus calls IS “a serious enemy” — “a conventional army that also has elements of an insurgency, plus terrorist elements.” But Petraeus, when asked, compared the Islamic State to al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI), the group he is credited with demolishing in Iraq.
“It has to be remembered AQI was much larger and more deeply rooted in Iraq than IS has been,” he said.

Petraeus termed IS’s recent capture of Ramadi, capital of Iraq’s western province of Anbar, “a strategic loss” that “calls into question once again the viability of the U.S. strategy.” Ramadi’s fall, he told me, “has done a setback to the narrative that IS is on the run.” But Petraeus assesses that the city “should be retaken in a matter of weeks or less,” and will not be “a tremendous challenge.” [What Obama really thinks about friends and foes, according to David Petraeus] He said, “There’s no question this is a setback to the momentum that has been achieved,” and it “calls for thorough review and tweaks and re-examination obviously.
That’s happening.” Who is David Petraeus? 1974: After graduating from West Point, David Petraeus is commissioned in the United States Army.
2007: As a four-star general, Petraeus commanded all forces in the multinational counterinsurgency of the Iraq war.

2008: Petraeus becomes head of U.S. Central Command. 2010: Petraeus takes the job as NATO commanding officer in Afghanistan. mid-2011: Petraeus ends a 37-year-long Army career to become head of the CIA.
November 2012: Petraeus announces his resignation as CIA director. Click to read more about Petraeus’s career.
Petraeus was the director of the CIA, after commanding international forces in Iraq and Afghanistan and retiring as a four-star general.
He resigned from the CIA in 2012 after he admitted to an extramarital affair with his biographer, who is a former officer in the Army Reserves.
He was accused of supplying secret information to his mistress and eventually pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor over the matter.

[Based on the story? Browse newly released CIA intelligence briefs from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan ] Despite the personal scandal, Petraeus remains perhaps the most colorful figure in America’s recent wars.

He devised the strategy popularized as the “surge,” adding about 30,000 U.S. troops to the U.S. force already in Iraq and moving them out of large compounds into the neighborhoods to improve security.
He also expanded the strategy known as the “Anbar awakening” of enlisting Sunni tribes to turn on transnational jihadis from al-Qaeda.
Now, with recent setbacks in Iraq, the White House, the Pentagon and Capitol Hill are looking to him for advice. He still preaches the importance of matching political and military action.
The Senate voted 61-38 on the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities - short of the two-thirds majority required.
Wheelchair-bound Republican former presidential candidate Bob Dole came to the Senate floor to back it.
The accord has been signed by 155 countries and ratified by 126, including the UK, France, Germany, China and Russia.
Wednesday’s treaty was intended to guarantee disabled people the same rights and freedoms as their fellow citizens around the world.
Advertise “Bob Dole is here, sitting in a wheelchair, not wanting to let anybody know.
But Bob and I and John McCain, (Senator) Dick Lugar, all veterans, especially Vietnam veterans … (former Attorney General Dick) Thornburgh, all veterans, all heavily wounded.
They’re all in support of this,” Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee and Obama’s nominee for secretary of state, said as Dole was wheeled onto the Senate floor.
Just eight of 47 Senate Republicans voted for the measure, despite support for it from a number of prominent party members and veterans groups.
Sen. Jim Inhofe of Oklahoma said he opposed the pact because he does not trust the United Nations.

“It’s the unelected bureaucratic bodies that will inevitably put the United States in a position of having to comply with one-size-fits-all rules that disregard the American model of federalism,” Inhofe said.
The White House said it was “deeply disappointed” at the vote, caused by “a handful of Republican senators”.

“This treaty would simply help protect Americans with disabilities who chose to live, work, or travel abroad, and it would encourage other countries to recognize the rights of people with disabilities, reflecting our values of equality and opportunity for all,” it said in a statement.
“It’s a sad day when a handful of folks in the Senate… can’t support the basic tenets of equality and fairness that inspire so many of us, as Americans,” the White House added.
Kerry said the treaty was “pretty simple” and “straightforward. It says that you can’t discriminate against the disabled”.
Supporters said ratification would not require any change in US law, but Republican opponents warned it could lead to greater bureaucracy and was too broadly written.

“It is because of concerns over the one-fits-all approach of international organisations that past Republican leaders have kept treaties like this from ever coming to the floor in the first place,” Sen. Jim Inhofe of Oklahoma said in a floor speech.
Advertise The accord was negotiated under President George W. Bush, also a Republican, and signed by President Barack Obama in 2009.
It is based on the 1990 Americans with Disabilities Act and would not require any changes to US law, supporters argued.

Among those calling for its ratification were the United States Olympic Committee, the Special Olympics and more than 100 other faith, business and disability advocacy organizations and conservative leaders included Bush and 1996 GOP presidential nominee Bob Dole of Kansas.
An estimated 10 per cent of the world’s population – about 650 million people – is disabled, the UN says. Advertise Source: BBC News Like this: Like Loading...
He "appreciated" the "importance" of the monument, three judges were told, but didn't know that he was swinging from a war memorial.
Gilmour, of Billingshurst, West Sussex, was given a 16-month jail term after admitting violent disorder in July.

The 21-year-old is appealing against the sentence. Judges heard that he had ingested the hallucinogenic drug LSD and Valium before joining central London demonstrations against fee rises last December.
He was photographed high on the Cenotaph swinging from a Union flag and leaping on to a Jaguar which was part of a royal convoy.
A crown court judge ruled he had also thrown a bin at the car, a decision his legal team is appealing.
The judge at Kingston-upon-Thames crown court said he accepted the incident at the Cenotaph was not part of the violent disorder but described it as "outrageous and deeply offensive behaviour".
Gilmour, who was adopted by singer David Gilmour, kicked the window of Topshop's flagship Oxford Street store during his rampage which ended with him carrying away the leg of a mannequin.
David Spens QC, defending Gilmour, said his client "couldn't identify" the Cenotaph, which commemorates war dead.
The barrister added that his client had not owned a television in more than 10 years, and this was "not actually as surprising as might have been thought".
He said he had turned to drink and drugs after being turned away by his biological father, the writer Heathcote Williams.
Mr Spens said Gilmour had "successfully reformed and rehabilitated himself" and tackled his "underlying drug and alcohol problems".
He said: "My submission is that this sentence was unduly harsh, unnecessarily so."
The court said it would not give a ruling until other Court of Appeal decisions arising from the August riots, which may affect the case, had been given.
He announced her appointment at the charity screening of the show’s finale organised by Dorset Rape Crisis in Bridport, Dorset, on Monday night.
Hesmondhalgh said she was proud to have “given a voice” to rape victims in the eight-part crime thriller.
She said she was honoured to help raise awareness of all those doing amazing work.

The charity said they were “thrilled” she had accepted the role. The third and final series of Broadchurch, which was partially filmed in West Bay, Dorset, has focused on the rape of Trish Winterman, played by former Coronation Street star Hesmondhalgh.
Trish’s relationship with her rape counsellor, Beth Latimer, is one of the successes of the show.
Jodie Whittaker, who plays Beth, joined Hesmondhalgh at the final episode screening.

Tracy Parsons, from Dorset Rape Crisis, which worked closely with the show’s writer and producer Chris Chibnall, said the series had proved there was plenty of help for those who were struggling to come to terms with rape.
“We are so thrilled that Julie Hesmondhalgh has agreed to be our patron for Dorset Rape Crisis,” Parsons said.
“It’s a real honour for our trustees, staff and clients to have someone so high profile.

“Having the final episode showing was fantastic. Julie and Jodie stayed behind and answered everybody’s questions, which gave a real insight into those involved in making the series.” Hesmondhalgh said: “It’s a great relief to have given a voice, even this tiny little voice, to women who have been through something like this and all the shades in between.” Talking about her new role as patron of Dorset Rape Crisis, she added: “I am honoured to help raise awareness of all those doing amazing, invaluable work.” She said rape was “the issue of our time”, adding: “You can talk at home to your family about consent and respect and healthy sexual relations.”
Some have seen bills rise in the range of 900% following a reassessment, something many describe as "ridiculous".
It leaves almost all of the profits of some energy schemes being handed over to councils, with some now being run at a loss, according to the BBC Wales.
The Welsh Government was aware of the problem and was considering targeted help.
But the British Hydropower Association accused ministers of doing nothing, while Community Energy Wales told the BBC that the changes were "crippling" projects.
Community energy schemes are generally on a small scale and run by groups of volunteers, with money raised going into the local community.
But the system for assessing business rates is having a disproportionate effect on hydro schemes.
Rates in England and Wales are set by the Valuation Office Agency, the Welsh Government having powers over the rates in Wales.
The British Hydropower Association has asked Finance Secretary Mark Drakeford for help.
Its chief executive Simon Hamlyn said: "Community hydro schemes are now really struggling.
"People who are running businesses have now said, 'Well we just can't afford it, so we're just going to walk away from the scheme.'
"We do not want to do that." Community Energy Wales director Keith Jones said the rise on most hydro schemes was 300%.
"No business plan we've ever looked at features hitting them with effectively a huge tax," he said, adding the increase was "crippling" projects.
The Scottish government has given 100% business rates relief to all community energy schemes, while England has seen the rise capped at £600.
Gavin Gatehouse is behind the Ynni Anafon hydro scheme in Abergwyngregyn, Gwynedd.
Its rates bill has gone from just over £900 to more than £2,000 per month, he said.
It has taken five years to build the project and it could raise up to £40,000 a year to support projects across the region.
A charity has been set up to hand out grants, but the rise will mean less money can be given out.
Another community hydro scheme in Bethesda is also expected to operate in the red.

"It's very frustrating and I'm very angry about it," said Mr Gatehouse. "Our profits are being slashed to bolster underfunded local authorities. This is just compensating for not giving local authorities enough grant."
Mr Drakeford said: "At the last budget, we set aside more than £210m for rate relief in 2017-18 - this is there to help businesses, including community energy producers, meet their bills.
We have also said we will work with stakeholders to design a new small business rate relief scheme for 2018 onwards."
She said when she had her eldest son Dylan, who is now 14, she was told "I’m sorry, your son has Down’s syndrome."
Despite having worked as a nurse and her husband working as a doctor, she said they were given all the "really bad" information (about Down’s syndrome).
"They will tell you the average life expectancy is 50, and that they won’t (go to mainstream school etc), and all the negatives about it, and they will never do this and that," she said.
But her son, who is in Year 9 at a mainstream school and is on the Down’s Syndrome GB swimming squad, has gone on to prove them wrong.

She decided to do something about it, and, while Dylan was two, a health visitor put her in touch with Katharina Barker, from Cardiff, and Nicky Williams, from Risca, who also have children with Down’s syndrome.
"There was a sense that there was something wrong with the support that we were getting and we wanted to do something about it for the future," she said.
Katharina said, while the support they received at the birth of her daughter Amelie, now 11, was good, there are few specialists.
"It’s pretty frustrating because if nobody points you in the right direction you won’t find the services for Down’s syndrome because there is nobody specialising in it," she said.
The three decided to hold a coffee morning to enable other parents, in Monmouthshire, Blaenau Gwent, Caerphilly, Newport and Torfaen, to share their experiences.
After its success, the women decided to set up a charity to offer speech and language therapy, educational support and an annual conference.

While Nicky has now stepped aside, the Monmouth based 21 Plus charity is celebrating its 10th anniversary and Victoria and Katharina said they are even more determined to increase the provision of their services.
Their work saw them being named finalists in the national St David Awards citizenship category.
"We are trying really hard to help our kids achieve their potential and give access to more opportunities for children with Down’s," said Victoria.

"One of the mums said she loves that she can ask us anything. Sometimes you are afraid to ask certain questions; it’s the little things that you don’t want to feel stupid asking, that is why I do it."
Albert Newman drove about thirty miles the wrong way on M42, then A42 and finally M1, so he ended up smashing into a van.
At the inquest they showed one police force had no highway patrols while another didn’t realize Mr. Newman’s license was already cancelled, therefore the mistake slipped by unnoticed.
The hearing was delayed—officers need to answer more questions, therefore the coroner pushed it back.

*Mr. Newman, a dementia stricken man from Nottingham, hit his Mazda Premacy into a Transit van near Kegworth, Leicestershire last October – Michael Luciw didn’t survive and Andy Harrington was left injured.
* *The inquiry learned Warwickshire police got the first call about a car going the wrong way on the M42, yet they recorded the opposite direction at first, therefore the report was off.
* *Error got fixed but Newman crossed onto the A42 into Leicestershire where road police had already end shift, therefore county left without motorway patrols.

* Pamela Oxlade, traveling with her husband to Birmingham Airport, told the inquest, “We just passed a lorry, then two balls of light showed up.” *It raced past in a flash, felt unreal—there was no car outline you could see in the dark.
* **I called 999 and described what was happening; therefore the responder said they already aware.
** We said, therefore, we’re about a half hour off the M1 heading straight to Birmingham.
It felt like a giant sigh of relief, ‘cause they knew. About twenty minutes later Mrs. Oxlade caught sight of signs urging drivers to slow down – a car was moving the wrong way.
**Trevor Kirkman, the coroner, says Leicestershire police not handling the process right; it looks pretty broken.

** It drove far, nobody tried to stop, therefore just kept rolling. Therefore at the Loughborough hearing they found out months before the crash Nottinghamshire Police had talked to Mr. Newman after a tip reported his driving seemed like dementia.
Did anyone even look at the paperwork? It would have shown his license was revoked for medical reasons two years ago.
Mr. Kirkman pushed the hearing back to December; was the police even allowed to take the car then?
He didn’t know, therefore the case was delayed. *In conclusion, at the end a senior officer of Nottinghamshire police apologised to families, admitting maybe the force could've stopped the tragedy.*
Today it is common to imagine novel inventions emerging from anonymous Eurekas and popping out of nondescript laboratories teeming with young scientists after many grant applications.

But perhaps the age of the backyard inventor is not dead yet. It turns out that there are a couple of doctors who are consultants in anaesthesia at Morriston Hospital, Swansea, and they had their own Eureka while playing in their garages with glue guns and car-body filler.
Their eureka came with a joke that they wanted to design something as cheap and easy to use as a wind-up radio (as invented by Trevor Baylis) for use in a medical context.

One of the doctors Dr Williams has spent a career combining medical research with work, training healthcare workers in remote, rural areas of the developing world, and such a device would, he realised, make sense to doctors everywhere.
He reports to have seen all equipment in whole operating theatres go to waste for the lack of a spare light bulb or constant power supply in Zambia.
In response to that they wanted to create devices essential for clinical treatment on a shoestring budget.

After less than a week of modifying basic medical equipment using power tools they produced a prototype of the ShakerScope--a light which can be simply modified for use looking at the eyes, ears and throat, and which requires no batteries.

Dr Patrick Finlay, chairman of the medical engineers' division of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, said: "About 95 per cent of medical devices fail in developing countries, according to the World Health Organisation, mainly because of where and how they were designed -- usually by people in the West who rarely consider world conditions.

An invention like this is precisely what is needed £ $ A for a normal exam of a patient, you need three different battery-powered instruments, and somehow that is just not going to happen in a poor country."
The ShakerScope trialled by Dr David Williams is operated by a powerful magnet which is surrounded by a looped coil of wire.
As Michael Faraday discovered in 1831, moving a magnet through a coil of copper wire induces a current.
By shaking the ShakerScope for 30 seconds it is possible to generate enough current to power a bright light at the top of the half-metre long ruler on which the magnet sits for a good three minutes.
"That doesn't sound long, but it is long enough for most examinations of ears and eyes or for intubation, inserting tubes into the trachea," Dr Williams said.
Once charged, the scope will hold its charge for weeks, and the light emitting diode which it uses for illumination will last as long as 10,000 hours.
Dr Williams and Dr John Dingley have also devised simply interchangeable heads, allowing their invention to be converted into any number of different devices.
Former MK Dons midfielder Carl Baker scored on his debut to earn Portsmouth a draw, cancelling out Reggie Lambe's opener for 10-man Carlisle.

Jamie Devitt had already been sent off for the Cumbrians before the break. Pompey made a flying start to the new campaign with Milan Lalkovic seeing a stinging fifth-minute effort well saved by Carlisle keeper Mark Gillespie.

Carlisle were reduced to 10 men when Jamie Devitt picked up a second yellow card in the space of six minutes for pulling back Gary Roberts.
Baker restored parity on 37 minutes with a low left-foot drive across Gillespie and into the bottom corner from 10 yards.

(American Airlines (AA)) (Southwest Airlines (WN)) Two airliners touched wings on the taxiway in Detroit on Wednesday morning, prompting an investigation by air safety officials.
The wing of an American Airlines plane struck the tail of a Southwest Airlines plane as they were moving and waiting to take off.
The incident happened at 06:05 local time (11:05 GMT) at Detroit Metropolitan Airport.
Passengers were left sitting on the aircraft, and there were no immediate injuries reported or fuel leaks.
The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) said it would look into the incident.
Ground accident Aviation Passenger Fletcher Sharpe, who was on the Southwest flight, told the BBC from the airport that he was waiting to switch flights following the crash.

"Sitting on the plane, a few were whispering they thought the two planes were close but then we didn't know there was going to be a collision until it happened - there was a loud crunch and scraping," he said.
"I thought maybe they ran over something and I looked out and saw the right wing of the plane and it was damaged - I could see the tail end of the other plane and it looked like part of it was gone."
"It was pretty frustrating. I know it's a stressful job but making sure you have enough clearance is one of those things that even people driving a car learn the hard way."

Broken axel PhillipsAre Swift passenger tweeted this image of the broken tail of the Southwest plane (PhillipsAreSwift) Passenger Jim Bishop told Fox 2 News Detroit that he was left sitting on the American Airlines plane for about 2.5 hours with little information to start with.
"For about 10 minutes there was no address to us ... then they made an announcement saying there was a little accident, please be calm."
"Then one of the stewards took the microphone and said in 35 years of flying, I've never been involved with this."
The temperature was below freezing at ground level at the time of the incident and the Southwest plane was being sprayed with de-icer at the time of the incident.
The planes involved were both Boeing 737s. Southwest said its aircraft needed to be checked after it was involved in the incident with the AA plane which had been set to fly to Dallas.

The 95 passengers had been re-booked. "We apologise to our customers for the inconvenience and are working to get them all to their destinations as quickly as possible," Southwest said in a statement.
A spokeswoman for AA said their 150 Dallas-bound passengers were also booked on alternative flights.
The 66-year-old slipped on his way to the toilet and banged his head, requiring stitches for a "severe gash" close to his eye.
He struggles to walk because of a back operation, which contributed to the fall.
He was taken to hospital and will be kept under observation for up to 24 hours.
The gigs, due to be held on 8 and 9 June, will be rescheduled for November. The postponement was announced hours before he was due to take to the stage.
Some fans were already on their way to London when they were informed. One wrote on Facebook: "Sorry to hear that ... but we are on a train heading to see him.

As well as sending "sincere apologies and thanks to fans", the singer said he had had a "fantastic week at his first shows in 10 years" and that he "really wanted to continue".
"He sends his sincere apologies and thanks to fans. "He is disappointed not to be able to perform and wishes to apologise for any disappointment caused.

The pop singer is best known for being a drummer and singer in the prog-rock band Genesis, and went onto to become of the most successful songwriters and performers of all time.

Along with Sir Paul McCartney and Michael Jackson, he is one of only three recording artists who have sold more than 100 million albums worldwide both as solo artists and separately as principal musicians of a band.
He has had three UK and seven US number one singles. They include A Groovy Kind of Love and Against All Odds.
Among his accolades, he has won seven Grammy Awards, six Brit Awards, an Oscar and two Golden Globes.

The University Hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS Foundation Trust was rated "inadequate" following an inspection by the Care Quality Commission (CQC).
The Royal Lancaster Infirmary and Furness General Hospital in Barrow were highlighted as needing to improve the level of care.
The trust said it was not halfway "through a process of significant improvement."
Last year, the trust running hospitals in north Cumbria was one of 11 high-performing trusts following the Keogh recommendations into high mortality rates.
The CQC, health watchdog, said that on a previous visit in February, it found maternity and A&E services had improved but that "many of the concerns raised then remain today."
Inspectors were particularly concerned about the medical care in one part of the Royal Lancaster.
Recruitment of nurses and doctors across the trust were a "fundamental" problem, with services "too reliant" on temporary staff.
Prof Sir Mike Richards, chief inspector of hospitals, said: "The trust has a long history of problems with the quality of care.
So it is disappointing to report that many of these issues remain unresolved. "I do not believe the trust can resolve its challenges without external support," he said.
The trust runs three hospitals, including the Barrow and Lancaster facilities, which were visited along with Westmorland General Hospital near Kendal.
Inspectors said Westmorland General - which had previously faced closure - was largely offering a good service.
The trust's chief executive, Jackie Daniel, said: "The CQC's reports demonstrate the halfway through a process of significant improvement which will take a number of years to complete.
"Changing the culture within a large and complex organisation is not something that can be done overnight." All the inspection reports are available from the CQC website.
The book was put together and signed by the squadron's most senior doctor as a ninth birthday present for son in 1943.
The commanding officer for the sortie was shot down and killed on his way back from the bombing raid.
Flt Cdr Henry Melvin 'Dinghy' Young, a pilot Avro Lancaster A-Apple in the first wave which bombarded the Möhne Dam, signed the autograph book.
It was sold in Newark, Nottinghamshire by a man whose father had gathered the autographs at a RAF base in Scampton, Lincolnshire, where the Dambusters, Squadron 617, was formed in March 1943.
Bombing raids were carried out on three dams in the industriales Ruhr Valley of Germany in May using Barnes Wallis's distinctive bouncing bomb.

Of the 19 planes that flew the mission, eight were shot down. Flt Cdr Henry Melvin 'Dinghy' Young, the 27-year-old deputy commander was killed when he was shot down over the North Sea on his return to England.
He was named 'Dinghy' because he had twice survive smashing into the sea in an inflatable boat after other missions.
His Avro Lancaster A-Apple flew in the first wave which hurled the bombs the Möhne Dam.
Signed by others from different squadrons stationed at Scampton, the book reveals the names of Gp Capt Robert McFarlane and Flying Officer Chas Walker.

McFarlane later commanded a Lancaster Bomber squadron in the Battle of Berlin, and Walker was an Australian cricketer who died in action in December 1942. The signatures are accompanied by small illustrations.
One man drew a detailed sketch of a Lancaster cruising through the skies while another, by an Australian man, is of a kangaroo.
A join effort depicts two cartoon airmen with the caption 'Jolly good show, what?!'

also appears. James Brown, who sold the album, also put up for auction a silk map which the seller's father retrieved from the burning wreckage of a Lancaster bomber. He also dug up the man's original commission as a flying officer.

She said the Games would be a source of "honour and pride" for the country. Ms Rousseff, whose ratings have tumbled during a domestic economic crisis, pledged that her country would show itself ready to deliver a safe and secure Olympics.
Ms Rousseff said 12,000 people would each bear the Olympic torch through about 300 Brazilian cities next year.
"We are now 399 days from the opening of the Olympic Games and on 5 August the world will once again look at us and see the lighting of the Olympic flame," Ms Rousseff said in a ceremony in Brasilia.
The torch relay will begin in the capital in May and end at Rio's Maracana stadium in August during the Games' opening ceremony.
The Olympics will run until 21 August. The torchbearers will be selected by the organising committee and sponsors in coming months.
Each of them will run with the torch for 300m. The Olympic flame will pass through the Federal District, where Brasilia is located, and 26 Brazilian states in 90 to 100 days.
Ms Rousseff said security would be high on the agenda, and welcomed the thousands of fans who came to Brazil from across the world for the football World Cup last year to return for the Rio Olympics.
The International Olympic Committee has voiced concerns about the pace of preparations.
There have also been concerns about the clean-up of polluted bay waters in Guanabara Bay, where the sailing and windsurfing Olympics events will be held.
Officials say they are aware of athletes' concerns, but do not expect water contamination to cause any considerable health risk during the Games, in August 2016.
"We hope that we can respond to the challenge," Ms Rousseff said. "We will do a historic Olympics."
Some 206 countries are due to take part in the event in Rio, the first city in South America to host the Olympics.
She died on Monday 8th April 2013, at 87 years old. She died peacefully. Her funeral was on Wednesday 17th April 2013.
It was a ceremonial funeral, with military honours. Margaret Thatcher was controversial from the start.
When she came to power in 1979, she promised she would change the way the country was governed.
She did make huge changes in Britain. She persuaded us that privately-owned companies could run government-owned services, like British Gas and BT (British Telecom), better.
She gave hundreds of thousands of ordinary people a stake in society by selling them their council houses.
She began the process by which the City of London became the centre of banking and business.

She was a hero when, in 1982, she sent British troops to defend the Falklands Islands, a tiny group of islands 8000 miles away in the South Atlantic. They had been invaded by Argentina, but we won them back in a short war.
Hundreds on both sides died, but we came home victorious. Despite such huge support, some of what Margaret Thatcher did was opposed.
In 1984 tens of thousands of miners went on strike, that is, they refused to work for a year, because she wanted to close down many mines and get rid of many jobs.
Protesters and riots erupted again in London in 1990 because of the poll tax, which protesters argued was designed to tax the poor, not the rich.
Margaret Thatcher became famous as the “Iron Lady”. She hardly ever slept for more than four hours in a night, and she always backed her own strong opinions.
In 2012 a movie appeared on cinema screens about her life, called The Iron Lady.
She was 11 years in office, and won three elections, longer than any other prime minister in the 20th century.
But she outstayed her welcome, even with her own party, and when she left Downing Street, she cried.
It has been over 20 years since then, but Margaret Thatcher is not forgotten. She was the prime minister who changed Britain so much, the most important political figure of the modern age.
The 33ft (10m) sinkhole collapsed at Fontmell Close in St Albans on 1 October last year, on the site of a former clay pit.
Some properties are still without utility services and the road closure, while inquiries continue.

The county council hopes to have repairs finished by Christmas. After the hole collapsed in the early hours, more than 50 families were left without electricity, water supplies or sewage facilities until temporary services could be restored for the majority.
They still have to use a temporary road across nearby Nomansland Common to access their homes.

A "detailed surface microgravity investigation" and exploratory drilling confirmed the hole had been caused by "mine workings" and a ground subsidence report found "no indication of significant voiding", the council said.

"We've had to look at why the ground collapsed before we could start work to repair the road, but we're back now and keen to get on with the job," said Terry Douris, Hertfordshire County Council's cabinet member for highways.
"It has been a very stressful time for the residents and it would be marvellous if they could safely be back in their own homes before Christmas."
Ben Bagshawe, one of the residents who was evacuated along with his heavily-pregnant wife, had a baby boy about a week after the hole appeared.
They have been living in a rented flat, with the costs being met by his insurance. "It's been annoying but it hasn't been the end of the world," he said.
Their neighbours, Rosemary and Derek Broom, whose house was closest to the hole, have remained in their property.
They said they "probably have the safest location in the country to live at the moment".
Mrs Broom said: "Everything has been surveyed, the roads, the field, the children's recreation ground so we are not at all anxious."

The human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccine can prevent head and neck cancer, say scientists and charities.
The sexually-transmitted virus is fought off by jabs given to 12 and 13-year-old girls to prevent cervical cancer.
The Welsh government said it was still waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation.
A letter on the issue will be sent by Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru and Cardiff University's team of HPV experts on Monday.
They told BBC Radio Wales' Eye on Wales programme cases of head and neck cancers are increasing.
"I've noticed over the last 10 years a change in the people who have head and neck cancer," said Dr Mererid Evans, consultant oncologist at Velindre Hospital in Cardiff.
"They tend to be younger men, they tend to have families, their average age is 55 and the majority of them don't smoke."
Jon Antoniazzi from Tenovus Cancer Care said: "HPV is responsible for 5% of the cancer burden worldwide.
The Welsh government has the chance to take a stand on stopping these cancers, and show it is committed to the health of the public and future generations.
"We're calling for them to challenge the status quo, think outside the box and start protecting boys against these cancers."

Image caption Since 2008, 85% of girls in Wales have been given the vaccination There has been a school vaccination programme since 2008 which mean 85% of girls have been given the vaccination in Wales.

The Welsh government said: "We await the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation (JCVI) recommendations on this issue and we will consider any suggestions for a change to the HPV vaccination programme in Wales."
Eye on Wales is on BBC Radio Wales at 12:30 BST on Sunday 26 June. To listen again go to the BBC iPlayer.
This spring, Chapman's Ice Cream offered to buy the Beavercrest Community School in Markdale for about CA$1m ($741,000; 596,000), in part a tribute to the community that raised them.

"There's all sorts of red tape and asbestos issues, but this is our back yard and we are looking to work with the board and to throw some financing in as well," Chapman's vice-president Ashley Chapman told the BBC. "Somebody has to do something to begin to sort out this issue."
He called on the school board and government to find a solution, suggesting the company buy the building and lease it to the school board at a cost that would allow it to function.
Still, the aging building could need millions in renovations and laws around private interests buying public assets are complicated.
"In essence our offer was really a 'band-aid' just to stem the bleeding in the short term".
Beavercrest is one of some 600 schools the province has closed or will close since 1990 to save money, most in rural towns and villages.
If it closes, village kids can face up to a 90 minute bus ride to schools in other districts the closest which are also slated to close.
The school has 195 students and is capable of holding 319, a recent school board study found. Chapman said the changes need to have "the kids best interests in mind".
A Beavercrest graduate himself, Chapman said the offer is both the right thing to do and good business.

Founded by Chapman's parents in 1973, the company is now one of the largest ice cream facilities in Canada and has been doubling their staff rate over the last six years with further business growth in sight.
The company has to attract workers to Markdale, a hamlet of 1,325 people. Despite wage increases it remains hard to do. "If we don't have an elementary school, how do we bring in people?"
The Criminal Justice Psychoactive Substances Act was introduced five years ago. That's when the blanket ban was brought in.
Before it happened, there were about 100 so-called headshops selling legal highs across the state.
Today there are none. "The headshop industry is no longer in Ireland," said Det Supt Tony Howard from the Garda Drugs Unit.

He was tasked with enforcing the act. "We became concerned because a new generation of young people were starting to experiment with new psychoactive substances and they were doing it generally from the point of view of people who hadn't previously abused drugs," he added.
"Their view was because they were legal highs, it was okay." The ban made it a criminal offence to advertise, sell, supply, import or export psychoactive substances.
Tobacco, alcohol, caffeine and medicines were excluded from the ban in the Republic of Ireland.

Before the act came into force selling legal highs could be very profitable. Fire fighters discovered a safe which contained 450,000 euros (£330,000) in the rubble of a Dublin headshop, which was set alight in an arson attack.
As the selling of legal highs wasn't illegal at the time, police were forced to hand the money back to the owner of the safe.
That wouldn't happen today because of the ban. Det Supt Howard found many headshop owners wanted to stay the right side of the law.
"The industry itself saw how strong the legislation was and assisted us in giving up whatever quantities they had left in store," he said. Should the UK follow Ireland's lead and ban legal highs?
The law got headshops off the high street. But there are those who believe it isn't the best way to keep users safe.
Tony Duffin is the director of the Ana Liffey Drug Project in Dublin. He said lots of harm is still being caused to people by substances previously sold in the shops.
He told Sky News lots of recreational users are now buying psychoactive substances online.

And those who use them more often are buying them from drug dealers. "In New Zealand they are introducing laws to regulate headshop drugs so the UK should look at all their options in terms of drug policy," Mr Duffin said.
Police acted after complaints two men were acting suspiciously in the vicinity of secondary schools in Carrickfergus.
Images shared on social media platforms of a clown and his sidekick in a balaclava have unnerved many in the town.
A number of social media users took offence at officers for ‘spoiling Halloween fun’, but police acted on reports from parents who felt their children had been left afraid of the clown.
Posting on the PSNI Newtownabbey and Carrickfergus Facebook page, an officer wrote: “We all like a bit of fun.

We all enjoy what passes on social media, but terrifying pupils on their way to and from secondary schools is a different matter.” The substitute teacher clothed as a clown got in touch with police to explain he had no intention of causing distress.
Going by the name of the Carrick ‘Killer Clown’, he told police it was “meant as a bit of a wheeze for Halloween and certainly was not intended to frighten pupils or cause any this kind of distress”.
The police officer wrote: “He is fully aware of the sensitive nature surrounding schools and photographs etc.
near schools.” Speaking to BBC Radio Ulster’s Evening Extra programme, the clown said he had been receiving messages from worried parents.
“That wasn’t the aim. It was meant to be just fun. I am a parent myself and obviously it was brought to my attention there was a bit of a problem when someone raised an issue of concern,” he said.
“I was going to ask the PR officer for Carrick PSNI was there any way to turn up at school heads and apologise personally, but obviously would have needed to strip the civvies that day.

He passed on my apology and it was accepted, so maybe parents will know.” A post on the Carrick Killer Clowns Facebook page earlier stated: “The photos from the schools have been taken down due to the positive and negative response from them.

It was originally meant as a bit of a laugh but obviously some parents have seen it differently and not funny.” They then shared an image of themselves outside Carrickfergus PSNI station a short time later.

The Chancellor’s Autumn Statement – more details, now a set per‑student rate, extra funds for children with extra needs, therefore schools get more money.

Another £100,000 is needed to save the 1733 portrait of Gambian Ayuba Suleiman Diallo, painted by artist William Hoare.
The purchase price of the artwork is £555,000, with funding from the Heritage Lottery Fund, The Art Fund and the National Portrait Gallery (NPG).
The portrait has never been seen in public before, but is currently on display at the London gallery.
Diallo was a member of a prominent family of religious clerics when he was captured as a slave in Africa at the age of 29 and transported to work on a plantation in America.

After trying to escape and being sent to jail he met lawyer Thomas Bluett who, impressed by his intelligence and education, brought him to England where he was received as a celebrity by royalty and the literary elite.
The NPG said Hoare's painting was "the first British portrait to honour an African subject and present him on an equal footing with other British sitters".
Diallo "was renowned during his lifetime as a man of great intelligence, revealed in Hoare's striking portrait", the statement added.
The portrait was in a private collection for several years and had never been on public display, a gallery spokeswoman told the BBC News website.
It was sold at Christie's auction house in London on 6 December last year for £554,937.50, she said.
After the sale, Culture Minister Margaret Hodge placed a temporary export bar on it to give UK museums and galleries the chance to raise funds to match the auction price.
The Heritage Lottery Fund and The Art Fund have pledged £333,000 and £100,000 respectively while a substantial sum has also been invested by the NPG.
The Heritage Lottery Fund's grant will also help to support the costs of acquisition, conservation, display and touring of the painting to other galleries and museums in the UK.

Zeinab Badawi, broadcaster and national portrait gallery trustee, said: "An exceptionally rare portrait of an 18th century African depicted here in Britain would be a visually arresting and intellectually enriching addition to the national portrait gallery, reflecting the rich tapestry of portraits that captures Britain's cultural history."
Liberty Global, which owns Virgin Media, said original figures from Virgin showed that it had connected 465,000 new premises in the UK and Ireland in 2016.
That was revised to 314,000 after Liberty found that Virgin had inflated the figure and implied it would be able to deliver those connections quickly.
Liberty said in a regulatory filing that Virgin had included in its count of premises "constructed" connections that were not yet fully made but rather "essentially complete".
These included 142,000 new sites that were due to be connected in the first quarter of 2017.

"In late February 2017... it became apparent to...Liberty Global that construction activity relating to the connection of a significant number of [these premises] had either not progressed as originally understood," the statement said.
"This spurred a review of the circumstances, which identified that the completion status of construction in relation to some of the premises had been misrepresented."
Liberty's review also found that Virgin had "inadvertently" counted 9,000 premises that were not completed.
"[Virgin Media] continues to expand at a faster rate than any other broadband operator in the UK," said consumer telecoms analyst for Cable.co.uk, Dan Howdle.
"However, it's clear the parameters in place for reporting the programme's progress left far too much to the imagination — this was qualitative rather than quantitative.
"Virgin Media is right to take rapid action to redress the situation, but this sort of thing does have the potential to damage a brand.
That said, we have no reason to believe Virgin... set out to mislead anyone in any way."
Four Virgin Media employees have been suspended as a result of Liberty's probe and face disciplinary action, including losing their jobs.
Virgin Media said the setback would affect the number of premises it would connect in the first half of 2017, but it is taking steps to "turbo charge" Project Lightning.
It has hired a new managing director, former Kelly Group chief executive Robert Evans, to run the project.
And henceforth it will no longer include premises that are not fully completed in its targets.
Project Lightning was launched in February 2015 to connect around four million UK homes and businesses to broadband speeds of 300Mbps.
It had connected 567,000 premises by the end of December, less than the 718,000 that had been originally reported.
The industrial action centres on a 1% pay increase awarded to their counterparts in England, Scotland and Wales last year.
The Department of Health monitored the safe delivery of services during the industrial action.
The department said midwives in Northern Ireland were offered the same agreement as those in England.

'Average increase' "As disappointing as it is that we were not able to do more in 2014/15, we should not forget that midwives and other non medical staff will actually have received at least 1% from that year, the average overall increase from incremental pay progression is 3.7% and some staff will have received increases of up to 6.7%," a spokesman said.
The most senior band of midwives received the 1% increase as a one off payment last March.
However it was not given to lower pay bands, with the majority of midwives instead receiving an annual increment worth around £1,500 a year.
The Royal College of Midwives (RCM) argue all midwives should receive the 1% pay increase along with their UK colleagues, as well as incremental pay progression.
Pay talks Pay talks between the Department of Health and health unions, including the RCM, took place again on Tuesday.
The talks were described as constructive, however further industrial action is planned.

This comes in the form of an overtime claim for work done. Amy Leversidge , RCM said the health department "have been a bit sneaky in suggesting that midwives in Northern Ireland have received the same pay rise as those in England".
She added: "What happened is that midwives on higher pay bands received the 1% increase as a 'temporary uplift' in pay for the month of February.
In April their salaries reverted back to the 2013 rates. "Incremental pay progression is not a pay rise it is a step up the pay scale based on experience and suitability to perform the role.

"It is an integral part of our national pay structure in the NHS. We really don't want to be in the situation come February 2016 where we will find out what will happen - we want to sit around the table and come to a negotiated pay deal."
Midwife Hazel McAllister said: "We are no less dedicated, no less compassionate and no less hard-working than our colleagues in the other parts of the UK who did receive the 1% pay award.
"We are really very disappointed that our work is not being recognised by the people who are refusing to pay us.
"I've been a midwife for 37 years, it's a fantastic job, I just worry about future of the profession."

Kevin McGuigan Sr died on Wednesday night after being attacked by gunmen at his home on Comber Court off the Short Strand.
It is believed that two men shot him at close range a number of times in the head and chest before making their escape.
The BBC reported that the 53-year-old was one of a number of people speculated to have been involved in the murder of former IRA commander Gerard 'Jock' Davison in May.
Sinn Féin said speculation that the Provisional IRA (PIRA) could have been involved in the murder of McGuigan is without foundation.
However, the DUP said there would be "implications" if such speculation proved correct.
The father-of-nine was taken to the Royal Victoria Hospital following the attack, but he died a short time later.

The BBC's Northern Ireland home affairs correspondent Vincent Kearney said it was a "planned and professional, execution-style" killing carried out by two men in balaclavas using semi-automatic hand guns.
Detective Chief Inspector John McVea, who is leading the murder inquiry, said: "I know the gunmen were on foot, dressed in dark clothing and may have had their faces covered."
He urged anyone with information on the movements of the gunmen before and after the attack to come forward.

In Battle of St Matthew'sājiagm3 McGuigan was questioned by police about the murder 47-year-old father-of-three Jock Davison three months ago in the nearby Markets area of the city As well as being a former Provisional IRA commander and having been a one-time friend of McGuigan, Davison, it is understood, was involved in a feud with him.
McGuigan and Davison were the joint founders of the DAAD (Direct Action Against Drugs) paramilitary group, which killed more than a dozen alleged drug dealers.
McGuigan had survived a DAAD "punishment attack," despite allegedly being a DAAD official at one time - the attack was rumoured to have been ordered by Davis Runrat.

Det Ch Insp McVea said: "I am aware that in the immediate aftermath of Kevin's murder there has been a large amount of speculation surrounding who may be responsible, the motivation behind the attack and Kevin's standing in the community.

"MciGuigan was never considered a suspect in the murder of Jock Davison, but he was believed to have been in a position to witness the incident at the time it occurred - and that is still the standing police assessment."
"Let's be absolutely clear here, speculation of this nature is reckless - it is foolhardy and has the potential to leave Kevin's family enjoying further harm and suffering."
"It is absolutely vital that the police investigation is allowed to take its course.
At the same time, it is equally important that if anyone has information surrounding last night's murder please come to forward and tell us what you know as a matter of urgency."
Although MvVea stopped short of naming McGuigan as a suspect he suggested at a press conference this afternoon that the investigation into Davison's murder is still considering all options.
He also called on community representatives to help in easing tensions in the area.
"Now is the time for calm heads. When emotions are high I would ask our community leaders to exercise calm and restraint in these difficult circumstances."

The reactions in the Baltic to the British majority’s decision on the Brexit referendum include views that this is in the British interest along with others pointing out that Russia will be the true winner.
The first target for criticism was David Cameron, and like in the rest of the Union, his critics there pointed out that he put his party over the needs of the kingdom in initiating the vote.
“David Cameron should apologise to his fellow Europeans for playing roulette with our common future.
Although it's of little help by now,” Estonian Health and Labour Minister Jevgeny Ossinovski commented on Facebook.
Parliament Speaker Eiki Nestor wondered if Cameron was a real statesman: “Prime Minister of Great Britain did not lie to his people when he asked them to take a decision in the ballot box.

But premiership does not mean only election result. Why the man gave priority to election result instead of the future of the United Kingdom or all of Europe?” “David Cameron will join long list of British Prime Ministers whose record was less glorious for their country,” added former Latvian President Vaira Vike-Freiberga on Twitter.
Lithuanian conservative Audronius Azubalis said the referendum results showed “political irresponsibility”.
“I very much love Britain but, as can be seen, there are quite many idiots there, as well,” popular Lithuanian journalist Algis Ramanauskas said on Facebook, ratcheting up more than 1,000 likes.
Meanwhile, there are backers for the decision to leave the European Union among Eurosceptics in the Baltic states’ social networks.
“Land of Hope and Glory” is like a second national anthem for the Brits. Today's day is the day of hope and glory.
Day of freedom and national independence. This victory should be felt also in our Estonian hearts,” Estonian parliamentary member Martin Helme said.
“Britons finally cast their votes against European integration zealots. People are fed up being told how to live,” Lithuanian journalist Andrius Uzkalnis said.
“Do not worry, Trump will be elected, too,” he added. “People say there is a need to get really tough in negotiations between the EU and Britain.

I am sorry, but should the only option the EU has with regard to Cameron's Brexit be the UK being a victim in an honour killing?” Estonian political analyst and columnist Ahto Lobjakas said on his Twitter feed.

Russian-speaking public activist Aleksandr Gaponenko in Latvia perceived Brexit as a future opportunity for Latvia to follow suit; he and a group of like-minded people would soon start collecting signatures under a petition on the matter.

Gaponenko believes “the authorities will be forced to embark on repressions against those who put down their signature, and civilized Europe would not tolerate this and expel Latvia from the European Union (EU) over its repression against the supporters of leaving the EU,” Latvian public television reported.
In Latvia, at least, some commentors point to Russia as the true winner of the Brexit.
The influential Swiss curator also topped the annual Power 100 list - put together by London-based magazine ArtReview - in 2009.
This year, Polish curator Adam Szymczyk has risen from 14th to second in the run-down.
In third place are the Swiss art dealers Iwan and Manuela Wirth, who topped the ArtReview list last year.

"There is no escaping Hans Ulrich Obrist. Between all his activities he circulates a huge network of artists, thinkers, scientists, curators and a whole catalogue of other people," ArtReview's Deputy Editor Oliver Basciano told the BBC News website.
"He uses these connections to disseminate ideas, which is important in an age when contemporary art is more often about ideas than physical objects."

US dealer David Zwirner has dropped from third to fourth. Serota solid Sir Nicholas Serota, the Tate director who confirmed last month he's stepping down from the role after almost 30 years, to take over as chairman of the Arts Council, is in fifth place on tie with Frances Morris, who was named as new director at Tate Modern in January.
Top of the pops This year's top 10 shows that art dealers still rule the roost.
The powerhouse that is the Wirth family, have continued their grip on the market alongside D Zwirner.
Swiss partners Iwan and Manuela have spent the last two decades establishing themselves as the world's leading gallery owners, even opening up a new public galleries complex in Somerset last July .
David Zwirner has dropped one place, in a bad year that saw his entire family being abducted on a trip to Rio de Janeiro.
Other names featured in the top 10 include Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, who is down nine slots at number 10.

ArtReview favourites take up a few small spaces further down the list, with feminist theorist Donna Haraway at number 43, British video artist Ed Atkins at number 50 and the art collective from India, Raqs Media collective rising up 24 spots to 86.
The Power 100 list is a matter of interpretation but is compiled by a jury of 16 comprising writers, artists, curators and critics who judge candidates on their influence over the past 12 months.
To see the full 2016 100 list - go to the ArtReview website. Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsEnts, on Instagram, or if you have a story suggestion email entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.

"Extra-judicial release" of detainees is "a giant step backward", the US said in a statement.
The detainees are part of a batch of 88 prisoners whom the US first held but handed over to Afghan custody last year.
While they are "dangerous individuals", according to the US, there is not enough evidence to keep them in jail, according to Afghanistan.
Earlier this month the Afghan government announced its intentions to release 72 of the detainees.
The US was quick to condemn the decision, saying at the time that there is "strong evidence" linking them to "terror-related crimes".
Hundreds of prisoners have been released since the Afghan government took over Bagram jail in March last year but the batch of 88 detainees remain a bone of contention.
According to the Afghan government there is no evidence against 45 of the 72 detainees that are currently scheduled to be freed.
In the case of the remaining 27 the evidence available was not enough to put them on trial.
The US says the release of any of the planned 88 detainees would violate a memorandum of understanding signed once it handed control over the Bagram jail to Afghanistan.
"The ARB [Afghan Review Board] is releasing back to society dangerous insurgents who have Afghan blood on their hands," the US military said on hearing 37 detainees were ordered released.

Among the 37 named "seventeen are linked to IED (bomb) attacks" while "others were directly tied" to or had knowledge of attacks that injured or killed Afghan and coalition troops, the statement said.

The two countries have been at loggerheads after choosing not to sign a security deal that could make official America's withdrawal from Afghanistan and the transfer of the security mission to Afghan troops.

The American-led international military presence in Afghanistan as mandated by the UN Security Council is due to transfer all security duties to Afghan forces and prepare to withdraw its troops by the end of 2014.
Washington and Kabul are negotiating a "Security and Defence Cooperation Agreement" that would allow up to 10,000 US military personnel to remain in Afghanistan for another decade.

If you have recently indulged in the spicy chicken wing in Angola or the tangy "yassa poulet" in Senegal, the chances are that the chicken has been hauled over thousands of miles to reach your plate.
Depending on your location in Africa, chickens are increasingly being shipped -- frozen -- from Brazil, Germany or elsewhere in the European Union.
According to the US Department of Agriculture, chicken imports to sub-Saharan Africa tripled between 2004 and 2014.
Below are four reasons for the influx and how the continent may boost the poultry industry: 1) Why chicken and not beef?
Africa's population is on track to double by 2050 and reach 2.5 billion by mid-century.
As that figure rises, so does demand for meat, and especially chicken. "It is the meat of choice for most Africans," says Kevin Lovell, the CEO of the South Africa Poultry Association.
An expensive cattle industry and restrictions on pork due to religious reasons in some parts of the continent make chicken stand out.
Once they move to the cities, people prefer not to prepare their own food, relying instead on local fast-food joints or global brands that have made their way into Africa.
Kentucky Fried Chicken, for example, now has more than 700 branches spanning 13 of Africa's countries.

"Meat production has lagged behind the increase in demand brought about not just by rising population, but urbanization as well," Calestous Juma, a Professor of the Practice of International Development at Harvard University said.
This is no small feat. By 2030, the World Bank estimates that 50% of Africans -- or more than half a billion people -- will be living in cities, up from 36% in 2010.
2) What will feed the birds? Many Africans are familiar with the "road runner" chicken, which darts in and out of their backyards.
Tough, but tasty, it scavenges for food and offers some food and potentially income with minimal input.
But intensive farming requires a constant supply of chicken feed, largely made up of maize and soy.
Africa's weak agricultural sector means that feed needs to be imported at a heavy price, with little incentive for farmers to increase the production of grains.

Mobile operators, culture secretary Maria Miller and the telecoms regulator Ofcom will meet in the next few days to try to accelerate the delivery of spectrum that will allow mobile phones to achieve higher download speeds.

The regulator has informed the government that it can speed things up and that new 4G networks could become available to use in many areas by May or June. That is much sooner than the end-of-the-year date previously expected.
Ahead of the meeting, O2 said it was hopeful of launching 4G in the summer of 2013.
"It's been a very good process and feels like we've made a lot of progress, so I'm hopeful that we'll have a basis for moving forward," said Ronan Dunne, chief executive of O2.

"'We're pleased with the progress but frustrated by the time it has taken." A spokesman for Ofcom would only say: "Delays have been caused by litigation, and threats of litigation, by competing companies."

In the original dispute, O2 and Vodafone were annoyed when EE, a partner which used to be known as Everything Everywhere, was given a head start by being allowed to use existing 1,800MHz spectrum to launch a 4G service.
O2 even threatened legal action to prevent its rival getting ahead. But under a proposed deal, EE could be announcing a date for its 4G launch at the end of this month.

O2 and Vodafone won't be able to offer 4G services until parts of the radio spectrum, which was, until recently, used to transmit analogue television and air traffic control signals, is cleared and sold off.
The UK's fourth largest network, Three, will get some of EE's 4G spectrum but not until September 2013.
Ofcom said that it could bring forward its planned auction of the airwaves by up to two weeks from its original date of January.

"We could speed up the delivery of other frequencies and bring forward the date when they would be transferred, so that EE's headstart would potentially be narrowed to around six months, which would have a big impact on reducing the lead time that people were concerned about," Ed Richards, chief executive of Ofcom, told the BBC.
However, he quashed hopes that people would be buying 4G-ready phones by Christmas, explaining that the timetable was dependent on no legal challenges to the plan being made.
"Ofcom made a clever move by letting EE launch early", said Matthew Howett, a telecoms analyst at the technology consultancy Ovum.

"It's really set the hare running and will force others to respond to that." A source at one of the big networks added that they were also demanding a commitment from EE to avoid holding up Mitco (Mobile Interference Coordination group), a body set up to ensure that other signals, such as digital television, don't disrupt the use of 4G.
The female, who was 14 at the time, told detectives she believed that Robert Howard tried to rape her in his flat in Castlederg.
Year later, 15-year old Arlene disappeared. No trace of her body was found. Howard, who died in prison last year, was the chief suspect.

Sheffield's Brook, the IBF's welterweight champion, will jump two weight divisions to face Golovkin, the undisputed world middleweight king, in a high-profile contest in London on 10 September.
Brook, 30, is one of 14 world-title holders from Britain. "If I were to beat Golovkin, that would make me the best pound-for-pound on the planet," he told BBC Sport.
"Back in the day, when there were a handful of world champions, it was nationwide when a world title got won.
There's no wow now. Everyone's like: 'Oh, there's a British world champion now.'

So you need to do something to stand out." Brook is unbeaten in his 36 professional fights and has made three defences of the IBF welterweight crown he lifted when he beat American Shawn Porter in 2014.
But he has been criticised for the quality of opposition he has faced up to now.
Golovkin, a Kazakh knockout artist, has a perfect record from 35 fights, with 32 knockouts.
The 34-year-old has a record 91% knockout-to-win ratio in world middleweight championship history.
"The excitement is immense and the fans get to see a blockbuster," Brook added.
"It's not just a normal champion against champion - it's the best fight in boxing.

"You have two unbeaten fighters and two big punchers going at it. To step up two weights against a man nobody wants to fight - and people know that - there are so many different factors that make this, and they can see why they need to tune in."
Brook will vie to surmount a challenge his domestic rival Amir Khan was unable to do.
Bolton's Khan also stepped up two weight divisions to face then-WBC champion Saul Alvarez in May, but was stopped in six rounds.
Golovkin, who holds the WBA, WBC and IBF middleweight titles, is one of the most feared men in boxing.
In May, Mexico's Alvarez opted to relinquish his WBC title rather than face him.
Mr Blair said the party, which he led from 1994 to 2007, had to be focused on winning power, rather than being a "fringe protest movement".
The former prime minister has been deeply critical of Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, saying ahead of his leadership election win that the party faced "annihilation" if he became leader.
Mr Corbyn's office said it had no comment to make on Mr Blair's comments, set out in an essay for the Spectator magazine.
Mr Blair wrote: "Every part of the Labour Party that is a part of a Party that wants to be in government, and not just a fringe protest group, realises the tragedy of Labour's situation."
His article does not mention Mr Corbyn by name but his comments underline the divisions within the party over its future direction.
Most Labour MPs did not believe Mr Corbyn should lead the party but Mr Corbyn won a decisive victory, securing more than 50% of the vote of Labour members.

Unease has been felt within the party, particularly since the Commons vote on air strikes against so-called Islamic State in Syria, with some MPs claiming they have faced abuse online for backing military action - "abuse and intimidation" that Mr Corbyn said would not be accepted.

Others have expressed fears that moderate Labour MPs could face calls for their deselection as parliamentary candidates because of pressure from the Momentum grassroots group of Labour members, which grew out of Mr Corbyn's leadership campaign, although the group has denied this.

Chirpy moderation? Mr Blair also made a strong defence of Labour's record in government under his leadership, saying the party had "effectively discarded" the idea that socialism was an ideology Labour should be committed to.
Mr Blair said the party had "fallen short" on areas where it needed to offer hard choices.
"Significant elements" of the party, he said, disliked the "compromise" and "chGoneearth politicking" involved in securing power and believed it represented a betrayal of Labour's mission.
But he insisted "more modernising and less ideological thinking" was necessary to tackle problems such as housing inequality and social exclusion.
Labour was "asking the wrong questions, never mind failing to get the right answers", he argued.

Image copyright PA Image caption Mr Blair said Labour was offering policies that were not solutions Mr Blair said he recognised that many Labour Party members felt the party had "lost its way" but during its time in government, but he said, "I feel we found it".
"I know we disappointed people, including the traditional supporters of the Party.
And I know that our attempts to deal with the world as it is and change it to what we could, never to what we should did not convince enough people that real progressives are always modernisers.
Not because they do not believe in principle. But because they have the courage not to be bound by it when reality stands in the way."

One of the first plays on tour this season is All My Sons with black-led theatre company Talawa.
About all-American couple Joe and Kate Keller whose son is missing in action after World War Two, director Michael Buffong tells arts correspondent Tim Masters why it’s a 20th Century classic.
Why take All My Sons on the road for Arthur Miller’s centenary? The centenary obviously gives it a bit more focus and draw attention on a truly wonderful piece of work, from an amazing writer.
Our tour just happens to coincide with the centenary. It wasn’t planned but a wonderful accident.
Why is All My Sons an American classic? It’s American and it’s also universal. So, it’s the American dream, and the lengths people will go to achieve it.
This play is about loyalty, it’s about trust, it’s about betrayal, it’s about secrets, it’s about pride, and how pride closes your world off and doesn’t allow you to think in a balanced way.
It’s about living in a fantasy and it all coming crashing when the truth is revealed.
Joe Keller is loyal to his family, and he says: ‘I did it for you. ’ and sometimes doing things for your family is not enough.
You have a responsibility to the community as a whole and that’s often his short-sightedness.
You had five-star reviews when you staged it in 2013, does that add to the pressure of being out on tour now?
I suppose it does, I haven’t really thought about it. I might start now and not sleep!
It’s pressure, there’s good reviews and bad reviews, it’s probably inseparable from theatre.
How much do you change this time round? It’s great to go back and rediscover such a brilliant play and there are many, many layers in the text.
Half the cast is new, and therefore you’re going to discover new things. It’s constant reinvention.
It just speaks to quality of the piece to be able to do that. Does having a black cast give it a fresh interpretation?
It adds a different layer when you think about a black family’s striving to achieve the American dream.
The stakes are potentially higher because of the experience of black people in America.
But ultimately it’s a family drama and it’s an all-American family. You took over the Talawa in 2012. Are you still learning? Yes, I feel I’m just starting out.

Mr Netanyahu's comments have irked the White House, even as he has moved to walk some of the comments back.
The US and Israeli relationship has been growing increasingly strained over differences on a number of issues.

Even so, Mr Obama said the men "okay, actually - it's very business-like". "I've probably met with Bibi more than any other world leader," Mr Obama said. He said their relationship is not the root of their disagreements.
"He is representing his country's interests the way he thinks he needs to -- get me?
- and I'm representing my country's interests the way I think I need to," Mr Obama said.
"The issue isn't a matter of relations between leaders but a very clear ... substantive challenge and concern," Mr Obama said.
"It can't be reduced to a matter of somehow let's all hold hands and sing 'Kumbaya.'
" Israel has denied earlier Israeli reports it was spying on United States-led talks.
Mr Netanyahu has been criticising the America's role in the Iran nuclear talks which he says could have security implications for Israel.
Mr Obama objects to comments Mr Netanyahu made during the closing moments of his election campaign denying the creation of a Palestinian state.
During a news conference on Tuesday, originally called to discuss Afghanistan, President Obama would not address the reports, first disclosed by the Wall Street Journal, about the spying allegations.
But he said Israel and other regional allies have been briefed on the progress of the talks.
And he said Mr Netanyahu's subsequent efforts to walk back his election season comments have not been sufficient to make a Palestinian state possible.
"I don't think it is a secret ... that we believe two states is the best path forward for Israel's security, for Palestinian aspirations and for regional stability.
That's our view and that continues to be our view. And Prime Minister Netanyahu has a different approach.
And so, this can't be reduced somehow to a matter of let's all hold hands and sing 'Kumbaya.'
This is a matter of saying, "We have a difference on policy. And the results of an election won't be dispositive about that.
And, particularly, during an election, Israeli political leaders are going to be out there for their views.
I'm less concerned with labels than with substance. "The issue here is not a matter of relations between leaders," Mr Obama said.
He added: "The issue is a very clear substantive question. We believe that two states is best for Israel's security, for Palestinian aspirations and for stability in the Middle East.

Prime Minister Netanyahu has a different approach." "I did indicate to him that given his statements before the election, it is going to be hard to find a path where people are seriously believing that negotiations are possible," Mr Obama said.
"I've said this before and I will simply repeat: Prime MInister Netanyahu, in the election run-up, stated that a Palestinian state would not occur while he was prime minister.
And I took him at his word that that's what he meant, and I think that a lot of voters inside Israel understood him to be saying that fairly unequivocally," the president said.
In a US television interview, Mr Netanyahu said he supported a two-state solution but said "circumstances have to change."
Mr Obama noted that Mr Netanyahu had not said that a Palestinian state would "never" be established.
