The two men, Gunners Joseph Rowbottom and Albert Venus, aged 27 and 22, were killed on 24 May 1915 during the Second Battle of Ypres.
Their bodies were found during work on a new housing development. Family members attended the reburial at Ypres Town Cemetery as the coffins, draped with Union flags, were lowered.
Six sets of remains along with shoulder titles of the North and East Riding Batteries of the Royal Field Artillery (RFA) were recovered in April 2013.
Rowbottom, from Wrawby, North Lincolnshire and Venus, from Hull, are the two whom Ministry of Defence (MoD) investigators have been able to identify.
'Suddenly you're involved' Union flags were folded and handed to each of the families.
John Howden, 73, from Roos, East Yorkshire, represented his great uncle, Gunner Venus.
He said: "When he gave me the flag I got a lump in my throat and I had tears in my eyes.
"I didn't think I would be like this. "You are always on the outside looking in and then suddenly you are involved and it becomes emotional."
Mr Howden said that he knew nothing of his great uncle until a letter arrived from the MoD and that he was pleased that a DNA trace had been confirmed.
The representative for Gunner Rowbottom was Caroline Rowbottom, the granddaughter of his cousin.
Mrs Rowbottom, who lives in Brigg, North Lincolnshire, said: "We were shaken when we got the letter from the MoD because we had no idea that he even existed.
"He wasn't on our family tree and that's very sad. "The ceremony was very poignant.
"They created the whole thing very well." Security alert Investigators from the MOD's Joint Casualty and Compassionate Centre (JCCC) are trying to identify the four other men.
A traditional five-gun salute was not fired because of a security alert caused by the recent Brussels bombings.
Gunner Rowbottom was also known as Milky Joe in local newspaper reports of the time because he was a milkman before he enlisted.
Gunner Venus was posted to the 2nd Northumbrian Brigade in December 1914 and attached to the Hull Batteries to complete his training as a gunner.
Joe Robinson, 24, from Leeds, was detained in beach resort of Didim with fiance Mira Rojkan and her mother.
He is believed to have posted photos on social media last year, which showed him with a Kurdish militia while in Syria.
"We have no idea yet when he will appear before the court," said Kaya Sertkaya, the defendant's legal representative.

Mr Robinson, an ex-British Army soldier who served in Afghanistan, went to Syria in 2015 to visit Kurdish guerillas, the YPG, who are battling against so-called Islamic State (IS), an experience he has discussed in the media.
The YPG is regarded by Turkey as an offshoot of Kurdish militant group, the PKK, involved in an armed struggle inside Turkey since 1984.
In the UK, however, the YPG is not regarded as a proscribed terrorist organisation and is considered as one of the main US allies in the fight against IS.
Mr Robinson's father Andrew called for diplomatic intervention, telling the BBC: "When I first found out that he'd been detained on suspicion of being a terrorist I was absolutely distraught.
I did not know what was going on in Turkey. We've just been trying to obtain as many facts as we can.
Hopefully the government, maybe the Foreign Office, can give us some information."
His mother Sharon Robinson called his detention "the most ridiculous thing I have ever heard in my life".
His lawyet said Mr Robinson is being held in Aydin, western Turkey, suspected of the crime of "being a member of a terrorist organisation".
Mr Sertkaya added: "I have met him in the custody yesterday, he appeared to be in good health and spirit.
"Yet there is an uncertainty on the judicial proceedings as the state of emergency in Turkey has been creating huge backlogs especially in detention inquiries regarding terrorist-related charges."
He said it is likely his client "will not appear before the court at least for three months".
The Foreign and Commonwealth Office said in a statement it is providing assistance to the family and remained in contact with authorities in Turkey.

Guney Yildiz - a Turkey analyst at the European Council on Foreign Relations think tank who has discussed Turkey's legislation criminalising Kurdish militant groups' supporters - said it is "not a surprise" that Mr Robinson - for having past associations with a group considered a security threat by the government - could face legal difficulties in Turkey.
Hart, 29, has not played for Manchester City this season and was told he could leave the club.
Sam Allardyce, who told BBC Radio 5 Live he will name his captain this month, said: "It is a concern."
But the ex-Sunderland manager did say that his squad for next month's World Cup qualifier with Slovakia - which will be named on Sunday - would include Hart.
Capped 63 times for his country, he had a poor Euro 2016, making mistakes for goals against Wales and Iceland, to whom England lost in the last 16.
The goalkeeper is out of favour with incoming City boss Pep Guardiola, with Argentinian Willy Caballero named in the side in each of their matches this season.
While Everton are interested in signing Hart, the England keeper is reluctant to move to Seville or Borussia Dortmund, even though the two clubs are interested in signing him.
On Saturday, Barcelona said they had reached an agreement in principle with City over the transfer of their goalkeeper, Claudio Bravo.
"We want as many players playing as we can when they join up in the squad and then play for England and be successful," said Allardyce.
"That happens less now because you are not going to get all the England players playing in the Premier League, like it used to be about 20 or 25 years ago."

England play their opening Group F qualifier for the 2018 World Cup in Trnava on 4 September, which will be their first match under Allardyce, who was named manager after Roy Hodgson resigned following the Iceland defeat.
Allardyce has yet to decide whether Manchester United forward Wayne Rooney will continue as captain.
"I will name the captain no later than Wednesday because everyone keeps asking me," he said. Sign up to get news, features, exclusives and analysis direct to your inbox.
Just clinched Taiwan’s presidency, she stays firm: Taiwan’s future something only its people can decide.
**Therefore, China calls the island a breakaway province and says they'd reunite it by force if they think they must.
** Beijing gets to decide, maybe, exactly where Ms. … ends up. Tsai on Taiwan’s sovereignty, firm; and her next steps? She's still not sure. She’s been oddly vague about this, leaving us guessing.
Her enigmatic nature extends beyond China, therefore many Taiwanese perceive her as quiet unpredictable force.
I’m not one for the spotlight. My rapid rise in politics? Just an accidental life.
*Thus, why this election important?* Just the economy, or is that all they're focused on?
Therefore what keeps the China‑Taiwan split going, I wonder? Ms., it’s the title you use for a woman when you’re not saying if she’s married or not.
Tsai is Taiwan's first female leader, yet unlike many other famous Asian women she not from a political dynasty.
She, the youngest of eleven kids from dad’s fourth wife, basically grew up fairly well‑off, don’t you think?
Her dad ran a booming auto shop, earned cash from land deals, therefore he forced her to attend a public school so she could see a wider world.
First thirty years – all school. She earned a law degree at National Taiwan University, then a master's in law from Cornell in the United States, therefore her path felt set.
S., has a Ph. Thus D., an LSE graduate, eventually became law professor. Her English skill?
Impressive, so in the 1990s they invited her to be a legal advisor for Taiwan’s WTO entry talks, therefore she stepped onto the public stage.
She served as Lee Teng‑hui’s security adviser, helped shape his view that Beijing and Taipei are two separate nations; that really angered China, didn’t it?

Though Chen Shui‑bian was now president, the strait was awfully tense at that moment; therefore, Ms. Tsai, who heads the Mainland Affairs Council, figured out a way to talk to a China that was hostile, maybe it helped?
In 2001 she rolled out the **“Small Mini Links”** program; it gave direct ferries from Taiwan’s far‑out islands straight to mainland China, so trade could finally move.
Later: her push for the first chartered flights between the two sides. By 2003—despite the uneasy buzz about Taiwan opening to China far too fast—Ms.
Therefore, Tsai got Mr. Chen and the legislators to amend Taiwan’s China‑policy law; now Taiwanese firms can legally invest on mainland.

The German company is taking on the dairies division – processing and delivering milk – in an £80m deal after profits at the UK dairy food group plunged 95% to £900,000 in the six months to 30 September.
Dairy Crest processes and delivers about 1.3bn litres of milk a year to retailers and residential doorsteps.
Dairy Crest said the sale would be in the interest of consumers, customers and dairy farmers.
The dairies business accounts for a little over 70% of group sales, which rose 1% to £682.1m in the first half.
The deal, which remains subject to shareholder approval and may take months to complete, will enable the company to focus on the more profitable cheese and spreads divisions, Dairy Crest said.

About 14,000 dairy farmers in the Britain produce 3.3m litres a day, but there is continuing controversy about whether the industry is sustainable because farm gate and retail prices for milk keep falling.
Shareholders welcomed Dairy Crest’s plan to retreat from a loss-making industry, and the shares rose 10% in morning trading on Thursday.
Müller said the deal would help reduce costs and promote exports of British-made dairy products, including yoghurt and desserts.
Ronald Kers, chief executive of Müller UK & Ireland, said: “We are concerned about the long-term viability of the UK fresh milk sector.
The UK fresh milk sector is facing a period of major change. Given the serious excess capacity in the processing industry, this situation is not sustainable in the medium or longer term.

“We very much believe that this sector has a future, but a combined business will help us to minimise costs, increase efficiency and competitiveness and ensure that we can reinvest in the future of the sector.” Müller Wiseman Dairies, Müller’s UK arm, will take over milk processing factories at Foston in Derbyshire, Chadwell Heath in Essex and Severnside, in the south-west near Gloucester, as well as Dairy Crest’s glass bottling plant in Hanworth, Middlesex, where Dairy Crest is already consulting with workers over the future of the site, and 72 depots.
Müller entered the UK market with the acquisition of Robert Wiseman Dairies in 2012.
Beaulieu Convent School Headmaster Chris Beirne has criticised the amount of money and "opulent additions" with which parents surround the event.
He also voiced concerns about drinking and drugs at the Year 11 end-of-term dance for 15-16 year-old students.
One former student accused the school of "over-reacting", saying it was a rite of passage for young people.
Headmaster Chris Beirne said the amount of "time, money and effort" dedicated to the prom, or leavers' dinner, was contrary to the values of the school.
In a letter to parents he quoted an unnamed "colleague from another island school" who said the build up to the event was not "wholly positive or good".
They said the financial burden and competitiveness "became just too much for parents to bear" and said drug and alcohol consumption at after-parties was also a concern.
Pressure to "look thin, be tanned, have perfect hair, skin and nails" was also "challenging and stressful".
Mr Beirne said ultimately he "can no longer continue to tolerate the risks and responsibilities" associated with the event.
Instead, the independent Catholic school will continue to host a mass dedicated to Year 13 leavers and their families.
The service is followed by a drinks reception. The £5,400-a-year-a-place private school in Jersey caters for about 760 pupils aged 4-18.
'First taste of maturity' Former student Hannah Hosegood said the prom was "a first taste of maturity, a time when we are treated like adults, and should act as adults in return".
The 20-year-old who left the school in 2011, said: "If there are issues with drugs or alcohol, treat those people as individuals."
"These girls have been looking forward to this, they were little, little girls, and its just something you never forget," she added.
The ex-health minister has made the case for funding the NHS with a separate tax, shown on every payslip.
Under Mr Lamb's proposal, tax would not rise - the new tax would be offset by cuts in income tax or national insurance.
He said without a funding injection, there was a risk of the NHS "toppling over".
The proposals have still to become party policy and will not be debated at this weekend's conference in Bournemouth.

But according to Mr Lamb, who is his party's health spokesman, "a ring-fenced NHS and care contribution, fully identified on your pay packet, and totally separate from other taxation" is "an idea that really interests me".
He is "also interested in local areas being able to raise extra funds for the NHS and care, if they choose".
The Lib Dems would want such a change to apply across the United Kingdom, although health and social care are devolved so it is unclear how this could be made to happen.
Mr Lamb lost out on the Lib Dem leadership last July, when Tim Farron was elected through a ballot of party members.
He thinks a "cross-party commission should look at new ideas, such as these, and others, like a dedicated health and care tax".
He will also "consult extensively" with health organisations, professionals, patients, trade unions and academics.
Ministers have already promised a £2bn increase in England's National Health Service budget this financial year, with an extra £8bn on the way by 2020.

But Mr Lamb told BBC News he does not think this is enough. "Unless we contribute more as a society, in line with other advanced Western countries, to keep pace with demand from an ageing population, the NHS could end up with a £30bn black hole," he said.
"And the social care system is already on its knees… a further injection of around £5bn is desperately needed to make it sustainable for the long term".
'Party battle' Mr Lamb was a health minister in England's coalition government, until May's election.
His party then took a hammering - getting 8% of votes cast and returning just 8 MPs out of 650.
"I have seen the financial figures and I know there isn't enough to meet demand," Mr Lamb said.
"It's vital that we confront the challenge, or we will see this most beloved of public institutions toppling over."
At present, taxpayers are given a personal tax statement each year, showing how much they contribute to the health service.
Mr Lamb was one of the instigators of a proposed cross-party commission examining social care before the 2010 election.

That was, however, rejected by the then Tory health spokesman, Andrew Lansley, who accused Labour and the Lib Dems of getting engaged in a political "party battle", particularly over the possibility of a "death tax" to pay for care.
He will also take questions from the audience during the charity event, with the May 26 dinner in Edinburgh likely to be one of his most high-profile addresses since he stepped down as president.

The address at the EICC is being organised by The Hunter Foundation, which was set up by leading businessman and philanthropist Sir Tom Hunter. Tables for 10 at the dinner are expected to sell for around £5,000.
The Hunter Foundation has previously attracted the likes of Bill Clinton, Leonardo DiCaprio and George Clooney to Scotland.

DiCaprio was in Edinburgh last November, where he addressed the Scottish Business Awards, also at the EICC, and made an appearance at Home, a restaurant in Queensferry Street which donates all its profits to the homeless. Fans queued for hours and waited in torrential rain for his arrival.
A year earlier Hollywood star Clooney visited a branch of the Social Bite sandwich chain in Rose Street to lend his support to its work helping the homeless and left a tip of $1,000 (just over £650).
Hundreds of well-wishers gathered outside the venue to meet the actor and activist, who spent about 15 minutes greeting a 200-strong crowd.

Proceeds from May's event, which is being staged in partnership with EQ Travel Management, will be split between Scottish children's charities and the Obama Foundation, set up by the former president and his wife Michelle.
Sir Tom also intends to make hundreds of free places at the event available to local young people.
He said: "From the South Side of Chicago to the White House has been an epic, historic journey and we look forward to hearing about that journey and equally what the future holds for president Obama.
"We are both proud and delighted that we can bring president Obama to Scotland in this, our 20th anniversary year."

Sir Tom told the Press Association: "As a huge supporter of the Clinton Foundation and Barack Obama I'm over the moon - we're always looking to bring inspirational speakers to Scotland and they don't come more inspirational than president Obama.

"I can't take in the fact I'll be sharing a stage with him." The philanthropist added: "President Obama is very fond of music. We have a special treat for him - there are exciting guests in the pipeline."
First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is currently in New York on the first leg of a five-day visit to the US.
She told BBC Scotland: I'm really excited about that as are many, many people across Scotland who are really looking forward to welcoming President Obama and hearing what he has to say."
About 1,000 people turned up outside the Senedd building for the minute's silence and candle-lit vigil.
There are more than 2,000 French people in South Wales registered with the French consulate in London.
Marie Brousseau-Navarro, Honorary Consul of France in Cardiff, said the well-wishes for the people of France had been "very touching".
She said: "We are standing together in shock and in sadness with all who have marched across the world."
Saleem Kidwai, chairman of the Muslim Council of Wales, earned a round of applause after he called on all to "stand shoulder to shoulder".
He said: "My condemnation cannot be strong enough. In the end light will always overcome darkness and the truth overcome the lie."
First Minister Carwyn Jones was among those lighting a candle for the vigil during the minute's silence when some in the crowd held up pencils.

After a silence the crowd broke into applause. Earlier, Mr Jones said: "With tonight's vigil in Cardiff Bay, people in Wales have an opportunity to remember all those affected by the terrible events in Paris.

It also gives us a chance to make a visible statement demonstrating our support for the people of France, and others, who share our common values and belief in upholding the democratic principles and freedoms someone somewhere would seek to destroy with such indiscriminate acts of terrorism as we have witnessed during the last few days."
The Secretary of State for Wales Stephen Crabb tweeted: "Standing with the French community in Wales and in support of freedom of speech everywhere.

6pm this eve. Senedd, Cardiff. #CharlieHebdo". On Saturday London landmarks were lit in the colours of the French flag to show solidarity, and world leaders have convened in Paris for an unprecedented unity rally.
More than a million people marched on Sunday, dwarfing the numbers of 700,000 on Saturday.

Meanwhile, Swansea City's effort for a Paris united front took another twist on Saturday when striker Bafetimbi Gomis dedicated the team's goal in the 1-1 draw with West Ham to victims of the Paris attack.
Welsh police forces observed a minute's silence in honour of the victims of the Paris attack on the offices of Charlie Hebdo magazine on Wednesday.
French landmarks in Cardiff welcomed messages of support after the attack on satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo and the killing of a police officer on Thursday.
On Friday, French security services ended sieges on two hostage situations on the fringes of Paris by killing three gunmen who had seized hostages.
Ms Brousseau-Navarro added: "We have been truly moved by the hundreds of messages of support and condolences."

Retired teacher Ann Maguire, 61, was stabbed to death at Corpus Christi Catholic College in Leeds in April 2014 A teenager who stabbed teacher Ann Maguire to death at a school in Leeds should face a public inquiry into events before and after her shocking murder, her family have said.

Will Cornick, who was 16 when he was jailed for a minimum of 20 years in November after pleading guilty to murder, prevented the evidence from being subjected to a “full trial test”, her closest relatives said.

Mrs Maguire had taught at Corpus Christi Catholic College for 40 years Retired teacher Mrs Maguire, 61, had taught for 40 years at Corpus Christi Catholic College and had been planning to retire a few months later.
Cornick was 15 when he crept up behind her and stabbed her seven times in the neck and back as she helped another pupil with work.
Don Maguire, her husband, said an inquiry should look at whether anything more could have been done to save her.
“Given that a guilty plea was entered in the hearing at the Crown Court last year, a full criminal trial test of the evidence did not take place,” he said.

“We feel that a much more wide-ranging, independent and statutory review of all the evidence should be conducted so that all the lessons that need to be learnt from this tragic event, which has shocked and traumatised all the students and staff of the school, and, of course, our family, can take place.

“An independent, open and statutory review of what took place in the run up to the killing will not bring Ann back, but the family will have peace in the knowledge of whether or not there was anything that could conceivably have been done that might have prevented her tragic death and result in no other family having to suffer how we have.” ‘I wish it was me that had gone that day’ - sister speaks out over murder of Ann Maguire Cornick, 16, laughed after stabbing Spanish teacher Ann Maguire to death Management of Cornick, who was later diagnosed with psychopathic tendencies, is thought to be the focus of a review believed to have been carried out by the Leeds Safeguarding Children Board.
The Department for Education (DfE) said it understood the family’s desire for an inquiry into “the tragic events” and that Secretary of State Nicky Morgan had “much sympathy for their concern”.
A spokesman added: “We are aware that the Leeds Safeguarding Children Board (LSCB) has undertaken a two-stage learning lessons review.
We trust this will be transparent and rigorous. “The review was commissioned by the independent chair of the LSCB and is being overseen by an independent review panel.
“We hope the family will receive the support they need and our thoughts and sympathies remain with them.

No decision will be made until this process is completed.” Mrs Maguire’s sister, Denise Courtney, who lived with her, wept at the trial hearing at Leeds crown court as she said the family would never recover from the murder.
“I wish it was me that had gone that day,” she said. “Little can be added either for Ann or the family.
We get no reprieve from what has happened, the effort to get up and live is truly hard.”
James Vaughan got the opener on 61 minutes and grabbed his second six minutes later, and Bury looked to be coasting.
But Niall Maher was sent off for conceding a 70th-minute penalty, which Shaun Williams converted, and Callum Butcher then headed Millwall level on 86.
Substitute Aiden O’Brien then bagged a stoppage-time winner to condemn Bury to a club-record 10 straight defeat in all competitions.
Millwall were awarded a fourth-minute penalty before referee Chris Sarginson decided to consult his linesman and change his mind.
Vaughan went close with a glancing header before Neil Danns saw a 20-yard effort deflected wide.
Harry Smith headed narrowly wide for Millwall while Joe Martin’s free-kick was headed over, and Bury goalkeeper Ben Williams tipped Fred Onyedinma’s shot over.
The hosts took the lead as Danny Mayor’s right-wing cross was laid off for Vaughan to smash in off the bar.
Vaughan then side-footed home from close-range after a great cross-field run and pass by Scott Burgess.
Two minutes later Millwall broke and Maher blocked Onyedinma’s shot with his arm.
He was red-carded and Williams scored from the spot. Ben Williams saved from an Onyedinma header, but Millwall equalised as Butcher headed in Shane Ferguson’s left-wing free-kick.
Three minutes into stoppage time O’Brien flicked in Mahlon Romeo’s right-wing cross for Millwall’s winner.

The president of the Intensive Care Society, Mark Bellamy, told the BBC the resistance problem would grow unless better antibiotics were produced.
Sepsis is the immune overreaction to an infection and kills 37,000 people a year in the UK.

NHS England wants hospitals to work together to tackle the problem. Sepsis often develops after blood poisoning and the massive immune reaction can lead to organ failure or death unless treated promptly.
A fever and rapid heartbeat are common early symptoms. Earlier this year the Intensive Care Society launched a campaign to raise awareness of sepsis and prevent avoidable deaths.
There are an estimated 37,000 UK deaths every year due to sepsis. For comparison just over 35,000 people die each year from lung cancer and 16,000 from bowel cancer.
The intensive care society and the UK Sepsis Trust, say hospitals are not recording the number of people with sepsis and doctors do not know enough about how to spot and treat the condition early.

"I think people should have the confidence to say, 'I am much sicker than you think' and not assume extreme fatigue and confusion mean they have locomotor problems, when in fact they are showing confusion which is a symptom of sepsis."
Prof Mark Bellamy Leeds Institute of Biomedical and Clinical Sciences Julie Bignone nearly died after developing sepsis.
She was in hospital for seven weeks, including two weeks in a critical care unit.
She thought her fever was just a bad case of flu and stayed in bed for the weekend.
On Monday she went to her GP, who told her to come back if things deteriorated.
That evening, her husband and daughter became increasingly concerned and she was taken to hospital in an ambulance.
Julie was diagnosed with pneumonia and sepsis and told her daughters she could die. She was placed in intensive care and given huge doses of antibiotics.
Julie Bignone claims "doctors do not listen to patients" She thinks that she should have trusted her instinct and told people she had a much more serious illness than flu.
She told BBC News: "The symptoms of sepsis are not specific and that leaves lots of scope for things to be missed.
"We have to have a system where physicians listen hard to the patients and value their opinion. Doctors do not listen enough to their patients.
"I think people should have the confidence to say, 'I am much sicker than you think.'
And not assume extreme fatigue and confusion mean they have locomotor problems, when in fact they are showing confusion which is a symptom of sepsis."

'We need to get it right' Intensive care consultant Prof Mark Bellamy said that in recent weeks: "A number of patients in the unit I work have had no effective treatment for them with any antibiotics.

That was purely a theoretical risk a few years ago." Prof Bellamy, who also works at the Leeds Institute of Biomedical and Clinical Sciences, said raising awareness of sepsis and making sure patients were treated at the right time were crucial to making sure patients stood a good chance of survival.
"There is a spectre on the horizon that we are moving into an era of post-antibiotics as unfortunately they become less and less effective," he added.
Jonny Evans and Papiss Cisse appeared to spit at each other during Wednesday's Premier League game at St James' Park.
Referee Anthony Taylor spoke to both players after the incident in the first half but did not book either of them.
The Football Association will wait for Taylor's report before deciding whether to take disciplinary action against the players.
In March last year, Burnley striker George Boyd was banned for three matches for spitting at Manchester City goalkeeper Joe Hart.

But under updated FA rules, the offence now carries a mandatory six-match ban. The suspension could be even longer for Cisse because the Newcastle striker was sent off in December for elbowing Everton's Seamus Coleman.

Under FA rules, an extra one-game ban would be added to his suspension. Newcastle v Man Utd: Cisse and Evans incident 'disgusting' Newcastle 0-1 Man Utd: Carver & Van Gaal on Evans & Cisse spitting incident A number of former players have said Evans and Cisse should be punished.
Dietmar Hamman, the former Newcastle midfielder, described it as "disgusting", while ex-Manchester United defender Phil Neville said both players should be "ashamed".

BBC Match of the Day pundit Hamman said: "That is disgusting. You've got kids watching who watch every move of the players and I think the behaviour of the players towards referees and towards each other just gets worse by the week.
"You cannot have that on a football field." Fellow pundit Phil Neville: "That is six-game bans for both players.

The cameras are there and I think both players will be embarrassed by that." Ex-Newcastle midfielder Jermaine Jenas told BBC Radio 5 live: "Spitting is disgusting and there is no place for it in the game."
If, as TV replays suggested, Evans spat at Cisse as the Newcastle striker lay on the ground, before Cisse replied in the same fashion, it was not captured by the match referee.
Neither Newcastle manager John Carver nor Manchester United boss Louis van Gaal saw the incident.
Carver, whose side lost the game 1-0, said: "I can't comment on it. I just know there was a fracas on the halfway line."
Van Gaal added: "I don’t think Jonny Evans is a spitter. Maybe spitting on the floor, but from the bench, it’s impossible to see."
Media playback is not supported on this device Wales' Jenkins, 32, secured her first World Series win since 2012 to halt Jorgensen's run of 13 events and beat her British rival Jodie Stimpson.
"Helen has done a really strong case," said Stanford, who along with Vicky Holland has already secured her Rio place.
World Series London Triathlon switch "It was as good as it could have been and I don't see why she can't be on the team."

With an announcement anticipated early in June, two-time world champion Jenkins and England's Commonwealth title holder Stimpson are competing for selection on Britain's women's triathlon team for this summer's Rio Games.
"Helen has made a really strong case," said Stanford, Jenkins' fellow Welsh triathlete.
"British Triathlon has been talking about you have to show you are in a strong position to medal in Rio and she has proven that for sure.
"She has not put herself just in contention to medal, but she went and won the race, beat Gwen Jorgensen who is the one to beat to win a gold medal in Rio.
"To overcome her shows she can medal so it would be a bit of a shock if Helen was not picked."
Stimpson won the women's World Series season opener in Abu Dhabi and the World Cup event over a sprint distance in Australia.
But she was back in 12th place, more than three minutes down at the Gold Coast.
"Jodie started off the year with a really strong start," said Stanford, world champion in 2013.
"The Gold Coast selection event didn't go so well for her and that was the opportunity you had to show your hand although she did use the opportunities really well earlier in the year.
"It is going to be a tough selection for the selectors." Following her win in Australia, Jenkins said: "I've not been picked yet but I feel like I did enough today.
We have such a strong team and for Jodie to miss out on the Olympics doesn't seem right."
Cynthia Cheroitich, 19, survived by drinking body lotion and was only coaxed out of her hiding place on Saturday morning when security forces got a teacher she knew to help.

Ms Cheroitich, who already had some bloodstains on her trousers from wounds to her hands and leg, said the ordeal began at about 05:30 (02:30GMT) on Thursday while students were going to classes to prepare for exams.
"All of a sudden, we heard some gunshots and people started running for their lives.
We started asking what was happening. 'They are attacking us, they are attacking us!'
We just started running to our rooms, but the attackers came following us to our rooms.
They were knocking on the doors, and they came in. When they came in, they were telling us to come out.
We refused to come out and that is why we went to hide ourselves. I went to hide myself in the closet.
I was closing the doors on top of me and then I heard those people coming in. "
Those who came out after being told to do so were asked if they could recite Koranic verses, the militants have said.
Ms Cheroitich's account was similar to that given by other survivors. Ms Cheroitich said her room-mates left the closet, whereas she covered herself with clothes.
The attackers did not look in the cupboard when they entered the room with a torch, and so she remained undetected. The fate of the other girls was not clear.
"I was just praying to my God," she said. Ms Cheroitich said she later came across two bottles of body lotion in the closet which she drank to keep herself going during the nearly two-day wait.
"It was nice and lovely," she said, but added she was too scared to move. Police officers eventually got her to come out of her hiding place at 10:00 on Saturday.
At first, she would not believe that they were real officers and was suspicious that they were al-Shabab attackers "How do I know that you are the Kenyan police?"
she said to them. The attackers had been speaking Swahili as well as Arabic and English during the attacks.
Only when a college staffer she knew got her to come out, did she believe them.
The first minister announced in March she had signed an MOU, or memorandum of understanding, with SinoFortone and another Chinese firm.
When news of the deal's cancellation emerged, the Scottish government blamed a "climate of hostility" from other parties.
But opposition politicians insisted ministers should make a full statement on the "sad episode".
The first minister unveiled the deal, with a reported potential investment value of £10bn, in March.
It was signed by Nicola Sturgeon at her official residence, Bute House in Edinburgh, with SinoFortone Group and China Railway No.

3 Engineering Group (CR3). Opposition parties raised questions about the deal because the giant conglomerate that owns CR3, China Railway Group, was named in an Amnesty International report on human rights abuses.
It was also blacklisted by Norway's giant oil fund, because of concerns about the human rights and arms records of companies in its investment portfolio.
At the time Ms Sturgeon said no specific deals would be "taken forward if there is a perception that the perceptions about those deals are founded in reality".
Any planned investments would also be subject to scrutiny by the Scottish Parliament.
In August, the Sunday Times reported that the deal had collapsed. It said the Scottish government had been told it was known in China as the "Scottish shambles".
Documents released under freedom of information by the Scottish government last week cast further light on the deal.
They included an email from the department of the economy secretary, Keith Brown.
His spokesman said the Scottish government had been aware there was concern about the deal.

But he said they did not believe it had been cancelled. He also said that opposition parties had created a climate of hostility to foreign investment which could include Norway and Ireland as well as China.

In the email, the spokesman wrote: "We did not think the whole MOU was cancelled but understood meanwhile that SinoFortone didn't think it was possible to take forward a deal while there was such a climate of hostility from opposition parties.
"They maintain a view that there is benefit to Scotland in working with a partner like China to deliver benefits for our infrastructure and we are committed to exploring these opportunities.
"This MOU is about building relationships that can lead to investments and we have certainly not closed the door to that in anyway."
Opposition parties said the government should make a statement to parliament outlining the full background to the deal.

Labour economy spokeswoman Jackie Baillie said: "The SNP government must come clean on the status of this agreement as soon as possible. "People across Scotland deserve answers on this secretive deal.
This whole affair underlines really serious issues about openness, transparency and competence at the heart of the SNP government under Nicola Sturgeon.
"The SNP's handling of the deal with these two Chinese firms has been cack handed right from the start, and it's easy to see why the deal is being described as the 'Scottish shambles.'
They kept this under wraps until after the election, and now we find out the whole thing collapsed months ago but the people of Scotland have been kept in the dark yet again."

Scottish Conservative economy spokesman Dean Lockhart added: "This latest revelation will only serve to prove that, under the SNP, Scotland is not open to business, nor can anyone be sure of its reliability."
He added: "I thing Ms Sturgeon and Mr Brown would want to take question on this following what's been quite a sad episode."
She said current market valuations are "generally quite high," but she added that she didn't see any bubbles forming.
Chinese stocks posted the deepest losses regionally with the Shanghai Composite closed down 2.8% at 4112.21, its third day in the red.
The Hang Seng Index closed down 1.3% at 27289.97 for six consecutive losing sessions.
The Shanghai benchmark decline follows another batch of share sales by mainland companies, with investors pulling money out of other stocks ahead of the flotations.
There was also some worry about reports of regulatory action in China, for example setting a ceiling for margin trading.
The securities watchdog was also reported to be extending a ban on new clients using borrowed money to buy small-cap stocks.
Meanwhile, Japan's Nikkei 225 index was down 1.23% to 19291.99 when trading resumed for the first time since trading was suspended for a week-long holiday.

In Australia, the city's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.82% to close at 5645.70. On Wednesday, Australian shares had their worst one-day drop in more than two years, following lackluster results from the nation's biggest banks.

There's worry about the outlook for the country's big four banks. National Australia Bank, or NAB, the last of the four majors to report this week, announced a 5.4% rise in cash profit for the months to March.

NAB unveiled on Thursday that it planned to raise a massive 5.5 billion Australian dollars ($4.4 billion; £2.8 billion) through the sale of new shares, to help with its planned demerger and initial public offering of its troubled British lender, Clydesdale.
The move is also to strengthen its coffers. Australian media are calling it perhaps the biggest capital raising in Australian corporate history.
Investors have yet to digest the new unemployment numbers which showed a slight uptick to 6.2% in April. Back in South Korea, the Kospi index was down 0.65% at the close at 2091.00.
New Zealander Gibbes, who has been forwards coach at Clermont Auvergne and before that at Leinster, will take the Ulster job alongside the director of rugby, Les Kiss.
It has still to be confirmed whether Neil Doak, Ulster’s current head coach, will be retained on the coaching staff.
“The respect I have for Les, both as a coach and a person, was a big part of the reason why I want to go to Ulster,” said Gibbes.
Ulster are currently sixth in the Pro12 table and have just had a poor season in the European Champions Cup, departing at the pools stage.
Gibbes added: “Les and I have known one another for a long time and he talked me through the vision of where Ulster Rugby wants to go.
That had a big impact on me. I”m excited by the challenge and I will hopefully be able to complement the other coaches and the staff there.
I have a good understanding of the club from coaching against them with Leinster and Clermont.
This is a great opportunity to work with a very good squad at Ulster. When I was at Leinster we had some great battles with Ulster.
The recent games between Clermont and Ulster have also been hard-fought and we saw first-hand the quality of the players, so I’m looking forward to working with these guys.

“Clermont is a great club and we are top of the league at the minute. I want to finish off my time here as positively as possible before joining up with Ulster next season.” Gibbes joined Leinster in 2008 and won three Heineken Cups at the province.

He said: “My time in the northern hemisphere dates back to 2008. After six years at Leinster and three years at Clermont I have been afforded some great experiences and opportunities to further my coaching career alongside some great coaches and talented players.

I”m looking forward to using this experience to further Ulster’s ambitions. My wife and I really enjoy this part of the world and I know that she and my daughters will love living in Belfast and getting to know a new culture.” Gibbes, 40, moved to France in the summer of 2014 and was part of the Clermont coaching staff that took that club to the Top 14 final and the final of the European Champions Cup in his first season at the club.
Kiss, 52, said: “Jono’s CV speaks for itself. As a coach he comes with great pedigree and experience, and from my previous dealings with him he has always impressed me.
Jono really wanted to come and be part of Ulster Rugby, so I”m delighted that we have been able to bring him on board.

Since his playing career ended, Jono has been a key part of the management teams at two European powerhouses in Leinster and Clermont – he has delivered impressive results in those environments.” “It goes without saying that his expertise as a forwards coach will add significant value and he will provide excellent continuity.
However, it is his all-round knowledge of the game and his experiences as an international player and coach that will also add immense value to the development of both the team and the staff.
“We are currently reviewing our coaching structures for next season and Jono’s appointment as head coach is the first part of this process.
In the coming weeks we will be in a position to take the next step to get the right coaching balance for next year.
It’s a robust plan and screen that we have put in place and it is important to get the right people suited to the way that we want to go forward.”
The invitation to the birthday bash was recorded on video and posted by Crescencio Ibarra, the father, on Facebook.
Despite originally only intending to invite neighbours and friends to the party, which includes performances from regional bands, a meal and a horse race, he said he would not exclude anybody.
In the video, Mr Ibarra, flanked by his tiara-clad daughter and wife, Anaelda Garcia, says: "Hello, how are you?
We invite you to our daughter Rubi Ibarra Garcia's 15th birthday party on 26 December."
As Rubi beams at the camera, he lists the names of three bands booked to entertain revellers and promises a prize of 10,000 pesos ($490; 390) to the winner of a horse race.

Loading article content He finishes by saying "everyone is cordially invited". In Mexico, 15th birthdays are often marked by elaborate celebrations and are considered a rite of passage into adulthood.
It is not uncommon for families to splash out on live bands and for the birthday girls to wear posh frocks and tiaras, revelling in their queen for the day status.
It is not clear what triggered the interest in Mr Crescencio's sombre video. By Monday, it had been shared more than 800,000 times and generated hundreds of thousands of memes on social media.
Mr Ibarra told Mexican television that he was at a loss to explain what had captured the imagination.
"We only wanted to invite the people from the area; we didn't think this would get out of hand," he said.
He added that reports he had rescinded invitations to anyone except close friends were false.

In an interview published in El Universal newspaper, Mr Ibarra and his wife said that they had initially been embarrassed and saddened by their newfound popularity and about rural lifestyle being mocked.
But they soon embraced the attention and were continuing with the party on land outside the tiny hamlet of La Joya, in San Luis Potosi state.

Ms Garcia referred to daughter Rubi as her "queen" and said her favourite meme was one which says that US President-elect Donald Trump and Mexico's President Enrique Pena Nieto have agreed to allow the nearly six million undocumented Mexican migrants in the US to return home for Rubi's big day.
The official who oversees La Joya, Roberto Alejandro Segovia Hernandez, said the hamlet and the rural roads around it would be cordoned off by the police to ensure crowd control.
That, too, spawned more memes. Rubi's older sister told BBC Mundo that Rubi is "now very excited" and looking forward to the party.
Whatever one’s opinion of Mr. Aamer, his repatriation was applauded by many inside Whitehall just to have him home.
His sequestering for 5,017 days had put a strain on the US-Britain relationship and undermined efforts by the government to reach out to the most remote Muslim populations.
He will get the best medical treatment and a psychiatric evaluation, and meet the son born on the day he landed in Guantanamo Bay.

Yet with his return, the UK has now acquired a potential security headache. Davis Lewin of the Henry Jackson Society security and foreign relations think tank says the UK needs to be cautious and properly surveil Mr. Aamer.
His lawyers say he will submit to any monitoring, although they think it is unnecessary, as the allegations against him were extracted through torture.
If MI5 decide that Aamer is a “trace,” he’ll never know about it, as they go about their covert business.

Bigger issues concern the UK in terms of legacy and lessons learned. As some critics have put it, the US was not alone in losing sight of its legal and moral compass in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks.

London’s silence in not telling Washington to drop the Guantanamo experiment immediately, and not demanding British detainees in Afghanistan be sent home, was, critics allege, a dereliction of Britain’s own justice apple cart.
“Human rights and justice and the rule of law are universal,” says Andrew Mitchell, the former Conservative cabinet minister and one of the MPs who pressed for Mr. Aamer’s release.

“He has been denied these rights. It is terrible for him and … we need to protect these issues because they are the best way of defeating terror.… What we have to do is follow the rule of law and understand human rights are for us all.” American interrogations relied on intelligence supplied by Britain in some cases, possibly implicating the UK in the abuse of torture.
As a result, many MPs are now seeking explanations as to what Britain did or didn’t do in that post-9/11 interim.
“A significant step forward is to get [Shaker Aamer] on camera making statements about what happened in Britain,” says Mr. Mitchell.

Norman "Rimmo" Rimmington joined Barnsley in 1945 and played as a goalkeeper for the club He then took up several different posts including coach, assistant manager, groundsman, physio and kit man Supporters lined the streets outside the Tykes' Oakwell Stadium as the funeral cortege drove by Mr Rimmington, who was born in Staincross, was described by the club as a "fearless" goalkeeper who made 27 appearances before moving to Hartlepool United in 1947.
Outside football he was a pit fitter and mechanic. He returned to Barnsley in 1952 and continued working for the club in some capacity until his death at the end of December, aged 93.
He was taken from his home in Darton to All Saints Church in the village where a service was held before a ceremony at Barnsley Crematorium.
Family, friends, colleagues, former players and his old team-mate Eric Winstanley were among the mourners.
In an interview with BBC Sport, Mr Rimmington reminisced about "getting some stick as a goalkeeper" when playing for the Tykes.
"They could knock you into the back of the net and it was a goal; it's not the same game.
"They now go down as if they've been shot and there's nothing wrong with them," he said.
Mr Rimmington found out before he died he had been awarded the British Empire Medal for his services to football.
"I come from Barnsley, born in Barnsley, brought up in Barnsley and played at Barnsley," he said.
"I just love the club and everything I've done here". In a statement released by the club, it said 'Rimmo" was a "true club legend".

"Rimmo will always be a part of Barnsley Football Club and has represented the football club with tremendous pride, dedication and love throughout his life". Rimmo: The life of Norman Rimmington Born: 29 November 1923.

Staincross, near Barnsley Other jobs - pit fitter, mechanic 1946-47 Barnsley FC (27 caps) 1947-52 Hartlepool United (127 caps) 1952-61 Barnsley 'A' team coach 1961-1972 Head coach and physio 1972-1978 Groundsman and physio 1978-1980 Assistant manager and physio 1980-1985 Physio 1985-2016 Kitman and laundry
Pre-tax profits fell 10 per cent to £1.43bn, excluding settlement costs, in the three months to September.
The figures were published a day after Barclays confirmed investment banker Jes Staley would become the bank’s new chief executive in December.
Meanwhile its non-core companies — in the process of being disposed of — appear to have hardly budged.
Losses on these assets, which include certain investment bank assets and parts of the European retail banking arm, soared to £337m.
The bank set aside £270m to settle US mortgage bond claims and £290m for clients facing detrimental forex rates.
For the companies the bank wants to keep, such as its UK High Street bank and its Barclaycard operation, profits increased 1 per cent to £1.76bn.
After integrating a £560m and other one-time expenses and gains, pre-tax profit for the third quarter declined to £861m from last year’s £1.22bn.
Revenues declined from £6.4bn to £6.1bn in July-September. Staley, currently with US hedge fund Blue Mountain Capital Management, is virtually a lifer at JP Morgan.
He will fill the CEO’s post, lying vacant since Antony Jenkins was fired in July after acrimony with board members.
He will receive a £1.2m salary, a £396,000 pension and bonuses up to £5.5m mostly in the form of shares.
He’ll receive a further £1.15m in shares each year, which he will only be allowed to unload after five years.
In total, then, he will be eligible for as high as £8.2m for the year, assuming he gets the maximum bonus.
He’ll also be compensated in Barclays shares worth around £1.93m, for JP Morgan shares he lost in connection with his departure.

Staley said in his message to the bank’s staff he would focus on those parts of the investment bank that are less dependent on capital, including merger advisory and trading stocks, in line with some analysts’ expectations.
The attempt to have 30 minutes free parking was dismissed. Changes were proposed by four DUP MLAs but Infrastructure Minister Chris Hazzard described their motion as "seriously misguided".
He said "a staffing resource would be required to enforce 30 minutes free parking".
However, an amendment from Sinn Féin, calling for a review of on-street parking, was backed by MLAs and Mr Hazzard said he is keen to see that happen.
"I'm not against a review - a strategic look at on street car parking policy and where we're going," he told BBC News NI.
"But at the same time, I voted against the DUP motion, because it [had] a pre-formed conclusion that we should radically reduce the fines before we even do that review.

That's not the right way to go about it," he said. The DUP motion, tabled by former minister, Edwin Poots, and his colleagues William Humphrey, George Robinson and Alex Easton, argued that on-street parking needed to be more "flexible" to help traders bring business into towns and villages.

Parking enforcement was privatised in Northern Ireland in 2006. Initially the charge for a fixed penalty notice to a car driver parked illegally was set at £60, but halved to £30 if paid within 14 days.
In 2012, MLAs at Stormont voted to increase the penalty charge to £90 - and £45 if paid within 14 days.
The then Roads Minister, Danny Kennedy, said "a higher fine" would serve as a better deterrent to prevent drivers parking illegally.

The infrastructure minister said he believed that "at least two-thirds" of motorists fined for breaches of parking regulations were still paying them off within the two-week deadline at a reduced rate of £45.
"When you look at many parts of the region, that is probably the right figure," Mr Hazzard said.
Earlier this week, a Belfast City Council committee voted in favour of abolishing the city's annual run of free parking in the city centre dates in the run-up to Christmas.

Harrison Ford will reprise his role in Indiana Jones 5 - to be released in 2019 - and told the BBC that "I think it is perfectly appropriate to return to the character when there is a good idea to do it".
"And I think in this case the right circumstances came along and the right circumstances include Steven Spielberg as director and a great script, so I am delighted to be doing it."

Speaking to the BBC to help promote the DVD release of Star Wars: The Force Awakens , Ford also responded to suggestions that - even though his character Han Solo died in that - he might got a look in on a later episode playing the same role.
"Anything is possible in space," he replied. "I wanted Han Solo to sacrifice himself for the good of other people.
To lend some gravitas to the story... I think it helps the story and it helped make it less.. for me, it helped make it less science fictiony."
"It has been a wonderful experience," Ford said of The Force Awakens . "And working with really great actors, a script I trusted, and a director with a very deft hand and a generous heart.

It has been a pleasure." Asked whether he felt an emotional connection to the characters he plays, Ford replied: "No, I think it would be a mistake to identify too strongly with the characters I play."

"I want them to be an emotional experience that is available to the audience. I want audiences to have a familiar experience of the character … I want people to be interested in seeing who the guy is rather than knowing him."
Ford first appeared as Indiana Jones in Raiders of the Lost Ark (1981), and followed this up with three more films, the most recent being Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008).
All four Indiana Jones movies to date have been directed by Steven Spielberg , and produced by Star Wars creator George Lucas.
Star Wars: The Force Awakens emerged as the UK’s biggest hit of 2015, grossing £94.06m in the 16 days since its release.

Partial results announced by the Electoral Commission so far indicated that the NPP's Mr Akufo-Addo has garnered more than the required 50% plus one needed to secure victory over his fiercest challenger, incumbent President John Dramani Mahama of the National Democratic Congress.
The president-elect is expected to be inaugurated on 7 January after his one-month transition. Mr Akufo-Addo lost in the 2008 and 2012 elections.
But the manner in which he conducted himself after defeat struck a chord with many people.

He has been credited for saving the country from bloody violence in 2012, when if he had called on his supporters to take to the streets to protest that year's result, Ghana would have gone the way of other countries on the continent.
Instead, he pursued a legal challenge and accepted what the Supreme Court decided.
The 72-year-old son of the late Edward Akufo-Addo, a former chief justice and ceremonial president under a military government, has kept to his 2012 campaign promise of free high-school education.

But the flagship of his campaign was the "one district, one factory" policy that he says will steer the country towards an industrialisation drive. The idea is to have a factory in all of Ghana's 216 districts.
"The time has come for us to move our industrial development forward," he told supporters at a rally in eastern Ghana over the weekend.
"We need jobs; the future of our country is in danger because we don't have jobs for our young people.
The current government does not have jobs." In the north, Mr Akufo-Addo promised "in every village you will have a dam" to promote agriculture in a region, which happens to be Ghana's bread basket.

Members of the governing NDC have pooh-poohed this with claims they are all hollow promises, but listening to Mr Akufo-Addo on the campaign trail, he really believes these are programme he will retain.
His wife, Rebecca Akufo-Addo, has been actively involved in her husband's campaign.
When asked how she would described Mr Akufo-Addo on the TV talk show, Standpoint, which profiles Ghana's famous personalities, she had this to say: "He is very loving.
He loves his family. He's very political. He loves politics. He has always loved this country.

And he thinks that he has to be involved very strongly in it." Mr Akufo-Addo is credited with building the NPP, his party, which first competed in an election in 1992, as Ghana returned to multi-party democracy after years of military rule.
His political experience is in a league of its own from all those who vied to lead Ghana today.
At barely 30 years old, he was a political activist who campaigned for an end to the military regime in the late 1970s.
He was educated in Ghana and the United Kingdom, worked as a lawyer in France, and was an MP from 1996 till 2008 for the Abuakwa South constituency in eastern Ghana.

In an interview with the BBC’s Andrew Marr, Gen Sir Nicholas Houghton said not being prepared, in principle, to commit the UK’s nuclear forces would “undermine the operation of the deterrent” and expressed his anxiety that a “manifesto” of that kind could become national policy.
The Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, later called on the defence secretary to take action against Sir Nicholas over the remarks.
“It is a matter of serious concern that the chief of the defence staff has intervened directly in issues of political dispute.
It is essential in a democracy that the military remains politically neutral at all times,” he said.
“By publicly taking sides in current political arguments, and in issues of party-political controversy, Sir Nicholas has clearly breached that constitutional principle.

I am therefore writing to Michael Fallon to ask him to take action on this matter and to remind Sir Nicholas and all other military personnel of the importance of avoiding any appearance of political involvement in our national debate.” Corbyn, a long-standing vice president of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament (CND), clashed with members of his shadow cabinet at the Labour conference in Brighton when he said he would never press the nuclear button.
He welcomed the opposition of Labour in Scotland to the UK’s Trident weapons system, and describing it as an “issue of immense importance for the whole country”.

GMB union launches stinging attack on Corbyn over nuclear issues Read more The Labour leader stood on a mandate at his election to scrap the renewal of the Trident system and is “determined to promote the Nuclear Weapons Convention – to push as quickly as possible for the banning and complete elimination of nuclear weapons”.
He believes the idea of nuclear weapons “for some nations to be able to inflict enormous violence, mass murder and spread destruction on a huge scale is utterly repugnant”.

Asked about Corbyn ruling out the possibility of using nuclear weapons, Sir Nicholas told Marr: “Well, it would worry me if that thought was translated into power.” Sir Nicholas told Marr that “submarine-based strategic nuclear deterrence” provided the “ultimate guarantee” of the UK’s safety.
“If a prime minister said they would never press the button, we would have to admit to any potential aggressor that the deterrent simply doesn’t work – it’s incredible,” he said.

The operational success of deterrence “relies upon credibility”, he added. “The whole thing about deterrence comes from the idea of deterrent of the worst case, that you have to have a degree of credibility about the ability to use these things.” He added: “The reason we have a nuclear deterrent is because we can’t predict how the international scene is going to evolve in the 15 to 20 years necessary to renew Trident ...

I can absolutely understand why people would have little time for Trident if they were certain that the way the future will evolve poses little threat.” Trident nuclear deterrent vital, says senior diplomat in leaked letter Read more The In an apparent acknowledgement of the potential delicacy in commenting, Sir Nicholas admitted that “politicians get themselves into all sorts of messes” suggesting that “certainty” about Trident is the “reality that they confront when they are in power”.

At a wreath-laying ceremony in his Islington North constituency after Remembrance Sunday national commemorations at the Cenotaph, Corbyn said: “I think [Sir Nicholas’s remarks] were kind of unhelpful.

I think he was overstepping his role.” Interviewed on Channel 4 News, Corbyn had some words of advice for Sir Nicholas: “I ask him to recognise that in a democracy, it is the elected political leadership that makes the decisions.
I will be asking for the defence secretary to have a discussion with him … If he wants a discussion with me, that is fine,” he said.

“He should not seek to intervene by expressing them in public.” Additional reporting by Toby Helm and Mark Townsend Contributors: Andrew Sparrow (AndrewSparrow), Peter Walker (peterwalker99) and Matthew Weaver (matthew_weaver) Topics Jeremy Corbyn Nuclear weapons Trident Armed forces Conservatives Labour party Defence news Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share via Email Share on LinkedIn Share on Google+ Share on WhatsApp Share on Messenger Reuse this content View comments Responding to the remarks, a Downing Street spokesperson said: "The government's position on the nuclear deterrent is clear - it will remain in use for as long as necessary.
"We expect members of the armed forces to advise on the operational security of our nuclear deterrent" "We can confirm that Jeremy Corbyn has written to the Defence Secretary.

We'll respond to Jeremy Corbyn's letter in due course. Downing Street will be handling any further queries.” Michael Fallon, the defence secretary, said: “The chief of the defence staff is absolutely right that the credibility of our nuclear deterrent is not undermined by this misguided question.

The government remains fully committed to maintaining an independent nuclear deterrent as the ultimate guarantee of security for a nuclear nation.” Responding to Corbyn’s criticism the leader of the Liberal Democrats, Tim Farron, said: “This is hypocrisy of the highest order from Jeremy Corbyn, because he has clearly made his views on Trident extremely public.

Bizarrely, he is now mocking public debate on the issue.” MP's curiosity Another recent example of straying from the traditional line was afforded by the chair of the Commons defence select committee, Julian Lewis, who has questioned whether it was right for the UK to cut the number of Trident carrying submarines.

Lewis, refusing to be distracted by the “public squabble between leaders about whether or not there can be a nuclear deterrent if a potential aggressor thinks or knows that the leader would not be prepared to use it”, also cites strategic anti-nuclear weapons agreement with Russia from the days of the cold war.
“It is well known that it requires only a minimum of four ballistic missile submarines to guarantee that at least one is always at sea.
What is less well known is the Americans and Russians each maintain a total of 14,” said Lewis.
“This raises the question of whether it is wise to flaunt the fact that when the UK moves to four, it means that from time to time none will be on patrol.

It may be hoped that such periods will be short in duration. Nonetheless, is it wise to expose ourselves to a situation where a potential aggressor might think it was opportune to attempt some act of nuclear blackmail on any occasions when we had no submarines at sea?” With the decision to defer the issue of renewal of Trident until 2016, the Commons defence committee may be planning to contribute something of the spirit to the matter.
Place your bets early because, in the words of former Labour minister Denzil Davies, nothing in politics today can be considered truly surprising.
John Collins, 74, Terry Perkins, 67, Brian Reader, 76, and Daniel Jones, 58, pleaded guilty at Woolwich Crown Court.
Jewels, gold and cash worth an estimated £10m were taken in the raid at Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Company in London’s jewellery quarter.

The thieves ransacked more than 70 safety deposit boxes. Perkins of Heene Road, Enfield, north London; Collins of Bletsoe Walk, Islington, north London; Jones of Park Avenue, Enfield; and Reader of Dartford Road, Dartford, were arrested in May.
They pleaded guilty to conspiracy to burgle between 1 January and 7 April, namely to burgle the Hatton Garden Safe Deposit building in London.
They were also charged with conspiracy to convert or transfer criminal property but the Crown said that after they pleaded guilty they would not face drug conspiracy charges.
Earlier this month it was revealed by a law firm acting for the safe deposit company that Hatton Garden Safe Deposit had been wound up because it was insolvent and unable to pay its debts.
No date was set for sentencing. The Metropolitan police launched an inquiry into why officers failed to respond when an intruder alarm was activated at the building during the burglary.
The Met apologised for not following procedures in dealing with the call and said it would investigate why the call was downgraded.
Five other men have pleaded not guilty to conspiracy to commit burglary and are awaiting trial.

Hugh Doyle, 48, of Riverside Gardens, Enfield; William Lincoln, 60, of Winkley Street, Bethnal Green, east London; and John Harbinson, 42, of Beresford Gardens, Benfleet, Essex, also deny a charge of laundering and are due to face trial in November.
Paul Reader, 50, of Dartford Road, Dartford; Carl Wood, 58, of Elderbeck Close, Cheshunt, Hertfordshire; have not yet entered pleas.

Perkins’ daughter, Laura, her husband, Jem Walters, known as Ben Perkins, Terri Robinson, and her husband, Steven, appeared in court charged with conspiracy to convert or transfer criminal property between 1 January and 19 May.

The four were charged last month in connection with the raid. Ben Perkins, 43, and Laura Perkins, 40, both of Manor Court, Enfield, east London, and Terri Robinson, 35, and Steven Robinson, 46, both of Sterling Road, Enfield, were charged last month in connection with the raid.
